HEADLINE: As California Thirsts, Dams Make Comeback 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LAKE SHASTA, Calif. 

 BODY:
At a photo opportunity three years ago, the Clinton administration's interior secretary, Bruce Babbitt, took a sledge hammer to the soon-to-be-dismantled McPherrin Dam in California's Central Valley and declared that the era of great dam building in the West was over. Environmentalists had long argued that many dams did more harm than good, and after years of battling, the government agreed.
 Told of that declaration recently, Curtis Knight chuckled bitterly. 
 Mr. Knight, the northern regional manager for California Trout, an environmental group, was strolling on a pristine stretch of the lower McCloud River and explaining how it would be inundated by a proposed enlargement of the nearby 602-foot Shasta Dam. 
In scale at least, the Shasta project, which would raise the dam between 6 feet and 200 feet, harks back to days that many thought were over, when the demand for power and irrigation water led engineers to build colossal dams across rivers throughout the West.
But this new proposal is part of one of the most ambitious water-management programs in history, one that involves raising the heights of several dams in California and building new ones, in the first federally financed dam construction of this type in years. And just as significant, the proposals, which would affect a vast swath of the state, from the McCloud River with its feisty trout to the cotton crops of the Central Valley to the lawns of San Diego, have been worked out by the same groups that had been fighting over dams for years, including a number of environmental groups.
But it is not that people here have necessarily changed their views about dams. Rather, they say they have been forced by the state's seemingly limitless need for cleaner and more plentiful water to at least consider something that had been anathema a short while ago.
"When we began this process five or so years ago none of us expected dams to even be part of the debate, because they didn't pass the laugh test," said Barry Nelson, a senior analyst at the Natural Resources Defense Council, which participated in discussions on the water program. "But we're willing to take a serious look, as long as there are thorough studies." Other environmentalists think the willingness to consider new dams is a slippery slope.
The focus of the program is one of the largest and most overtaxed systems of natural and man-made plumbing in the world, the 700-square mile Bay Delta. It is where the Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers meet the eastern reaches of the San Francisco Bay in a maze of channels, aqueducts, oxbows, dams, islands and wetlands.
The delta has provided most of the water for California's growth for more than 100 years. It now supplies water for 22 million people -- mostly in Southern California -- and irrigates 4.5 million acres of some of the most productive farmland in the country. It is the largest estuary on the West Coast, with a watershed that drains roughly 40 percent of the state. It is also the state's largest habitat for fish and wildlife, including two-thirds of the state's salmon.
The delta's problems began several decades ago, when state and federal officials sought to dig a new canal to divert more water away from the river system to the urban areas of Southern California. Environmentalists and others, warning that the canal could have a devastating impact on the lower reaches of the delta, fought vigorously and successfully to stop the construction.
But that just began a new era of hand-to-hand legal combat over every water proposal. Not a single comprehensive water project has gone forward since then, and in the meantime water quality has declined, a number of species have become endangered, including salmon and the delta smelt, and the farmers and cities have complained that they have had to make do with less water.
Realizing that only compromises and sacrifices could break the logjam, more than a dozen federal and state agencies, as well as agricultural groups, urban water districts and environmentalists, began, starting in the early 1990's, a long process of study and debate.
Last summer they reached a historic consensus, agreeing to spend $8.6 billion in the first seven years, and more over the next two decades to revitalize the delta water system. The majority of the money would come from the federal government, and the rest from the state. The plan envisions that over time the users of the water, particularly farmers, will pay the full cost of their allotment without subsidies, but this is uncertain. 
The agreement, called the Cal Fed program, contains gains and sacrifices for just about everyone. Farmers would get less water than at times in the past, but the deliveries would be more reliable. Urban areas would get cleaner water, but less of it. Environmentalists would see areas like the lower McCloud inundated, but the tradeoff would be more clean water flushing through the lower delta, helping revive endangered species. There would also be better flood control, more water for use in droughts and new money for water conservation and recycling.
"The Bay Delta system is clearly being maintained at a very low level, and everyone recognizes that we don't know if it can sustain another serious drought," said Patrick Wright, the Cal Fed director. "So everyone wants to move forward, and they're willing to consider things they would never have thought about before as long as it all moves forward together."
But the fragile consensus is being strained. Many of those involved are troubled by the compromises, and some groups have gone to Congress, which would have to rule on legislation to carry out the program, to try to regain some of what they had given up in the Cal Fed framework.
Supporters of the program say that because it relies on a vast web of compromises, picking apart pieces of it could bring the effort down.
"This is the most sweeping water policy and restoration policy program ever in this state," said Mary Nichols, the state's secretary for resources. "We're committed to the whole program rather than pieces. If not you run the risk of running off the rails, which would lead us back toward the old water wars, even within the federal government."
The last major dam built in California was the New Melones Dam on the Stanislaus River in the 1970's, which environmentalists fought. Since then, not only have a handful of smaller dams been torn down, but the few new dams have generally involved a new generation of technology; water is diverted from rivers, usually just at flush times, and stored in off-stream reservoirs, causing less disruption to the ecosystem. Many of the Cal Fed dams would fit this model.
One subject of debate is how quickly the dam projects should be built. Initially, two bills were introduced in Congress, by Senator Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat, and by Representative Ken Calvert, a Republican. Both have been harshly criticized by environmental groups that accuse them of moving too swiftly on the dams. 
By contrast, the Cal Fed program proposes studies of the expansion of the Shasta and several other dams, and construction only if the economics and environmental issues balance out. And while the program generally offers the agricultural groups only commitments to try to provide a steadier flow of water, the two bills offer statutory guarantees.
Representative George Miller, a Democrat whose district east of Oakland includes one of the dams that would be enlarged, has now offered a third bill that he says would bring the legislation closer to the Cal Fed agreement. But even Mr. Miller, who has solid environmental credentials, admitted that the dams and their destructive consequences, have to be seriously considered.
"It may be a price that has to be paid," said Mr. Miller, referring to the impact on the McCloud. 
It is still hard for some people to imagine paying that price. On a drizzly morning on the lower McCloud, not far from where it spills into the huge Lake Shasta, a majestic scene that plays out day after day unfolded. A bald eagle suddenly appeared, patrolling the narrow canyon from above, while wild brown trout darted under the perfect crystal blue waters. If the dam is raised and the canyon flooded there would be more room for houseboats and more lake beaches.
"This is not an economically vibrant area, so we could use the jobs," said Mr. Knight, the regional manager for California Trout. "But look at this, look at what you'd lose. And I can tell you, people here hate the idea of inundating a couple miles of river just to send the water to Southern California. They hate it."
Tom Graff, the regional director for Environmental Defense, a group that has fought on water policy for years, said he thought the program was simply too complex to work. "There's this idea that everybody can win," Mr. Graff said. "We'll clean the delta and get more water to urban districts and the farmers. I think that that's just wrong. You can't do that."
And some of the most powerful farm groups are already threatening the equivalent of a nuclear strike, litigation, if they do not get the guarantees they have been demanding.
"That is a question I'd rather not have to think about," said Stephen Birmingham, the general manager of the Westlands Water District, a powerful San Joaquin Valley agricultural group, when asked how he would respond if his efforts to obtain more water were dropped from the bills. "I don't think it's a question of what we would be prepared to do. It's what we would have to do."
That kind of talk worries people like Mr. Miller.
"For the first time in 100 years of California water wars we had a consensus process," he said. "It invited a lot of people to the table who had not had a place before. The consequences are huge if this process comes apart."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK; 
N.F.L. Enjoys Stability, But Problems Remain

BYLINE:  By MIKE FREEMAN 

 BODY:
While the economy waffles, and sports organizations like Major League Baseball ponder the possibility of a work stoppage, the National Football League has undoubtedly entered what some league officials are calling a second golden age.
 The first was probably when the league realigned three decades ago, beginning the formation of modern football. Now, the N.F.L. is enjoying the kind of success -- steady and long-term success -- that most companies dream of. 
 Commissioner Paul Tagliabue deserves a lot of the credit for the league's current state. Two of the main things he emphasized beginning in the early 1990's have stabilized the league now. Tagliabue felt that strengthening the relationship between management and the players union, and maintaining revenue sharing, were two of the most important agendas the league needed to accomplish to secure a stable future. 
"We've demonstrated that those two aspects are key in maintaining a strong league," Tagliabue said.
The past few months have seen the league make a number of key decisions that support the contention of a new golden age:
*Tagliabue said he expected to have an extension of the collective bargaining agreement completed soon. The extension could go through the 2006 season.
*Owners have made instant replay, which has worked very well, a permanent part of the league.
*The league realigned in May for the first time in three decades. The last realignment in 1970 was contentious, but as a sign of how well owners in football are getting along now, the recent debate took about an hour and could not have gone more smoothly.
*The N.F.L. beat the Oakland owner Al Davis's $1.2 billion lawsuit over the rights to the Los Angeles market.
*The quality of play in the N.F.L. remains strong.
Television ratings for the league over all are solid, assistant coaches have better retirement and health packages, and players are earning their college degrees in record numbers thanks to the league's player development program (20 players earned their degrees this off-season alone, including Jerry Rice and Eddie George).
Of course the league is not perfect.
The N.F.L. needs to take better care of injured, older, retired players, some of whom end up with painful injuries and penniless because benefits for them have dwindled. And punishment for players who get into trouble off the field, especially in domestic violence cases, needs to be tougher.

Rice Inspiring Raiders
The move by the Oakland Raiders to sign the former San Francisco great Jerry Rice is already paying off.
Signing Rice, even though he turns 39 in October, could turn out to be one of the smartest personnel decisions of the off-season. He is already having an effect on Raiders players as they watched his relentless work ethic in recent spring practices.
Rice has had a career-long habit after making a catch in practice of sprinting 30 or 40 yards as if he were breaking for a touchdown. Every catch. Every practice. It has caught on with some of the Raiders receivers, who were imitating Rice in the team's workout late last month.
Rice no longer possesses scary speed, but where he will be valuable to the team is that he still loves to go across the middle. Not that other Raiders wide receivers do not, but Rice remains among the best at it.

Super Bowl to Unemployment
Remarkably, some six months after winning a Super Bowl with the Baltimore Ravens, quarterback Trent Dilfer is still looking for a job. In a conference call with reporters last week, Dilfer expressed dismay that he was still unemployed, but optimism that he would be quarterbacking for a team by the start of the season.
"Obviously, circumstances have not worked out the way I thought they would," Dilfer said. "I'll take the same approach last year when I was a backup, then got ready to play in Baltimore. I'm not going to let the circumstances dictate how I prepare, or how I play the game or what I'm focused on. I'll be playing football next year, I'm pretty confident of that."
Dilfer was 7-1 as a starter in the regular season last year and threw for a touchdown in the Ravens' 34-7 Super Bowl victory over the Giants. Those numbers should be enough for Dilfer to get a job as a backup for a premier team, at the least.
But nothing solid has come his way. He has received interest from teams like the Washington Redskins and the Kansas City Chiefs, but the talks always disintegrate. And Dilfer says he rejected the overtures of the sorry Cincinnati Bengals to become a starter there.
Part of Dilfer's problem, according to a team that was interested in him, is that his demeanor is too low-key in interviews. What also seems to hurt Dilfer is the notion that it was Baltimore's defense -- and not Dilfer or the offense -- that won the Super Bowl. Adding credence to that is Dilfer did not complete more than 12 passes in any of Baltimore's four postseason games.
"I'm very proud that I'm one of 22 quarterbacks to win a Super Bowl, but at the same time, I was a victim because I sat back and didn't ask for credit," Dilfer said.
Then Dilfer summed up his current predicament, and probable future, this way.
"There has been some interest," he said, "There will be some desperate teams. There will be injuries. There will be teams that find out that the guys they have aren't the guys they thought they were."

Rookie Absentee Control
When one player skipped the recent N.F.L. rookie symposium with what a person familiar with the situation called an unexcused absence, it was not entirely unusual. The N.F.L. gets a 99 percent turnout to its mandatory symposium each year, but there is always a person or two who skips the event.
But the N.F.L. feels even that small a number is too many. So the league is considering taking more drastic action to prevent rookies from being missing in action.
One thing the N.F.L. might do is increase the fine for missing the symposium with an unexcused absence from $10,000 to twice that amount, or even more.
The problem with setting a fine at a much steeper amount is that the players' union might balk.
But the N.F.L. think that a stiffer penalty might be worth it because officials believe that the symposium, a life-skills seminar, is that important to players.

HEADLINE: Move to Curb Biotech Crops Ignores Poor, U.N. Finds 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 6 

 BODY:
Opposition in richer countries to genetically modified crops may set back the ability of the poorest nations to feed growing populations, according to a new United Nations survey. 
 A movement against these crops, genetically changed for various reasons -- including higher yield, more nutritional value and pest or disease control -- is strongest among Western Europeans and to some extent Americans. 
 "The current debate in Europe and the United States over genetically modified crops mostly ignores the concerns and needs of the developing world," according to the survey, the Human Development Report 2001. It is published by the United Nations Development Program and will be released on Tuesday in Mexico City. 
"Western consumers who do not face food shortages or nutritional deficiencies or work in the fields are more likely to focus on food safety and the potential loss of biodiversity," the report states, but "farming communities in developing countries are more likely to focus on potentially higher yields and greater nutritional value, and on the reduced need to spray pesticides that can damage the soil and sicken farmers."
The report draws a comparison to successful Western-led efforts to ban the use of the industrial pesticide DDT worldwide, which has allowed a resurgent population of mosquitoes to devastate tropical countries with several virulent strains of malaria. 
Still, the United Nations remains concerned about the consequences of genetic advancements, too. In Geneva on Friday, the World Health Organization and the Food and Agriculture Organization jointly recommended that governments test all genetically modified organisms before they enter the market, looking especially for the potential to cause allergic reactions. 
Mark Malloch Brown, administrator of the United Nations Development Program, which publishes the 11-year-old annual survey, said the report moved in a new direction this year by challenging some cherished opinions about what the third world needs. The 2001 report looks at three areas -- food, medicine and information systems -- where high-technology can be made relevant and useful to poor countries, as long as risks are well managed.
Mr. Malloch Brown recommended a closer look at recent history and a move away from what he called "an anti-technology bias." He added that advances in food production -- the "green revolution" of the early postcolonial years -- were based on crop science.
Turning to information technology, the report created a new technology achievement index that ranks countries in four categories: leaders, potential leaders, dynamic adopters and the marginalized. The new index offers some surprising findings based on factors such as inducements to innovation, prevalence of old technologies like telephones and general educational levels. 
While India, for example, has islands of high technology, it ranks at the bottom of the dynamic adopters category, just above marginalization -- not only well below China by virtually every measure, but also far behind Southeast Asia, Latin American and parts of Africa and the Arab world. At the other end of the scale, Japan and Korea rank fourth and fifth on the leaders list, which is led by Finland, the United States and Sweden. Singapore outranks a majority of European countries.
The core of the 2001 report remains the broad human development index, devised in 1990 by the late Mahbub ul Haq, a Pakistani economist. This year, Norway rose to the top of the index that measures quality of life very broadly. Australia, Canada, Sweden, Belgium and the United States followed. 
At the bottom of the list is Sierra Leone, in last place among 162 nations surveyed. Of 36 nations considered lowest in human development, 29 are African.

HEADLINE: Taiwan's Hard Times Rekindle 'One China' Debate 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 7 

 BODY:
For a 78-year-old pensioner with heart trouble, Lee Teng-hui is not easing up. When Mr. Lee, the former president of Taiwan, came home from a visit to the United States this week, he greeted well-wishers by grabbing a megaphone and bellowing, "Let's all have confidence in our Taiwan."
 Those seemingly benign sentiments have propelled Mr. Lee into the white-hot center of Taiwanese politics. 
 Fourteen months after he stepped down, the economy here is sputtering, and the government is paralyzed. China, meanwhile, is growing stronger by the day. Polls indicate that as their fortunes diverge, the idea of uniting Taiwan with its fast-growing neighbor is gaining ground here.
For the man who spent his career trying to fashion a separate identity for Taiwan -- often drawing Beijing's wrath in the process -- this gradual drift toward China is alarming. And it has prompted Mr. Lee to set off on an emotional, some say quixotic, campaign to restore the hope of his people.
"He thinks people are putting China's interests ahead of Taiwan's," said Huang Chu-wen, an adviser of the former president. "We feel that emphasizing Taiwan's indigenous culture should be our No. 1 priority."
Last month, Mr. Lee threw his support behind Chen Shui-bian, the pro-independence opposition leader who succeeded him. That enraged Mr. Lee's comrades in the Nationalist Party, who were swept out of power in that election after a half-century of rule.
And now, Mr. Lee is lending his prestige to efforts to start a new party, one that would ally with Mr. Chen against the Nationalists in legislative elections this December.
Mr. Lee's moves have far-reaching implications, not just for Taiwan's politics but also for Taiwan's relationship with China and the United States. Experts here say it could fuel latent animosities between people of mainland Chinese descent and native Taiwanese who share this island. Mr. Lee and Mr. Chen are both native Taiwanese.
It could also draw a jagged line between those who support or oppose unification with China.
"He is appealing to people who believe in Taiwanese independence," said Wu Nai-jen, the secretary general of Mr. Chen's party. "He is whipping up nationalist feeling, not a rational discussion of the issues.'
Political discourse has been uncommonly heated for the last few weeks. Some of Mr. Lee's Nationalist colleagues are howling for his expulsion, while newspapers and talk shows debate his motives.
But critics and defenders of Mr. Lee agree that he has accurately gauged the public mood. The collapse in the global technology industry has devastated Taiwan's economy, pushing growth to its lowest level since the early 1970's and unemployment to a nearly two-decade high. As times become tough, more people believe that maybe Taiwan should cast its lot with China.
Two recent surveys reported a spike in the percentage of Taiwanese who say they could accept "one country, two systems," the arrangement under which China took possession of Hong Kong from Britain in 1997.
While those who favor one country, two systems are still in a minority, the number has almost doubled, to 33 percent, since the last polls in 1999. 
"People suddenly have doubts about Taiwan's long-term economic and political future," said Chu Yun-han, a professor of political science at National Taiwan University.
In this gloomy atmosphere, China beckons. Taiwan companies are flocking to Shanghai to open factories. Unlike the past, when investors used China's cheap labor to make sneakers and other low-end goods, factories now churn out advanced chips and notebook computers.
For many college students here, China is replacing the United States as the land of opportunity. "All my classmates think they are going to work in China," said Chou Ju-yi, 21, an electrical engineering major at National Taiwan University. "They think they will have no choice, because the economy here is so bad."
Ms. Chou said she opposed unification. But her boyfriend, Hsu Chieh, said he believed that integration was inevitable, and desirable. "China is getting stronger and stronger," said Mr. Hsu, who is 21 and studies botany. "To survive, we will have to integrate our economy into China. And to do that, we have to have political integration."
Such attitudes run deep in Taiwan's business establishment. One of the island's most powerful industrialists, Wang Yung-ching, recently called on President Chen to accept Beijing's demand that Taiwan recognize a single China of which it is a part. Mr. Chen's refusal to do so has angered Beijing.
The Nationalist Party, which under Mr. Lee took a confrontational approach toward Beijing, has changed course and begun to cultivate ties with China's leaders. A former Nationalist prime minister recently visited Beijing while the mayor of Taipei went to Hong Kong.
The chairman of the Nationalists, Lien Chan, denies that his party has tilted toward Beijing. But he makes no apologies for the visits. 
"The majority of the people here do not agree with the idea of Taiwan independence," said Mr. Lien, who served as vice president under Mr. Lee. "We have to make this clear to the leaders in Beijing."
It was the Nationalists' shift toward China that precipitated Mr. Lee's break with his party. Mr. Lee had anointed Mr. Lien as the party's presidential candidate in 1999. But experts say the former president secretly preferred Mr. Chen. In the end, Mr. Chen trounced Mr. Lien.
Despite the bad blood, Mr. Lien said he was aghast that Mr. Lee appeared to have switched sides. He speculated that other people were exploiting the former president's name to further their own goals.
Mr. Lee declared recently that he would die as a Nationalist Party member. But he has met with former Nationalist lawmakers who are thinking of running in the new party being formed by Mr. Lee's adviser and protege, Huang Chu-wen.
Mr. Huang said his goal was to win 35 seats in Taiwan's 220-seat Legislature. If he does, and if Mr. Chen, with Mr. Lee's implied blessing, can increase his party's seats to more than 75 seats, from 66 now, Mr. Chen's party and its allies would gain a majority. In the past, his government has been stymied because the Nationalists control the assembly.
Political oddsmakers say the chance of both those things' happening is slim. But Mr. Huang said Mr. Lee has a broader agenda. He is trying to stem the tide of pro-China sentiment. If he fails and Taiwan lets its identity erode, he said, the island will be powerless to ward off Beijing.
"The mainland would be quite happy to let this situation continue," Mr. Huang said. "They figure maybe Taiwan will collapse by itself."

HEADLINE: Economic Cooperation Planned 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, July 7 

 BODY:
Finance ministers of the seven leading industrial nations appeared uncertain at a meeting in Rome today about whether the worst of the world's faltering economy has been reached, but agreed to draw back from sharpening differences and focus on greater cooperation.
 "We were not here to throw rocks at each other," said the treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, briefing reporters after the day of talks at the 16th-century Villa Madama here. 
 Mr. O'Neill said the ministers agreed to try to identify structural weaknesses in individual countries, so that working on those problems would "raise potential sustainable real growth in the world economy." 
The ministers were gathered to lay the groundwork for a meeting of the leaders of the Group of 7 countries in Genoa, Italy, in two weeks. The G-7 countries are Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States.
Earlier this week, Mr. O'Neill appeared to criticize Europe and Japan for not doing enough to live up to their roles as "locomotives" of world growth. But on Friday, the French finance minister, Laurent Fabius, contradicted Mr. O'Neill, suggesting that the two main reasons for the faltering world economy were higher oil prices and the slowdown in the United States.
Today Mr. O'Neill appeared to backtrack, explaining that freight trains in the United States are not pulled by one, but by "two or even three locomotives."
For their part, European ministers stressed the interdependence of the world's three largest economic zones -- the United States, Europe and Japan. "The international slowdown is undeniable," Mr. Fabius said at a meeting with reporters. "No area has been spared."
Part of the toning down appeared motivated by the conviction that the image of sharp differences hurt consumer attitudes, reinforcing the slowdown. "It is possible to talk people into a sour mood," Mr. O'Neill said. Mr. O'Neill stressed strong auto sales and housing starts as indications that the American economy is not as sick as it is often described and said he told the finance ministers he was moderately optimistic for the remainder of the year, expecting more than 2 percent growth in the last quarter, and "something over 3 percent" in all of 2002.
But European officials were more skeptical. French officials said they believed the United States could experience a slight rebound later this year, but were unsure it would be sustainable. They admitted that Europe had not pulled its weight this year, but said the possibility of declining oil prices improved Europe's prospects in 2002. 
The German finance minister, Hans Eichel, said he saw "little reason to give in to pessimism." But he admitted that international interdependence "proved much greater than we had imagined previously."

HEADLINE: A STRONG DOLLAR CLOUDS PROSPECTS FOR QUICK REBOUND 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7 

 BODY:
More than six months after the Federal Reserve began battling to reverse the economic slowdown in the United States, economists and business executives say an unexpected rise in the value of the dollar is complicating the prospects for a rebound.
 Despite six interest rate cuts by the Fed this year -- an effort that would typically be expected to weaken the dollar -- the American currency has strengthened against the world's two other major currencies, the euro and the Japanese yen. As a result, American products have become more expensive when sold abroad. 
 At the same time, economic growth appears to be decelerating in Europe, and Japan is again flirting with recession. That weakness is dampening demand from abroad for American goods and services, making it even harder for the domestic economy to emerge from its doldrums. 
"The global slowdown that's becoming more visible in the economies of our trading partners and the surprisingly strong dollar are going to be a drag on the recovery," said James Glassman, an economist at J. P. Morgan in New York.
The faltering world economy was a primary topic of discussion for finance ministers from the seven leading industrial democracies meeting today in Rome. But Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill and his counterparts from Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan showed little inclination to take any coordinated, concrete steps to stimulate renewed growth or to weaken the American currency. Page 10. 
In the last few weeks alone, several prominent companies -- including DuPont, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, Coca-Cola and Nike -- have cited the strong dollar in explaining profit shortfalls or reductions in their earnings expectations.
Traditionally by this point in an economic cycle, a weakening currency would make American goods less expensive in foreign markets, helping offset the slump at home by bolstering demand from abroad and elevating corporate profits.
But with the dollar having risen this year rather than fallen, many companies based in the United States are reporting disappointing foreign sales or are failing to meet their profit targets because money they earn in foreign currencies is worth less when translated back into dollars.
Complaints from exporters about the dollar are a staple of economic policy debates. And a strong currency has numerous benefits, including helping to hold down inflation by making imports less expensive -- not to mention making foreign travel less expensive.
Moreover, the overall outlook for the economy is generally more affected by domestic factors like consumer confidence and spending by businesses on technology and other equipment than by international developments.
But in this case the squeeze on exporters from the dollar is combining with weak demand from slumping economies at home and abroad to put particularly intense pressure on American manufacturers, which have borne the brunt of the slowdown. In response, industrial companies have laid off hundreds of thousands of workers since last summer and have been the main contributors to the rise in the unemployment rate, which reached 4.5 percent last month, up from a low of 3.9 percent in October.
"For large manufacturing corporations," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, "the impact of the high dollar and slower growth abroad is the No. 1 problem they have to deal with."
It is not just big companies that have been hit. The Electron Energy Corporation of Landisville, Pa., makes magnets that are used in radar and satellite communications equipment. It has only 100 employees, but it has customers all over the world.
With the dollar so strong, said Michael Walmer, the company's president, sales in Germany and France are down 30 percent.
"It's a great time to travel there," Mr. Walmer said, "but I'd rather have it be a great time to sell our products."
The dollar's rise this year, especially against the euro, has surprised most analysts. But it appears to reflect nothing more than a continued belief by investors and business executives that the United States offers a better climate for investment than anywhere else.
Even at a time when the stock market has stalled, companies are scaling back on capital spending and the United States is struggling to avert a recession by reducing interest rates, economists said investors still seemed to prefer holding dollars or property in the United States over taking a chance on buying stocks and bonds or factories in Europe or Asia.
That is especially true when, as now, the economies of other countries are faltering.
"Foreigners know that if the United States is in trouble, then their own countries will be in worse trouble, because the U.S. is the global engine of growth," said James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management, an investment firm. "Holding dollars is the safest place to be. It's hampering the Fed's efforts to restart the U.S. economy."
On Friday, the dollar was worth just under 126 yen, compared with 114 yen just before the Fed started cutting interest rates in January, a rise in the dollar's value of 10.5 percent.
Similarly, it cost about 84 cents to buy a euro on Friday, compared with about 94 cents in early January, a change of 10.6 percent.
Earlier this year, analysts expected Europe to post higher economic growth rates than the United States would. But Europe has slowed abruptly in recent months; Germany's economy, the Continent's biggest, has been hit particularly hard.
Mr. Glassman said J. P. Morgan estimated zero growth in the second quarter among the 12 countries that have adopted the euro as their currency, and that growth for the full year in Europe would only be 1.7 percent. Japan, he said, is likely to grow only 0.4 percent this year. 
The consensus forecast for growth in the United States this year is around 1.8 percent, with an extremely weak second quarter followed by a steady pickup in the second half of the year.
The United States has cut interest rates and taxes in an effort to head off a recession. But the European Central Bank has held rates steady and national governments in most of Europe have been unable or unwilling to cut taxes.
Japan has already cut its short-term interest rates almost to zero in an effort to pull itself out of its decade-long slump and has been running big budget deficits to give the economy a boost.
But it has made little headway addressing underlying problems like the huge volumes of bad loans that have crippled its banking system. And if the government in Tokyo aggressively pursues a proposed austerity policy aimed at clearing away the bad debts that have accumulated over the last 10 years, economic conditions could become worse before they become better. American officials are waiting for evidence that Japan's latest recovery plan will actually be implemented.
The slowdown in the United States, Europe and Japan is hurting economies elsewhere. In Asia, excluding Japan, growth is projected to slow this year to a 3.9 percent annual rate, half that of last year, according to J. P. Morgan.
"Virtually everywhere you look you're talking about subpar growth," Mr. Glassman said.
Some economists said the strong dollar and the weak global economy would have a limited effect on the prospects for a recovery in the United States, where the combination of the tax cut and the Fed's interest rate reductions is expected to provide a powerful stimulus in coming months.
"While at the margin it would always be better if they were growing faster or buying more, Japan's current problems are not going to affect the U.S. economic cycle in any major way," said Carl Weinberg, chief global economist at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm. "Euroland takes at most 15 percent of our exports, maybe less, so it's not going to change the quality or character of the economic trajectory here."
But the developments have put new pressure on the Bush administration to rethink its adherence to a policy of support for a strong dollar. 
Business groups are trying to convince the Treasury Department that the dollar's strength is as much a result of speculation in the currency markets as of economic fundamentals, an argument that has not gotten a sympathetic hearing so far in Washington. The Bush administration, like the Clinton White House before it, has signaled that the only effective way for other countries to strengthen their currencies is to make their economies more competitive.
Still, manufacturers and other business constituencies are increasingly calling on the administration to signal that Washington does not want any further rise in the currency -- and that it would ultimately back an international effort to decrease the dollar's value in an orderly way.
"There is no reason to exclude international agreement and coordinated intervention as a means of dealing with an overvalued dollar, in part as a way to prevent an excessively sharp adjustment later on," Mr. Jasinowski, the manufacturers' representative, said.
In the meantime, companies like Sensormatic Electronics, a maker of antishoplifting tags and equipment in Boca Raton, Fla., are feeling the pinch. Per-Olof Loof, the company's president and chief executive, said earnings were running more than 10 percent behind expectations this year because of the dollar.
"It's not an easy problem to deal with," Mr. Loof said, "but it needs to be put on the agenda for the central banks and the politicians."

HEADLINE: AUTO RACING; 
Earnhardts Dominate The Night At Daytona

BYLINE:  By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

DATELINE: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 7 

 BODY:
In an almost supernatural second act to Nascar's most dramatic race of the year, Dale Earnhardt Jr. roared to the lead in the final laps of the Pepsi 400 tonight to win on the racetrack where his father was killed.
 His teammate Michael Waltrip was second. Five months ago here, in the first race of the Winston Cup season, Waltrip won the Daytona 500 with the younger Earnhardt second. Dale Earnhardt Sr. was in third place when he crashed into the wall on the last turn of the final lap. 
 At the end of tonight's race, instead of steering his No. 8 Chevrolet into victory lane for the traditional photo opportunity, Dale Jr. drove onto the grass and spun his car in a mad pirouette of triumph. Waltrip followed him onto the grass and the two cars danced until both drivers jumped out of their cars, climbed atop Waltrip's No. 15 Chevrolet and hugged.
The crowd of 197,000 roared as Dale Jr. led through most of the race, then stood stunned afterward, unwilling to leave a feel-good turn to the tragedy that had absorbed the sport since Feb. 18. For the 38-year-old Waltrip, second place seemed far sweeter than February's victory, his first in Winston Cup competition. Dale Sr. had hired him for his racing team in a vote of confidence that his record seemed not to deserve. But his joy was short-lived.
Echoing what has become the legend of that race -- that Dale Sr. blocked the back so his protege and his son could finish first and second -- Waltrip said tonight, "Dale held for us, and I fought the battle and held them off."
Waltrip was referring to his third-place position behind Rusty Wallace until he saw a chance to pass and get right behind the 26-year-old Dale Jr.
By the middle of the 160-lap race, Earnhardt seemed to have taken control at the top of a pack of four that was widening a gap to three seconds over the rest of the field. Mike Skinner, Steve Park and Ricky Rudd were usually the three behind him. The crowd, sensing his victory, was in full roar.
With 20 laps to go, crew chiefs along pit road were calculating tire wear and gas consumption for a final pit stop. The only thing that could spoil the show now was the so-called Big One, the major accident that drivers have been concerned about in this tight, restrictor-plate racing.
What they got, though, was more than a Little One. As cars began peeling off for the final pit stop, someone dived too quickly off the track and started a 12-car chain reaction. It was during this third caution period that the lead changed hands in the restart. Dale Jr. dropped out of the top five.
But with five laps to go, he made a bold move that brought him back to the lead and his first victory of the year.
Elliott Sadler finished third, followed by Ward Burton and Bobby Labonte.
 While the racing teams have tried to play down the drama of tonight's race, saying they wanted to get past the tragedy, fans and the news media have been talking about the presence of Dale Earnhardt Sr. haunting the Winston Cup series's return to this speedway. After the race, his son also discounted the drama of the moment. 
"I felt if I did the right thing I'd win," Earnhardt said. "My car was the best car here." 
He added, "I didn't think about what happened here in February."
What happened was sports' equivalent of the deaths of Elvis and Diana, Princess of Wales, an opportunity for people who identified with Dale Sr., a hard-nosed outsider who intimidated his way to racing success, to grieve openly. Although Dale Sr. was important economically to the sport, he was not universally beloved by other drivers. His relationship with his son was not always smooth.
This week, Dale Jr.; his father's widow, Teresa; and others refused to give interviews about the death. The track promised a fireworks memorial after the race, but otherwise kept it to a low profile. 
"All year long people have been pushing for us to do well, you want to win for the fans, that's why I pulled down for them, to hear them cheer," Dale Jr. said, referring to his spins after the race. "I wanted to do some good doughnuts but looking at my marks now, not so good." 
But he was willing to admit, "You couldn't have written a better script."

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF; 
When Disney Winked, Florida Swooned

BYLINE:  By ALECIA SWASY 

 BODY:
IN the summer of 1965, central Florida was buzzing with rumors about mystery land buyers who were snatching up thousands of acres of old citrus groves. A local television station, swept up in the excitement, issued a bulletin with a scoop: the station had received a telegram from Detroit confirming the Ford Motor Company as the buyer. Pity the reporter bamboozled by that hoax -- a second telegram arrived later saying Ford wanted the land to grow hay for its Mustangs. 
 The real buyer, of course, was Walt Disney, who had a clandestine team of lawyers and real estate agents plotting each day's acquisitions on a large map inside his movie studios in Burbank, Calif. Mr. Disney's team had ruled out 12 other locations, including St. Louis, Niagara Falls and the Baltimore-Washington area, and assembled 27,258 acres for his dream theme park in Orlando. 
 Since then, Orlando and the surrounding area have been blessed and burdened by the Walt Disney Company empire. That is the relationship chronicled by Richard E. Foglesong in "Married to the Mouse: Walt Disney World and Orlando" (Yale University Press, $27.95). 
Recent books have said much about Mr. Disney and his company, but Mr. Foglesong offers a different slice of life. His book is about those who courted the Mouse, as the Disney company is known by the locals, and which many think has grown increasingly ratlike in its behavior.
The author asserts that the state of Florida erred by giving what he calls overly generous powers to Disney in the 1960's, permitting it to create its own sort of government. The company is free to self-regulate land use and road building, among other basic services. State law even provided that Disney could build its own nuclear power plant or airport.
Of course, there is little wonder that lawmakers waived the magic wand for Disney: everyone wanted a new business in the area to ease its reliance on the boom-and-bust citrus industry and soften the effects of spending cutbacks on its military contractors.
Mr. Foglesong, a professor of politics at Rollins College in Winter Park, Fla., is a bit academic at times. But one of his book's greatest strengths is its rich detail about how a notoriously secretive company goes to great lengths to preserve its image as the home of the Magic Kingdom. He interviewed scores of elected officials and dug through property and court records.
He tells how Mr. Disney and his successors worked covertly to complete 47 land deals, sometimes courting individuals who held tiny plots worth $350 an acre. Buying such a huge overall tract was Mr. Disney's obsession after his 230-acre California theme park became surrounded by a "neon jungle" of fast-food restaurants and souvenir shops.
Mr. Disney's site selection, called Project X, showed the extremes reached by the company to avoid publicity. Disney emissaries checked into a Tampa hotel under assumed names. The company hired Donovan, Leisure, Newton & Irvine, a New York law firm whose lead partner, William Donovan, had directed the wartime Office of Strategic Services, a forerunner of the C.I.A., to help conceal the research project. Mr. Donovan procured business cards, letterhead and phone numbers in the name of Burke & Burke as a cover. When the Florida operatives needed to talk to Mr. Disney, they called the law firm, which connected them to Mr. Disney on the West Coast. Nobody at Disney was permitted to dial Orlando numbers, so as not to arouse suspicion.
THE author also criticizes Martin Andersen, who at the time of Disney's site selection was the publisher of The Orlando Sentinel. The author writes that Mr. Andersen knew something about Disney's land purchases but sought to suppress publicity about them. The paper's editorial page, which Mr. Andersen controlled, published an editorial that said secrecy about Disney was understandable -- an odd position for someone who is supposed to endorse telling people what's going on. 
Few officials kept an accurate accounting of what the Disney company promised at the time, versus what it built. Mr. Disney told the Florida Legislature that he would build Epcot as a community where 20,000 people "would live and work and play." In 1975, when Disney was about to build Epcot, Henry A. Kissinger, the secretary of state, even said that it would enhance world peace more than his shuttle diplomacy did.
Disney described Epcot as a city, in order to obtain power over its planning and zoning. But Epcot was built more like "a permanent world's fair," Mr. Foglesong writes. He again criticizes the media as fawning over Disney in its coverage of Epcot's opening in 1982. The television networks had live coverage of the event. 
While Disney was happy with that type of publicity, it showed a different personality if media coverage cast the company in a way it did not like. When The Orlando Sentinel wrote a tough story about Disney in 1985, nearly 20 years after Mr. Andersen had sold the paper and stepped down as publisher, the company removed The Sentinel's news racks from its properties.
The book also chronicles how people feared challenging Disney. Finley Hamilton, for example, owned the local Hilton hotel, near Disney's construction site. Disney officials asked if they could train their future hotel staff at the Hilton. Mr. Hamilton said his hotel lost money during the Disney management training, partly because the chef spent so much time preparing meals for company executives and the hotel maids were used to clean their homes. Mr. Hamilton complained in a letter to Disney but chose not to sue for fear of losing future business, Mr. Foglesong writes.
IN the years after Disney's arrival, smaller parks died, and Disney's self-regulated government gave it an advantage over rivals. Disney was the first to open a movie studio park, beating Universal Studios by 13 months, about the time it took that park to obtain land-use permits. Disney suffered no such delay because it effectively ran its own land-use department.
Mr. Foglesong also details how local law enforcement officials are often frustrated at Disney's behavior. One of Walt Disney World's security guards, for example, was involved in a traffic accident in which a 19-year-old man died; his family sued the company. The courts upheld Disney's refusal to release its records of the incident.
The author also writes that little information regarding serious crimes on Disney property, like burglary and rape, is reported to any law enforcement agency. 
The book further questions Disney's good-neighbor image in describing its use of a limited pool of bond money in central Florida. In the three counties eligible for the money, one possible use for the bonds would have been to help finance housing, something that some of Disney's own employees lacked. Instead, an application from Disney's government district was granted the money. Disney used the money to expand a sewage treatment plant needed for its expanding hotel empire.
To be sure, Disney put Orlando on the world map. Before it opened, 3.5 million tourists visited central Florida annually. By 1971, that number had climbed to 10 million. The current estimate for 2001 is 55 million. The area now has 100,000 hotel rooms, more than New York City or Los Angeles. The company employs 55,000 people at its parks and hotels. And Walt Disney World generates more sales tax revenue than any other Florida company.
Still, the author wonders if too many people have been "blinded by pixie dust." True to the title, he recommends therapy for the relationship between Disney and Orlando. "It has the potential," he says, "to transform this one-sided economic development marriage."

HEADLINE: Yard Work 

BYLINE:  By TARA BAHRAMPOUR 

 BODY:
LAST Fourth of July, the day throngs of spectators flocked to the New York waterfront to watch giant ships glide in from around the world, 200 white-clad sailors and 400 civilians caroused on the roof of a building in the Brooklyn Navy Yard overlooking the docks. Some twirled dance partners to a swing band. Others feasted on strawberries and focaccia. After a hazy sunset, the revelers crowded along the railings to watch red, white and blue fireworks burst over the harbor's black waters.
 An admiral, surveying the pageant, approached the host. "Why did we give this place up?" he asked. 
 "I don't know," replied Marc H. Rosenbaum, the host and the president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation. "But you can't have it back." 
To the uninitiated New Yorker, the enthusiasm might sound overblown. From the outside, the Navy Yard does not look welcoming. Along Navy Street and Flushing Avenue, two main bordering streets, cracked sidewalks skirt high brick walls and barbed wire. Signs read "No Trespassing" and "Warning: This installation is patrolled by military working dogs." Chain link fencing keeps vandals away from Admirals' Row, once-elegant officers' houses now so decrepit that trees push up through the rooftops. Bordered by the Farragut housing projects at the tip of Fort Greene and the elevated Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, the site is not usually seen as a viable link to the Brooklyn waterfront. If anything, locals know it either as the locus of Robert De Niro's failed bid to build movie studios or as the place to fetch towed cars.
Few people know that the Navy Yard -- 205 acres of land and 95 acres of water sandwiched between Williamsburg, Fort Greene and Vinegar Hill -- is no longer a navy yard but a city-run industrial park. It houses 86 structures, 40 of which are rentable buildings with a total of four million square feet of space. There are sparkling offices with digital subscriber lines and views of Manhattan; a 19th-century brick warehouse where sets for "Saturday Night Live" are built; and the 200-year-old Naval Hospital, which is a designated landmark. The yard contains 200 tenants and 3,500 workers, and its administrators hope it will one day bustle with three times that many jobs.
That hope rests on several factors, including the state of the economy, the interest the next mayor takes in the yard, and the yard's success in furnishing its tenants with adequate transportation. But however well these plans succeed, they are particularly poignant given the yard's rocky past, a period of decline that seemed to parallel that of all Brooklyn.
"We can really point to things the way Europeans can point to 1917 and say after this the world changed," Bernard Malamud wrote in a 1983 article about his home borough. "For us, it was the Dodgers leaving, the folding of The Brooklyn Eagle and the closing of the Navy Yard."
In Brooklyn, at least, change has been cyclical. After 45 years, the borough has a professional baseball team again. The Brooklyn Eagle, which folded in 1955, was resurrected in 1995. And celebrating its bicentennial this year, the Brooklyn Navy Yard is back, a brick and concrete Sleeping Beauty that has been harboring a quiet renaissance. 
In its two centuries, the yard has mirrored the history of an emerging nation. In 1801, the freshly minted United States Navy bought 41 acres of marshy farmland and docks from a private landowner for $40,000. Wallabout, the name of the deepwater bay, was Dutch for "bend in the river." Shipbuilding boomed there during the Civil War, when the yard produced the Intelligent Whale, an experimental submarine (it didn't work); it was also the birthplace of the battleship Maine, whose sinking in Havana in 1898 set off the Spanish-American War. 
The yard's peak came in World War II. Nicknamed the Can-Do yard, it quintupled its property, employed more than 70,000 and built and repaired thousands of Allied ships. The Arizona, sunk at Pearl Harbor, was Brooklyn-built, as was the Missouri, where the Japanese signed the surrender that ended the war. Feeding off the boom, nearby shops sold sailors' outfits, and bars and lunchrooms roared with activity.
But in the 50's, as traditional cargo shipping gave way to giant container ships and much of the area's trade moved to New Jersey, the yard began to fade. In 1966 the Navy left, taking away 9,000 workers, and in 1970, it sold most of the property to the city for $22 million. The following year, officials considered building a new industrial park, but the city's fiscal crisis halted that plan. With only two large shipbuilding companies still operating there and city money scarce, the yard began to deteriorate.
The Navy Yard still has four working dry docks, including a 150-year-old granite one that is a landmark and two as long as the World Trade Center towers are high. But with only three ship-related businesses, today's yard is not the same place where a teenage Pete Hamill worked as a sheet metal worker, or where Arthur Miller, fresh out of college, pulled 11-hour night shifts as a shipbuilder. Its scattered brick-and-concrete warehouses contain a lively patchwork of manufacturers that occupy 93 percent of the rentable space and turn out a diverse range of products.
Joining longtime tenants like Sweet'n Low and the Brink's armored car service, which with 500 workers is the yard's biggest employer, are companies like Scott Jordan Furniture, which makes custom tables and bed frames, and Capsys, which uses a cavernous 1940's brick building to make prefabricated houses. Modern Uprisings Studio captures the movements of New York City Ballet dancers and others in a computer modeling and animation studio. In a revamped 19th-century plumber and boiler shop the Great Harbor Design Center makes "ice stone," a marblelike substance made from recycled glass and used for walls, floors and decorative plaques.

Dressing Up the Image
A development corporation was formed in 1966 to help put the yard into local hands and reclaim some of the jobs lost when the Navy left, but for two decades it was mired in inefficiency and scandal. In 1993, to rehabilitate the yard's image, the group was renamed the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation.
Things took a while to improve. The yard's reputation suffered when the city considered installing a giant waste incinerator; the idea was abandoned after protests. In 1996, the corporation's president was dismissed during an investigation into whether she had followed proper bidding procedures for buying $30,000 worth of office furniture. Later, as part of an agreement with the Manhattan district attorney to avoid prosecution for perjury, she admitted to lying under oath about details of the purchase.
Mr. Rosenbaum, a lawyer who describes his professional life until 1996 as "the steel and glass world of litigation," came to the Navy Yard in 1996. At that point, "the Navy Yard had a four- or five-year life span left in it," he said. "The piers were being undermined. The entire bulkhead was leaking to the extent that it was causing sinkholes in various places."
That was about to change.
"Giuliani recognized what a gem this place is," Mr. Rosenbaum continued. "We already had 30 businesses and 1,000 jobs, which would be lost unless money was put in." The city began investing heavily in the yard. It has committed $101 million since 1996, to last through 2004. Other public sources have added $27 million, for a total of $128 million. 
The nonprofit corporation, whose board consists of city appointees, community representatives and private individuals, sometimes trades money for people, accepting lower bids from companies that will bring jobs to the yard. 
The blond-bearded Mr. Rosenbaum, 53, revels in his gritty domain. 
"It's like somebody opened up a whole new life for me," he said, trotting energetically down a flight of stairs. He rattles off a list of the yard's attractions. "We're close to Manhattan, we have river access, we've got excellent security. We don't require a lot upfront for deposits, and we'll take chances on new companies that other landlords will not."
Three years ago, when Woodside Press was priced out of its Queens space, its owner, Andrew Birsh, considered leaving the city. Then a friend told him about the Navy Yard. "I took one look at this place and seized it," he said. He estimated his that rent in Manhattan or Woodside would have been around twice the $5.75 per square foot he now pays. 
At the yard, Mr. Birsh has also found an unusual camaraderie. "I went to a sheet metal guy by the dry docks," he said. "I said, 'You want a deposit?' He said, 'You're in the yard, so no.' That really wouldn't happen anywhere else."
Another incentive is low taxes. After the yard was designated a state enterprise zone in 1998, the sales tax was reduced from 8.25 percent to 4 percent. As a city property, the yard is free of real estate tax.
"If we quote $8 a square foot," Mr. Rosenbaum said, "that's what it costs." The range of amenities is wide. Today, $4 a square foot will get you a warehouse with no heat; $22 per square foot gets newly renovated offices with air-conditioning and D.S.L.
Natalie Hurwitz, a local commercial real estate agent, says that while in the early 90's the yard was going begging, recently, demand for space has soared.
"Now they're relatively full," she said, noting that the yard has been helped by the tightening local real estate market. "In Williamsburg and Greenpoint, we're losing industrial space very rapidly to other uses: high tech, retail and residential." The yard also offers unusual architectural features, like 30- and 40-foot ceilings. 
On the downside, the site is cut off from nearby communities. "It seems very isolated," she said, "even though there are people working there all the time." And while the yard has been known for low rents, "now they've been jacked up," she said.

Courting the Community
During Prohibition, when sailors were forbidden to use the Sands Street gate to keep them away from the area's houses of prostitution, the yard's walls were a barrier against the surrounding community. But the yard is working to shed its fortresslike image. Besides offering tours, it is courting residents to work there. Two years ago it set up an employment center that now places around 20 people a month, 30 percent of them within the yard.
"Over the last eight years or so, the nature of the yard has changed," said Bob Evans, chairman of Community Board 2. "I think it's become more of a partner in the larger community."
The improved relations were evident in May, when corporation officials presented the community board with a plan to deepen the adjacent water and use the silt to create four more acres of Navy Yard property. During the incinerator battle of the early 90's, Mr. Rosenbaum said, the community so distrusted the yard that some accused it of bringing in nuclear waste. But at the May meeting, the response was positive: dredging could start this fall.
The brick walls stay up, however, in large part to protect the public from the hazards of the remaining ship repair work. "At the same time that we're reaching out to the community, we have to honor boundaries," Mr. Rosenbaum said.
In any case, businesses prefer the high walls. "When we were in Greenpoint, every night there was some ringy-dingy trying to bust in there," said Scott Jordan, whose business employs 26 people. At the yard, he said, nothing like that has ever happened.
But the yard is hard to get to. The closest subway stations, the High Street stop of the A and C trains and the York Street stop of the F, are a 7- to 10-minute walk away, and city buses do not enter the compound. Access does not seem to be hurting business, however, judging from the high occupancy rate. In February, the yard began running shuttles to nearby subway stops. 
But Ron Shiffman, director of the Pratt Center for Community and Environmental Development, said the yard needed more than shuttles. "I think we have to build either a light rail system or higher-occupancy vehicles than those that now serve the Navy Yard," he said.
Mr. Shiffman believes the yard is going in the right direction. But a rosy future is not guaranteed. An economic downturn would affect the yard's fortunes, as will the mayoral election. A new administration might replace Mr. Rosenbaum with someone who has different ideas. "I'm always worried that there won't be the same commitment in a future administration," he said.
Then there are the movie studios. Plans for a major film studio in the Navy Yard were rumored to have died in 1999, when Robert De Niro's widely publicized bid fell through. But another studio entrepreneur, Louis Madigan, has been in contract with the yard since 1998. In partnership with Steiner Equities, a real estate developer, Mr. Madigan has completed demolition to make way for two enormous buildings that will house 11 sound stages. When finished, possibly as soon as next year, the $150 million 650,000-square-foot project, Steiner Studios, will be the nation's biggest outside Hollywood.
Some neighbors are not pleased. Early this year, members of the Williamsburg Hasidic community threatened a lawsuit to halt construction of the studios, which one rabbi likened to bringing Times Square into Amish country. 
"We'll do everything we can to make sure that's not the case," Mr. Madigan said, adding that the studios would bring 2,000 jobs to the yard.
Others question the viability of the project, especially when more movies are being made abroad and many use digital technology. Some worry that the yard's transportation problems will hurt the studios, given the large numbers of people they will employ.
Mr. Rosenbaum, noting that the studios can be used for making commercials or rented out for purposes other than moviemaking, said he was not worried. In the worst case, he said, "They'd default and we'd have some really beautiful air-conditioned warehouse buildings."
But he said he was confident that the studios will succeed. Smiling, he slipped a tape into his office VCR. A scene from "Mickey Blue Eyes" flickered on, showing Hugh Grant and James Caan burying a dead body along an industrial waterfront. "That was filmed right down there," Mr. Rosenbaum said proudly, pointing out the window.

The Outside Is Misleading
On June 1, completing a process that took years, the Navy signed over most of its remaining property, 28 scenic, grassy acres on the north end. Known as the annex, the area is dotted with mature trees and buildings in Greek Revival and French Second Empire style. The transfer had been delayed by asbestos removal and questions about human remains. The site had been a burial ground from the late 1700's until 1910, beginning when British prison ships moored there during the Revolution.
Today, plywood covers the annex's buildings, which include the Naval Hospital, an imposing three-story structure with frosty, whitewashed halls and basement cells that were used for Confederate prisoners. 
"The annex is a burden," Mr. Rosenbaum said. "Before we can develop it, we have to spend money on security. The hospital is a landmark, so we have to check with the state historic preservation office before we can do any work on it." Possibilities include leasing the area to an institution or using it as a back lot for the studios. Whatever it becomes, it will have to earn its keep.
The crumbling Admirals' Row, shrouded in weeds and mulberry trees, is still under the jurisdiction of the Army Corps of Engineers, which plans to turn it over to the city. Proposals have included recasting the six or so buildings as upscale food stores and community offices, but Richard Drucker, the yard's vice president of planning and development, estimates renovation of the deteriorated property could cost up to $30 million. (One officer's house that remains well preserved is the 1806 Commandant's Residence, a white clapboard manor house on the yard's south end. Now in private hands, the structure, a landmark, is said to have been designed by Charles Bulfinch, architect of the Capitol in Washington.)
The yard's image is another problem. It has convinced skeptics that it does not wallow in nuclear waste or lead paint. Still, most New Yorkers are unaware of it.
"Every time we're mentioned, people are surprised," Mr. Rosenbaum said. "I hear story after story of the derelict Brooklyn Navy Yard. We have 200 tenants, but still we're seen as obscure."
That might be helped by sprucing up the outside, which Mr. Rosenbaum acknowledged looks unappealing.
"I refer to it as having a postapocalyptic look," he said. "But the outside is the least of what we're concerned with. You're not going to waste your money on dermatology or plastic surgery if you have osteoporosis."
In fact, Mr. Rosenbaum seems to enjoy the contrast between the dilapidated exterior and the modern businesses it harbors, like pearls inside a crusty oyster shell.
"The theme," he said with a grin, "is, 'You can't judge what's going on in the Navy Yard from the outside.' "

HEADLINE: This Summer, Sale Britannia 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH SIANO 

 BODY:
IF President Bush had included Britain on his European itinerary last month, he might have saved enough to cover some tax-rebate checks. With weak bookings for summer, hotels, tour operators and other related businesses all over Britain are cutting prices. "I think there are a lot of them, particularly this summer," said Tim Lovell, vice president for the British Tourist Authority in the United States, referring to the deals. 
 July and August bring good weather, so it hardly seems like a time for a clearance sale on British tourism. But Mr. Lovell said that his office was projecting a drop of 10 to 15 percent in visits by Americans this year, versus last year. "Last year was a bumper year, and it's hard to follow up on that," he said. A few months ago, the foot-and-mouth epidemic -- since brought under control but not eradicated -- probably caused many Americans to wait before making plans to visit Britain in summer, said Tom Keefe, owner of Addison Travel in Andover, Mass. And Wall Street hasn't helped. "The people in e-commerce didn't get their bonuses this year, and the older people are nervous about their stocks," Mr. Keefe said. 
 Even Amberley Castle, which has stood fast near Arundel, 58 miles south of London, for nearly 900 years, has flinched. A midweek stay in its suites has been cut by $72 a night; rates are now $325 to $361 (at $1.44 to the pound); www.amberleycastle.co.uk.
Less-palatial accommodations are being discounted as well. Marriott offers a two-night weekend stay with breakfast from $143 a person at several London hotels through Aug. 31, for reservations made before July 31 through a travel agent or www.marriott.com. And the Francis in the Square, near the Roman spa in Bath, has cut midweek rates by $36 to $87 a person with dinner and breakfast until Aug. 30; weekends, $14 more. Call (44-870) 400-8223. In Edinburgh, the Howard, a town house hotel, has cut a two-night stay by $115 to $245 a person until July 31, with tickets to the Royal Yacht Britannia, moored nearby. Call (44-131) 557-3500.
The deals extend to transportation. Through July 31, BritRail is discounting its Classic Passes -- good for unlimited trips in increments of eight days to a month -- by 25 percent, an offer that extends to Scotland; (877) 677-1066. Virgin Atlantic will let children 11 or under fly free to London from Chicago, Miami, Boston and San Francisco, if parents buy a ticket by Aug. 31; (800) 862-8621.
Tour operators on this side of the Atlantic are getting into it as well. DER Travel Services of Rosemont, Ill., has extended a program that provides a one-week rental of an economy-class car (V.A.T. extra) in Britain with the purchase of two airline tickets to England or Scotland from DER. Bookings must be made by July 31, but the cars are available until Aug. 31; (800) 549-3737.
Recent efforts to lure Americans have included full-page advertisements in major newspapers by the British Tourist Authority. 
For hotel deals, www.londontown.com and www.all-hotels.com merit a look. The British Tourist Authority Web site is at www.travelbritain.org.

HEADLINE: When Free Markets Leave Workers in the Dust 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The column says any society that ignores the consequences of economic disruption on its citizens "undermines its own cohesion and adaptability."
 By that argument, President Bush receives credit for protecting steel workers in West Virginia and Pennsylvania through quotas. 
But why does he abandon California in the energy crisis? 
 Aren't people in California part of the American community? The column says it is human nature, and morally and economically defensible, to care more about people who are nearby over those who are far away. Still, as far as Mr. Bush is concerned, people who are "nearby" are only those who will vote for him.
Favoring potential supporters with blatantly hypocritical policies could further polarize the United States electorate, an electorate left sharply divided after the recent presidential race. It could help undermine the very sense of national community that Mr. Redburn wants to foster.

ALEXANDRA BALLANTINE
Brewster, N.Y., June 18
