HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
A campaign for an online brokerage firm promises to eliminate the 'middleman.'

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
AT a time when online trading volume is contracting and most Web-based brokerage firms are cutting their advertising budgets, a new online brokerage firm is seeking to generate awareness among and business from potential customers with a television, print and online campaign.
 Because the effort by Brokerage America, a division of Andrew Garrett Inc., comes as interest in trading stocks -- by yourself or through a broker -- is waning, the timing of the campaign, by a New York agency named Dirty Water Integrated, is either as smart as selling the Nasdaq short when it reached 5000 or as foolish as buying shares of Pets.com as they kept falling. 
 The intended strategy is one that often turns up in economic downturns: advertise when your competitors reduce or eliminate their ad budgets, to gain what is known as share of voice, not to mention take advantage of lower rates for advertising time and space.
That could help Brokerage America make headway in a crowded field in which the top 10 firms already control more than 90 percent of the market, particularly when Brokerage America is so late to the party -- or is it a wake? 
Yet the number of households trading online "is still expected to grow" in the coming years, said Drew Sykoff, co-chairman and chief executive at Brokerage America in New York.
"And another good reason to launch now is that we're getting 3 to 10 times more in buying power for the ad dollars we spend," he added, "whether on the Web, in print or on TV."
The campaign for Brokerage America carries the theme "Cut to the trade," meant to emphasize what Mr. Sykoff described as a principal "difference between us and our competitors," which is that Garrett, as a market maker in 1,100 Nasdaq stocks, will use its own operations to execute orders, in addition to offering free trades as many other online brokerage firms have done or still do. By working with Brokerage America, the campaign asserts, investors will be working with a market maker and doing away with "an invisible middleman" who was "taking a cut on every trade."
That thought is brought to life in a comically exaggerated way in two television commercials, which begin running this week. They show middlemen intruding in other everyday commercial transactions, like ordering dinner at a restaurant and buying groceries at a supermarket.
The idea is to dramatize the concept that "you don't tolerate a middleman in other aspects of your life, so why tolerate one here," said Peter DePasquale, chief executive of Dirty Water, which was opened in April 2000.
That "gets right at the heart of the heavy users of online brokers who are still active even though the market is contracting," he added. "We've lost the casual online investor; what's left is the core."
Advertisers -- and agencies, too -- can make money in a slowing or declining economy, Mr. DePasquale declared, "if your promise is compelling" for that core frequent customer.
The commercials were preceded by print and banner ads, some of the "teaser" variety, asking computer users to visit real Web sites with fanciful addresses like www.youronlinebrokerisafatcatgettingfatter.com and, evocative of an episode of "The Sopranos," www.isyouronlinebrokerdippinghisbeak.com.
"You would think, 'Why would the world need another online broker?' " asked Rob Austin, partner and creative director at Dirty Water.
You might ask the same question of the world needing another campaign for an online brokerage firm, particularly one speaking with a sassy, worldly wise, even world-weary tone of voice heard so often from other companies in the category.
"It's humorous and has a little bit of an edge to it, to get the point across," Mr. Sycoff said of the Brokerage America campaign, especially to "the savvy self-directed investor."
"At a time when people are reeling from losses and looking for added value," he added, "there's never been a better time" for that.
Brokerage America plans to spend $7 million on the campaign. That is more than some large, established online brokerage firms spent to advertise in the first three months of 2001, according to CMR in New York, a unit of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending.
For instance, the Morgan Stanley Dean Witter online brokerage unit of Morgan Stanley spent $5.5 million to advertise in the first quarter of this year, CMR reported, compared with $20.6 million in the corresponding period of 2000.
Other online brokerage firms spent far more than that, but still reduced their spending considerably. For example, according to CMR, Ameritrade Holding spent almost $30 million in the first three months of 2001, compared with $45.7 million in the same period last year, and the E*Trade Group spent $10.9 million in the first three months of 2001 compared with $30.4 million in the first three months of 2000.

HEADLINE: U.S. Farmers Look Back...; 
...and See Soy Growers In Brazil Shadowing Them

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER L. RICH 

DATELINE: ITACOATIARA, Brazil 

 BODY:
The blazing midday sun dances off the long line of bright gold barges preparing to disgorge their cargo, Asia-bound soybeans, at this tiny but up-to-date Amazon River port. The barges, lashed nine tight, made the uneventful 600-mile journey down the Madeira River from the heart of Brazil's soybean country in less than 48 hours, cutting almost a week off the traditional overland route. That translates into a considerable savings that can be passed along to the beans' buyers.
 Meanwhile, 4,000 miles north of here, on the Mississippi River, 15-barge configurations loaded with Iowa- and Illinois-grown soybeans often wait in line for hours to pass through a series of creaky 80-year-old locks that will lower them down to the sea at New Orleans, where they will be transferred to freighters bound for foreign ports. Each hour of delay costs American farmers an estimated $500. 
 In the race to move soybeans to the global marketplace, Brazil, Argentina and China are gaining and the United States, the longtime champ, is faltering. 
As they watch competitors invest heavily to reduce shipping time and costs, American farmers say that the river that once helped make United States agriculture the low-price leader is now costing them about $100 million a year in delays.
Against objections from environmentalists and some economists, a farmers' group is clamoring for taxpayers to pay at least part of the bill of more than $1 billion to lengthen and upgrade the locks.
The contentious question of Mississippi River improvements cuts to the heart of a larger issue: how do third- or fourth-generation American farmers compete against more agile entrepreneurial rivals like those here in Brazil, where land is plentiful and cheap, and government regulators are distant?
Much of the Brazilian soy is already cheaper to produce than its counterpart in Iowa by as much as $1.50 a bushel, or around 20 percent.
While a number of American agricultural exports face such threats, the soybean situation is among the most glaring. Over the last five years, the United States' share of world soybean exports has fallen 27 percent, to about 53 percent of the global market. In that time, the Brazilians have more than doubled their share of the soybean export market.
One big problem for American soy farmers is that they no longer receive set-aside payments to limit production and help support prices. But since the 1996 farm bill did away with such supports, presuming that farmers would export their way to prosperity, world demand has not been high enough and bumper crops have sent prices spiraling to 30-year lows, making every penny of competitive advantage count.
That is why Tim Burrack, an Iowa soybean and corn grower, went home spooked from a fact-finding trip to the port at Itacoatiara earlier this year. The port was the brainchild of Blairo Maggi, one of Brazil's largest soybean producers, with around 125,000 acres under cultivation in the central-western state of Mato Grosso. After trying in vain to have the Brazilian government move ahead with promised infrastructure projects, Mr. Maggi used $20 million of his own money and $40 million from the state of Amazonas, where Itacoatiara is situated, to turn the Amazon-feeding Madeira River into a viable waterway.
When low tides threatened to run his towboats aground, he imported sonar equipment from the United States to map the riverbed. When logs floating downriver from timber-cutting operations upstream threatened to poke holes in their hulls, he equipped his boats with high-powered propellers used by Finnish icebreakers. At the port, he uses a Swedish vacuum pumping technology not yet found in the United States to unload the barges and then load the beans into 50,000-ton freighters at 25 tons a minute.
Since the port opened in 1997, soy shipments on the Madeira River have quadrupled, to more than a million tons a year. In the process, Mr. Maggi's shipping costs fell 20 percent.
Meanwhile, the long-awaited Mississippi River decision is on hold because of doubts raised about an eight-year cost benefit analysis and environmental impact study by the Army Corps of Engineers that favored upgrading the locks. The study data is now being reviewed again, and a final decision may not come for years.
"We are in danger of losing everything unless we wake up," Mr. Burrack, the Iowa farmer, warned his fellow growers. "Down there, they are entrepreneurs. They tell the government to get out of the way. They do it themselves. In the U.S., we farmers are going to the government and asking for more."
Critics of the river upgrade say that it amounts to a billion-dollar taxpayer subsidy to agribusiness concerns -- Cargill, Archer Daniels Midland and others -- that are themselves investing heavily in expanding their operations in Brazil and elsewhere to take advantage of lower-cost production.
They say that even if the project is completed, it will be impossible for American farmers to cut their costs as sharply as Mr. Maggi has, because the American grain transport system over all is already highly efficient. American producers, they say, should look elsewhere to improve competitiveness.
One vast difference between the two countries is the cost of land. Iowa soybean farmers pay $2.38 more for enough land to grow a bushel of soybeans than do their counterparts in Mato Grosso, according to an Iowa State University study. Mike Duffy, an economist at the university and an author of the study, thinks the difference in land prices will shrink over time as the relative value of the countries' crops converge.
But the country's center-west region already produces soy for 20 percent less than in Iowa. And once the Brazilian government liberates the use of genetically modified beans, a decision widely expected but tied up in the courts pending the results of environmental impact studies, production costs may fall even further.
Paradoxically, the soybean boom in Brazil came largely at the hands of the United States. In 1980, after President Jimmy Carter banned agricultural commodity sales to Russia for 16 months in response to the invasion of Afghanistan, farmers in the southern states of Rio Grande do Sul and Parana began switching to soybeans to meet the new world demand.
The Brazilian government offered incentives for people to move into a vast, unoccupied area called the "cerrado" -- the scrubby flatlands of Mato Grosso -- to prepare the land for agriculture.
Many original settlers of this new frontier, who had initially planted rice or raised cattle, went broke by the 1990's, when the country opened up to global trade and a new economic scheme stabilized hyperinflation but cut into their profits. The cleared land was snapped up by experienced soybean growers.
There are now about eight million acres of soy under cultivation in Mato Grosso, according to the government-funded agricultural research agency Embrapa Soja, and another 125 million acres of land -- about the size of Illinois, Iowa and Kansas combined -- readily available in the cerrado region alone. In the last decade, Mato Grosso has become the country's leading producer of soybeans and cotton, the second-largest rice grower and the fourth-largest in terms of cattle.
"There is a huge amount of land, the soils run deep, they are easy to work, easy to clear, they've got good drainage; it's land that lends itself very well to agriculture," said Randall Schnepf, senior economist at the United States Department of Agriculture's Economic Research Service. "The question has generally been infrastructure access to that region."
Mr. Maggi's spiffy new facilities handled only a small portion of the nine million tons of beans harvested in Mato Grosso this year. Indeed, around the country, 68 percent of the soybean crop travels the old, expensive route: by truck, over thousands of miles of unreliable roads.
The Brazilian government has been promising a system of paved roads and navigable waterways to reduce the costs of agricultural production in the cerrado and Amazon regions, but chronic economic instability and high budget deficits have held up the works.
Now, private capital is filling some gaps. A consortium of Brazilian pension funds and outside investors like GE Capital and Chase Capital Partners is working to complete the long-promised Ferronorte railroad, which would eventually give growers in the interior of Mato Grosso a straight shot to the port of Santos in Sao Paulo, cutting transport costs by as much as half.
The rail line, which has already reached the state border, is expected to haul three to five million tons of soy this year, and should eventually carry as much as 12 million tons when it is completed around 2004.
But the project that causes the greatest anticipation among Brazilian growers and the greatest fear among American producers like Mr. Burrack is the eventual paving of a 1,200 mile stretch of highway from the Mato Grosso state capital, Cuiaba, to Santarem, on the edge of the Amazon River in the northern state of Para. The road, which is currently unpassable most of the year because of flooding, would not only reduce costs for current production; it might open up a big new region to agriculture.
The government, though, has yet to follow through on a 20-year-old promise to pave the stretch. As the country grapples with an energy crisis that has turned the focus of investment toward power generation, the road's completion seems even more distant.
Still, in anticipation, Cargill, the Minneapolis food conglomerate, and Bunge, its Argentine counterpart, bought the port at Santarem.
Some American growers say that though the threat from Brazil is real it has been overblown. Among other things, the Brazilians have to contend with a heavy tax burden, and they have no United States-style farm support program to help them cope until prices rebound.
And even though Brazil's currency has weakened considerably this year, making the country's exports seem cheaper, many of the necessary farm supplies are paid for in dollars, which mostly cancels out the gains.
American optimists also say that environmental regulators inside Brazil have finally started to legislate against the type of large-scale land clearing that was common in the last decade. Additional infrastructure projects, like the creation of connecting waterways, are encountering resistance.
Still, Mr. Burrack and other American farmers are warning their compatriots to beware. "I figure we've got 10 to 15 years to get ourselves in position to compete on a low-scale commodity business, or we need to move forward on something that is more value-added," Mr. Burrack said in a recent phone interview.
The Brazilians have the same goal in mind. Embrapa Soja, the world leader in tropical soybean research, is busily upgrading its patented bean and developing new products for the export and domestic market.
Brazilian soybean producers say that there is room in the international market for everyone. But with more scrub turned into farmland every day, their aspirations are looming larger.
"We would be very nervous," Mr. Schnepf of the United States Department of Agriculture said, "if they can do the same thing with corn."

HEADLINE: Needy Workers Wait for a Kansas Plant to Reopen 

BYLINE:  By JOHN W. FOUNTAIN 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, Kan., July 3 

 BODY:
The cluster of white buildings and steel bins rises above these cattle-covered plains like a miniature city of skyscrapers. But the giant Con Agra beef processing plant here is still these days. Gone are the rows of workers' cars that used to fill its parking lots, and gone, too, is the bustle of business from sunrise to sundown.
 A fire on Christmas night that started on the kill floor and took 18 hours to extinguish closed the plant, and six months later, it is still closed, leaving many of the 2,300 workers with a growing sense of desperation. 
 Several hundred of them have found other jobs. But most have not. Unemployment in Finney County, of which Garden City is the seat, is about 11 percent, up from 3 percent to 4 percent in the last decade. For many people, unemployment compensation ran out last month and their savings are gone. Deepening the uncertainty, ConAgra has said nothing about the plant's fate.
With the economy slowing and unemployment rising across the Midwest, the plant's closing could not have come at a worse time. And living in sparsely populated western Kansas only worsens the outlook for the ConAgra workers. 
"A lot of families stated they were holding on until their kids got out of school, and they didn't want to interrupt their children's education," said Harold Frost, of the Salvation Army, which has helped hundreds of families. "I'm really surprised that they haven't picked up and moved on."
Many are unlikely to stay through the summer.
"It's hard with no job," Christina Felix, 21, said this week in a white frame building known as Emmaus House. It is a local shelter for the homeless and a food bank, where Ms. Felix and others out of work have come in recent months for baskets of free food.
"It's hard with no job," she said. "I have three daughters and no husband."
For the time being, Ms. Felix has a job cleaning potatoes at a plant near Garden City, seasonal work for two months at $6.20 an hour, considerably less than the $9.50 an hour she earned cleaning the ConAgra plant. When the potato job ends, she does not know what she and her daughters, ages 3, 4 and 5, will do. An uncle has already moved to work in ConAgra's plant in Dumas, Tex., and Ms. Felix is wondering whether she will have to do the same.
Others can relate to her plight. Sylvia Aniles, 34, said she had had no luck finding a job. At ConAgra, Ms. Aniles made $9.75 an hour, cleaning cattle hooves. She said she had worked at the plant for two years. The $179 a week in unemployment benefits she has been getting is about to run out, and she worries about how she will pay the $340 monthly rent on the trailer where she and her three children live.
"It's very, very difficult," Ms. Aniles said just before she and her children carted away a box at Emmaus filled with powdered milk, cereal, green beans, chicken, frozen cherries, beans and rice.
Like Ms. Felix and Ms. Aniles, most of the other former ConAgra workers are Mexican immigrants. Mostly unskilled laborers, they had been able to support their families in this city of around 28,000 people, about 60 miles west of Dodge City.
For miles around, the smell of feedlots floats on the Midwestern summer breezes. People have grown used to the smell of cattle manure; the most pragmatic, like Mayor Jim Wharton of Garden City, call it the smell of money. Mayor Wharton, 85, is worried about the welfare of a sizable portion of the Garden City's work force and the financial well-being of the town.
"It has affected everybody," he said. "The whole town is down quite a little bit.
"Our sales tax, as of now, is still holding," he said, but he added that he was not sure how much longer that would be the case.
About 80 percent of the city's expenses are financed by sales tax revenues, which will decline as people who have lost jobs spend less.
Here in cattle country, fields of sunflowers, golden grain and emerald alfalfa bask in the sun. This iswhere lawmen like Wyatt Earp and Bat Masterson and saloon-rowdy gunslingers once roamed. There seems to be little that is not touched in some way by the cattle industry. Indeed, Garden City is part of a golden triangle for the beef industry that includes Dodge City and Liberal, 70 miles south of Garden City. Until the ConAgra plant closed, the meat-packing industry in the three cities cleared about 20,000 head of cattle a day, officials said.
Despite the loss of ConAgra, Garden City still claims as its own what officials say is the largest beef packing plant in the world, IBP, although it is three miles west in Holcomb. Despite its size, that plant can absorb only so many workers.
Most laid-off ConAgra employees spend their days filling out job applications. Jorge Perez, 38, knows the routine. Mr. Perez, a father of two, said he had held a variety of jobs doing "everything, construction, whatever" since the plant closed.
Working at a meat packing plant is not easy. The industry has long been criticized for hazardous conditions. Some workers, wielding sharp knives in close quarters under pressure to be fast, have lost fingers and limbs or worse. But the wages and benefits have great appeal, many here say, especially among people with little formal education.
Officials at the ConAgra Agri-Products Company, which is based in Greeley, Colo., and is a unit of Con Agra Foods Inc., concede that the company has been slow in deciding whether it will rebuild the Garden City plant.
"We realize that the decision making process has taken longer than anticipated," said Karen Lynn, a company spokeswoman, who added that ConAgra had not received a settlement from an insurance claim on the fire, which the authorities said was caused by spontaneous combustion.
A network of local churches and charities is trying to help those out of work. The Salvation Army has spent more than $45,000 subsidizing rent and helping to pay utility bills. It has also provided about 350 families with food, Mr. Frost said. The United Methodist Mexican American Ministries in Garden City has spent $65,000 on rent and mortgage subsidies for ConAgra families, Penny Schwab, the director, said. And at Emmaus House, more than 180,000 meals have been served to families in the first six months of the year. Emmaus House served 111,000 all of last year.
Since the closing, about 20 percent of the Garden City workers have been hired by ConAgra plants in other cities, including Grand Island, Neb., and Dumas, though Garden City officials and former workers say many have returned here, unable to find housing or reluctant to uproot their families.
"We're mad and sad," said Ms. Aniles, the mother who is still looking for work. "We're mad because we don't have a job. We're sad because we don't hear anything."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Corning and Alcatel Announce Large Cutbacks

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER with SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Corning and Alcatel, two companies that had flourished in recent years making the building blocks of the communications industry, announced severe cutbacks yesterday, including plant closings, new layoffs totaling 3,500 workers and, in the case of Corning, the suspension of dividend payments.
 The actions came in response to a glut of installed fiber optic capacity and hundreds of millions of dollars of fiber optic equipment in warehouses that has not yet been sold. Corning executives said yesterday that most of its inventory would become obsolete before it could be sold. 
 The announcements are the latest examples of turmoil in the communications industry. A sharp decline in spending by start-up carriers, slowing spending by large established phone companies and a drought in financing for expansion of existing networks have contributed to a reversal of the industry's fortunes in the last year. 
Corning, based in Corning, N.Y., is taking a $300 million second-quarter write-off for that excess inventory and writing off another $4.8 billion related to its acquisition of the Pirelli optical components business and the NetOptix business based in Natick, Mass. -- a plant that is now being closed. In addition, Corning is closing two other plants, including one completed just a year ago in Benton Township, Pa., and one still under construction in Nashua, N.H.
As John Loose, the chief executive of Corning, said in a conference call after the markets closed yesterday, "Last December, we were planning and budgeting for a very different world than the one that confronts us today."
In addition to the $5.1 billion in second-quarter charges, Corning executives said the company would take a $300 million to $400 million charge in the third quarter, most of it related to the layoff of 1,000 workers. The company is also eliminating dividend payments on its common stock from the third quarter onward.
Standard & Poor's, the credit rating agency, lowered Corning's corporate credit rating yesterday by one notch, to A-/A-2, from A/A-1, and Moody's Investors Service put the company's debt under review for a possible downgrade.
Alcatel, whose main North American site is in Plano, Tex., announced yesterday that it would lay off 2,500 of its workers in this country, or one-sixth of its work force in the United States. The announcement comes after Alcatel's failed effort to acquire another ailing communications equipment company, Lucent Technologies, in May.
Serge Tchuruk, Alcatel's chief executive, said last month that the company planned to sell most of its factories to cut costs. Alcatel, which is based in Paris, has already cut 2,000 jobs in the United States this year. The company has also offered buyouts to 9,000 employees in the United States.
Mr. Loose of Corning said he did not except the United States economy to rebound before the end of this year, at the earliest. The telecommunications business, he said, would lag the rest of the economy, and would turn around no earlier than a year to 18 months from now.
Shares of Corning closed at $15.10, down 3 cents, but dropped below $14.40 in after-hours trading. American depository receipts of Alcatel closed at $16.25, down 27 cents.

HEADLINE: Cities and Their Suburbs Are Seen Growing as Units 

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9 

 BODY:
The vast majority of new jobs and economic wealth created in the United States over the past decade were generated within metropolitan areas, a new analysis for the nation's mayors shows. 
 Cities have long been home to industries that fueled the nation's economic growth, from automobiles to computers. But urban cores combined with suburbs have formed world-class metropolitan regions that accounted for more than 80 percent of the country's growth in income, employment and production of goods and services during the 1990's, the study says. 
 Were the New York metropolitan area a country, its $437.8 billion economy would rank 14th in the world, just behind South Korea, but ahead of Australia and Taiwan, says the report to the United States Conference of Mayors, which is to be released here on Tuesday. 
Still seeking to shake the stigma of urban decay or suburban sprawl, cities and adjacent counties are mounting a campaign backed by the nation's mayors to pressure state and federal governments to invest more resources into metropolitan areas that city leaders say are driving the nation's economy.
"The challenge is getting everyone to understand the interdependency between cities and suburbs," Mayor Marc H. Morial of New Orleans, the conference's president, said in a telephone interview. "We're not talking about regional government. That's where people get hung up." 
Beginning in September, Mr. Morial said he and other mayors would tour the cities to highlight the features, including a skilled work force, affordable housing, strong infrastructure and low crime rates, that they say make metropolitan areas economically competitive. 
The report underscores an urban renaissance under way in many of the country's major metropolitan areas. The nation's largest cities grew nearly twice as fast in the 1990's as in the 1980's, with three out of every four urban centers gaining population, analyses of the 2000 census figures show. In most cases, suburbs grew even faster than nearby cities. 
Just as governors have long promoted trade to build their state's economies, the nation's mayors and regional economic development boards are playing a more active role in the global economy. Denver has opened trade offices in London and in China. Akron, Ohio, has struck deals with three German machine companies that brought 70 new jobs to the region. 
In addition to New York, the metropolitan areas of Los Angeles-Long Beach, Calif. ($363.7 billion), and Chicago ($332.8 billion) would rank among the world's top 20 economies were they countries, according to the study. The New York region included New York City and some northern suburbs, but Nassau and Suffolk Counties and Newark were counted separately. 
The mayors' report, compiled by DRI-WEFA, an economic forecasting company in Lexington, Mass., computed the total value of goods and services produced in each of the nation's 319 largest metropolitan regions. 
The overall gross metropolitan product increased to $8.5 trillion in 2000 from $4.8 trillion in 1990, an average annual gain of 5.8 percent, the study said. The share of the nation's economic output produced in metro areas nudged up to 84.7 percent in 2000 from 84.3 percent in 1990, and the study's authors projected the share to reach nearly 87 percent by 2025. 
Of the 22.2 million jobs created in 1990's, 84 percent were generated in metropolitan areas. Last year, the average metropolitan area worker collected $38,000 in wages and benefits, compared with a nonmetropolitan area worker who earned $24,800. In a troubling sign, the income gap between metro and nonmetro workers has increased to $13,200 per worker from $4,600 in 1985. 
Urban analysts said the statistics illustrated the increasing interdependency of metropolitan economies as well as the sheer size of the economic output.
"This helps people think regionally, which is a more realistic measure," said Robert Lang, an urban analyst with the Fannie Mae Foundation, an independent research organization. "Economies don't stop at a city's edge." 
Indeed, the Fannie Mae Foundation recently released a list of 53 rapidly growing cities on the edge of larger cities, like Mesa, Ariz., and Arlington, Tex., that it called "boomburbs." 
But sprawl, congestion and declining schools have accompanied rapid economic growth, and the mayor's report called on state and federal officials to help address these problems. 
"The more successful these regions are, the more they're stuck in traffic, the more they're gobbling up open space, and the more disconnected the working poor are from jobs," said Bruce Katz, director of the Brookings Institution's Center on Urban and Metropolitan Policy.
Mr. Katz said that with the exception of places like Portland, Ore., and Minneapolis, most metropolitan areas do not have strong advocates in government. 
"Metropolitan areas are the step-children of American governance," said Mr. Katz. "These regions face enormous challenges and they don't have their own voice."

HEADLINE: Bergen Officials Call for Ambitious Rail Service Expansion 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 9 

 BODY:
Bergen County officials called today for creation of an expanded multibillion-dollar rail system that would include three new train lines in the county and links between them and three existing commuter lines.
 The county executive, William Schuber, said the broader, integrated network would include construction of the first new train stations in Bergen in 50 years. He said it would ease highway congestion, spur economic growth and provide the first rail links between communities in the western and eastern halves of the county and the Meadowlands sports complex in East Rutherford. 
 In a news conference here with the county's director of planning and economic development, Chester P. Mattson, and Assemblywoman Rose M. Heck, Republican of Lodi, Mr. Schuber called on state legislators and mayors in Bergen, New Jersey's most populous county, to join them in seeking approval of the plan. 
The system they outlined was basically identical to an expanded rail plan proposed for Bergen that New Jersey Transit, the state's mass transit agency, will hold public hearings on this week and next.
The main difference is the timetable. Mr. Schuber called for simultaneous creation of the three new lines and five transfer stations connecting them and existing lines. New Jersey Transit has not committed itself to anything so ambitious.
"The key to the economic future of both the Meadowlands and the county," Mr. Schuber said, "is the immediate and guaranteed investment in a comprehensive rail network plan -- not a piecemeal plan, not a single line today and hopes of something bigger tomorrow."
In an apparent effort to persuade local officials to prod New Jersey Transit, Mr. Schuber said the future of the county's economy could not be left "in the hands of others."
"We must take an active part in creating our own destiny," he said.
New Jersey Transit would not comment on the proposal. For now, the agency has not backed the construction of any of the three proposed new rail lines or any transfer stations linking them and existing lines.
The public hearings that are to begin Tuesday are the first phase of a study of the costs and the environmental impact of a broader system, and New Jersey Transit said it did not plan to endorse any segment of it until the study was done.
"Each line will be studied on its own, but in conjunction with the others," said an agency spokesman, Michael Klufas. He said the studies would include possible interconnections between new and old lines.
Mr. Schuber said his proposed system would cost several billion dollars and take at least 10 years to build. Mr. Klufas said projected costs would not be known until the studies were finished. The federal government would provide the bulk of the money for any expanded system, New Jersey Transit officials said.
The three proposed new lines once carried commuter trains but are used now only to haul freight.
One, the Northern Branch, would link the Englewood-Teaneck area with New Jersey Transit's main train terminal in Hoboken. Another, the New York, Susquehanna and Western, would run from Hawthorne in Passaic County through Bergen to Hoboken. Commuter service on both ended in 1966. Light rail lines similar to the new, trolley-like Hudson-Bergen line between Bayonne and Jersey City are proposed for both routes.
The third proposed line, the West Shore, would run from West Nyack, N.Y., in Rockland County, through eastern Bergen to Hoboken. Commuter trains last ran on it in 1959. 
Under Mr. Schuber's plan, the three lines would be linked to the county's three existing lines -- the Valley Line, the Bergen Line and the Main Line -- by new transfer stations built near track intersections in Hawthorne; East Rutherford, where the sports complex is situated; Hackensack, Ridgefield Park; and Fairview in the county's southeastern corner.

PERSON: Cheryl J. Hurley 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
The (Mostly Late) Greats, in New Circulation

BYLINE:  By ROBIN FINN 

 BODY:
THIS country does a crummy job as guardian of great books by its dead authors. Or it used to. Edmund Wilson voiced that criticism 40 years ago, crankily and accurately. And Cheryl J. Hurley, the blond-coiffed, high-heeled, ladies-who-lunch look-alike (the resemblance ends there) who is chief executive of the Library of America, is relieved that he did. 
 If not for him, she might have missed her life's calling, rescuing books as the head of a patriotic nonprofit publishing house that was created by a committee of scholars in 1979 and is still going gung-ho. It recently dusted off Longfellow's reputation after a half-century of neglect; it will sponsor a reading of maritime works July 17 at the South Street Seaport; and in September it will revive the writings of Dawn Powell, the urbane, underappreciated New York novelist whose prose packs Dorothy Parker pungency. 
 If not for Wilson, Ms. Hurley would be childless -- she calls the 124 omnibus volumes published during her 22-year tenure her children, remembers them in her will and hopes philanthropists with cash to burn are bitten by the book bug, too. For $50,000, a bookworm can adopt a volume in the Library of America series, guaranteeing that Frost or Fitzgerald (they're already sponsored) or Stowe, Steinbeck or Hammett (they're still available) remain in print in perpetuity. The Library of America doesn't just restore the country's literary heritage to print, it keeps it there.
"We're not only a publisher, we're a cultural institution," observes the impeccably groomed Ms. Hurley as a rosy flush -- she doesn't mean to brag, she's just convinced of her mission's virtues -- creeps upward from the lapels of her double-breasted jacket. "Who's looking after our literature, not just the greatest hits, but the shorter, earlier, quieter writings? To provide a comprehensive selection of an author's work, that's our passion and motivation," she recites, sounding zealous and then, after hearing of her interlocutor's ignorance about L.O.A., sounding miffed. "We've got to do a better job of getting the word out."
Ms. Hurley used to explain an author's eligibility for Library of America publication this way: he or she had to be great, American-born and dead. But when the Library of America found its own rule too fusty, it broke it: Vladimir Nabokov was included (Ms. Hurley considers "Lolita" the "quintessential American novel"), and so was Eudora Welty, the first living author to make the cut.
"She has been a great friend to us, and we wanted to do something to make her happy, and this did," Ms. Hurley says.
WHAT else makes the Library of America indispensable? Ms. Hurley jumps up and -- Want evidence? Here's evidence -- snatches several volumes from her shelves. She publishes the authentic version, be it the poetry of Frost or the elliptical prose of Faulkner, as the author intended it. Richard Wright's "Native Son" is the most dramatic case in point. It seems some passages packed a double whammy of provocation, racial and sexual, in the 1940's that prompted the Book-of-the-Month Club to delete them. "And the author agreed," she says sympathetically, "because he just wanted to get his book published and seen." But the two L.O.A. versions of Mr. Wright's works, early and late, are printed intact, just as he wrote them. If originality offends, so be it. It also sells, and garners front-list reviews. 
"We have to sell a lot of books in order to survive," notes Ms. Hurley, whose Ford Foundation and National Endowment for the Humanities seed money ran out decades ago. "But we have a higher purpose." Like bringing the observations of the Boston historian Francis Parkman out of terminal hibernation, which she calls "an important rescue." These days the budget is $7 million, with eight releases each year and annual sales of 250,000 units. It is, she says, a break-even pace, but she worries that only 40 of her titles have found sponsors. "Eight new orphans a year," she frets.
Although Ms. Hurley, 53, claims to love all her children equally, she admits to loving the early Henry James a tad more passionately. He monopolizes a dozen volumes of the black dust-jacketed series filling the built-in bookcases in her charming office (French doors, bay window) in a likewise charming 1905 Beaux-Arts building at 14 East 60th Street. Her favorite haunts, the Grolier Club and the Alliance Francaise, are nearby. Her Francophile leanings developed as contrast to the Pittsburgh suburbs where she grew up, with her nose in a book. She was thrilled that, as Wilson had hoped, the Editions de la Pleiade, a compendium of French classics, was agreed on as a model for L.O.A. She had read them while pursuing a master's degree in French at the University of Michigan.
Ms. Hurley, who lives in Manhattan and Bridgehampton with her husband, Kevin, an economist and hedge fund specialist, came to L.O.A. with zero publishing experience but ample connections after seven years at the Modern Language Association. Two decades after Wilson raised the alarm, Richard Poirer, Jason Epstein, Dan Aaron and Tom Tanselle, literary heavyweights all, accumulated $1.8 million in start-up grants, and Ms. Hurley was enlisted "to find the office space and buy the Xerox machine and all the rest."
"They did what any group of men does when they want something to happen: they hire a woman," she said. "For the first five years, we called this 'the project.' We didn't know what it would become; we just wanted to get some books out.
"By the way, please take a book when you leave," she suggests.
Old habits die hard.

HEADLINE: West Virginia Is Beset by Record Floods and Mudslides 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: MULLENS, W.Va., July 9 

 BODY:
Mud filled thousands of homes today and kept drivers stuck on mountain roads after flash floods washed through the narrow valleys of southern West Virginia, carrying off mobile homes and forcing residents to their rooftops.
 At least one person was killed in southern West Virginia as thunderstorms sped through the region on Sunday. Three people were killed in neighboring eastern Kentucky, more than two dozen families were evacuated in southwestern Virginia, and thousands lost power in West Virginia, Indiana, Ohio and North Carolina. 
 Officials said that as many as 3,000 homes had been damaged by water or mudslides and that some had been destroyed. State officials estimated damage was more than $20 million.
The police would not let anyone drive into Mullens today because so much mud filled the town after record flash flooding. Down the Guyandotte River, mud blocked the roads into the town of Pineville.
"I've been in some of these homes," said Lacy Wright Jr. "There's mud two feet thick. There's instances where they don't even know where their homes are."
Gov. Bob Wise, whose helicopter was used to lift people off roofs, declared a state of emergency in eight counties.
Flooding after heavy rain is routine in the region. Most homes, roads and railroad tracks are squeezed together along creeks and rivers at the bottom of narrow valleys.
Nearly eight inches of rain fell at Mullens, 55 miles south of Charleston, the National Weather Service said.
The Guyandotte peaked on Sunday at 18 feet in Pineville, passing the 1997 record of 17.7 feet. A flood gauge in Welch quit working when the Tug Fork River hit 17.8 feet, more than 4 feet above flood stage, the weather service said. 
The United States Geologic Survey said flooding on parts of the Guyandotte exceeded the 100-year flood level, the estimated maximum expected in such a period.
"It's never happened here like this," said Bill Wade, who is 82. "I saw a school bus completely covered in water. I saw a casket floating down the street. I saw motor homes and mobile homes floating in front of me."
Repeated storms from May 15 to June 11 caused millions of dollars in damage. Sixteen counties were eligible for federal disaster assistance from that flooding, including most of those flooded again on Sunday.
"I might leave now," said Doug Acord, 47, in Corinne, where the Guyandotte River normally is around 6 inches deep but ran about 20 feet deep on Sunday. "We just cleaned up a couple of months ago and now this is worse. I'm getting tired of this."
The region's employment and population have plunged in the past 10 years, partly because new machinery has meant fewer people are needed to work in the coal mines that dominate the economy.
Wyoming County has lost 11 percent of its population since 1990 and now has 25,708 residents, according to the last census. McDowell County has lost 22 percent. McDowell's unemployment rate was 7.9 percent in May and Wyoming's was 6.4 percent, compared to a state rate of 5.1 percent. Many of those who remain in the area are elderly.
In the McDowell County town of Kimball, stores were covered with mud, windows were broken and wooden fronts were caved in.
"We're just completely in shock. This whole town is gone," said Donna Gianato, 36, who operates Gianato Hardware with her husband.
Asked if his town would rebuild, Mayor Jack Premo of Kimball said: "I would put a big question mark beside that."

HEADLINE: Decaying Depots On the Tracks to Freedom; 
New Interest in the Underground Railroad Inspires an Effort to Preserve Its Landmarks

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

DATELINE: BUFFALO 

 BODY:
In a bathroom stall in the basement of the oldest black church here, Bishop William Henderson pulls away a framed poster and pokes his head into a dank, musty hole, revealing a crawl space. He breathes in the air and pulls out the history.
 "The slaves they brought in here were the weakest," the bishop said, beginning a walk though the Underground Railroad past of the Michigan Street Baptist Church. "They would hide them from the bounty hunters here. There was a false wall here they could remove. They would feed them and clothe them. I can still feel the spirit of the whole thing. I can still feel it." 
 Like many of the remaining vestiges of the Underground Railroad, a clandestine network of safe houses and trails that helped slaves flee the South before the Civil War, the church is awash in history and one step away from ruin. It has a sagging roof that is a heavy snowfall away from collapse, a crumbling facade and a dwindling congregation of 25 people who are struggling to raise the $2.5 million needed for a renovation. 
Now, after more than a decade of quiet progress by dozens of historians and researchers in identifying and verifying sites on the Underground Railroad, efforts are under way to save dozens of the sites, many of them, like the church, on the brink of being lost forever. What is not clear is how much money can be raised to save dozens of old buildings with a dramatic history that are, for the most part, modest, decaying structures.
The interest extends beyond New York, where 69 potential sites have been identified, to other states that played pivotal roles in the Underground Railroad, mostly in the North or along the Mason-Dixon line. The National Park Service has been at work for a decade on a project to determine the authenticity of sites. Last month it released a list of the first 10 that will be officially designated on a national "Network to Freedom" roster. 
Tours of locations have begun, and commissions are studying what to do with the sites, including the possibility of promoting them as tourist attractions.
In Cincinnati, the National Underground Railroad Freedom Center, a $102 million museum, is scheduled to open in 2004.
"The Underground Railroad seems to incite the imagination of people of all races," said Charles Blockson, a Temple University historian who traces his interest in the subject to his grandfather's singing of spirituals depicting the flight of slaves. "It was a clandestine organization, and it conjures up images of soft knocks on doors, whispers, trapdoors. It rivals anything in a book by Agatha Christie or in James Bond. It has intrigue, suspense, heroes of all races. It is what I call an American epic to rival the civil rights movement."
Much of the effort is at the grass roots. Kevin E. Cottrell, an amateur historian and preservationist, is leading the effort to repair Michigan Street Baptist Church and make it the crown jewel in a revitalized African-American historic district. 
Residents of Fulton are rallying to save a house, scheduled for demolition, that once belonged to a noted abolitionist. Just before an old Syracuse church building was sold for conversion to a restaurant, conservators painstakingly cut out sculptures from a basement wall that are thought to be the work of escaping slaves who hid there. 
And in April, the city of Peekskill removed an abandoned building from the auction block after discovering evidence that it was a safe house for escaping slaves in the early 19th century. Community activists hope to make it a museum.
The very secrecy of the Underground Railroad -- slaves and those helping them risked prison or death if caught -- has proven an impediment to documenting or corroborating the history of some locations. Myth and legend are mixed with truth and reality; ties to the Underground Railroad are claimed for many an old farmhouse.
But little by little, historians both academic and amateur have made headway in the past decade in buttressing oral history passed down for generations, with diary entries, old newspaper accounts and letters found in historical and church archives.
"This interest is being generated by the public; we scholars are chasing this train to catch up," said Judy Wellman, a historian at the State University of New York College at Oswego. She has been active in researching and preserving sites, including the house scheduled to be torn down in Fulton, which once belonged to the abolitionist Charles Case.
One site on the National Park Service list is Murphy Orchards near Buffalo. It is a financially struggling apple farm, but on it is a barn with a subterranean room that historians believe harbored escaping slaves.
"I would hope that the prestige and credibility offered by being part of the Network to Freedom would inspire the community to do something to preserve what is here," said Carol Murphy, the owner of the farm, who allows Mr. Cottrell to conduct re-enactments of a slave hunt on it.
A New York State commission began work two years ago to establish a "freedom trail" of sites -- it is examining 69 so far -- related to the Underground Railroad and early African-American history in the state. The trail would include markers at key sites, and commission members hope that they would be promoted as tourist stops. The commission is also writing a fourth-grade curriculum on the Underground Railroad for use in schools.
(The New Jersey Historical Commission expects to issue a report this summer on Underground Railroad sites, and on efforts to preserve them.)
Separately, Assemblyman Arthur O. Eve, a Buffalo Democrat, has tried for the past few years to have Harriet Tubman honored by having the date of her death, March 10, designated a state holiday. Tubman, called the "Moses of her people" for her rescue of hundreds of slaves, lived in Auburn and is buried there; the black church that owns her farm there is seeking to raise $1.8 million to refurbish the buildings. The latest state holiday measure has passed in the Assembly and is awaiting action in the Senate, which has rejected previous measures.
Scholars say the renewed interest in the Underground Railroad can be traced to the civil rights movement, and to the subsequent burst in interest in African-American genealogy and history and in the Civil War era. At the same time, many communities are researching local history as part of a boom in heritage tourism.
Monroe Fordham, a history professor at Buffalo State College and editor of the journal Afro-Americans in New York Life and History, said he saw the interest in the Underground Railroad as an outgrowth of "the community or public history movement of the past three or four decades."
It has, he said, "helped to shift our attention to the histories of ordinary people, and heretofore overlooked groups and topics. That phenomenon has helped to make social history and related topics more attractive -- hence more attention to topics like reform movements, histories of women, ethnic groups, etc."
But preserving such history is still largely the province of local historical and preservation societies and grass-roots campaigners who are often short of cash. Gov. George E. Pataki recently announced that $1 million would go toward preserving historical sites, but people involved in restoration efforts say millions more would be needed to rehabilitate decrepit buildings and turn at least some into museums.
There have been some close calls. A few years ago, Douglas V. Armstrong, an archaeologist at the Maxwell School of Syracuse University, got a call about some interesting sculptures a developer planned to tear out of a basement wall in the Wesleyan Methodist Church building, which was being renovated. 
Mr. Armstrong found seven crude clay sculptures, depicting faces, etched onto the walls; historians, noting the abolitionist activity of the Syracuse church, surmised that they were made by escaping slaves. 
"Nobody has ever seen anything like it," Mr. Armstrong said. He added that the sculptures were removed two years ago for display at the Onondaga Historical Association. 
With the renewed interest has come some tension over how such a heritage should be honored. Preservationists and grass-roots historians, who have sought to preserve and restore original sites on shoestring budgets, sneer at such things as the money going to the Freedom Center, which endured some controversy for removing a slave pen from a Kentucky farm for its exhibition hall. 
The congregation at the Michigan Street church chafed at early plans to locate a museum in the basement, going so far as returning a state grant that was to have been used to help repair the church.
"I think the congregation felt things were slipping out of our hands," Bishop Henderson said. "Even though it is a historical landmark, we want to maintain it as a place of worship."
Bishop Henderson said the church eventually came around after plans for the basement museum were dropped. 
Many preservationists think that the key to ensuring the survival of treasured sites, particularly in economically depressed upstate cities, is to promote heritage tourism, which could bring fresh attention to long-overlooked history and help pay for the sites' upkeep.
Mr. Cottrell, who wears period dress and conducts tours of Underground Railroad sites, is a leader in the drive to recognize the Michigan Street church and other sites in New York. "A lot of these places are not on the beaten path," he said. "They don't have a docent. They don't have a gift shop. So the tourist bureaus say they are not marketable."
Some Underground Railroad sites, including the Michigan Street church, have landed on the National Register of Historic Places, making demolition difficult, if not impossible. The designation, however, does not ensure the sites will be well maintained or actively promoted.
Bishop Henderson, who opens Michigan Street Baptist for scheduled visits, said the church would be satisfied as long as the building is shored up and kept as a church.
"We don't want to see it collapse," he said. "It's vital. It's a living memorial. And it's a church."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-8

Pinochet Unfit for Trial, A Chilean Court Rules
An appeals court ruled that Gen. Augusto Pinochet, 85, is mentally unfit to stand trial on charges that he covered up the killings of political opponents by a death squad shortly after he seized power in Chile in 1973. Human rights lawyers plan to appeal. A1

Colombian Rebels Criticized
Human Rights Watch said the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, the largest rebel group, regularly violated noncombatants' rights by attacking civilians, kidnapping for ransom and recruiting children. A4

Mexico Pressed on Torture
Amnesty International, in a report to be published today, will urge President Vicente Fox to fulfill his promises to end the use of torture and the concocting of confessions by the police, and it will ask him to review cases it cites as prominent victims of trumped-up political charges. A4

Japan Firm on Textbooks
The government said it would order no further revisions of textbooks that many critics say whitewash Japan's record of imperial-era atrocities in East Asia. There were immediate protests in China and South Korea. A3

Indonesian Leader's Threat
President Abdurrahman Wahid said he would declare a state of emergency and call new elections unless Parliament dropped plans to begin proceedings to remove him from office. A8

Palestinian Homes Destroyed
Israeli crews demolished 14 homes at the edge of a Palestinian refugee camp in East Jerusalem. Mayor Ehud Olmert said the structures had been built without permits. A8

U.S. Rebuff on Small-Arms Pact
The Bush administration warned that it would not join a pact to curtail the international flow of illegal small arms if it infringed on the American right to own guns. A8

NATIONAL A10-16

Pentagon to Seek Funds To Test Missile Defense
The Pentagon is preparing to ask Congress for money to build a missile defense test site in Alaska that could also become the command center for a working antimissile system as early as 2004, military officials said. If it became operational, the site would violate the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. A1

Caution on Soft-Money Bill
Sponsors of legislation to rewrite campaign finance laws said they were uncertain that they could hold together a House coalition to pass a ban on unlimited, unregulated political donations. Debate begins today. A1

Bush Appeal on Patients' Bill
President Bush urged Congress to pass a patients' rights bill that addressed his concern for limiting lawsuits, portraying himself as a proponent of -- not an obstacle to -- legislation most Americans support. A14

California Power Talks Fail
A federal mediator ended two weeks of negotiations about California's demands for electricity refunds, with the state and power suppliers seemingly no closer to a settlement than when the talks began. The talks' failure shifts the burden of resolving the yearlong dispute to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. A14

Urban Economic Engines
The vast majority of jobs and economic wealth created in the United States in the past decade were generated within metropolitan areas, an analysis for the nation's mayors shows. Were the New York metropolitan area a country, its $437.8 billion economy would rank 14th in the world, just behind South Korea, but ahead of Australia and Taiwan. A10

Hearing for Ex-Klansman
A judge in Birmingham, Ala., confronted with conflicting psychiatric evaluations, began hearing evidence on whether Bobby Frank Cherry, 71, a former Ku Klux Klansman, is competent to stand trial as the final defendant in the 1963 church bombing that killed four black girls. A14

NEW YORK/REGION B1-6

Staten Island Power Plant Can Operate, Judge Rules
A state judge in Staten Island refused to halt operation of a new minipower plant in the borough, ensuring that the generator and nine others central to a Pataki administration plan to avoid summer blackouts in New York City would be used, at least for now. A state appeals court is still to rule on whether the New York Power Authority skirted its own requirements in building the plants. B1

Medical License Regained
Dr. Steven J. Bier, the owner of a Bronx radiology clinic who was accused of failing to diagnose breast cancer because of faulty tests, regained his license in a settlement of state charges, but he must undergo retraining before practicing mammography again. Retesting has found cancer in 25 of his patients. B3

HEADLINE: A Ravaged Musical Prodigy At a Crossroads With Drugs 

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
The judge in State Supreme Court in Manhattan stared sternly through her glasses at the defendant, whose body trembled. "You have been around this planet for a long time, and you've been using drugs for a fairly substantial amount of time as well," she said. "What I want is for you to go and get some help with this problem."
 She was giving Gil Scott-Heron a choice. He could go into a lengthy drug rehabilitation program. Or he could go to state prison. 
 Mr. Scott-Heron, the musician, writer, spoken-word poet and activist whose politically pointed lyrics in the 1970's helped give rise to rap, reached a crossroads on July 2. After years of reports about his drug use, and after 10 days in jail, the gaunt 52-year-old pleaded guilty to felony possession of cocaine, and agreed to enter a residential treatment program in September. 
In return, Mr. Scott-Heron, the onetime prodigy whose albums full of anthems about race, economics, love and addiction have found fans across several generations, was allowed to leave the country for a European tour that was already supposed to have been under way.
That moment of courtroom reckoning has inspired dismay among friends who see him as a victim of punitive drug laws, and hope among others who want him to get help, but little surprise. Mr. Scott-Heron has always denied having a drug habit, and continues to do so, adamantly. "Most of the people who comment, I've never smoked a joint with," he said. But friends, relatives, fans and professional associates have concluded differently. Cocaine, they believe, particularly crack cocaine, has had him in its grip for years.
His body, if nothing else, would seem to give him away. His cheeks are sunken, many of his teeth gone, his physique emaciated, his deep, rumbling voice sometimes slurring into unintelligibility. A reviewer described him as "a raggedy old man." A fan wrote on the Internet last week: "Life, and the elements within, has beat the brother down pretty bad, as many of you who have seen him perform recently will attest."
Mr. Scott-Heron is certainly not the only famous person to battle addiction, or even the best known. His case, like that of Robert Downey Jr. or Darryl Strawberry, shows how fame adds an excruciating public cast to private disintegration, but also how it can insulate a person against the worst consequences of his habit. Drug user or not, Mr. Scott-Heron is still a profitable commodity to many people, whether promoters, publishers or band mates, who know that to confront him about his drug use could mean losing his favor.
Mr. Scott-Heron said in an interview last week: "The people who have the most access to me -- people who I've played music with for 20 years -- the fact that they're still around, either they have the I.Q. of a plant or I don't have a problem." He pleaded guilty, he said, only because he had to keep his tour commitments: "I had to say what I had to say to go where I needed to go."
When he began his career with an explosive brilliance, there was no hint that a judge would be deciding his fate 30 years on. Born in Chicago, raised in Tennessee and New York, he won a scholarship through his writing to the prestigious Fieldston School in the Bronx. He went on to Lincoln University in Pennsylvania, and at 19, wrote his first novel. At 21, he released his first album, which included the iconic "The Revolution Will Not Be Televised." He was, wrote Nat Hentoff, the columnist, a "protean phenomenon."
He set angrily political poems about black pain and what he regarded as American hypocrisy to funk. He wrote of the race into space in "Whitey on the Moon":
A rat done bit my sister Nell.
(with Whitey on the moon)
Her face and arms began to swell.
(and Whitey's on the moon)
I can't pay no doctor bill.
(but Whitey's on the moon) . . . 
He penned lyrics about Watergate, illegal immigrants, and, in one of his biggest hits, "Johannesburg," apartheid. He rapped about Ronald Reagan in "Re-Ron."
And he empathetically addressed addiction's cost and chokehold. "You keep sayin' kick it, quit it, kick it quit it! God, did you ever try to turn your sick soul inside out so that the world could watch you die?" he wrote in "Home Is Where the Hatred Is."
People said hearing his music changed their lives. In 1975, he was the first artist signed to the Arista label, where he made 11 albums. He was seen as a legend in the making.
Today, although rappers like Chuck D of Public Enemy cite his early work as a major influence, he is seen as someone who did not make it as far as his talent merited. Many artists become less productive or reliable over time even without drugs, and many struggle with record labels, as Mr. Scott-Heron has. (He was abruptly dropped by Arista in 1985.)
But it seems likely that some of his promise was squandered through drugs. Since 1984 he has made only one new studio album, the 1994 "Spirits." He has continued to tour regularly, and sell out shows often, but also has earned a reputation for failing to show up for concerts. And he has been arrested on drug charges in England, Canada and Australia as well as New York.
"Has anyone seen Gil Scott-Heron?" one fan wrote on the Internet after Mr. Scott-Heron did not appear for a performance.
Another fan wrote, "This happens a lot when Gil is supposed to play," adding, "Go and see him before it's too late."
Still, Mr. Scott-Heron has maintained enough function, including writing a nonfiction manuscript that he says is 800 pages, to cite it as evidence that he is not a regular drug user. "It's hard to have a habit when you're working all the time," he said at the apartment in a drug-infested part of Harlem where he lives.
Prickly when the subject of drugs arises, he is otherwise charming and funny. An avid sports fan, he said of the Mets, "I think they're having a worse year than I am."
To his younger half brother, Denis Heron, that ability to get by is the problem. "I guess we were hoping he would hit bottom, and we could jump in," Mr. Heron said. "But he's a survivor. He's learned how to hover right above crashing."
The challenge that his situation has posed for his family, friends and the criminal justice system is whether, and how, to force help on someone who denies that he needs it.
"I sort of lost interest," said Mr. Heron, who barely sees his brother anymore, adding that he saw nothing to do "short of grabbing him and throwing him in a room and saying, 'One of us isn't walking out until we're both sober.' "
In the end, Justice Carol Berkman of State Supreme Court did resort to coercion -- threatening prison to force treatment.
"He didn't want to do this, he had to be pushed," said Mr. Scott-Heron's Legal Aid lawyer, Robert Kitson. "He had to be put in jail and threatened with the end of his tour before he went into rehab."
Outside the courtroom, the person pushing the hardest has been Mr. Scott-Heron's former girlfriend Monique de Latour. She has confronted his band mates for their failure to act. She has urged promoters not to book him, saying that supplying him with cash supported his habit. She has pressed prosecutors to put him in treatment. And on July 2, she faxed Justice Berkman a letter arguing for rehabilitation, not prison.
Many of Mr. Scott-Heron's friends see her as a woman scorned venting her fury. They say that she is trying to ruin his life, and that she has betrayed him by publicly discussing his drug use and helping ensnare him in the criminal justice system.
Ms. de Latour is "vicious and malicious," said Alistair Abrahams, Mr. Scott-Heron's manager in Europe, who was busy last week trying to reassemble the pieces of a tour. Mr. Scott-Heron said he had not seen Ms. de Latour in 18 months, and called her a "very unhappy woman."
Ms. de Latour, an artist whom Mr. Scott-Heron met in Australia in 1995, is undeterred. "If they want to blame me, that's fine, if it's going to get Gil some help," she said. His band mates "think he needs to be on stage, whatever it takes," she said. "My point is, he may drop dead next week, and then you won't have anyone to be on stage."
His band mates talk not about drugs, but about Mr. Scott-Heron's generosity. Larry McDonald, who plays in Mr. Scott-Heron's band, Amnesia Express, said, "No matter how people perceive someone with problems like this, he is one of the nicest people I've ever been around, and probably the closest I've come to working with true genius."
Mr. Scott-Heron's case poses a question: does friendship mean helping someone to live as he wishes or forcing him to live as he should? Some friends see drug use as a personal choice. "I think someone should be free to do to themselves what they wish," said Jamie Byng, publisher of Canongate Books, which is reissuing Mr. Scott-Heron's novels and poems in the United States. He blamed "the absurd war on drugs" for Mr. Scott-Heron's plight.
Mr. Scott-Heron's lawyer agreed, pointing out that his client now has a felony on his record for possessing 1.2 grams of cocaine.
Mr. Byng did say that he has so worried over Mr. Scott-Heron's health over the years that he feared getting a call saying he was dead. But, he and others said, it was not their problem to solve.
"I didn't realize that playing God was something I was supposed to do," said Larry Gold, the owner of S.O.B.'s, the club in Manhattan where Mr. Scott-Heron often plays.
Some argue that there has always been a connection between drugs and art. And some wonder how sobriety would affect Mr. Scott-Heron. "There's certainly the possibility that when somebody sobers up they're not as vital, not as creative, not as charismatic," said Anuj Desai, editor of Black Book magazine, which published a rhyming piece by Mr. Scott-Heron this month.
It is hard to assess Mr. Scott-Heron's creativity now, because so little of it has been made public of late. The manuscript of his latest book, "The Last Holiday," which he has been working on for at least eight years, has just been delivered to his publisher. It is his extended riff on a tour with Stevie Wonder in the early 1980's to help make the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday a national holiday.
The success of an 18-to-24-month rehabilitation program, the length the judge suggested, is hard to predict. Long-term treatment is considered the most effective, but coerced treatment has yielded mixed results.
Last week, Mr. Scott-Heron, overjoyed to be free, and free to tour, seemed unconcerned. In September, he said, he would try to convince the judge that she had been wrong about him. If not, he would agree to her conditions -- rehab or prison.
Asked if he had ever been in a program before, he replied, "I was on 'Saturday Night Live.' "

HEADLINE: Layoffs Planned By The Journal 

 BODY:
The Wall Street Journal is laying off 16 journalists from its staff of 636, most of them connected to the specialized coverage of small business and entrepreneurship, according to Steven Goldstein, a spokesman for Dow Jones & Company.
 The layoffs come as the newspaper, like the industry, continues to lose advertising; ad linage in The Journal through May is down 34 percent, compared with the first five months of 2000 -- a period that was near the peak of the advertising boom. 
 In a memo informing his staff of the layoffs, The Journal's managing editor, Paul E. Steiger, wrote that despite the layoffs, "We will aggressively pursue stories on small business from a wide range of beats and perspectives. We will continue regular weekly reports on economic and regulatory developments and trends affecting entrepreneurs and entrepreneurship. . . ."
Among those laid off were three editors and 12 reporters, three of these in New York and six others in national bureaus, including San Francisco, Chicago, Atlanta, Pittsburgh, Washington and Orlando.
Last fall, The Journal closed its four regional editions and laid off 20 people.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Autodesk Is Planning to Reacquire Its Spinoff, Buzzsaw.com

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 

 BODY:
Plucking its former spinoff from the shark-infested waters of Internet start-ups, Autodesk Inc. on Tuesday intends to announce that it will reacquire Buzzsaw.com, a provider of Internet services to help manage construction projects. The move comes less than two years after Autodesk sent the company out on its own.
 Autodesk, which makes software used in computer-assisted design work, said it would spend $15 million to buy the 60 percent of Buzzsaw shares it does not already own. The company said the acquisition would allow Autodesk to add as customers not only designers, but also the construction managers and workers who use designs. 
 The acquisition ends Buzzsaw's pursuit of an initial public offering. Autodesk, which had invested $22.5 million in Buzzsaw since spinning it off in November 1999, said the struggling capital market made it more sensible to buy Buzzsaw than to keep financing it.
"Autodesk has rescued its errant child," said David Metcalfe, an analyst with Forrester Research.
The acquisition is expected to close in August. Autodesk, which has a market capitalization of $1.82 billion, said it will not take a charge. In fact, the company increased its earnings forecast for the current quarter, saying that it no longer has to complete another planned investment in Buzzsaw.
Carol Bartz, chief executive and president of Autodesk, said she expected the company to report earnings of 44 to 54 cents a share, a 4 cent increase from her previous forecast.
Autodesk shares gained $1.06, or 3.1 percent, to close at $34.86. 
Buzzsaw's software allows construction companies to exchange documents over the Internet and to share those documents with subcontractors and architects, saving time and courier fees. It was financed by Crosspoint Venture Partners, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Banc of America Securities and Impact Venture Partners.
Executives from the two companies said they entered the dot-com feeding frenzy to test Buzzsaw's business model and possibly land a lucrative initial public offering. Autodesk's headquarters are in San Rafael, Calif., a small city on the edge of Silicon Valley, but Buzzsaw set itself up in the heart of San Francisco.
"We did that on purpose, to put them right in the middle of dot-com mania and let them go," Ms. Bartz said. "The whole idea was to say: 'You are a different kind of company. You live and die by those rules.' "
Though Autodesk managed to survive by those rules, reporting sales of $5.3 million in its first year, the game around it changed. The well of money for public offerings dried up. But the executives said Buzzsaw is making strong headway, winning contracts to manage such large construction projects as the 110,000-square-foot Toys "R" Us scheduled to open in Times Square in September.
Carl Bass, chief executive of Buzzsaw, said the site has 125,000 users, who transfer as many as 75,000 files a day for construction projects.
"I'm more convinced than I was even two years ago that this is the model by which people will be exchanging documents, in this industry and others," said Mr. Bass, who will become an executive vice president when the acquisition is completed.
But the construction industry is adopting the changes much more slowly than many venture capitalists would like, said Mr. Metcalfe, the analyst. Financial expectations for technology companies exceeded the industry's willingness to adopt those technologies.
"They just threw too much in way too early and didn't let them form naturally," Mr. Metcalfe said.
Ms. Bartz said some potential customers had been scared away by concerns that Buzzsaw would close shop. The acquisition will allow Buzzsaw to use Autodesk's international sales force and more closely integrate its software with Autodesk's, she said. 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 11, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the plans of Autodesk Inc. to reacquire Buzzsaw.com, a provider of Internet services, misstated which company reported sales of $5.3 million in its first year. It was Buzzsaw, not Autodesk.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Online Grocer Calls It Quits After Running Out of Money
Webvan, the online grocer that epitomized the buoyant optimism that the Internet could revolutionize even the most entrenched industries, closed and will seek bankruptcy protection.
 Webvan ran out of money before it could hope to turn a profit, burning through nearly all of the $1.2 billion put up by investors. Its search for a buyer or source of additional cash was fruitless. Page A1. 

Autodesk to Buy Back Buzzsaw.com
Autodesk intends to announce today that it will reacquire Buzzsaw.com, a provider of Internet services to help manage construction projects, less than two years after sending the company out on its own. Autodesk will spend $15 million to buy the 60 percent of Buzzsaw shares it does not already own. Its shares gained $1.06, to $34.86. C9.

Mars Is Expected to Buy Royal Canin
Mars, the pet food and candy company, is expected to announce today that it is buying part of Royal Canin, the French pet food maker, according to executives close to the deal. C7.

Aventis Ready to Sell CropScience
Aventis has entered into exclusive negotiations to sell its agrochemicals business to Bayer for $3.4 billion plus the assumption of $1.7 billion in debt. Obstacles complicate such a deal, including the fact that Schering owns 24 percent of the unit, called CropScience. C11.

Survey About Accountability Online
The first major study of public attitudes about accountability online, to be released today by the Markle Foundation, found that Americans would like to have significantly more input into the rules that govern the Internet. The report found that 63 percent of American adults go online, up from 39 percent in 1998. C9.

Key Stock Gauges Gain Modestly
Stocks gained modestly because of bargain hunting and news of an unsolicited bid for AT&T's cable TV business. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 46.72 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,299.40. The Nasdaq composite index rose 22.55 points, or 1.1 percent, to 2,026.71, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 8.19 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,198.78. C11.

It's About Timing for Ad Campaign
As interest in trading stocks is waning, Brokerage America, a new online brokerage firm, has started a $7 million advertising campaign. The timing of the campaign, by a New York agency named Dirty Water Integrated, is either as smart as selling the Nasdaq short when it reached 5,000 or as foolish as buying shares of Pets.com as they kept falling. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C6.

I.M.F. Warning on Asian Recovery
Stanley Fischer, a senior official for the International Monetary Fund, warned that the structural reforms demanded by Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan could undermine long-term regional efforts to recover from the economic crisis of 1997 and 1998. World Business, Section W.

Consumers Slow Pace of Borrowing
Consumer credit rose a seasonally adjusted $6.5 billion in May -- a 4.9 percent annual rate, the Federal Reserve reported, much less than expected. Consumers, worried about their jobs in the face of layoffs, borrowed money at the slowest pace in the last 19 months. C7.

Cutbacks for Corning and Alcatel
Corning and Alcatel, which had flourished in recent years making the building blocks of the communications industry, announced severe cutbacks, including plant closings and new layoffs totaling 3,500 workers. Corning also suspended dividend payments. C9.

Cathay Pacific Fires 49 Pilots
A labor dispute abruptly escalated in Hong Kong as Cathay Pacific Airways dismissed 49 pilots a week after the pilots' union began a work slowdown against the carrier. World Business, Section W.
