HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs; 
Policy by Obituary

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Let's do a quick test. I'll mention a name and you tell me what comes to mind. Ready? Secretary of State Colin Powell . . . Quick -- what comes to mind? Well, actually nothing.
 Now the fact that Mr. Powell's tenure so far doesn't conjure up anything doesn't make him a failure as secretary of state. It's way, way too early for such judgments. Sometimes the best policies involve doing nothing, because there's nothing to be done. But there are two basic ways to do nothing. One is to rely on biology, the other is to rely on creative diplomacy, and for now the Bush foreign policy is more biology than diplomacy. 
 A biological foreign policy means that you have run out of ideas or political room to maneuver for how to deal with a certain foreign leader, so your whole approach is waiting for that leader to die. Biology!
The most obvious case of biology in U.S. foreign policy today is Cuba, where nine U.S. presidents have been boycotting the country and waiting for Fidel Castro to die. But the fact is, the Bush foreign policy is also to wait for Saddam Hussein, Yasir Arafat and Kim Jong Il, the leader of North Korea, to die and be replaced by more pragmatic figures.
One problem with a biological foreign policy is that bad guys can live long: Mr. Castro is said to have given up smoking cigars and is eating yogurt; Mr. Arafat takes regular naps and puts only honey on his cereal. Another problem with biology as foreign policy is that it enables these leaders to divert attention easily from their actions to ours. So the U.S. is blamed for starvation in Iraq, lack of development in Cuba or the breakdown of Israeli-Palestinian peace. 
If the Bush team prefers to do nothing in certain places, let's at least do nothing creatively, so the pressures are on the rogues, not us.
On Iraq, let's stop messing around with "smart sanctions" designed to let more goods into Iraq while weeding out military items. The states surrounding Iraq that would have to impose such smart sanctions have no economic incentive to do so. And the Arab world wouldn't give America any more credit for smart sanctions than dumb ones. It's a half-measure. If we're not going to go to war against Saddam, let's at least put a serious offer on the table that puts all the focus on him: let's offer Iraq full diplomatic relations with the U.S. in return for full intrusive U.S. inspections of Iraq's weapons facilities.
The real issue is weapons inspections, and it has gotten totally and dangerously lost. If we are just going to wait for Saddam to die, let's at least create a context in which all the world sees that it is his insistence on developing and hoarding weapons of mass destruction that is the problem.
On the Arab-Israel front, a great power like the U.S. does not belong arranging cease-fires. This has allowed Mr. Arafat to turn everyone's attention away from the fact that he rejected a peace plan put forward by the Clintonites that offered Palestinians 95 percent of what they wanted. The Bushies should say to Mr. Arafat that the U.S. will get re-engaged if he accepts the Clinton plan, or a Bush adaptation of it. The focus should not be on whether Mr. Powell is serious about mediating but on whether Mr. Arafat is serious about a deal.
On Cuba, we should long ago have lifted the embargo so Cubans could see that the reason their economy is so backward is not because of the U.S. blockade but because of Mr. Castro's idiotic Marxism. On North Korea, the Bushies have raised the bar so high in their talks with Kim Jong Il -- to restrict his missile production -- that it appears they don't really want a deal and are just waiting for him to die. Mr. Kim can export a lot of missiles while we wait for him to die. 
The one area where the U.S. did not rely on biology -- but on force, incentives and creative diplomacy -- was in Serbia. There we created a context where all the focus was on whether the Serbian people would allow Slobodan Milosevic to be their leader. Slobo wanted to make us the issue, and we made him the issue.
The U.S. can't choose the leaders of Cuba, Serbia, North Korea, Iraq or Palestine, but we can do more than wait for them to die. We can create a context that puts greater pressure on these leaders to make better choices, a context that puts all the blame on them, not us, if they don't and a context that may not solve any of these problems but at least strengthens us with our allies and the people in these countries.

HEADLINE: Effects of the Tax Cut 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Missing from Paul Krugman's assessment of the budget predicament produced by President Bush's oversize tax cut (column, July 6) is the impact of the impending shortfall on average, struggling Americans.
 Disproportionately, Americans with disabilities (about one-fifth of the population) are below the poverty line, are not working, lack adequate health insurance and are the first to feel the impact of economic downturns because we tend to rely heavily on government spending to survive. 
 As Congress and the administration get out their budget-cutting axes, we see the likely impact: more homeless people on the streets, Social Security privatization proposals that will lower monthly benefit checks, draconian welfare reform proposals and inadequate federal support for critical investments like special education, affordable housing, accessible transportation, assistive technology, vocational rehabilitation and home and community-based long-term care. 

ANDREW J. IMPARATO
President, American Association
of People With Disabilities
Washington, July 6, 2001

HEADLINE: If Comcast Buys AT&T Cable, Efficiency Is Likely to Improve 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
AT&T cable subscribers would probably see a more efficient operation if Comcast acquires AT&T's cable operation, analysts said yesterday. But those efficiencies might not translate into lower prices or enhanced programming.
 The combination would create the nation's largest cable-television outfit, reaching about 22 million subscribers. The companies now have little geographic overlap. Comcast is strong in the mid-Atlantic region, while AT&T's cable operations are spread across the country, with a big presence in cities like Denver and Dallas. 
 Comcast is considered to be at the technological forefront of the cable industry and is expected to bring the other service in line if the deal is done. AT&T has been criticized for failing to bring the cable systems it acquired from companies like Media One and TCI up to the same level as competitors. 
In an interview yesterday, Comcast's president, Brian Roberts, emphasized his company's operating margins and its long history in the cable business.
"Consumers will benefit from a golden age of new products we'll introduce, from video on demand to television commerce," Mr. Roberts said.
AT&T's investors welcomed the offer, pushing the stock up nearly 12 percent, while Comcast's stock fell 7 percent on concerns about the price tag -- $44.5 billion plus the assumption of $13.5 billion in debt.
Some analysts expect that a larger Comcast will have greater economies of scale, enabling it to purchase equipment and services at lower prices.
In theory, these price efficiencies could be passed to consumers. Consumers could also gain access to a wider variety of programming, albeit it at Comcast's choosing, and find problems like billing discrepancies kept to a minimum.
But the real impact is anything but clear. Comcast could wield considerable influence over the cable-television industry on matters like operating software, set-top boxes and, especially, programming. 
Comcast, which controls most of the rights to programming from Philadelphia's sports teams, has used political influence and legal arguments to keep competitors at arm's length there, according to Jeff Chester of the Center for Digital Democracy in Washington. 
When satellite broadcasters sought to enter the Philadelphia market, Comcast refused to provide them with broadcasting rights for local sports games, citing a law that prohibits such programming from being transmitted by satellite, said Pantelis Michalopoulos, a lawyer who represented EchoStar, one of the satellite companies affected.
"If a behemoth controlling 30 percent of the cable market is created, the impact on consumers would be severe," Mr. Michalopoulos said.
A person close to Comcast's dealings in Philadelphia said the company's commitment to wire every home, in poor as well as rich neighborhoods, helped to influence city officials in their decisions to limit competitors' access. And Comcast's dealings with satellite companies in Philadelphia is limited to that city, the person said, citing agreements to provide programming to satellite broadcasters in other cities.
Some analysts expect consumers will wind up paying more.
"As in other big deals, consumers will pay for the premium Comcast is offering to buy AT&T Broadband," Mr. Chester warned. "Who else will foot the bill?"

HEADLINE: Bush Seems to Ease His Stance On the Accountability of Schools 

BYLINE:  By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9 

 BODY:
With a joint committee yet to tackle differences in the House and Senate education bills requiring annual nationwide testing of public school students, the White House appears to be favoring the Senate's weaker demands for state accountability for educating poor, black and Hispanic children. 
 As governor of Texas and candidate for president, George W. Bush touted his success in raising educational achievement for all groups of students in Texas. A key to that effort was the state's practice of not only reporting test scores by race, ethnicity and poverty level, but also penalizing schools in which initially one quarter, and eventually half, of all students in each subgroup did not reach proficiency. 
 The House education bill adopted Texas's insistence on mastery of the basics of reading and writing by all groups. It leaves states to define the minimum that children need to know, but outdoes Texas in toughness by requiring all children in each subgroup to reach mastery in a dozen years, a goal the White House now deems impossible. 
A Senate version of the education bill, which the White House favors, backs away from such strict accountability. It allows states to report achievement as an average of the scores among all groups, weighting for some groups of students more than others. Critics contend that the Senate version would allow states to avoid penalties if, say, middle-class white students do very well while minority children lag far behind. 
Sandy Kress, the White House's educational adviser, denied that Mr. Bush had moderated his stand on the importance of reporting test scores by racial and economic groups.
"The president did believe and still does believe that data should be disaggregated," Mr. Kress said. But he said the administration wanted a law that would spur improvement without labeling all schools as failures, as he contended the House bill would do.
Critics, however, accuse Mr. Bush of caving in to political pressures from states wary of the tougher standards, and they note that some 22 Republican governors face re-election battles next year.
In their broad outlines, the education bills agree on annual testing in reading and math for all children in grades three to eight, and on imposing penalties that could include shutting down schools that fail to educate children year after year and reopening them under new leadership.
But education experts from both the right and left are warning that Washington's ability to deliver on the promise of President Bush's ambitiously named blueprint, "No Child Left Behind," will hinge on upcoming negotiations over questions initially set aside to propel the education bill's swift passage. 
They include where states should set the bar for student achievement and what kind of progress is "adequate." How much time should schools have to show improvement, particularly for poor, black and Hispanic students? Who will pay for the new testing and reporting regimes? 
With conference committee members yet to be named, the Democratic leadership in the Senate appears to be cooling its collective heels, awaiting some commitment on spending from the administration. Mr. Bush's plan increased the education budget to $19 billion from $18.3 billion, but the House is seeking $23 billion, and the Senate $31.3 billion. Some here predict nothing will leave the conference committee until after the appropriations process in September.
"It makes a lot of sense for the Democrats to just sort of let it sit," said David L. Shreve, senior committee director of the National Conference of State Legislators. 
The president, for his part, needs to start the clock ticking on school accountability if he plans to show results by the 2004 elections. In an apparent bid to kick-start the conference committee's work, at a Rose Garden ceremony this morning, he urged Congress to deliver an education bill to his desk before its August recess. 
When Mr. Bush unveiled his plan in January, it spoke of tests that would measure the "adequate yearly progress" of all students, regardless of race, ethnicity or economic status. The plan continued to allow states to define proficiency, as either mastery of a given body of knowledge or as a measure of a child's performance relative to the average of others taking the test. But the plan said a federal test, the National Assessment of Educational Progress, would be used to confirm the state results.
Under the House bill, states would have 12 years to raise all students to proficiency in reading and math, and they could face cutbacks in federal aid or even school closures long before then if students are not on track to reach those goals. Under both bills, states would have to break out scores by gender and for students with limited English, as well as by ethnicity, race and poverty.
The Senate requires proficiency in 10 years, but only holds states accountable for a composite score averaging different racial, ethnic and economic groups. States may weight scores of the group showing the most progress and the one that performs worst, although the bill does not say by how much. The Senate would require each group of students to improve at least 1 percent a year -- a dubious goal, given the variability of test scores.
While the House bill specifies that states must measure proficiency in specific skills by grade level, the Senate allows states to continue using tests that measure progress in relation to the performance of other students, as a handful now do. 
Critics say the Senate's complicated formula for reporting scores and determining penalties will frustrate parents and students who could use clearer information to demand change. 
"There's more room for game-playing," said Amy T. Wilkins, education policy analyst at the Education Trust, a nonprofit group that lobbies for schools in poor districts. "Because what you have to do is meet a composite score, you could get a lot of gain from your white kids and a little gain from black and Latino kids, and still be O.K."
Ms. Wilkins said the Senate initially proposed using only a composite score, adding the 1 percent requirement -- "the absolute minimum they could come up with" -- only under pressure. "Talk about 'the soft bigotry of low expectations,' " she said, recalling a catchphrase of Mr. Bush's campaign.
Critics of the more transparent House plan, which avoids statistical manipulation by ethnicity or income, say it is politically unworkable. Surprisingly, given President Bush's initial insistence on tough accountability, those critics now include Mr. Kress.
Mr. Kress said the House's stricter standards would label most states failures. When Mr. Bush pledged as a candidate to crack down on education, he meant "true, persistently failing schools," Mr. Kress said. "He was not talking about nearly every school in America."
Mr. Kress insisted that the Senate bill was not lax. "All groups have to jump over the bar," he said. "The question is where the bar should be set."
He continued: "Do you set it at a level where the most troubled schools would be slated for serious corrective action, or have a standard that most schools across the country would fail?"
Others suggest that the White House did not want to undermine the standing of Republican governors. 
The administration, which negotiated the education legislation largely as a three-part dance with the House and Senate, now faces criticism from several quarters, and has few outside allies. The conservative Heritage Foundation called its recent analysis of the education bills "Still Leaving Children Behind." Though preferring the House to the Senate bill, the foundation considers it only slightly better than the status quo.
Krista Kafer, the author of the analysis, cited national test scores showing that more than 60 percent of poor black and Hispanic fourth-graders could not read at a basic level.
"If you can't do reading or math, your opportunity for the American dream is nonexistent," Ms. Kafer said in an interview. "And that trumps local control. It's greater than union concern about private school."
The two chambers must also decide which tests will confirm the state results and determine penalties or rewards. The Senate bill requires using the National Assessment of Educational Progress, a test that 41 states currently give to a sampling of fourth- and eighth-grade students. The House would allow this test or another, like the Stanford 9.
Critics worry that using a variety of confirming tests would hinder parents' efforts to compare their state with others. But conservatives in the House, concerned about eventually establishing a national curriculum, fought against making the National Assessment mandatory several years ago. 
A final battle looms over a provision known variously as Charter States or Straight A's. It gives states or localities unprecedented flexibility with some federal money, provided test scores do not fall short three years in a row.

HEADLINE: Sorting Out a Future After Dot-Com 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN STELLIN 

 BODY:
When Rebecca Bregman was laid off from an Internet company in March for the second time in a little over a year, she decided to put the turmoil of the technology industry behind her. 
 "Twice is enough," she said. "I didn't want to be one of those people who got laid off five times." 
 As the casualty list of defunct dot-coms grows, so does the number of workers who have collected multiple pink slips and who are concluding that it was not this job or this company that did not quite work out, it was this industry. And for them, the question of what to do next looms large. 
Although much has been written about dot-com carpetbaggers returning to the banks and law firms they left to join the Internet gold rush, for many disillusioned dot-com workers, the future involves more complicated choices. Those who joined Internet companies just out of college rarely have other careers to fall back on. Others simply find themselves at a loss, exhausted by long hours and the disappointment of being part of a boom that went bust.
For Ms. Bregman -- who was laid off from the online entertainment company Pseudo.com in February 2000, only to be given another pink slip about a year later from Conde Nast's online unit -- the short-term solution was to return to a prior career as a production coordinator for films. "Even in the Depression, people went to the movies," she reasoned. "So that's what I decided, I had to get back into film."
Since March, Ms. Bregman has been the coordinator on a Nickelodeon special and the assistant coordinator for a feature film. She says she does not especially enjoy the long days on the set or the anxiety over finding another project every few months. "But it's better than working at a dot-com," she said. "I just don't know what dot-com I'd even want to work for -- there's not a lot of sites that interest me anymore."
The disappearance of many of the industry's more entertaining sites, not to mention the culture of fun that brought beanbags and foosball tables into once-staid offices, is one of the reasons some Internet workers have decided to move on.
"It's an entirely different culture, entirely different expectations," said Ben Clemens, who left his job in August as director of information architecture at Rare Medium, a Internet consulting firm in New York, when the company shifted away from Web site design toward more technical systems integration projects. "The kind of people who do that work are not bad," he said. "They're just different."
Mr. Clemens spent several months working for an Internet company in London before returning to New York this spring. Now, he faces the challenge of mapping out a new career without a clear focus. "I'm what is rapidly becoming a cliche," he said, "the person who was doing this stuff who is not doing it anymore who really doesn't know what to do with their life."
For some, that quandary comes up even before their job actually ends, as the company's bank account heads toward zero and additional financing is uncertain.
"It sort of reminds me of the last few months of college when you realize, 'This is all ending, and I'm going to have to get a real job,' " said Garret Glaser, vice president for marketing at a start-up that makes software to run online marketplaces. He said the company has been looking for "another round of funding in an increasingly unforgiving market," which had created an atmosphere of uncertainty for employees.
If the company does not survive, Mr. Glaser said he had 10 years of experience in advertising and brand management to fall back on. But that is not necessarily his first choice. "I've kind of looked at this," he said, "as an opportunity to take a left turn and do something completely different."
But one concern is whether his recent work experience will be attractive to prospective employers, as dot-com becomes the resume equivalent of last year's bell-bottoms. "When all of a sudden it isn't trendy anymore, it looks like the wrong thing to be wearing," Mr. Glaser said. "This is kind of along the same lines. I'm sort of quick to say we're not really a dot-com."
That sort of revisionism has even spread to the Web site that once chronicled the less glamorous aspects of working for an Internet company, Netslaves.com. The site recently changed its tag line from "Horror stories of working the Web" to "Undertakers of the New Economy," partly in response to changes in the industry, said Steve Baldwin, one of the site's founders.
Mr. Baldwin described what he sees as "a kind of cocooning going on" among laid-off Internet employees as they reassess their lives, live off their severance and perhaps take a break. "You're never going to see more backpacking former dot-commers in Europe," Mr. Baldwin said. "They're trying to figure it out, clear their heads and hopefully come back with a plan."
But coming up with that plan may require making some concessions to the reality of the post-new economy, which has reintroduced the workplace trade-off between making a lot of money and having a job that could be described as fun.
"Even though a lot of companies have been downsized, in a lot of cases egos have not been," said Bonnie Halper, founder of the recruiting company SendResume.com. Ms. Halper, who primarily recruits for Internet and technology companies, said many laid-off Internet workers had not adjusted their expectations to the market.
"I tell them to be realistic. I say, 'Listen, you have a year's experience; you're not going to go in with a V.P. title,' " she said. "They walk away disheartened; they still expect six-figure salaries."
But for those who have not yet given up on the industry, she offers some words of hope. "There are still jobs," she said. "There are actually profitable companies. It's just finding the right thing at the right time."

HEADLINE: Seoul Defends Itself Against I.M.F. Criticism 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, July 10 

 BODY:
The official charged with overseeing Korea's financial industry defended the government's record today against criticism that it unwisely pressured Korean banks to extend credit to troubled companies.
 Lee Keun Young, chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission, responded angrily to criticism from Stanley Fischer, the International Monetary Fund's second-highest official, of the government's role in approving huge loans. 
 Mr. Lee said the I.M.F. official demonstrated a "misunderstanding of the situation" when he said in a visit here Monday that the government should get out of the financial sector and "stop guaranteeing things front, right and center." 
Even though the government owns a majority stake in most banks, said Mr. Lee, "there is a clear distinction between management and ownership" and "decisions are based on the banks' own interests."
Mr. Lee's remarks put the government in the position of confronting the I.M.F., which has itself been a target of criticism since it pieced together a rescue package of $58.5 billion at the height of the Asian economic crisis in December 1997.
The issue of credit to floundering companies is important here because the economy is coping with falling exports and a declining stock market exacerbated by difficulties in the United States and Japan, Korea's largest trading partners.
In Tokyo today, Mr. Fischer, the fund's first deputy managing director, called for "a more expansionary monetary policy that would lower the value of the yen," making it easier for Japanese companies to export, bringing money into Japan and improving the economy of the region by increasing imports.
In Korea, Mr. Fischer saw "a conflict between the government as owner and the government as supervisor" of the banks. That remark appeared as a rebuke of Mr. Lee, who also serves as governor of the Financial Supervisory Service, set up in 1999 to oversee a banking system mired in nonperforming loans.
Mr. Lee, talking to journalists, said that loans to debt-ridden Hyundai companies, including Hynix Semiconductor and Hyundai Engineering and Construction, were based on "decisions by relevant banks."
He also defended the failure to sell SeoulBank, which the government took over in the economic crisis. Although the I.M.F. had set the sale of SeoulBank as a condition of its 1997 rescue plan, he said, "there is lack of interest with investors." Mr. Lee said he had granted a three-month extension to SeoulBank while it pursued what may be its final opportunity in current negotiations with Deutsche Bank.
The government would also "look for ways to sell the government stake" in other banks through a "gradual process."

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
London's Bad Boys Grow Up, and the Scene Does, Too

BYLINE:  By William Grimes 

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
IT'S easy, looking across the ocean, to see London as a distorted reflection of New York. The key industries are the same, the fashions and the slang overlap, and the dining scene, to an uncanny degree, seems to follow the same script: all boom, no bust. The pound is weak, financial markets are unsettled, but nothing seems to slow down the food economy. Restaurants keep opening, diners keep filling them, and no one can figure out how long the boom can continue, what the next food trend will be or who all these people are. 
 Nonstop activity does not equal creativity. That's true of New York, too. But London still generates a fizzy kind of excitement. It has a few surprises up its sleeve, and no shortage of interesting new restaurants. 
 When Richard and Peter Harden created their restaurant guide, Harden's, a decade ago, they reported 34 noteworthy restaurant openings -- noteworthy meaning visible enough to merit inclusion in the guide. The figure last year was 120. In recent years, openings have exceeded closings by at least two to one. (In New York, by comparison, the Zagat Survey reported 311 noteworthy openings last year and only 89 closings.) 
In sheer numbers, in other words, the culinary explosion that propelled London to the front rank of international dining cities hasn't slacked off since the peak years of the mid-1990's. 
One difference now is that with the pound weak against the dollar, Americans can feast to their hearts' content. And New Yorkers, in particular, accustomed to tipping in the neighborhood of 20 percent, will discover a pleasant surprise at the bottom of the bill. In virtually every restaurant, optional tipping has given way to the Continental model, with a service charge automatically added on. It is a mere 12.5 percent. 
As in New York, the percolating restaurant economy can be deceiving. Increasingly, it's hard not to feel that Londoners are getting more, and still more, of the same. There is restless activity and bustling commerce, but little sense of forward movement.
The colorful names that gave the dining scene a sense of danger now seem quiescent. The bad-boy chefs have no trouble keeping their names out of the tabloids these days. 
Gordon Ramsay, having earned a third Michelin star, now seems intent on empire-building. He has opened Amaryllis in Glasgow, his hometown, and in September will open Gordon Ramsay at Claridge's, a three-star bid at one of London's most venerated dining rooms. Marco Pierre White has retired from the kitchen to concentrate on running his restaurant group. Gary Rhodes has kept his spiky hair but acts more and more like an elder statesman. Jamie Oliver, the Naked Chef, may be the last soldier in Britain's long, strong line of kitchen shock troops. His type does not quite fit into the smoothly organized, mature market of 21st-century London, where, to a much greater extent than in New York, well-financed restaurant groups like A-Z, Belgo, Savoy and Groupe Chez Gerard define the upper-middle and top end. Many newer restaurants seem like one more model rolling off the assembly line or a shrewdly calculated effort to diversify the portfolio.
An exception is Drones, Mr. White's newest restaurant. The name should ring a bell, for two reasons. It was at the Drones that P. G. Wodehouse's Bertie Wooster spent quality time doing nothing in particular, other than ordering a Lizard's Breath cocktail when the mood hit him. Drones is also familiar to Londoners as an old Belgravia standby that fell on hard times. The original Drones, created in 1973 by David Niven Jr., was a society-celebrity hangout. Food was emphatically not the point, and when the celebrities drifted away, Drones had only its name to recommend it.
Mr. White changed that. He kept the name, redecorated the place in an odd way and turned the menu into an attractive homage to old-school, fuddy-duddy British cooking, with a few fusty French classics added -- the kind of food that suits a place called Drones. It was a shrewd move. New British cuisine has become so firmly entrenched that its early champions, chefs like Stephen Bull and Alistair Little, now seem like remote historical figures rather than revolutionaries. New British seems so old, in fact, that old British seems new.
The menu proudly embraces old standards like potted shrimp, updated with a light layer of lemony mayonnaise on a densely packed mass of tiny North Sea shrimp. Kipper pate gets a swift kick from a splash of whiskey, and salade a la russe makes an appearance, fitted out with a mound of fresh crab and a dollop of mayonnaise sauce. It's as old-fashioned as a pair of spats. Black pudding cannot be avoided on a retro-minded English menu, which is fine with me. Pig's trotters are welcome, too, and if both of them are in the same dish, as at Drones, even better.
The roster of old favorites includes asparagus with hollandaise sauce, escargots a la bourguignonne and grilled lobster with bearnaise sauce, but two main courses stood out. The first was a succulent roast chicken with, of all things, bread sauce, a less than attractive, pasty-looking blob rising, like a repressed memory, from the English culinary id. It is improbably delicious, an unrepentant mixture of bread crumbs and onion-flavored milk seasoned with cayenne pepper and nutmeg. Roast rump of lamb with clams stopped me for a moment. But it's a close cousin of beef with oysters, and the lamb, hugely flavorful, in a concentrated jus persille, put doubt to rest.
The design at Drones is indecipherable. An older English guest, looking around the dining room, said, "In a way, this reminds me of the Grill Room at the Dorchester Hotel, circa 1948." I defer. The walls are hung with black-and-white glamour portrait photos from the 1940's that don't lend any glamour. I stared hard at a marble pillar for some time before I realized that the marble was a patterned adhesive paper. Patterned paper also accounts for the stained-glass effect on the windows at the rear of the dining room. In the center of the room, giant pieces of white coral rest in a museum-style case, just because. In the Wodehouse world, strange things happen all the time, and no one seems very surprised. 
With star chefs twinkling less brightly these days, the return of Richard Neat counted as big news here. Mr. Neat, who at 26 had won two Michelin stars at Pied a Terre, skipped off to the Riviera in 1996, opened a restaurant and immediately earned a Michelin star. Evidently, too much sun can be a bore. With great fanfare, Mr. Neat settled into the Oxo Tower, south of the Thames near Blackfriars Bridge. 
The building has one famous resident already, fabulously successful and critically despised Oxo Tower, operated by the Harvey Nichols Group. Mr. Neat occupies 10,000 square feet on the second floor, where he has opened a brasserie, a formal restaurant named Neat and a Champagne bar on the third floor, with prime views across the river. British critics welcomed the long-lost Mr. Neat with open arms. The Evening Standard dished out a hefty three stars about five minutes after Neat opened.
I found it intermittently top-rate, more often slightly off and overall a mild disappointment. It struck me as a restaurant that needed another month to find its footing. The compact menu is immensely appealing, with a fresh, modern flavor and an unforced creativity in dishes like turbot served with a lasagna of gray shrimp and surrounded by an insistent, earthy mushroom jus. Roasted scallops are matched, surprisingly, with the ubiquitous black pudding, this time tossed with scrambled eggs and served with caramelized apple, making it a homey, two-for-one bistro fusion. Perhaps most startling was a firm, rich rillette of mullet with prune puree and almond cream, a reminder that Mr. Neat, a big influence on Paul Liebrandt at Atlas in Manhattan, can be a wild man.
Somewhat tamer, and among the best dishes I tried, were powerfully gamy pigeon breasts, served with white-bean gnocchi and an aromatic pea veloute, and lamb cutlets with a ballotine of offal, a gelatinous package not for the faint of heart but bliss for the rest of us. The visual pleasure is all in the view. The blandly modern interior, as one British critic put it, would be just about right for the Dubai Hilton. Out the window, it's another story, with St. Paul's close enough to be the centerpiece on the table.
Prime views are also on the menu at Smith's of Smithfield, a rollicking scene restaurant that would fit right into Manhattan's meatpacking district. This makes perfect sense, because it's already in the London equivalent, across from the Smithfield meat market. Smith's has a cafe on the ground floor, a brasserie on the second floor, a lounge on the third and a restaurant on the fourth, and even so it's nearly splitting at the seams as young Londoners try to push their way in. The cafe, which dishes out decent pub food (I have fond memories of a chicken and leek pie stuffed with huge pieces of tender meat), is a free-for-all. You don't reserve. You just join the scrum and leap for a table when it becomes available, or failing that, you make new friends and sit down at an occupied table. This is not a joke. The waitresses actually broker these awkward partnerships.
On the top floor, with its wraparound terrace, calm prevails. Mad cow or no mad cow, the accent is on beef -- British beef, identified by point of origin, down to the actual farm. The pedantry serves a dual purpose. It assures diners that they are getting flavorful, tender boutique beef, rather than the mass-produced variety. It also sends the reassuring message that the feed is carefully controlled and that eating the meat, therefore, will not result in a painful, lingering death 10 years after the meal.
The nonbeef dishes roam freely from hearty British to hearty Italian and points between. Black pudding and scallops turn up, unexpectedly, with celeriac mash. The British accent fades in and out. Grilled turbot with bubble and squeak comes with a salsa verde. Yorkshire pudding is paired not with roast beef, but pan-fried sweetbreads.
The beef I tried, a longhorn sirloin supplied by Gilbert McTaggart on Islay, did not impress me deeply. On the anemic side and mealy textured, it made me want to stand up and deliver a jingoistic speech on the excellence of American beef and its superiority to that of all other countries. But then again, I did not try the 21-day T-bone from the Orkneys or the shorthorn beef rib aged 25 days in muslin.
Desserts have an exuberance that leaps off the page. The menu at Smith's changes daily, but typically includes roast stone fruit with chilled grappa, Sauternes custard with Armagnac prunes or vanilla pudding with rhubarb and vanilla cream.
One of the longest-running acts in London dining is Nico Ladenis, chef and owner of Chez Nico. Mr. Ladenis created a stir last year when he simplified his menu, cut his prices and asked the Guide Michelin to unlist his restaurant, which had carried three stars since 1995. Mr. Ladenis, one of the city's more tempestuous personalities, preferred to settle into a relaxed, casual mode at Chez Nico (now cheznico), and he continues in that vein with Incognico, his new restaurant in the West End, just a few steps from the Ivy. 
Incognico will feel instantly familiar to New Yorkers. It has the cool air, dark wood and high ceilings that spell downtown. The atmosphere falls somewhere between cafe, saloon and club. The food is perfect for the setting -- well-executed, streamlined bistro fare with no airs. The place, consequently, is packed.
Salt cod wrapped in batter, fried to a deep brown and served with a thick aioli is a characteristic appetizer, uncomplicated but on the money. Things don't get a lot more involved. The appetizers run to dishes like smoked salmon with horseradish cream, braised prawns with Russian salad, seared scallops with garlic butter and arugula. 
It does not make for inspired reading. Eating is something else. In my dreams I relive the baby Dover sole, grilled and served with tartar sauce. The veal kidneys with mustard sauce occasionally break into the reverie, but it's that fish that disturbs my peace of mind.
The desserts at Incognico don't sound special either, but apple tart on a paper-thin crust delivers the goods. So does chocolate marquise with creme anglaise. One good index of a restaurant's intentions is the bread. Incognico has very good bread. And good bread-and-butter pudding too.
Perhaps the most distinctive new restaurant here is the Cinnamon Club, an ambitious attempt to put a modern face on traditional Indian food. In no time, it has earned the nickname Posh Spice, in part for its fancy dishware and French-style service, in part for its setting, in the Old Westminster Library on a quiet street near Parliament Square. 
The dining room is impressive in a peculiar way. The books have been left in place along the back wall and the mezzanine, and the bright lighting adds to the sense that the library staff is still running things and that the food will come down from the stacks.
The food is wildly hit or miss. When it's good, like a tangled nest of asparagus tips and okra with spiced yogurt, it's very good. When it's bad -- a swampy bowl of steamed mussels with pickled carrot and beets comes luridly to mind -- it can be awful. Some are both at once, like a dehydrated lump of duck surrounded by a thick Goan spice sauce and semolina flavored with curry leaf. Rabbit loin with cottage cheese and dried fruit intriguingly balances chewy textures with the fine-grained smoothness of rabbit meat. Chopped mustard leaves with garlic and chili have the punch and heft of a main course. 
The play of spices and chilies at the Cinnamon Club is kaleidoscopic, but the main point never gets lost, which is to bolster flavor rather than bury it. There's a subtle hand behind the enormous prawns coated in a complex mustard sauce, just hot enough, served with a fragrant saffron kedgeree.
For whatever reason, desserts seem to respond best to reinvention. A cumin yogurt dressing, creamily spicy, cuts the sweetness of tightly packed cakes of shredded, toasted coconut. Steamed mango rice cakes are opulently fruity but lightweight, and cardamom adds just the right blast of exotic spice to a plain carrot samosa. The waiters seem permanently confused.
If you had to pick a symbol for London dining today, you could do worse than the Cinnamon Club, a French-English-Indian restaurant doing business in a former library. No neighborhood is beyond the reach of serious food these days. What food that might be is up for grabs. No one even expects the next big thing. But everybody knows for a certainty they can count on at least one medium-size thing every week of the year, all year long. New Yorkers know the feeling.

HEADLINE: Singapore Says Economy Is in Recession 

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, July 10 

 BODY:
Singapore said today that its economy had slipped into recession, becoming the first of what economists predict will be a long list of export-dependent Asian countries that will suffer from the economic slump in the United States.
 Preliminary estimates by the Trade and Industry Ministry indicated that Singapore's economy shrank 0.8 percent in the second quarter compared with the first three months of this year, its second consecutive quarterly decline. The new data mark the first time that Singapore's economy has fit the technical definition of a recession since the height of the Asian financial crisis in 1998. The news helped send the Singapore dollar to an 11-year low against the United States dollar. 
 The ministry blamed slower growth in the United States, especially in the electronics industry, for the deteriorating performance of the Singapore economy. It said the downturn in the United States had also dimmed the outlook for exports to Europe and the rest of Asia. "With all the three main external engines faltering, Singapore's growth in 2001 will be significantly affected," the ministry said. It lowered its forecast for economic growth this year to 0.5 percent to 1.5 percent, down from an earlier estimate of 3.5 percent to 5.5 percent.
With no natural resources and a population of about four million, Singapore has little to shelter it from the global technology downturn. The electronics industry accounts for most of Singapore's exports, and the United States is one of Singapore's largest trading partners, so Tuesday's numbers came as little surprise to economists or financial markets. "This is going to be a bad year for Singapore," said Liew Chih Wai, an analyst at Standard & Poor's in Singapore.
The more populous economies in Asia, like China's, have sizable domestic economies to insulate them from a downturn abroad; less-developed economies, including Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines, are buffered to some extent by large agricultural sectors and revenues from other resources, like natural gas and oil.
Even so, Singapore's well-manicured economy is unlikely to be the last to slip officially into reverse this year. Economists say the Japanese economy has almost certainly begun to shrink, and many expect Taiwan, Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines to show recessionary trends once they release their own second-quarter data.
Economists also warn that even those Asian economies still posting statistical growth, notably Indonesia, have entered "recessionary environments," with growth rates too low to prevent joblessness from rising. Sluggish economic reforms have left Asia's banking industry mired, retarding the growth of domestic opportunities and combining with political instability to deter foreign investment.
"These economies are in a holding pattern," said Song Seng Wun, an economist at G. K. Goh Securities in Singapore. Until exports to the United States recover, he said, foreign investment and economic reforms will continue to suffer.
Mr. Liew, the Standard & Poor's analyst, and economists here said that affluent, authoritarian Singapore was relatively well-prepared to ride out the downturn. With at least $75 billion in foreign currency reserves and no external government debt, Singapore's economists have ample room to soften the recession's impact on citizens.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 12, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in World Business yesterday about the economy of Singapore slipping into recession misstated the gross domestic product for the second quarter compared with the first quarter. It declined 10.1 percent, at an annualized rate, not 0.8 percent.

HEADLINE: Soft Money's Scanty Leftovers 

BYLINE:  By Donna Brazile; Donna Brazile managed Al Gore's presidential campaign.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
If politicians really cared about efforts to get out the vote in America, they would stand up on the House floor this week and support real campaign finance reform: the ban on soft money in the Shays-Meehan bill.
 As a Democratic activist and an African-American who has worked all my life to increase the number of people who vote on Election Day, I was dismayed to hear some members of Congress are falling for the false argument that a ban on soft money would hurt minority candidates and grass-roots get-out-the-vote efforts. Just the opposite is true. 
 A ban on soft money would strengthen the hand of those who are out there in the community, shaking people out of their beds, greeting them in churches and meeting them in factories. I cut my teeth on grass-roots politics and have spent the last 20 years getting out the vote -- not just in safe or rich districts, but in marginal and poor ones as well. 
The Shays-Meehan bill will help take big money out of the picture. As long as we keep big money in the system, it will control the message -- through millions spent on expensive television advertising -- and the politicians, with big-dollar help for their campaigns. Big money makes a sham of the precept that ours is a government of, by and for the people.
Big money -- with its power over politicians and public perceptions -- hurts issues and causes that a majority of Americans care about. It blocks passage of health care reform. It protects polluters. It stymies provision of prescription drug treatments for older Americans. It keeps needed government programs for low- and middle-income Americans from being adequately financed.
Big money shuts young people and people of color out of the system and encourages cynicism. When I speak on campuses around the country, young people tell me there is no point in voting or getting involved because big money controls Washington.
Nor does soft money really help the democratic process in minority communities. Most of the big soft money that candidates spend all their time chasing after is spent on television ads or on media consultants, who typically advise candidates that campaigns are never won on the ground, but only with the help of services like theirs. Only scanty leftovers remain for increasing voter turnout and participation among minorities and in poor communities.
It's particularly distressing that some minority lawmakers, at this late hour, may block reform. With few exceptions, African-American and Hispanic members of Congress represent safe districts in which most voters belong to ethnic minority groups. According to the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, members of the Congressional Black Caucus won their elections in 2000 with an average of 79 percent of the vote. Campaign finance reform would not deprive these lawmakers of the ability to hold onto their seats. But it would open up the political pipeline by making it easier for new, modestly financed candidates to compete. It would allow more women and minority challengers (many of whom cannot get funding in the current political system) to run for office.
At the state and local level, a ban on soft money may force parties to build grass-roots programs, using volunteers, to work in the upcoming elections. Now, more than ever, we need candidates to campaign willingly in black and Latino communities, and not just late at night after they have spent all day in wealthy neighborhoods raising money. It is time to go back to the basics of knocking on doors, meeting people in the communities where they live and encouraging young people to help revitalize our ailing democracy.
In light of what took place in the presidential election, it is clear that we also need to overhaul our election laws. There is no place in our democracy for malfunctioning or broken voting machines, untrained poll workers or confusing ballots. There is no place for the purging of legally qualified citizens from voter rolls or any of the other barriers that kept Americans from casting their ballots.
The Senate has already passed the McCain-Feingold soft money ban, and the House ought to act immediately on the nearly identical Shays-Meehan bill. Members of Congress should oppose the Ney-Wynn bill being offered as an alternative; it is not true campaign finance reform. And both the House and the Senate have a responsibility to move quickly on comprehensive reform of our election processes. There is no cause for obstruction or delay on either front.

HEADLINE: Ousted Philippines President Officially Charged With Plunder 

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, July 10 

 BODY:
Under heavy guard against possible street protests, the former president of the Philippines, Joseph Estrada, was arraigned today on a charge of plundering the country while in office. 
 The case could last for years, causing a political diversion at a time when the Philippines is struggling, against mounting difficulties, for stability and economic revival. 
 Subdued and unsmiling, Mr. Estrada, a former movie actor, endured the limelight of dozens of camera flashes as he took his seat in a special antigraft court in Manila, according to reports from the scene. The judges entered a plea of not guilty for him when he refused to enter one. The charge carries the death penalty, although it is highly unlikely that he will be sentenced to death if convicted. 
Despite concerns about disorder, the streets were generally peaceful, with thousands of police officers and soldiers guarding the court.
Mr. Estrada, 64, is accused of stealing or misusing $76 million during his truncated two-and-a-half-year presidency, accusations similar to those that touched off impeachment proceedings against him late last year.
When it appeared in January that he would survive the impeachment moves, public anger against him exploded in huge street demonstrations. The Supreme Court quickly ruled that he had lost his legitimacy and the military escorted him from the presidential palace.
He was replaced by his vice president, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo. His conviction would shore up her assertions of legitimacy after her irregular accession to power.
Mr. Estrada was elected to a six-year term in 1998 with the largest plurality of any president in recent times. He continues to enjoy widespread support among the poor, who make up a majority of Filipinos. 
Although many in the political and business elite said Mr. Estrada's removal was essential to restore stability and confidence, it has for the moment led to a period of uncertainty. On May 1 his supporters tried to storm the presidential palace, and Mrs. Arroyo has warned repeatedly of possible coups and assassination attempts. The peso has fallen to its lowest rate in memory, less than 2 cents.
The government has also been diverted by an aggressive Muslim separatist insurgency in the south that has included repeated kidnappings.
Officials say the trial is a mark of political maturity, signaling that high-level corruption will no longer be tolerated. Graft and patronage still pervade life in the Philippines, untouched by legal constraints.
When President Ferdinand E. Marcos was driven from power in 1986, he fled to Hawaii and was never tried. Very little of the billions of dollars he stole has been recovered by the government.
Mr. Estrada's courtroom ordeal may well last longer than his presidency. He faces separate trials on charges of perjury and graft.
Already his lawyers are calling for postponements on the charge of plunder, defined as the systematic theft from the state on a huge scale. One of their arguments is that the plunder law is unconstitutional, despite the fact that Mr. Estrada himself voted in favor of it when he was a senator.
Prosecutors said that Mr. Estrada's lawyers had filed 41 motions covering 70 issues, and that the hearing today had already been delayed by 84 days.
There are several co-defendants, including Mr. Estrada's son, Jose Ejercito, who has just ended a term as mayor of San Juan, a Manila suburb. 
Though he refused to enter a plea, Mr. Estrada did have some words for the court. When he was asked to stand, he objected to references to him in the charge sheet as Asiong Salonga, a movie character he had played, and as Jose Velarde, a pseudonym he is accused of using on secret bank accounts.
He said he should be referred to by his titles in political office, as either a former mayor, former senator, former vice president or, as he still insists, as the serving president.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Former President Joseph Estrada at his arraignment in Manila. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Rise in Wholesale Inventories In May Was Biggest in Months 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10 

 BODY:
Sales at wholesalers fell in May and inventories rose more than at any time in the last six months, a sign that businesses may be reluctant to order more goods until the economy picks up.
 Wholesale inventories rose 0.2 percent, led by an increase in stockpiles of drugs, food and clothing, after increasing 0.1 percent in April, the Commerce Department reported today. 
Sales fell 0.1 percent, the third drop in the last four months. 
 That pushed the inventory-to-sales ratio, a measure of the time goods remain unsold, up to 1.32 months in May, the highest level since April 1999. As a result, wholesalers are struggling to keep stockpiles in line with sluggish demand.
The report "isn't good news for the economy because it suggests continued weak production as companies work off the inventory glut," said Tim Rogers, chief economist at Briefing.com in Boston. The May increase in inventories was the largest since a 0.4 percent increase in November.
Wholesalers account for about one-quarter of all business inventories. Retailers and factories account for the rest.
Some wholesalers say they have been able to reduce inventories. Computer equipment inventories were unchanged in May, as sales increased 3.6 percent, the Commerce Department said.
"We haven't had to make dramatic moves in our inventory levels," said Brooke Powers, vice president and general manager for purchasing at Tech Data, a large computer distributor in Clearwater, Fla.
The inventory-to-sales ratio has been rising since the beginning of 2000, when it was at 1.28 months, as sales slowed and stockpiles increased. In February 1997, the ratio fell as low as 1.23 months.
Inventories of nondurable goods, like clothing, drugs, food and paper, rose 2 percent after a 1 percent increase in April. Sales of nondurable goods fell 0.2 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Sour News From Corning Pushes Shares Down Sharply

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
News of a slowdown at Corning set off another sell-off on Wall Street yesterday, as investors' hopes for a business turnaround in 2001 dissipated further.
 Analysts said the market was waiting -- so far in vain -- for companies to say the outlook for future revenues and earnings was improving. 
 "Underlying this all is a feeling that the malaise in earnings isn't over yet," said Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at SG Cowen Securities. "The market is saying that those who thought there was going to be a considerable rebound in the third or fourth quarter this year were wrong." 
The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 123.76 points, or 1.2 percent, to close at 10,175.64.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 63.92 points, or 3.2 percent, to 1,962.79, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 17.26 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,181.52.
Corporate profits were again the focus on Wall Street. Investors punished Corning after it reduced its earnings forecast and said it would close three manufacturing plants and cut another 1,000 jobs from its photonic technologies division because of an abrupt slowdown. Shares of Corning fell 98 cents, to $14.12.
The sour mood spread to other technology issues, which suffered on similar concerns about future results. I.B.M. dropped $2.76, to $101.96, on worries it will miss second-quarter estimates.
The market also pounded Genentech, which fell $8.26, to $43.85, on news that its asthma drug might not get federal approval.
Financial stocks were weak, too, reflecting investors' uncertainty about growth prospects. J. P. Morgan Chase dropped $1.98, to $42.01, and American Express fell $1.20, to $37.
Analysts have said investors are waiting for second-quarter results later this month before taking any big steps. The market has been in a slump the last several weeks, with occasional rallies that have failed to spark any larger advances.
The Federal Reserve's six interest rate cuts this year had raised hopes of a turnaround by the end of the year. But the more than 700 earnings warnings ahead of second-quarter reports, which begin this week, have all but wiped out hopes of a recovery before next year.
"We're waiting for second-quarter reports. And the key aspect coming out of those reports isn't the earnings, but what a company's timing and prospects for a recovery are going to be," said Bryan Piskorowski, market commentator at Prudential Securities.
Also yesterday, Triton Energy rose $14.53, or 48 percent, to $44.43, on news that it was being acquired for $2.6 billion by Amerada Hess. Hess fell $2.01, to $77.35. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday as declining stocks increased demand for the relative safety of United States government securities. Concern that Argentina may default on its debt also bolstered Treasuries.
Investors are "unwilling to jump in and catch a falling knife" in the stock market as earnings disappointments persist, said Richard Madigan, who manages $600 million in emerging market debt for Offitbank Funds. That helps a "flight-to-quality bid" for Treasuries, he said.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 19/32 , to a price of 98 2/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.26 percent from 5.34 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 19/32 , to 96. The bond's yield fell to 5.66 percent from 5.70 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: Economic Troubles Worsen in Argentina 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Argentina's financial troubles deepened yesterday as the government had to offer 14.01 percent interest to attract investors to its three-month Treasury bills.
 The rate, on $827.7 million of securities, was the highest since the government began issuing such bills in 1996 and well above the 9.10 percent paid on similar securities just two weeks ago. 
 The government also sold $22 million in one-year securities with a yield of 15.96 percent. Analysts said that because investors were unwilling to take on this modestly longer-term risk, the government was unable to sell more of the one-year securities rather than the shorter-term bills. 
Investor caution about Argentina, which has been in recession for three years, is beginning to spread to other emerging markets, where problems are being aggravated by a slowing world economy. The slowdown is making it hard to sell exports and to raise capital abroad.
Each jump in interest rates makes the financial road bumpier for Argentina. Its domestic and foreign debt becomes more costly to service. But tax revenues remain weak, making it hard to pay for government programs and meet debt payments. Investors fear that Argentina might wind up in default if the government does not cut spending.
"The situation is deteriorating very rapidly, and the political situation is very tense," said Jose Barrionuevo, director of emerging markets strategy at BNP Paribas.
Disputes within the governing alliance may block further spending cuts. The prospect of elections in October also does not help, Mr. Barrionuevo said, citing the political pressure to maintain various programs. There was speculation last week that Argentina's economy minister, Domingo Cavallo, would announce some spending cuts soon, but he has not done so. 
The poor reception to the Argentinian debt auction helped send the stock market lower, with the Merval index down 6.1 percent. The price of benchmark bonds also fell. The price of the floating-rate bond maturing in 2005 fell to $74.55 from $77.99 Monday, according to Bloomberg News. The yield jumped to 23.88 percent, from 20.87 percent. The price of the bond maturing in 2008 fell to $66.75, from $71.15, with the yield jumping to 19.3 percent. The bonds have a par value of $100.
Investor jitters about Argentina spread to Brazil, where the currency fell to its lowest level since it was allowed to trade freely in January 1999. In late trading in New York, the real was at 2.4915 to the dollar, down 1.6 percent from Monday and 21.7 percent for the year.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY: Market Place; 
Despite cost-cutting, Compaq is facing declining earnings and sales.

BYLINE:  By Chris Gaither 

 BODY:
THE Compaq Computer Corporation, the world's second-largest personal computer maker, said yesterday that it expected to report lower-than-projected earnings and sales for the second quarter and that it would eliminate 1,500 more jobs than previously announced.
 Despite progress in cutting costs, Compaq said a sharper-than-expected slump in the European business market caused worldwide sales to decline 9 percent from the first quarter, to about $8.4 billion from $9.2 billion. The company had told Wall Street to expect sales of $9 billion. 
 "It is now clear that the economic slowdown is spreading overseas," Michael D. Capellas, the company's chief executive, said in a statement. "We will therefore move more swiftly and go even deeper in our structural cost reduction programs." 
Compaq said that profits and gross margins also suffered because the company lowered prices to remain competitive with its rivals in the personal computer market, particularly the Dell Computer Corporation.
Compaq, based in Houston, said it expected to post earnings of 4 cents a share for the second quarter ended June 30. This matched Wall Street's expectations, but fell one penny short of the company's forecast in April. Compaq will report its final results on July 25.
In April, the company said it would eliminate 7,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, through 4,500 layoffs and the attrition of an expected 2,500 employees. 
But with a slowing economy and fewer high-technology jobs to be had than in the boom times of recent years, Compaq's workers stayed put. As a result, the company yesterday said it would eliminate those 2,500 through severance, as well as an additional 1,500. The job cuts, expected to come both in the United States and abroad, bring the total to 8,500, or 13 percent of Compaq's workers. 
For the quarter, Compaq said it would take a restructuring charge of $490 million to cover the severance packages and to close plants that make the Alpha line of semiconductors for top-of-the-line server systems. Compaq announced last month that it would discontinue the Alpha line and use chips made by Intel.
Jeff Clarke, Compaq's chief financial officer, said the company should complete most of its restructuring by the end of the year.
"We now expect the payback, upon completion, from the combined restructuring programs to be approximately $900 million on an annualized basis," Mr. Clarke said. 
Compaq shares dropped 44 cents, or 3 percent, to close at $13.76 amid a widespread sell-off in technology stocks. The announcement, which came after markets closed, pushed the company's stock up to $14.10 in after-hours trading.
As the personal computer market slows, Compaq is trying to insulate itself by asking more from its Global Services division. The company, which lost the worldwide sales lead to Dell last quarter, is aggressively trying to sell more server systems and the technical services that accompany them. Even as it shed jobs in other parts of the company, Compaq added 750 employees to its services division during the quarter. The shift in focus puts Compaq in direct competition with services giants like I.B.M..
In the meantime, computer makers are trying to cut costs to keep profits steady. Compaq said it reduced its operating expenses by $100 million last quarter but was unable to meet its forecasts. The company said it was hurt by the declining value of the euro, as well as weaker-than-expected sales in Britain, Germany and Switzerland, especially in June.
Kevin A. McCarthy, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston, said he expected similarly disappointing earnings reports from other computer makers in the coming weeks. 
Some investors still hope that corporations will increase their spending on information technology and that sales of Microsoft's new XP operating system could help increase computer sales near the end of the year.
"But nobody's betting on that right now," Mr. McCarthy said. "In this environment, it's hard to see out even one quarter.

HEADLINE: Gap Found in Funeral Home Inspections 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, July 10 

 BODY:
The discovery of five decomposing bodies in a funeral home's garage here last month has led to yet another finding: Connecticut has not had an inspector for funeral homes for more than a decade.
 Officials of the State Department of Public Health acknowledged on Monday that the Wade Funeral Home -- which ceased operations on June 27, the day the bodies were found -- had not been inspected since 1988 and had been operating without a license for a year. They said the lack of routine inspections held true for the rest of the estimated 300 funeral homes in the state. 
 The revelation concerning inspections came after a hearing on Monday in which the embalming licenses of Wade's president, Michael Wade, and an employee, Monica Hammie-Richardson, were suspended; the home has been cited for numerous health violations. The partly embalmed bodies, which had gone unburied for three to five years, were found by the police after a complaint. 
A health department spokesman, William Gerrish, said the inspections stopped when the part-time funeral inspector, Thomas Dowling, retired in 1989. He was not replaced, Mr. Gerrish said, and financing for the position had been withdrawn.
"Our priority now is to make sure that funeral homes are inspected properly," said Mr. Gerrish, who added that the state would consider re-establishing the position.
The co-chairwomen of the Connecticut General Assembly's Public Health Committee said today that they were shocked by the absence of a funeral home inspector. One, Senator Toni Harp, Democrat of New Haven, said she would seek financing for an inspector at a meeting with state health officials on Wednesday.
"I'm hoping the only case of mismanagement and lack of procedure and protocol is here in New Haven, but we have no way of knowing that," Ms. Harp said. "This is a whole sector of our economy that has the potential of horrible things happening if we don't know the cleanliness of these facilities." The other chairwoman, Representative Mary U. Eberle, Democrat of Bloomfield, said she planned to introduce a bill next year to mandate inspections. The state now inspects homes only when they open, change management or face a complaint.
The executive director of the Connecticut Funeral Directors Association, John Cascio, said he would welcome such a bill. 
"We have been lobbying for this position for a number of years," said Mr. Cascio, whose group represents 222 funeral homes around Connecticut, though not the Wade Funeral Home.
"We take pride in our ownership and believe that an inspector should be responsible for randomly checking homes, making sure they're clean facilities with only licensed personnel," he said.
Mr. Cascio said that Mr. Wade, who faces another hearing Aug. 8 on whether his license will be revoked, was well respected in the industry.
Mr. Wade did not return several phone calls to his office today. 
State officials said that they had identified one of the five bodies as that of Fred Carmon, an elderly victim of a stabbing in 1998. The other bodies remain unidentified.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Compaq to Miss Forecasts And to Cut 1,500 More Jobs
Compaq Computer said it expected to report lower-than-projected earnings and sales for the second quarter and that it would eliminate 1,500 more jobs than previously announced.
 Compaq blamed a sharp slump in the European business market for a 9 percent drop in worldwide sales. Profits and gross margins also suffered because of price competition at home, the company said. Page C8. 

Conflict of Interest Rule at Merrill
Merrill Lynch barred its stock analysts from buying shares of the companies they cover, going a step further than the industry standard to remove a potential conflict of interest. A1.

Amerada Hess in $2.6 Billion Deal
Amerada Hess will buy Triton Energy for about $2.6 billion in cash, the companies said. The deal has the support of the buyout firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, which owns 38 percent of Triton. Shares of Triton soared $14.53, or 48.6 percent, to $44.43. Shares of Amerada Hess fell $2.01, or 2.5 percent, to $77.35. C2.

StarLink Passes Government Test
Virtually all the food samples collected from consumers who complained of allergic reactions to StarLink corn did not contain the genetically modified corn at all, government tests have found. C8.

Malone Resigns From AT&T Board
John C. Malone, the cable television magnate who is one of AT&T's largest individual shareholders, resigned from the company's board earlier than planned after he was excluded from talks related to Comcast's offer to buy AT&T's cable systems. C11.

Banker Is Nominated for the Fed

"Our offices were on the top five floors," he said. "Normally I parked in the underground lot where the bomb exploded, but by coincidence, my car was in the shop that day so I rode with someone else." The Boss. C6.

Argentina's financial troubles deepened as the government had to offer 14.01 percent interest to attract investors to its three-month Treasury bills. The rate was the highest since 1996 when it began issuing such bills. C4.
