HEADLINE: Calls for Change in an Ancient Occupation 

BYLINE:  By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: MOJAVE, Calif. 

 BODY:
The shepherd was deep in the desert, eight miles from the nearest road and more than four miles of rocky brush past the closest sign of civilization, a landfill. It was midafternoon, 110 degrees, and the 500 sheep he tends 24 hours a day, seven days a week were sleeping. But with nothing else to do, he was watching them anyway, pacing the parched earth with two panting border collies by his side.
 Two years and eight months into a three-year contract as a shepherd under a federal guest worker program, the 40-year-old Peruvian said he was still waiting for a day off. He lives in a 6-by-12-foot trailer with no running water, no electricity, no phone, no toilet. 
 "This is my bathroom," he says with a toothy smile, holding up a long-handled garden shovel. 
The man, who would not let his name be used for fear of angering his employer, is typical of shepherds in the United States, about 800 of whom toil in California. Mostly from Peru and Chile, they live isolated, nomadic existences here, dependent upon their employers for food, mail and all contact with the outside world.
Aside from tinny radios or tiny televisions that some keep in their trailers, they live much as shepherd have always lived, in the middle of nowhere with no human contact save for when their bosses come to move the trailer to a new grazing spot or bring their weekly rations of food and water.
In the universe of migrant farm labor, shepherds make up the tiniest sliver and are so invisible that with a few exceptions they have had no advocates to call for reform.
As federal guest workers, they are brought here because their employers, the sheep ranchers, could find no Americans willing to be shepherd, even here in California's farm belt, where unemployment in some counties is over 15 percent.
That may be not only because their living conditions make migrant farm workers seem pampered, but also because under a quirk in federal labor laws, shepherds are excluded from minimum wage regulations. Until July 1, when California's Industrial Welfare Commission, which regulates working conditions, ordered sheep ranchers to increase herders' wages by $150 a month, shepherds, who are essentially on duty 90 hours a week, made $900 a month.
Still, shepherds in California, the largest sheep ranching state after Texas, are the lucky ones. They make the most money. In other states, the pay is $600 to $800 a month.
Shepherds are also on the legislative map. When the state Industrial Welfare Commission refused to set working conditions for shepherds, such as overtime pay and rest periods, State Assemblyman Paul Koretz, a Democrat from West Hollywood, drafted a bill that would require rest periods and basic amenities, such as toilets, lighting, water and regular access to phones.
The bill, which has passed the Assembly and is expected to be reviewed by a State Senate committee today, would require shepherds to be given a 30-minute meal break in a five-hour work period if someone is available to relieve them. It would also require employers to provide housing that includes toilets, heating, lighting, water, stoves and refrigerators. 
"It's logical that at some point their conditions would have to change from the days of the Old Testament," Mr. Koretz said. "I'm generally trying to bring them up to the 20th century."
But passage of Mr. Koretz's bill is in no way assured. Ranchers vehemently deny that shepherds are mistreated, and lobbyists for the sheep ranching industry say that new regulations would kill an ailing industry. 
Over the last 20 years, sheep ranchers have seen their profits steadily erode. In 1999, California ranchers made 35 cents a pound for wool, 30 cents less than in 1994. Lamb meat wholesales for 82 cents to 83 cents a pound. In 1997, it was 91.6 cents.
With the erosion of profits, the herd in the state has steadily declined. From 1994 to 2001, according to the United States Department of Agriculture, the number of sheep produced in California dropped by a third, to 840,000, and the number of farms with sheep has dropped by 45 percent.
Officials of the Western Range Association, a lobbying organization representing ranchers in 11 states, did not respond to calls seeking comment. But in an article in The Fresno Bee, James Holt, an agricultural economist with the association, said the sheep ranchers had been trying to make it clear to legislators that the money to pay for any added benefits or amenities to herders is simply "not there."
"We've tried to be responsible and responsive" to shepherds, Mr. Holt said.
Dennis Hollingsworth, a Republican assemblyman from Temecula who voted against the bill, said he thought it would do more harm than good. The shepherds, he said, do not really need rest periods.
"Most of the time they are resting, unless there is a danger," he said. "Most of the time, it's just watching the flock."
Mr. Hollingsworth added that the impact of the bill "will not be better wages or working conditions for sheepherders. The impact will be that wool growers will leave this state and there will be less jobs for sheepherders to have in California."
Mr. Koretz said that he was trying to be sensitive to the industry, and that if necessary, he would moderate his bill so it could land on Gov. Gray Davis's desk and be assured his signature. But a small, persistent group of advocates for the shepherds say that modest goals for shepherds should not be compromised.
"We're not asking for Jacuzzis," said Chris Schneider, executive director of Central California Legal Services and a crusader for improved conditions for sheepherders for over a decade. "When an industry is going through a low period, we don't lower the minimum wage or say it could force their workers to work without getting paid."
Last year, the Fresno-based legal aid group published a report on the conditions of 41 shepherds in the lower Central Valley counties of Fresno and Kern, which contain most of the sheep ranches in the state, and found that 90 percent of the shepherds had never had a day off and more than 95 percent had no toilets. The report also said that many shepherds were not allowed visitors, and that they were threatened with deportation if they asked for such things as more food or clean water containers.
One former shepherd, Victor Flores, said he was dumped at a motel in Bakersfield when he asked his employer for more food. He said he was forced to take another job, as a dishwasher, and now, seven years later, works in a fruit packinghouse. He has formed an advocacy group, the Sheepherders Union, which documents the conditions and experiences of the shepherds.
"I never thought when I came here from Peru that this country would treat people as less than human," he said.
Ranchers say that the shepherds are paid much more than they would be making in their native countries, an argument that rankles those fighting for improved conditions.
"When someone comes to this country, we don't take their native country into consideration in how we treat them or pay them," Mr. Schneider said.
There is no denying that the shepherds live primitively. Visits to shepherds in Fresno and Kern Counties -- where finding just four herders took two days because of their remote locations -- found them in very old, dilapidated trailers, full of flies and mosquitoes. One shepherd had a plastic water barrel that was clearly full of fungi and smelled of rotted meat. One was spending a 113-degree afternoon in his 110-degree trailer, waiting for the sun to set so he could spend several hours putting up temporary fences to contain his sheep. All their dogs stayed in holes they had dug under the trailers to avoid the blistering heat.
The shepherd found in the Mojave Desert, the most remote location of any shepherd interviewed, will be moved in October during what is called the lambing season, to farmland outside of Bakersfield.
He said he looked forward to it, despite the backbreaking 13-hour days of caring for newborn lambs and their mothers, because then he has greater contact with the outside world. Two or three shepherds work together and occasionally go to stores to get supplies for the sheep. 
"I get depressed here very often," he said.
But he also considers himself fortunate. Once a week, a kindly man he met when he was stationed near Bakersfield during the six-month lambing season brings him a newspaper. And his employer comes to check on him every other day. Many shepherds do not see their bosses for a week or two, when they bring supplies. A few weeks ago, his employer replaced the shabby 6-by-8-foot wooden trailer he was living in with a newer, 6-by-12-foot one that has seating besides a bed.
And while he has never seen a movie, eaten at a restaurant, attended a church service or even spent a free hour walking around the one city in the United States he has glimpsed, Bakersfield, he said he would renew his contract and do the work for another three years.
"My sons are 11 and 12 and I want the best for them," he said. "That's what I keep remembering all the time while I'm here."

HEADLINE: Homeowners' Suit Says They Are Victims in Deceptive Sales Scheme 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

DATELINE: CARLE PLACE, N.Y., July 10 

 BODY:
They are nurses and police officers, minority couples and families, most of them from working-class New York City neighborhoods. And they say they listened avidly to the offers of affordable suburban houses on tree-lined streets near country clubs, beaches, lakes and good schools for their children.
 But one Bronx couple seeking their dream home say they were duped into buying in a Suffolk County neighborhood plagued by drug dealers and prostitutes. A family from Brooklyn say they paid $171,000 for a house worth at least $50,000 less. And in every case, they say, monthly mortgage payments soared by up to $1,000 within a year after they moved in, as their foundations cracked, siding rusted and floorboards warped. 
 Those were just a few of the complaints in a class-action civil rights lawsuit filed today in Federal District Court in Central Islip against a long list of builders, bankers, appraisers and mortgage brokers who the suit says conspired to sell poorly constructed new homes at inflated prices, and to deceive buyers into believing that property taxes would be deferred or reduced. 
Federal prosecutors say that 20 people have been criminally charged in their continuing investigation into the scheme and that 13 have pleaded guilty to charges. 
The suit, brought by four named plaintiffs, claims to represent about 400 black and Hispanic families who bought homes from $160,000 to $200,000 -- 300 of them in Suffolk County and 100 in Staten Island.
It says that minority buyers were targeted in newspaper ads, featuring fake endorsements from black celebrities like Maya Angelou, Whoopi Goldberg and David N. Dinkins, and offered deals with no down payment. Many were told that they would be moving into a white or ethnically diverse area, the suit says, only to discover that their new neighborhood was segregated. 
They were also promised that they would pay no property taxes for the first year, the suit says. But mortgage payments were later raised to make up for that, and 80 homes have been foreclosed on -- though the lenders were protected, the suit says, because the mortgages are insured by the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.
"The American dream was turned into the American nightmare," the families' lawyer, Lenard Leeds, said after a news conference at his offices in Carle Place. "Everyone thought they were going to provide a better life for their families, and now they are facing bankruptcy and foreclosures of their homes."
The suit names 25 individuals, including the builders and their corporate entities, mortgage brokers and five banks. It seeks compensatory and punitive damages, as well as a stay on further foreclosures. 
Mr. Leeds said the number of plaintiffs makes this the largest class-action lawsuit in New York State charging racism in real estate practices. A spokesman for the state attorney general could not confirm that.
Over the last 18 months, 20 people have been criminally charged by the federal authorities in connection with the scheme, said James E. Tatum Jr., an assistant United States attorney, who is prosecuting the case. Mr. Tatum said that the 13 who have pleaded guilty have acknowledged that they used false documents to obtain mortgages insured by HUD.
They include Isaac Toussie, one of Long Island's largest residential developers. Mr. Toussie, who is free on bail, is scheduled to be sentenced in September and faces up to five years in prison.
Mr. Leeds said that Mr. Toussie and his father, Robert, who is also a developer, headed the scheme.
Isaac Toussie's lawyer, Matthew J. Rosenblum, said he had not seen the lawsuit, and could not comment on its specifics, but said it was disheartening "to realize that people are taking advantage of his legal situation to try to benefit themselves financially."
Mr. Rosenblum said that when his client pleaded guilty to mortgage fraud he told the judge that home buyers, to qualify for HUD loans, would lie about their income and that he would help them to do it.
"If these very same people are the ones coming forward saying they were misled, well then, I have a real problem with that," he said. "It is really disgusting."
Mr. Leeds said the families deny that they colluded in any scheme. "They claim that in the scheme, Toussie said that this is what has to be done and that it is always done like this and that it is required and proper," Mr. Leeds said. "He said they should just listen to him and everything would be fine."
One homeowner in Gordon Heights, Pamela Jones, said she was "freaked out" when her monthly mortgage payments jumped to $2,500 from $1,700 after her first year. But just as troubling, she said, was the realization that her Suffolk County house was near a block where drugs were sold.
"My son kept saying one thing that stuck in my head: 'I don't see any white people out here. The ad says we are going to be in a mixed neighborhood. I only see black people,' " said Ms. Jones, a registered nurse.
She said she was "stuck," because she can get only about $80,000 for the house, which cost her $188,000.
A named plaintiff in the suit, Juan Quintanilla, a New York Police Department detective, said he and his wife, Leticia, and their four children have struggled emotionally and economically since they moved from Richmond Hill in Queens to their house in Medford on Long Island.
"They have shot at my house because they know I'm a cop and I'm increasing the police presence by going to the cops and telling them, 'Look what's going on,' " said Mr. Quintanilla. "Now we are being harassed. They are calling me names, like Rat."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Roberto Sanchez said shoddy construction caused problems, like this foundation crack in his Middle Island, N.Y., house. (Kevin P. Coughlin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Camp David: Ruins on the Ground 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Robert Malley (Op-Ed, July 8) did a great service in trying to educate us about how complex the stakes are in the Middle East. 
 America is the moral leader in the world. 
It set the standard in postwar Europe; we refer to it as the Marshall Plan. The plan did not dictate an outcome but allowed for a process that led to self-government and balanced power. What the Marshall Plan did was to create a climate where democratic institutions and free-market ideas could grow without fear of state-sponsored reprisals. 
Maybe a Powell plan for the Middle East can be brought to the table for Congress and the American people to begin the debate. If we start now, maybe the next generation of Israelis and Palestinians will be debating a Middle East economic union rather than blowing each other to pieces.

AHMED MOHSEN
Ridgecrest, Calif., July 8, 2001

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS; 
Beijing Must Wait, Worry, and Not Mess Up

BYLINE:  By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 10 

 BODY:
Having arrived here as strong favorites to secure the 2008 Summer Games, leaders of the Beijing bid must now survive a peculiar 72-hour Olympic malady -- the agony of the front-runner.
 Recent Olympic history is fraught with candidate cities who seemingly held a hefty advantage, only to fritter it away in the final days before members of the International Olympic Committee held their vote. Beijing was favored over Sydney for the 2000 Summer Games, but lost by two votes, just as Athens's expected victory for the 1996 Olympics evaporated into a triumph for Atlanta. 
 Beijing is still perceived as the desired choice on Friday by a majority of the 119 voting I.O.C. delegates. But the days before the vote are always anxious moments, what Francois Carrard, executive director of the I.O.C., calls a time of "rumors, rumors, rumors, intoxication and manipulation." In the aftermath of its victory, Sydney admitted that its slim victory margin came after delegates from Kenya and Uganda were offered $35,000 apiece the night before the vote for the 2000 Games. 
Unfailingly, favorites seem to lose steam, while the challengers -- Toronto and Paris, in this case -- appear to gain momentum. Lobby sitting in the I.O.C. hotel becomes the skillful art of negotiation. A certain buzz can overcome logic in the perceived order. "Some of it is that some members grow resentful at being told by the media how they're supposed to vote," Dick Pound, an I.O.C. delegate from Montreal, said.
Of course, much of this is a mental exercise. Most of the delegates aren't even here yet. But it is an accepted rule in Olympic voting, as it is in Olympic running, that it is often better to be chasing until the homestretch than leading.
"History shows, the last couple of days you can't win very much, but you can lose it all," Thomas Bach, a German delegate, said. "You have to avoid mistakes."
Paris and Toronto are counting on the winds of change that have blown through the I.O.C. since the Salt Lake City bribery scandal. Ten corrupted members resigned or were removed. Another three dozen delegates have been added, most of them athletes and the heads of international sports federations. Presumably they are more independent, less predictable and clubby in their voting.
Also, delegates have been prohibited from visiting the candidate cities, purportedly to shield them from receiving excessive gifts and favors. What this is supposed to mean is that the merits of the bids will prevail over jewelry and scholarships for the families of delegates. One Olympic official confided privately and proudly Monday night that only favors seemed to be changing hands this time, not money.
Just in case someone would try to illicitly leverage the electronic ballot on Friday, the I.O.C. will have three delegates scrutinize the voting.
"If we win, a significant part will be because of the reforms," the head of the Toronto bid, John Bitove, said.
Of course, Toronto and Paris remain underdogs. Short of some drastic action by the Chinese or an official protest from the officially neutral Bush Administration, Beijing is likely to prevail, several delegates said today.
Kim Un Yong, an influential delegate from South Korea and a member of the South Korean Parliament, said that Beijing would have to really mess up, "or the U.S. Congress would have to pass a binding resolution."
"The U.S. can't tell the I.O.C. what to do, but it could cause big repercussions," Kim said. "But America is neutral. They never won by force in Cuba or Vietnam. Look at what Nixon did. He went to China and then good relations started. If you push too hard, sometimes you solidify a place against outsiders. Bush knows this. His father knows this. And American business is waiting to do business in China."
There are five interlocking Olympic rings, not one, Kim said, meaning all the countries who participate in the Olympics, not just American and European countries, should have an opportunity to be host to the Games.
"If Beijing gets it, it will be because of universality," Kim said when asked how the I.O.C. might be thinking generally. "It is a country of 1.3 billion people. It's a great sports country. It deserves to have the Games. There is hope that they will open the country and improve human relations and the economy and that China will become a good member of the international community, as happened with Seoul and South Korea in 1988."
Still, Toronto and Paris appear confident about their chances. Paul Henderson, an I.O.C. delegate from Toronto, said that his city offers certainty when the Olympic committee is already in an uncertain period about Athens's preparation for the 2004 Games and is about to enter an uncertain period on Monday when it replaces Juan Antonio Samaranch as president after two decades. Perhaps the I.O.C. will not want to enter yet another chancy period by awarding the 2008 Games to Beijing, Henderson said.
"We don't have any political dogma to shove down anyone's throat," Henderson said. "We're nice people. Sydney proved that to be a pretty good recipe for success. Do you want risk or no risk?"
The Olympics are a sporting event, and are not likely to "change the political direction or dogma of a country at all," Henderson said.
Toronto is basing its bid on an inviting compactness. Twenty-five of 28 sports would be contested in an area of about three miles along the waterfront. The bid is "sneaky smart," Pound said.
"What we have heard the last 60 days from people in support and not in support of us is that we have the best bid," Bitove said. "Then some say, 'Yes, but there's politics.' Hopefully, they'll do what's right for sport and the athletes. That's what the goal should be for the Olympics."
Paris is offering the beauty and culture of one of the world's great cities, and is seeking, as it did with soccer's 1998 World Cup, to unite a diverse ethnic population with a common sporting goal. Claude Bebear, the head of the Paris bid, said he had been told by one delegate that "if they let the wives vote, Paris would win 99 percent."
Bebear has previously criticized the Beijing bid, saying, "If you read the Olympic charter closely, you'll find on nearly every line a reference to human rights." But he backed away from those remarks this week. Both Prime Minister Lionel Jospin and the soccer star Zinedine Zidane will be brought in to rally the French vote.
Paris and Toronto have their weaknesses. Paris faces the obstacle of geography, because the next two Olympics will be held in Europe -- Athens in 2004 and Turin, Italy, in 2006. I.O.C. delegates are also concerned about potential police raids on athletes suspected of using performance-enhancing drugs, in the same way that French authorities conducted raids on the Tour de France three years ago. As for Toronto, it may have damaged its chances with intemperate remarks about Africa by its mayor.
When asked today whether Beijing appeared to be losing ground, Wang Wei, the bid leader, said, "I don't believe so."
Only one thing is certain about Friday's vote, Jacques Rogge, a delegate from Belgium, said. "There will be no recount."

D1); Young men playing soccer in front of the Eiffel Tower, where the beach volleyball competition will be held if Paris gets the 2008 Games. (Associated Press)(pg. D4)

HEADLINE: Ferrer Opposes Surtax Cut, Saying City Needs Revenues 

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

 BODY:
Taking a politically tricky step in his campaign for mayor, Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx continued yesterday to promote the repeal of a recent city tax cut -- an idea that is setting him apart from his rivals. 
 Mr. Ferrer, speaking at a mayoral forum in Midtown Manhattan, said the revenue that the city would lose from the recent rollback of a surcharge on the personal income tax would be better spent on after-school programs. 
 Mr. Ferrer said the tax cut, included in the latest budget, would save a typical New York family only about 4 cents a day. Altogether, Mr. Ferrer said, that rollback would deprive city residents of about $800 million in services over the next four years. 
"If you ask an average working family in this city, 'What would you rather have, 4 cents extra a day in your pocket or after-school programs in 200 middle schools?' " Mr. Ferrer said, "I think I know the answer most New Yorkers would give: 'Save the 4 cents a day and give me the services.' "
Mr. Ferrer, who has built his campaign on criticizing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, also chided the current administration for the possibility of spending as much as $500 million in public money to help build sports stadiums or improve existing ones. "This is soaking taxpayers," he said. 
Mr. Ferrer's musings drew little enthusiasm from the other mayoral candidates in attendance -- Herman Badillo, City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and Public Advocate Mark Green, who arrived late. The event, at the Metropolitan Club on East 60th Street at Fifth Avenue, was sponsored by the Forum Club, a group of business professionals. 
Two candidates, Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Vallone, promoted what they contended were their low-tax and pro-business records and vowed to wage a business-friendly economic strategy if they made it to the mayor's office. As the audience picked its way through a lunch of stuffed chicken and zucchini, Mr. Vallone reeled off a list of taxes he said he had either abolished or reduced. 
"There is no way that anybody should be talking about raising taxes again in order to keep this a safe city, to make it a smart city and to have affordable housing," Mr. Vallone said.
Mr. Hevesi saluted the many business tax cuts enacted in recent years and urged the repeal of the city's commercial rent tax. He proposed that the city government do a better of job of identifying -- and then enacting -- the agendas proposed by New York's major industries. 
The city government's proper role in the economy is "assisting business to come here and prosper here and then to get out of the way," Mr. Hevesi said.
Mr. Green, who did not speak about taxes at the forum, favors delaying the reduction of the tax surcharge, said his spokesman, Joe DePlasco. Mr. Green also opposes the city's recent rollback of the commercial rent tax, Mr. DePlasco said. Another mayoral candidate, Michael R. Bloomberg, skipped yesterday's forum and spent the time meeting with development officials in Queens. Mr. Bloomberg, who has not attended most of the other forums so far, said his time was better spent meeting voters. 
"My objective is to go to every single neighborhood and shake every hand," he said. 
Back at the Metropolitan Club, whose opulent setting formed the backdrop for the forum, the absence of Mr. Bloomberg, a wealthy financial news media executive, became the subject of good-natured quips. 
"He's not here," said Mark Simone, a radio and television host who presided over the forum. "I guess he just felt out of place in a room full of wealthy businessmen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayoral candidates at a forum yesterday, from left, Mark Green, Herman Badillo, Fernando Ferrer, Alan G. Hevesi and Peter F. Vallone. (Justin Lane for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FedEx Freight Rates to Rise 

BYLINE:  Dow Jones News 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif. 

 BODY:
 The FedEx Corporation's freight companies are planning to increase rates 5.9 percent next month, amid higher costs for service centers, safety programs and World Wide Web based data systems. The move, effective Aug. 6, comes one week after Yellow Freight System, a unit of the Yellow Corporation, said it would raise trucking rates 4.9 percent on Aug. 1, defying the nation's slow economy. FedEx said the rates will increase at its less-than-truckload carriers Viking Freight, based in San Jose, Calif., and American Freightways, based in Harrison, Ark., which FedEx acquired in February for about $1.2 billion.

HEADLINE: U.S. Won't Block China's Bid for Olympics 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10 

 BODY:
The Bush administration, uncertain that it could effectively oppose China's bid for the 2008 Olympics, has decided to remain silent on the issue. But in doing so, it has come to believe that there could be advantages for the United States if Beijing prevails, officials said today.
 A victory for Beijing in the vote, to be held by the International Olympic Committee on Friday in Moscow, could cause the Chinese government to hesitate to use military force against Taiwan in the coming years, and could encourage an improvement in its human rights behavior, a senior administration official said. 
 In some ways the memory of the boycott of the 1980 Moscow Olympics hangs over the administration's calculations. Policy makers suggest that the prize of the Olympic Games and the fear of a boycott, similar to the one called by President Carter after the Soviet Union's invasion of Afghanistan in 1979, would probably ride high in the minds of Chinese leaders. 
"Clearly the Chinese leadership and people put enormous store in not just being awarded the Olympics but in showcasing China," an administration official said. "The last thing they would want is to jeopardize the Olympics in the way the Soviets did in the wake of Afghanistan." 
Bush officials acknowledge that Beijing's oft-stated goal of reuniting Taiwan with the mainland -- separated since the civil war of the 1940's -- is more important to the Chinese government than the Olympics. But they also say that being chosen for the 2008 Games could put a brake on any drastic action. "The Olympics is a factor on the side of restraint," the senior official said. 
Taiwan supports Beijing's bid, apparently as a way of buying time in the standoff between the two. 
The administration has argued that it is taking a neutral position on the host country, on the ground that the United States government has no vote on the International Olympic Committee. But the White House could make its displeasure known if it chose to, should Beijing be selected. 
Among the considerations in not voicing American opposition, officials said, was the fear of further stirring up Chinese nationalism.
After strained relations with China in the administration's early months, the White House is now trying to set the stage for President Bush's trip to Shanghai in October for the annual meeting of Asian and Pacific leaders. Mr. Bush plans to go on to Beijing, and the form and substance of that visit will be negotiated this month when Secretary of State Colin L. Powell makes his first trip to China. 
So, public opposition to China's bid for the Olympics would sour the atmosphere -- with no notable gain -- at a moment when the administration is intent on improving relations.
Yet the administration's willingness to go along with Beijing on the Games also carries some peril. If China is awarded the Olympics, any objectionable behavior would probably bring calls from some conservatives for a boycott, calls that would present a Republican administration with a difficult choice. 
But administration officials played that possibility down today, saying Beijing's conduct would have to be "egregious," as one official put it, to gather enough momentum for a boycott. 
The White House has been helped in its low-key approach by the muting of voices on Capitol Hill.
The most vocal critic has been a Democrat, Representative Tom Lantos of California, the ranking member of the International Relations Committee and a vigorous advocate of human rights. In the Senate, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, has said it would be counterproductive for the administration to try to interfere with the choice of the Olympics city. 
A Senate resolution calling for a rejection of Beijing on human rights grounds has been bottled up in committee by Mr. Biden and will not be voted on before the decision on Friday in Moscow.
The administration's professed neutrality has also been helped by a split among human rights groups.
While Amnesty International is opposed to holding the Olympics in Beijing, other groups, like the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights and Human Rights Watch, have taken a middle-of-the-road position, urging the Olympics committee to monitor China's human rights behavior before and during the games.
In developing the theme that a victory for Beijing was not all bad, Bush administration officials also say the role of host would encourage China to concentrate on its most pressing domestic concern, economic growth.
"They need a decade of economic stability," said one senior Bush official. "China wants to calm things down. In this sense, the Olympics is very good for China; it will put them on their best behavior and will force domestic change."
In contrast to the Bush administration, the European Parliament passed a resolution last week opposing Beijing's bid, citing abuses of human rights. 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 12, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the Bush administration's view of China's bid for the 2008 Olympics misstated the stance of Amnesty International. It is not opposed to the Olympics being held there; it takes no position on the question.

HEADLINE: Alternative Bill Attracts Some Minority Support 

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10 

 BODY:
To its supporters, a bill offered by the House Republican leadership to rewrite the nation's campaign finance laws is a common-sense alternative to legislation that would ban unrestricted soft-money donations to the national parties.
 To the supporters of broad campaign finance overhaul, the alternative, written by Representative Bob Ney of Ohio, seems designed to divide the coalition of House members who have voted in the past for campaign finance overhaul. 
 The choice between the two bills is at the heart of this week's campaign debate in the House, and few of the lawmakers who will lead the debate on the House floor are willing to predict the outcome of final votes. It is not clear which bill, if either, will pass. 
"It's a cliffhanger, but we have picked up tremendous steam in the last week," said Mr. Ney, whose bill is being cosponsored by a Democrat, Representative Albert R. Wynn of Maryland. "I'm optimistically cautious."
Mr. Ney (whose name rhymes with hay), has found support among black and Hispanic supporters who are wary of a blanket ban on soft-money fund-raising, which they say has proved useful in get-out-the-vote and voter-registration projects. Mr. Wynn, the bill's co-sponsor, heads the campaign finance task force of the Congressional Black Caucus.
The core of the broader bill, sponsored in the House by Representatives Christopher Shays, Republican of Connecticut, and Martin T. Meehan, Democrat of Massachusetts, is the ban on soft money, the unregulated, unrestricted contributions to national party committees that can be made by corporations, unions and wealthy individuals. In April, the Senate passed a soft-money ban as part of the McCain-Feingold bill.
Soft-money contributions rose to nearly $500 million in the last election, double the total in the 1996 campaign and more than 10 times the total in 1988, when soft-money fund-raising began in earnest because of a loophole in the federal election law.
The Shays-Meehan bill, which is similar to McCain-Feingold, would also place strict new limits on political advertising in the final weeks before an election.
The Republican leaders of the House last month came up with an alternative, the legislation sponsored by Mr. Ney, chairman of the House Administration Committee.
Mr. Ney's bill would not end soft money but would, according to its supporters, end the worst abuses of the system by capping the donations. 
Under the legislation, an individual donor could give an annual maximum of $75,000 to each of the six national political party fund-raising committees. That would allow a total of $450,000 a year if a donor wanted to give the maximum to both parties.
The bill would place far fewer limits on political advertising just before an election than would the Shays-Meehan bill, although it would require the public disclosure of the amount of money spent on the ads and the names of the officers of the group paying for them.
The two bills differ sharply on limits on so-called hard money, the regulated donations that unlike soft money can be directly used to aid individual political candidates.
Current law allows an individual donor to make total hard-money contributions of up to $50,000 to candidates and parties during a two-year election cycle.
Under the Shays-Meehan bill, the total would be raised to $75,000. Under Mr. Ney's bill, an individual donor could give many times that amount of hard money.
According to an analysis by Common Cause and Democracy 21, groups that have endorsed the Shays-Meehan bill, the Ney bill would allow total hard-money contributions of $435,000 in a two-year election cycle, with the money divided among individual candidates, political action committees and the six national party fund-raising committees. (The Democrats and Republicans have separate fund-raising committees for House candidates, Senate candidates and for the party organization, for a total of six committees.)
Opponents see the Ney bill as a move to split the bipartisan coalition of House members who voted for soft-money bans in both 1998 and 1999 but who now worry that a ban would limit their ability to raise money for re-election.
But Mr. Ney said that his bill "places reasonable limits on national political party soft money and requires disclosure of -- but does not restrict -- spending on issue ads."

Individual contributions to national parties would increase to $37,500 per year, from $25,000 currently. All these amounts would be indexed for inflation. NEY-WYNNWould leave limit on individual contributions at $1,000 for all federal candidates, and would index it for inflation. NEY-WYNNWould not be restricted, although groups that ran advertisements mentioning a federal candidate and reaching his or her electorate within 120 days of any election would have to disclose its officers and the amount spent on the advertisement within 24 hours.(Sources: Congressional Quarterly; Congressional Research Service)

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Outside the Box

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
During last year's campaign, George W. Bush solemnly pledged that his tax cuts would not come at the expense of future retirees, that the reserve the Social Security system was accumulating to help it pay benefits to the baby boomers would be kept in a "lockbox" -- that is, that Social Security surpluses would not be used to cover deficits in the rest of the budget.
 Ever since Mr. Bush was sworn in, however, it has been apparent that he takes some of his promises more seriously than others. And so no sooner were big tax cuts for the rich in the bag -- an event followed, with breathtaking speed, by the revelation that revenue projections are in free fall -- than administration officials suddenly discovered that the lockbox is a silly idea. Here's what Mitch Daniels, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said last weekend: "There is no box, there is no mattress. Paul O'Neill doesn't have a hole in the backyard where this money goes. . . . What's unfair is to mislead the American people into thinking this money's in a box somewhere. It isn't. That box has nothing but promissory notes in it." (Thanks to Joshua Micah Marshall for that quote.) 
 Clearly, Mr. Daniels knows that because of the tax cut Mr. Bush will soon break his promise to protect the Social Security surplus. (I could have told you that would happen eventually. In fact, I did. But the truth is coming out ahead of schedule.) And he probably also knows that, administration claims to the contrary, the budget shortfall is not just a temporary consequence of the slumping economy. So now he needs to play down the significance of that breach of promise. 
The lockbox is, of course, not a literal box of cash. It is a rule, similar in spirit to the spending caps that conservatives love to impose, whose purpose is to protect politicians from temptation.
The need for the lockbox arises from two crucial facts about the federal budget. First, that budget is dominated by the retirement programs, Social Security and Medicare -- loosely speaking, the post-cold-war federal government is a big pension fund that also happens to have an army. Second, a decade from now the population served by those programs will explode, as the baby-boom generation reaches retirement age.
Because of those facts, merely balancing the federal budget would be a deeply irresponsible policy -- because that would leave us unprepared for the demographic deluge, with no alternative once it arrives except to raise taxes and slash benefits. To ease the burden we should run large surpluses for the next decade -- surpluses that will pay off the federal debt, and perhaps help purchase assets to back promised payments. 
If politicians were saints, we could count on them to run the needed surpluses without imposing a rigid rule. But in the real world politicians need an artificial backbone. And hence the concept of the lockbox. The Social Security system is currently taking in more money than it pays out; the lockbox says that this part of the overall budget surplus is not available for tax cuts or spending increases. 
Now economists who have examined the long-run U.S. fiscal situation uniformly find that even with this rule, tax increases or reductions in benefits will still be needed when the boomers retire. So maintaining the lockbox is not a high standard; indeed, a minimum standard would also put the surplus of the Medicare hospital insurance fund in the box.
The real problem with the lockbox is that it is too easily evaded -- that politicians can use creative accounting to get around it. And that is exactly what the Bush administration has done: its tax plan is a Rube Goldberg device of delayed provisions, expiring provisions, hidden costs, etc., all designed to preserve the illusion that Mr. Bush is keeping his promise to protect Social Security. It is a testament to how deeply irresponsible the plan really is that despite all this effort Mr. Daniels now feels the need to tell us that the lockbox is meaningless. 
So yes, it is crude and naive to picture Mr. Bush stealing money from the piggy bank and giving it to his rich friends. Refined, sophisticated analysts know that what he has actually done is to undermine America's fiscal integrity in order to provide big tax breaks to his rich friends. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
The Interpublic Group will revamp now that it is the world's largest agency company.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
IN what may be the largest reorganization on Madison Avenue, the Interpublic Group of Companies is being made over as it becomes the world's biggest agency company.
 The reorganization of Interpublic, based in New York, affects 60,000 employees who work on accounts with billings estimated at $68 billion. It comes less than three weeks after the completion of Interpublic's estimated $1.68 billion acquisition of True North Communications in Chicago. That deal made Interpublic first in worldwide billings and revenue as it leapfrogged the WPP Group in London. 
 The changes are centered on a realignment of Interpublic into four principal worldwide divisions. Several top executives assume new duties, several familiar agency names disappear through mergers and several giant new shops are formed in specialized services like public relations and media buying. 
"This is a significant change in how we need to be put together to ensure growth for clients and, therefore, growth for us," John J. Dooner Jr., chairman and chief executive at Interpublic, said in a telephone interview yesterday.
"The True North acquisition became the final piece in the puzzle to allow us to do this," he said.
In some instances, however, the revamping does not go as far as was speculated in trade publications. For instance, there is no widespread rollup of smaller agencies to form centralized regional shops; almost all the smaller local agencies will operate as autonomous units.
The realignment was in the works for nine months, a lifetime to the advertising industry as the economic slowdown, combined with the dot-com meltdown, substantially altered the environment in which Interpublic and its competitors like WPP and the Omnicom Group operate.
As a result, the stakes are far higher for Interpublic than they would have been, and not only because Interpublic has twice since March reduced the estimates it provides to analysts on future earnings.
"O.K., it's a tough climate, we accept that," said Michael J. Russell Jr., who follows agency stocks for Morgan Stanley in New York. "But fool me once, shame on you; fool me twice, what's going on here?
"It's not, 'Show me,' as in I don't think you can do it," he added. "It's more like, 'Make us believe again.' "
Interpublic's stock is well off its 52-week high of $47.44. It fell 14.6 percent on June 15 when management warned analysts that spending cutbacks by clients would cause second-quarter earnings to fall short of estimates. The shares closed yesterday at $29.56, down 19 cents.
"What's past is past and what's future is exciting," said David Bell, the former chairman and chief executive at True North, who is now a vice chairman at Interpublic and will lead one of the four new principal units, named the Partnership.
"This is the best, most expedient way for Interpublic to chart its future," Mr. Bell, 58, said in an interview.
The Partnership will be formed primarily from the Lowe Group, which was one of Interpublic's three operating units before the reorganization. With billings estimated at more than $20 billion and about 17,000 employees, the Partnership will include the advertising agencies Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide and Lowe Health Care; the direct marketing agency Draft Worldwide; the public relations agency Golin/ Harris International; the sports marketing agency Octagon; and the media services agency Initiative Media Worldwide.
In addition, 11 other advertising agencies will report to Interpublic through the Partnership, some from True North, like the New York office of what had been the Bozell Group; Springer & Jacoby in Hamburg, Germany; Stein Rogan & Partners in New York; and Tierney Communications in Philadelphia. The rest come from Interpublic, including Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis; Dailey & Associates in Los Angeles; Deutsch in New York; the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va.; Mullen in Wenham, Mass.; and Suissa Miller in Los Angeles.
The Partnership will be overseen by a management committee headed by Mr. Bell; there are to be no formal titles. Other senior partners include Donny Deutsch, chief executive at Deutsch; Howard Draft, chief executive at Draft; Rich Jernstedt, chief executive at Golin/Harris; Jerry Judge, chief executive at Lowe Lintas; and Louis Schultz, chief executive at Initiative.
Contrary to reports in trade publications, Sir Frank Lowe, who had been chief executive at the Lowe Group, will not be chairman of the Partnership, as there will be no such title. Nor, it turns out now, will he be a member of the management committee. He will, however, continue as chairman at Lowe Lintas and chief executive at Octagon and, said Barry R. Linksy, executive vice president for planning and business development at Interpublic, "he will continue to contribute his creative expertise and his relationship with key clients" to the Partnership.
Just as Sir Frank's absence on the committee may raise eyebrows, so, too, may Mr. Deutsch's presence. Since he sold his agency last fall to Interpublic for an estimated $265 million in stock, there have been persistent reports that he would be tapped for a major management role in the reorganization. Although the leaders of the 10 other advertising agencies aligned with the Partnership will not report to Mr. Deutsch, he is to "represent their interests" on the committee, Mr. Linksy said.
Many of the agencies that belonged to True North are being grouped in a division called the FCB Group, after the FCB Worldwide unit of True North. Brendan Ryan, who was chairman and chief executive at FCB Worldwide, becomes chairman and chief executive at the FCB Group, which will have about 10,000 employees and $11 billion to $12 billion in billings.
Mr. Ryan, 58, praised what he described as the benefits of being supported by "the broad shoulders of a big, terrific company with its best years coming up right now."
The FCB Group includes former True North holdings like Foote, Cone & Belding, the advertising agency recently known as FCB Worldwide; FCBi, an interactive and direct marketing agency; R/GA, for Web design and development; and Marketing Drive, for integrated marketing. TN Media, the True North media buying agency with which FCB Worldwide worked, will disappear into Initiative Media.
Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich., also previously part of Interpublic, will report through the FCB Group, as will Weber Shandwick Worldwide, the public relations agency being formed by the merger of Weber Shandwick, an Interpublic agency, with BSMG Worldwide, a True North agency.
The merger, effective on Sept. 30, will create the largest public relations agency in billings, with an estimated $500 million in revenue; there will be 3,500 employees in 74 cities in 19 countries.
"We'll be a leader in government relations, high technology, financial relations and entertainment," said Larry Weber, who had been chief executive at Weber Shandwick and will relinquish that post in the merger to Harris Diamond, chief executive at BSMG. Jack Leslie, chairman at BSMG, will be chairman of the merged Weber Shandwick.
Mr. Leslie and Mr. Diamond will report to Mr. Weber in his new role as chairman and chief executive at the third principal Interpublic division, Advanced Marketing Services, formerly the Allied Communications Group, where Mr. Weber, 46, was also chairman and chief executive.
Advanced Marketing Services, with billings of $11 billion to $12 billion and about 10,000 employees, will be composed of agencies in three fields, Mr. Weber said: "constituency management, a fancy name for public relations; marketing intelligence, like NFO, the leading market research company; and specialized marketing services" like Jack Morton Worldwide, for event marketing, and the New America Strategies Group, a True North unit devoted to multicultural marketing.
The fourth principal division is the McCann-Erickson World Group, which Mr. Dooner headed before becoming the top leader at Interpublic. This division will see the least change from the reorganization. The World Group, with billings estimated at $25 billion and about 23,000 employees, will continue to be headed by Jim Heekin, as chairman and chief executive. It will continue to be composed of units like McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, Torre Lazur Health Care Worldwide, the Universal McCann Worldwide media services agency and the FutureBrand identity consulting company.
Two former True North agencies, Avrett Free & Ginsberg in New York and Temerlin McClain in Irving, Tex., will report through the World Group, along with Interpublic agencies like Austin Kelley and Fitzgerald & Company in Atlanta; Campbell Mithun in Minneapolis; Gotham in New York; and Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston.

HEADLINE: Democrats Say Bush's Tax Cuts Jeopardize Military Spending 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10 

 BODY:
Three of the Senate's most powerful Democrats warned today that President Bush's tax cut had made it virtually impossible to increase military spending significantly in 2002 without slashing other programs or dipping into surplus Medicare funds. 
 Senators Carl Levin, chairman of the Armed Services Committee; Kent Conrad, chairman of the Budget Committee, and Tom Daschle, the majority leader, said the Bush administration must find reductions in military or other programs or consider scaling back the tax cut, if it wanted to increase Pentagon spending by $18.4 billion next year. 
 "If you want $18 billion for defense, how are you going to pay for it?" Mr. Daschle said in a news conference in the Capitol. "How are you going to do it without using Medicare and Social Security trust funds? We're awaiting the answer." 
Though their remarks focused on just the military part of the $2 trillion federal budget, the Democratic leaders seemed to be signaling their broader political and fiscal strategy for the budget fight with the White House. 
That strategy seems intended to portray the administration and its Republican allies in Congress as favoring military spending and tax cuts over popular social programs for health care, education, agriculture and the elderly. 
The Democrats have also sought to avoid being cast as budget busters. Today, for example, Democratic leaders did not try to increase a $6.5 billion supplement to the 2001 budget, almost all of which will go to the Pentagon. The Senate tonight overwhelmingly passed the supplemental spending bill on a vote of 98 to 1. In past years, both parties have attached billions in favored projects to such budget supplements. 
Underlying the Democratic approach is the assertion that President Bush's signature legislative accomplishment, the $1.35 trillion tax cut, when combined with a softening economy, has sharply reduced the size of the surplus. Because of the shrinking surplus, the Democrats contend, the government would have to spend $42 billion of surplus Medicare and Social Security funds in 2002 to pay for the administration's proposed budget. 
Republicans dispute those estimates, saying that the surplus will be large enough to pay for Mr. Bush's entire 2002 budget request. The White House also rejects the idea that there is a Medicare surplus, arguing that the program is essentially in deficit. They contend that the Democrats are simply trying to find ways to accuse the White House of harming a popular program. 
"Regarding defense, we felt this is a much-needed increase," said Chris Ullman, a spokesman for the Office of Management and Budget. 
The proposed Pentagon budget for 2002 would be $18.4 billion above what the Bush administration initially recommended in February, and $33 billion more than President Bill Clinton's final military budget. 
Mr. Levin called today for scaling back a part of the tax cut that went to upper-income taxpayers to provide resources for basic military programs, like housing for the troops, maintenance and training. 
"I just don't see any alternative," Mr. Levin said in an interview. "Either you dip into the trust funds, or you go back into deficit spending, or you take money from education or health care. I don't see any other alternative except to revisit the upper-income tax breaks." 
Senator Conrad said the idea of rolling back the tax cut should be considered in the budget talks, though he stopped short of endorsing it. But he said he would oppose any increases in military spending that required spending surplus Medicare or Social Security funds. 
"For 2002, I think if the administration wants to spend more money, they have to come up with a way to pay for it, whether spending cuts or new revenue," he said.
The skirmishing over the budget came on a day when the four service chiefs and four service secretaries told a Senate hearing on Capitol Hill that Mr. Bush's proposed 2002 budget, despite containing the largest increase in defense spending since the 1980's, would not meet their needs. 
"The budget will put us on the road to recovery in some categories, such as military pay, housing allowances and health care," said Army Secretary Thomas White. "Secondly, it will start an improvement but leave us short of our goals in other areas, such as restoring our deteriorating infrastructure. And third, unfortunately, there will continue to be shortfalls in a number of critical areas, such as modernization and recapitalization of the existing force." 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 12, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about assertions by Senate Democrats that President Bush's tax cut jeopardizes military spending referred incorrectly in some copies to the surplus Medicare and Social Security funds that Democrats say the government would have to spend in 2002 to pay for the administration's proposed budget. It is $42 billion, not $62 billion.

HEADLINE: Bush Drug Plan Calls for Using Discount Cards 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10 

 BODY:
President Bush will call later this week for major changes in Medicare, and as an interim step wants to encourage the elderly to acquire drug discount cards so they can immediately get lower prices at pharmacies, federal officials said today.
 Such cards are issued by "buyers' clubs" organized by private companies that negotiate discounts with drug manufacturers and pharmacies. Administration officials said they were exploring ways to promote the cards' use by quick presidential action, without a need for immediate legislation or federal spending. 
 One such discount plan is run by Merck-Medco and the Reader's Digest Association. Merck executives emphasized that their plan was not insurance and was not a substitute for proposed Medicare drug benefits. But, they said, it does enable people to get discounts of 10 percent to 30 percent or more at any of 40,000 participating pharmacies, for a membership fee of $25 a year. 
White House officials are still trying to work out precisely how the government would promote such plans and encourage enrollment by Medicare beneficiaries.
Mr. Bush intends to set forth a detailed set of principles for Medicare legislation at a White House event on Thursday. The White House sent invitations today to members of Congress, consumer groups, pharmacists and health care providers. Mark B. McClellan, a health economist on the White House staff, met today with about a dozen House Republicans to seek their support.
Federal officials said Mr. Bush hoped to seize the initiative on the issue and shape Congressional debate just as the Senate Finance Committee is about to begin writing legislation to update Medicare, created 36 years ago, and add drug benefits. 
White House officials said Mr. Bush would emphasize that any new government drug benefits must be part of a comprehensive bill to revamp Medicare. One of the president's goals is to expand the role of private health plans; these include health maintenance organizations, which now provide care to slightly more than 14 percent of the 40 million beneficiaries.
Medicare H.M.O.'s typically provide some drug benefits to their members. But about one-third of Medicare beneficiaries do not have any insurance to cover prescription drugs outside hospitals.
Mr. Bush made "Medicare reform" and prescription drug benefits a central theme of his presidential campaign. In his first budget, he sought $156 billion for the purpose over the next 10 years. In response, Democrats said it would cost at least $300 billion over 10 years to provide minimally adequate drug benefits.
Democrats in Congress say they are open to modest changes in the management of Medicare, to increase competition among suppliers of goods and services. But they say they will not accept any changes that put financial pressure on the elderly to join H.M.O.'s.
Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the Senate's leading Democratic strategist on health care issues, said: "It's going to become increasingly apparent through the summer that 'Medicare reform' is not going to take place. But there will be a real attempt to pass a good, effective prescription drug program."
Indeed, Senate Democrats working on Medicare legislation are now heavily focused on adding a prescription drug benefit. The leading proposal, offered by Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, would provide drug coverage as a standard part of the Medicare benefit package. The Democratic majority on the Senate Finance Committee is expected to use Mr. Graham's legislation as the centerpiece of a broader measure that the committee could approve before the August recess.
The idea of drug discount cards may well be a highlight of the White House event this Thursday. Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut, said such cards made sense as a way to "give seniors immediate relief." 
But many drugstores and pharmacists adamantly oppose the cards. Indeed, the National Association of Chain Drug Stores, which represents companies like CVS and Rite-Aid, tried to persuade the Bush administration to drop its idea.
The association's president, Craig L. Fuller, who was White House chief of staff to Mr. Bush's father, said, "A discount card unfairly places the burden for reducing drug prices on the backs of retail pharmacies," requiring drugstores to lower their prices without necessarily affecting the wholesale prices charged by manufacturers. Pharmacists say the manufacturer's charge accounts for more than 70 percent of the retail price of a prescription, on average.
Gov. Gary Locke of Washington State, a Democrat, created a drug discount program for people 55 and older in the summer of last year, while he was running for re-election. A group of pharmacists filed suit, and in May a state judge stopped the program, saying the governor exceeded his authority when he created it by executive order.
Administration officials said Mr. Bush supported these principles for overhauling Medicare: 
*The private sector should play a major role in delivering drug benefits and managing drug costs, but the federal government must provide substantial subsidies for all beneficiaries.
*Elderly people should be able to choose the company that, under the administration's plan for an overhaul, would manage their pharmacy benefits. No company should have a monopoly; there should be at least two "pharmacy benefit managers" in each region. 
*The federal government should set an overall limit on the out-of-pocket pharmaceutical expenses of Medicare beneficiaries.
*People content with their existing Medicare coverage could keep it. The government would pay employers to continue drug coverage as part of retiree health benefits.
*The government should, for the first time, make payments to H.M.O.'s to cover the cost of providing drug benefits. Congress should make other changes to reverse the exodus of H.M.O.'s from Medicare. (In the last three years, managed care plans have dropped more than 1.6 million Medicare beneficiaries.)
On Wednesday, the House of Representatives is to vote on a bill that would allow imports of low-priced prescription drugs. Mr. Bush supported such legislation in the campaign, but now the White House is opposed, saying the bill could increase imports of "unsafe, unapproved or counterfeit drugs."

HEADLINE: To Expand Trade 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Robert M. Dunn Jr. ("Mexico's Growing Trade Advantage," Op-Ed, July 5) recognizes that trade is an essential means to support economic growth. 
Unfortunately, the post-World War II consensus on the value of expanded trade has been shaken, as is evident from Congress's failure to renew trade promotion authority. 
 There are 134 free trade agreements in force around the world, but the United States is a party to only two. American businesses are disadvantaged; their products and services are subject to tariffs that have been eliminated for foreign competitors.
Congress has a critical role: passing trade promotion authority legislation so that we can expand opportunities for American businesses and workers.

HAROLD MCGRAW III
New York, July 6, 2001

The writer is chairman, Emergency Committee for American Trade, and chairman and chief executive of The McGraw-Hill Companies.

HEADLINE: Ford Is Changing the Way It Rates Work of Managers 

BYLINE:  By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company told employees on Tuesday that it was changing a performance ranking system for managers that had become the subject of a growing number of lawsuits.
 In a message sent to Ford employees, Jacques A. Nasser, the company's chief executive, said that Ford was altering its year-old performance evaluation system that graded managers and supervisors according to a letter-based ranking system. 
 Under the system, those who received the highest grade, an A, were the most likely to receive raises and promotions while those who repeatedly received the lowest grade, a C, faced the possibility of dismissal. 
Since the institution of the system, known as the performance management process, at least six lawsuits have been filed against Ford asserting that the system was unfairly used to force out older employees and specifically white males in favor of younger and minority employees. Two of those lawsuits are seeking class-action status.
Anna Marie Gatteri, a Ford spokeswoman, said yesterday that the changes in the ranking system were not made in response to the lawsuits. And Mr. Nasser also noted in his memo that the performance system had "nothing to do with age or diversity."
"It has everything to do with inspiring the best performance," he said.
Under the old system, at least 10 percent of all employees were to have received a C. Earlier this year, that benchmark was lowered to 5 percent, Ms. Gatteri said.
Under the new system, Ford's 18,000 managers and supervisors are graded with three designations: top achiever, achiever and improvement required. Ms. Gatteri said there is no longer any minimum percentage of employees who have to receive the lowest ranking.
Lawsuits against Ford have asserted that the old ranking system was discriminatory because it encouraged managers to give older workers low grade's because a manger's overall performance was based, in part, on his ability to diversify Ford's work force. The company has said that it wants to diversify its management ranks but that it does not have quotas.
James Fett, a lawyer in Dearborn, Mich., who represents plaintiffs in some of the lawsuits against Ford, said the changes in the performance evaluation system were a "step in the right direction."
He said, however, that he did not plan to drop the lawsuits and that Ford had yet to make any offers to compensate what he described as the "economic and emotional damage" caused to his clients by the ranking system.

HEADLINE: Profit for Harley-Davidson 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, July 11 

 BODY:
 Harley-Davidson, the motorcycle maker, said today that its second-quarter profit topped Wall Street expectations as the nation's economic woes failed to hurt demand for its distinctive bikes. 
Milwaukee-based Harley-Davidson reported its second-quarter profit rose 27 percent to $115.6 million, or 38 cents a share, compared with $90.6 million, or 29 cents a share, a year earlier. Wall Street analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call expected earnings of 35 cents a share. Sales increased 12.7 percent to $850.9 million from $754.9 million a year earlier. Shipments of motorcycles grew 12.8 percent.

HEADLINE: Aetna to Close Some Unprofitable H.M.O.'s 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Aetna Inc., the nation's largest health insurer, said yesterday that it would close or sell numerous unprofitable H.M.O.'s and expand its business with self-insured companies and medium-size employers in an attempt to improve profitability.
 Aetna reported a $36.6 million operating loss for the first quarter of this year. 
 In a memorandum sent to all employees yesterday, Dr. John W. Rowe, the chief executive of the company, said Aetna planned to reduce the percentage of health maintenance organizations in which Aetna takes the risk for any losses. 
The company, based in Hartford, said it covered about 9 million of its 18.3 million members in these risk-bearing H.M.O.'s as of March 31. Aetna plans to shed up to one million members of unprofitable health plans this year. But for self-insured employers covering their own risks, Aetna will continue to offer networks of doctors and hospitals operating under H.M.O. rules. 
Dr. Rowe has said that demand for H.M.O.'s will continue, and it may increase if the economy weakens as employers and consumers struggle with rising health costs. 
"The H.M.O. isn't dead, it's in the bushes," he said in a recent interview. "For some segment of the population, it's still the best way to reduce medical costs."
Aetna has already begun unloading unprofitable H.M.O.'s in California, and several southern states. Last month it said it was closing health maintenance organizations with 44,000 members in 11 counties in central California and H.M.O.'s in Macon and Augusta, Ga., with a total of 25,000 members. Aetna has also sold H.M.O.'s with 75,000 members in St. Louis and Louisiana to Coventry Health Plans Inc.
In another move to increase profits, Aetna asked Connecticut regulators to approve premium increases averaging 18.1 percent for H.M.O. members and 32 percent for prescription drug plans in the state. The company also requested approval last week for changes in its pricing formulas so it could tie charges for larger groups of H.M.O. members to the group's costs in the previous period.
Kenneth L. Sperling, a health care analyst at Hewitt Associates, said Aetna was seeking the change so it could reduce premiums for employers with relatively healthy groups who might otherwise switch to another insurer. Aetna could raise premiums for groups with higher expenses to cover costs or drive them away, he said. 
In his memorandum, Dr. Rowe said Aetna would "refocus our strategy" for small business customers to steer them to more profitable products and retain their business, especially in markets where the company has a large market share and can use that power to keep its costs down.
