HEADLINE: Translating Union Into Khmer; 
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. Organizes in Cambodia

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia 

 BODY:
The black clouds of an early monsoon were piling up outside as Jason Judd of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. paced before a classroom of local union leaders and labor organizers, lecturing on what it takes to force garment factory managers to the negotiating table.
 "How do I get recognition?" he asked in a voice honed over years of organizing in the Deep South -- part Sunday sermon, part half-time pep talk. "How can I get it?" 
 The class hesitated but didn't really need to hear the translation to know how to respond. "Omnaich!" they replied. Power. 
"I didn't hear you," he said.
"Omnaich!" they yelled back in unison.
"If you can't say it," Mr. Judd said, "you can't have it."
Phnom Penh may seem far afield for America's umbrella labor organization. But the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has become active here and Cambodia has emerged as a test case in perhaps the most contentious issue on the international trade agenda today: establishing a floor under labor conditions in developing countries.
Cambodia is at the center of the debate thanks to a landmark 1999 agreement that makes it the only country whose garment exports to the United States are dependent on factories here living up to an internationally recognized labor code.
In addition to complying with a new labor law that lays out basic rules for health and safety on the factory floor, Cambodia is also required to allow unions to operate, to eliminate child and forced labor, and to work to prevent discrimination.
Supporters of the Cambodian arrangement, which is up for review later this year by the Bush administration, hope that it will set a precedent for future trade agreements by demonstrating that establishing such minimum labor conditions can work to the benefit of all.
In most developing countries, however, political leaders are adamantly opposed to any linking of worker standards to trade agreements, arguing that imposing rules from outside threatens to undermine the competitive advantage they need to support their own economic development.
Here in impoverished Cambodia, where the garment industry is the biggest export earner, the trade agreement has garnered a more mixed reaction. Many hope that submitting to American sensibilities will turn "Made in Cambodia" into a sign of merit to consumers. Yet they also fear that efforts like Mr. Judd's to make workers' voices heard will only drive manufacturers to countries like China and Vietnam, where conditions may be worse but the glare of scrutiny less severe.
"We may become a victim of our own openness," said Sok Siphana, secretary of state at Cambodia's Ministry of Commerce.
At the same time, the standards do not necessarily speak to some of the most critical conflicts within the industry, like those over pay and forced overtime. And despite the agreement, unions have made only limited gains in organizing garment factories in Cambodia. While they operate more openly than in many other poor countries, they have been stymied by fierce opposition from factory owners, most of whom operate on thin margins and are often squeezed themselves when dealing with the multinational apparel merchants.
Mr. Judd, the American organizer, arrived here in February in hopes of improving the situation for workers. With funding from the State Department's Agency for International Development, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s American Center for International Solidarity he runs here now offers seminars on organizing that draw not only union leaders, but also human rights groups and members of Cambodia's influential Buddhist clergy.
"We're helping these new unions to get stronger," he said. "We're helping them to build independent and democratic unions."
Cambodia's apparel industry was created almost overnight in 1996 by a bilateral trade agreement with the United States that cut tariffs on most Cambodian goods to 4 percent from 17 percent. Flights to Phnom Penh soon filled with investors from China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore eager to build factories.
From seven garment factories in 1994, there are now roughly 300, employing 170,000 people, mostly women. The industry earned $965 million last year, three-quarters of it exporting to American companies like Gap, Nike, Levi Strauss and Sears, Roebuck.
Though it means 11-hour days of monotonous toil six days a week, a job in a garment factory is highly coveted. In a good month, with overtime, an average worker can take home $70, three times the national average. Workers often pay up to $50 in bribes just to land a garment job.
In 1997, a violent coup drove most investors and aid agencies away from Phnom Penh, but not the garment factories. The same year, Cambodia adopted its new labor code, written with help from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the International Labor Organization.
Workers were quick to test their new rights. After refusing to work on a Sunday, Doung Sotheavy, now 31, remembers her Singaporean employers calling her into their office to sign a document. The next time she refused to work on a Sunday, the document said, she would resign.
Ms. Doung Sotheavy walked out, exhorting her co-workers to follow. When only a dozen came, she rented a public address system. "If you don't help me this time," she remembers calling to those still inside, "no one will help you next time."
The next day, the factory went on strike. A union was born, one of more than 75 started in the last four years. Last July, garment factory unions won a minimum wage of $45 a month, a first for Cambodia.
The incentive to improve working conditions and permit unions has come from Washington, where in 1998 trade negotiators were preparing to put quotas on fast-growing Cambodian garment imports. Amid pressure from American unions and public opinion, the Clinton administration pushed Cambodia to accept unprecedented conditions: if Washington decided in an annual review that its industry was in "substantial" compliance with Cambodian labor law and international standards, it would raise Cambodia's quota by 14 percent.
At the moment, the agreement is only barely on the Bush administration's radar screen. Few of the officials involved in such a decision are in place yet. "We expect to review this more closely as we get closer to the fall," an administration trade official said.
Condemned by Cambodia's Southeast Asian neighbors as a breach of sovereignty, the agreement has its share of holes. Perhaps the biggest is that it does not specify how Washington should determine whether Cambodia complies. Cambodia's own labor inspectors are poorly trained, and unions complain they are too easily bribed. The United States and Cambodia agreed to pay the International Labor Organization to set up an independent monitoring program, which is just beginning and has not yet made its first assessment.
Government officials, manufacturers and union leaders hope clean bills of health from the I.L.O. will give Cambodia an edge over cheaper labor elsewhere. "People will see the improved situation isn't perfect, perhaps, but good," said Van Sou Ieng, president of the Garment Manufacturers Association. "Then everyone will come to Cambodia and say, 'Give us space. Take our orders,' "
But labor organizers say that inspectors can do only so much. That much was demonstrated last fall, when a British documentary uncovered what it alleged was child labor at a factory routinely visited by inspectors from Gap and Nike. Union leaders and outside groups say that child labor is actually rare in Cambodian garment factories. The biggest problems, they say, center not around such traditional issues as under-age workers, ventilation or fire exits, but on retaliation against union leaders and forced overtime.
Gap says factory managers have tried to foil inspections with falsified payment records. Gap and Nike both pulled out of the factory highlighted in the documentary, citing a variety of uncorrected problems.
"If you're not in there it's hard to make sure that ongoing commitments the factory may have made are sustained," said Todd McKean, global director of compliance at Nike, which has withdrawn entirely from Cambodia as well.
Unions are more reliable watchdogs, organizers contend. And what happens, Mr. Judd asks, when workers decide that the minimum standards enforced by monitors are not enough? "To fight that fight," he said, "they're going to need a union."
Tall, thin and pale, Mr. Judd cuts an incongruous figure in Cambodian labor circles. Now 29, Mr. Judd developed a taste for organizing in 1992 when, as an economics student at Duke University, he helped a group of poor, minority women working the abattoirs of North Carolina's pig and poultry industry get a free clinic.
After a year abroad, he joined the Service Employees International Union in New Orleans, organizing street sweepers, school cafeteria workers and garbage collectors. Last year, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. hired Mr. Judd, who had since moved to Texas, to man its "solidarity center" in Phnom Penh.
Critics of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s actions here and elsewhere say it mostly represents American labor's efforts to protect jobs at home by thwarting low-cost competition from abroad. And they see it as an example of how labor, from the left, and traditional protectionists, from the right, are finding common cause to intervene in foreign countries.
"The circle kind of connects," said Ernest Z. Bower, president of the U.S.-Asean Business Council, which represents private sector interests in Southeast Asia. "They work together to make the yardstick impossible for the Cambodians."
Cambodia's unions seem to need little encouragement. In 1999 alone, they held 76 strikes, according to the United States embassy, most wildcat, some violent.
Such frequent strikes not only jeopardize the industry, Mr. Judd said, they are also a sign of union weakness. "If unions are better organized," he said, "they won't be striking all the time."
The American embassy estimates that no more than 0.2 percent of Cambodia's work force, which is largely rural, is unionized, most of it in garment factories. Of Cambodia's six union groups, labor activists say only one can be considered independent of political or commercial influence.
But even as the various labor federations bicker among themselves, would-be union leaders face greater challenges on the factory floor, where they say managers routinely interfere with organizers, harass members and fire leaders.
A former paratrooper named In Chinda took over the job of running the union at his China-owned factory after the group's president was fired this year. When the managers refused to re-hire his union president, Mr. In Chinda led the workers in a strike. Union leaders were finally invited to negotiate, but managers brought police officers to the meeting to arbitrate.
"I'm here to learn how to make my union stronger," Mr. In Chinda said before sitting down to listen to Mr. Judd.
While many labor activists back home hope that the United States will persuade the W.T.O. to include labor rights as part of trade deals, Mr. Judd sees his work here as a race against time. In 2005, the W.T.O. provision that allows major industrial countries to set garment-import quotas is scheduled to expire, removing the only lever currently available to enforce labor standards.
Developing countries have long sought to eliminate the quotas because they serve to protect apparel makers in the advanced industrial nations. But pessimists say that without country-by-country quotas, apparel makers may simply consolidate in bigger labor markets, like China and Mexico.
Let them, insists Sok Ha -- if companies don't measure up. Ms. Sok Ha, a student of Mr. Judd's, lost her job at one factory after the union she joined pressured the Ministry of Commerce to withdraw its license. 
But that only made her more defiant. Today, she is president of a newly formed federation. "We don't want to close down any factory," she said. "But better to have fewer companies that pay better. We want companies to obey the law more than we want new investment."

HEADLINE: Argentine Debt Creates Fallout That Is Wide 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The fallout from the financial crisis in Argentina was felt outside Latin America yesterday as the dollar fell and the stocks of some American and Spanish banks with exposure there dropped.
 The Brazilian real also fell to its lowest level since it began trading freely in 1999, and some Latin American stock markets declined. 
 "I would just say it is a function of contagion," said David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics in Essex, Conn. "Argentina is sending a shiver through investors' mindset." 
The fear among investors is that Argentina will actually default on its $130 billion of foreign debt or force investors into a restructuring that would reduce what Argentina owes. Argentina had to pay 14 percent interest rates to sell $828 million in three-month bills on Tuesday. And many analysts doubt that the government will be able to cut spending enough to offset the fall in tax revenues, after three years of recession, and leave enough to meet foreign debt payments.
Domingo Cavallo, the economic minister of Argentina, said on Tuesday night that Argentina could not borrow any more and had to reduce its federal government and provincial deficits by $3 billion. Many analysts doubt that such cuts are possible given Argentina's complex politics and the approach of elections in October.
"A lot of negative expectations are now in the air," said Arminio Fraga, the president of the central bank of Brazil, which has been hit the hardest by the fallout from Argentina. "We will see what the future brings." Referring to Argentina, he said, "They themselves have not given up. I understand it is not easy."
Mr. Fraga was in New York to meet with investors in an effort to convince them that Brazil's financial problems are only temporary.
In trading in New York, the dollar fell as the euro rose to 85.91 cents, up from 85.70 cents on Tuesday. The euro rose as high as 86.88 cents during the day. Against the Japanese yen, the dollar fell to 124.36, down from 125.37 yen on Tuesday.
While it may seem odd for the dollar to fall when investors are nervous, it can happen.
First, the dollar has been incredibly strong this year, especially given the slowdown in economic growth in the United States and the six cuts in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve. Secondly, a lot of this strength has come from foreigners, Europeans and Japanese, betting that both the euro and the yen would continue to decline against the dollar.
But these bets on the dollar, Mr. Gilmore said, leave these investors in risky positions from their point of view. So when there is uncertainty in the outlook, reducing their risk a little means selling the dollar to buy back euros or yen. 
The Merval stock index in Argentina fell 2.2 percent after a late day rally reduced its loss for the day. It was down 6 percent Tuesday. The Bolsa index in Mexico dropped 2.2 percent. The Bovespa stock index in Brazil rallied enough to turn an early loss of 1.5 percent into a 1.8 percent gain. The Brazilian real plunged to 2.553 to the dollar, a new low. The Mexican and Chilean pesos also declined.
Besides affecting the dollar, the fallout from Argentina is also reaching American banks that have exposure there and in other emerging markets. In just over two weeks the political and financial crisis in Argentina has worsened enough to send interest rates on three-month bills up to 14 percent from 9.1 percent.
In that same two week period, two of the American banks that have big exposure there, Citibank and J. P. Morgan Chase & Company, have seen their stocks drop. Shares of Citibank's parent, Citigroup, dropped 8.7 percent, and fell 3.1 percent yesterday, to $47.60. J. P. Morgan Chase is off 5.9 percent for the two weeks. The stock rose slightly yesterday, to $42.05.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS; 
Mixed Messages

BYLINE:  By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 11 

 BODY:
President Jiang Zemin of China is scheduled to make a state visit here on Sunday, but Olympic decisions made before he arrives will determine whether his visit will occur in splendid triumph or in bitter defeat.
 Two days before he arrives, on Friday, the International Olympic Committee will determine whether Beijing's bid for the 2008 Summer Games is more deserving than the candidacies of Paris and Toronto. 
 On a practical level, Beijing is favored because many of the 119 I.O.C. delegates seem to believe that the world's most populous nation, one that won 28 gold medals and finished third in the overall medal standing at the Sydney Games, deserves to stage the Olympics.
"I think, this time, we have prepared very well and we are very confident in our bid," said Tu Mingde, co-leader of the Beijing bid and secretary general of the Chinese Olympic Committee. But that assurance is mingled with anxiety. "In a sprint race, there is a gold medal, silver and bronze," he said. "In this race, there is only gold." 
In political terms, there appears to be a feeling among many delegates that the Olympics would accelerate openness in China, just as the awarding of the 1988 Summer Games to Seoul hastened the transition in South Korea from a military dictatorship to a democracy.
"While it may have political problems, in an I.O.C. context Beijing is a good city," said Dick Pound, an influential delegate from Montreal. "We have no basis in that context to discriminate against them."
Still, the delegates have been sent as many as 1,000 e-mail messages apiece by protest groups ranging from Tibetan activists to journalists to those advocating more humane treatment of dogs. Wei Jingsheng, the exiled Chinese dissident now living in the United States, tried to travel to Moscow to protest the Beijing vote but was denied a visa. Today, nine people were detained during a protest by Tibetan activists, including a photographer and an interpreter.
The awarding of the 2008 Games to Beijing would send a message that "the I.O.C. supports authoritarian rule and brutal oppression," Ngavan Gelek, chairman of the Tibetan Culture and Information Center here, said at a news conference this week.
The European Parliament has called for the Games to be denied to Beijing, as have some members of the United States Congress, over such human rights issues as the jailing of Chinese-American scholars, mass executions, the suppression of the Falun Gong spiritual movement and the repression of Tibet.
The Bush administration has remained neutral. Meanwhile, Olympic corporate sponsors like Coca-Cola, McDonald's and General Electric, the corporate parent of NBC, are no doubt eagerly seeking to expand their interests in a Chinese market of 1.3 billion people.
A victory for Beijing would serve as a celebratory prelude to China's expected entry into the World Trade Organization this year. 
But some officials believe that a second consecutive defeat for the city's Olympic bid would amount to an acute loss of face and, some believe, could foster isolationist tendencies inside China.
In some ways, Friday's vote will reflect just how self-confident the I.O.C. feels as it emerges from the damaging Salt Lake City bribery scandal. The delegates, representing 72 countries, are wrestling with a number of questions. Is the I.O.C. secure enough as an organization to gamble on Beijing? Are peasant revolts in rural China a sign that modernity might lead to instability that could threaten the Games? Would the beauty of Paris or the centralized sporting facilities of Toronto be a less risky, more attractive selection?
"In general, there are two schools of thought," said Thomas Bach, a delegate from Germany. "One is, you should not give the Olympic Games to a country until it has fulfilled certain standards of human rights. The other school is that awarding the Games will help open the country, and will put the world looking in for the next seven years."
Anticipating this debate, Chinese bid officials have hired Western public relations experts, and they have avoided threatening talk that failure to secure the Games might lead to a refusal to seek or participate in future Olympics.
Instead, bid officials have concentrated on the possibilities of opening the country and on the merits of the Beijing bid -- strong public and government support, a planned $12 billion environmental program to improve air and water quality and a $20 billion program to greatly expand its expressway system and to build modern sports arenas. The Chinese have also persuaded Olympic officials that they are serious about controlling the use of performance-enhancing drugs; for the Sydney Games, they withheld 27 members of their Olympic team.
Perhaps a sign of Beijing's confidence is that Chinese officials have not felt the need to release political prisoners this time, as they clumsily did before, in an attempt to gain support for their 2000 Olympic bid.
"Last time, the international environment was not very good for Beijing," said Wei Jizhong, leader of the previous Olympic bid, referring to the violent crushing of the student democracy movement in Tiananmen Square in 1989. "This time, I feel differently. We are concentrating on preparations and conditions in the city of Beijing."
The Chinese delegation is being led by Mayor Liu Qi of Beijing, who is reportedly taking language lessons so that he might deliver his final pitch to I.O.C. delegates in English. 
The Chinese have also brought Olympic champions in table tennis, volleyball and rifle shooting to help get out the vote. A film touting Beijing's bid to delegates has been made by the acclaimed director Zhang Yimou. The bid leaders have been eagerly schmoozing in the lobby of the I.O.C. hotel, giving interviews, always ready with a handshake and an apt metaphor.
While he could not say how much the Olympics would open China up, he was certain that the Games would foster change, said Tu, the co-leader of the bid.
"You might buy a carpet this year and silver utensils the next year, but when you invite V.I.P. guests for dinner, you accelerate the pace of your schedule," Tu said. "You might get a carpet next month, mahogany furniture and silver utensils in two months' time."
Wang Wei, the other co-leader of the Beijing bid, said: "The reforms will go on. The difference is that the Games will be a catalyst to accelerate change.'
The I.O.C. is a very independent organization, answerable to no one but itself, and many of the delegates resent being told how they should vote, whether it be by governments or by the news media. 
In 1993, only four years after the Tiananmen Square episode, Beijing led Sydney during several preliminary rounds of voting for the 2000 Olympics before losing by two votes.
Some delegates publicly chafe at critics' suggestions that awarding the Games to Beijing would be similar to allowing Hitler to exploit the 1936 Olympics. They point out that the Berlin Olympics were awarded in 1931, before the Nazis came to power, and that those Games are remembered for the repudiation of the notion of Aryan supremacy by the four-gold-medal performance of Jesse Owens, a black American.
If executions in China are to be an overriding issue, said Alex Gilady, a delegate from Israel, does that mean Dallas should not be allowed to remain a candidate for the 2012 Olympics because Texas also carries out the death penalty?
"Are we saying that only Western countries should apply?" Gilady said. "We can't keep universality in the Olympics, and not give other people a chance to host them."
This does not mean that Beijing is a lock to win. Over concerns about excessive favors, delegates have been barred from visiting the five cities bidding on the 2008 Olympics. 
Instead, members must rely on a written evaluation report and on a final presentation by each city before Friday's vote. As many as half of the delegates have never visited Beijing at any time.
"That might hurt Beijing," said Peter Tallberg, a delegate from Finland. "I have heard about the rapid changes, the move to a market-oriented economic system, but I haven't been able to see it."
Also, about three dozen new members have joined the I.O.C. since the bribery scandal, including athletes and heads of international sporting federations. That could put a premium on sporting facilities over geopolitical statements.
Johann Olav Koss, a delegate from Norway and a former Olympic speedskating champion, said he was concerned with issues like heat, pollution, and whether granting the Games to Beijing would "encourage what's going on there" in terms of human rights abuses.
Still, the mood here seems to be warming toward Beijing. Mitt Romney, head of the Salt Lake Organizing Committee, spoke today of building bridges, not walls, in attempts to communicate with other countries.
"I respect what people say about human rights and Falun Gong, but I have social problems in my own country," said Nat Indrapana, a delegate from Thailand. "Why should we put this particular weight on this country? I don't think they should be excluded."

HEADLINE: Black Caucus Members Find Themselves Courted Heavily in Soft Money Fight 

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11 

 BODY:
Few groups have heard as many kind words as the Congressional Black Caucus has heard this week from advocates of various versions of campaign finance legislation. 
 Today the caucus of 36 Democratic representatives and two nonvoting delegates heard flattering pleas for support from the Democratic leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt (twice), and two Republicans on opposite sides, Representatives Christopher Shays of Connecticut and Bob Ney of Ohio. 
 The kindest words of all may have been those of Mr. Shays, who told caucus members that if his bill to deny soft money, large unregulated contributions from corporations, unions and rich people, to national party groups was defeated, it would not be their fault. He said he told them that instead, "it will be my party that killed it." 
Representative Elijah E. Cummings, Democrat of Maryland, called Mr. Shays "impressive." Mr. Cummings said, "It made us feel a lot better." But even so, he was not persuaded to support the bill, arguing that soft money was the only resource African-Americans could count on for registration and get-out-the-vote drives.
And regardless of the fact that the bill sponsored by Mr. Shays and Representative Martin T. Meehan, Democrat of Massachusetts, is facing greater defections from Republicans who backed it two years ago than from blacks, attention has focused on the caucus to a degree perhaps unknown in its history.
One reason for the focus is that the caucus is generally cohesive and meets regularly, unlike the undecided or wavering Republicans who are harder to fit into a single room. 
Moreover, two years ago, when the Shays-Meehan bill was adopted by the House by a 252-to-177 vote, the caucus supplied 30 aye votes and only two nays. This year, while there is no hard vote count, Democratic leaders have worried about losing as many as half the 36 votes the caucus casts. But those leaders insist they have been making progress, and Representative Harold E. Ford Jr., a Tennessee Democrat who has been working on his caucus colleagues, said this afternoon "at this point there are 10 to 12 still opposed to it."
Some, like Representative Albert R. Wynn, Democrat of Maryland, are backing a bill that Republican leaders are pushing, the measure Mr. Ney advocated to the caucus this afternoon. It limits soft money contributions, but at a level opponents say is too high to mean anything. Under the Ney-Wynn bill, a corporation, union or individual could give each of the six national party committees $75,000 in a year, or a total of $450,000 to a party in a two-year election cycle.
Others oppose both bills because they see no point in curbing soft money. Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina, said "You got to be a little bit touched in the head" to limit soft money when last year Democrats managed to raise about as much of it as Republicans did. "We will never be able to balance the Republicans in hard money," Mr. Clyburn said.
He voted for the Shays-Meehan bill in 1999, but said that dubious Republican election practices last fall had led him to change his mind. "I've grown up a little bit since last November," he said. 
This is not the first time the caucus has found itself at the center of a close legislative fight, though perhaps the first since Republicans took control of the House in 1995. The Ney bill is the first major Republican legislative effort to draw black Democrats away from their leaders.
The caucus was founded in 1971, when there were 14 blacks in the House. And for the next 20 years, said David Bositis of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, until 1993 "there were basically too few members" to affect a House with huge Democratic majorities. 
After the 1992 elections, though, there were 39 voting members in the caucus, including 17 freshmen, and, Mr. Bositis said the caucus played "a very pivotal role," on issues like constructing the super-conducting supercollider in Texas and continuing spending on the B-1 bomber while it slowed down passage of President Bill Clinton's crime bill.
This year the only other cohesive group getting as much attention from the forces trying to eliminate soft money is the 17-member Hispanic caucus. Today it got one assurance it sought above all else -- a promise that Shays-Meehan backers would vote solidly against a Republican amendment that would prohibit legal resident aliens from making campaign contributions.
Negotiations with the black caucus were not finished. Mr. Gephardt promised to meet with the members on Thursday morning, hours before the crucial votes to discuss their request for a commitment of as much as 10 or 15 percent of all funds raised by all national Democratic Party organizations (the Democratic National Committee, the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee) be committed to registration and get-out-the-vote efforts in minority areas.
Representative Eddie Bernice Johnson of Texas, who heads the caucus, said Mr. Gephardt told its members that in the morning "he would be in a better position to tell us how he would help us."

HEADLINE: The Beijing Olympic Bid 

 BODY:
As the International Olympic Committee gathers in Moscow this week to select a host nation for the 2008 Summer Games, there is no mystery about the human rights record of China, the heavily favored contender. It is abysmal. As a matter of principle, China's human rights abuses and suppression of dissent should disqualify it from holding the Olympics. 
 But with the United States remaining neutral on China's bid, and the rest of the world unwilling to make human rights a decisive issue, the I.O.C. seems likely to approve the Chinese application. Having turned down China once before, in 1993 when it applied to be host to the 2000 Games, which were awarded to Sydney instead, many I.O.C. members are reluctant to disappoint the Chinese again. Since the modern Olympic movement began in 1896, China has never played host to the event. 
 If Beijing prevails over Toronto and Paris, the other leading aspirants, the United States and the I.O.C. should do what they can to turn the 2008 Summer Games into a force for constructive change in China. The long-term interests of advancing democracy and freedom there can be served if China recognizes that its handling of every aspect of the Games -- including the construction of new Olympic arenas, the treatment of foreign visitors and reporters and the political climate in which the Games are held -- will be closely monitored by the world. The Bush administration's neutral stance is based in part on a belief that the Chinese government may temper its domestic and foreign policies over the next seven years to avoid the possibility of a Western boycott of the Olympics.
We do not harbor the illusion that the Olympics alone can be a decisive turning point in China's conduct. But China, with one-fifth of the world's population and new economic aspirations, is not the monolithic nation it once was. Its destiny need not be as an international spoiler and the last redoubt of a discredited, inhumane political ideology. 
China's top leaders remain stubbornly opposed to political reform even as they expand economic freedoms and encourage entrepreneurs. But the Chinese people seem to have higher hopes for their nation, as many demonstrated during the democracy movement of the late 1980's. Their enthusiastic engagement with the outside world, though restricted by the government, suggests a yearning to become active participants not only in global commerce but the international community as well.
The I.O.C. and the world at large should make clear that granting the Olympics to China is not meant to reward the Chinese government but rather to signal to the Chinese people that they are welcome to play a greater role in international life. Close diplomatic and journalistic attention has to be paid to China's treatment of its own citizens in the years leading up to the Games. If Beijing is chosen, the committee itself can and should establish firm guidelines for China's staging of the Olympics.
China has already agreed to spend more than $10 billion on infrastructure and environmental projects to make Beijing worthy of the event. But it is of greater importance that the I.O.C. secure a commitment from China that it will respect the Olympic movement's humanitarian ideals. 
Olympic authorities must insist that no journalists, athletes or spectators seeking to attend the Games be denied entry to China, or find their activities once there restricted, even if their political views are abhorrent to the Chinese government. International media should have unrestricted access in covering preparations for the Games and all areas of Chinese life during the Olympics, including human rights and China's criminal justice system. 
Because of the Communist government's history of abusing prison labor and of forcefully removing people it considers undesirables in anticipation of major events, Olympic officials must also insist on the right to monitor labor practices at Olympic construction sites, as well as to oversee security measures leading up to the Games.
In a more humane world, the I.O.C. would bar China from serving as an Olympic host nation until the government learned to live with the free expression of political and religious views and stopped abusing citizens who oppose the authoritarian rule of the Communist Party. But there is reason to hope that the bright spotlight the Olympics can shine on the Chinese government's behavior over the next seven years could prove beneficial to those in China who would like to see their country evolve into a more tolerant and democratic society.

HEADLINE: Chancellor to Scrutinize School Building Costs 

BYLINE:  By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy outlined a series of reporting procedures to the Board of Education yesterday that will help his staff keep tighter control on spending under the system's five-year construction plan.
 The chancellor's plan calls for the staff to provide the board with monthly updates on the progress of construction projects, provide semiannual forecasts of the entire plan, and include all projects to the city's accounting system. Mr. Levy's staff informed the board of the changes during a two-and-a-half-hour meeting. 
 He also wants the deputy chancellor for operations to approve all changes of more than 10 percent of the cost of a project or exceeding $3 million. He will establish a commission of real estate experts to help review every city school to determine which ones can be expanded, possibly into high-rises, he said.
The move comes after spending required under the five-year capital plan was apparently approved with little oversight, creating a $1.9 billion overrun. Mr. Levy said that while much of the overrun was due to inflation, he and the board have ordered an audit.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani lambasted Mr. Levy last month when his staff proposed delaying the construction of new schools, mostly in Queens, and postponing most major school renovations in the five boroughs for two or more years because of soaring construction costs. The Mayor's Office of Management and Budget has long been empowered to review spending on the school construction plan on a case-by-case basis, but had not done such reviews, Mr. Levy said. Now it will, Mr. Levy said yesterday.
Under the five-year plan released in 1999 and approved by the City Council and the mayor, the city planned to spend about $7 billion on construction and renovation from July 1999 through June 2004. But projects already under way are coming in so far above the original estimates that Board of Education officials now predict that the projects are likely to cost up to $1.9 billion more.
Most of the projects were begun under the previous five-year plan. Officials said yesterday that the costs of many of those projects, originally estimated in 1994, were never updated. In addition, the Board of Education has had trouble finding enough sites for new schools, and those they find sometimes have environmental problems requiring extensive cleanup.
The plan is undergoing intense scrutiny. The board has asked for an accounting of spending so far and for more information on expected overruns, and a special commission appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki is continuing a multiyear investigation of the board's construction process.

Summer School
Absenteeism -- a chronic problem last summer -- might be a problem again this summer, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday. He said that many of the 190,853 students ordered to attend five weeks of summer school or face repeating a grade were not yet showing up for classes.

HEADLINE: To Cash In on a Lifestyle, Apple Hits the Mall 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

DATELINE: McLEAN, Va. 

 BODY:
THE store is so self-aware that it doesn't even have its name on a sign. Instead, a glowing white apple with an iconic bite beckons shoppers in an upscale mall in this affluent Washington suburb. 
 Inside the white airy interior, black-clad salesclerks walk the bleached wooden floor, past translucent computers, petite digital cameras and slim scanners. 
 With or without its name spelled out, the merchant's identity is unmistakable. The 6,000-square-foot store is part of a foray by Apple Computer into retailing, part of a campaign to create an Apple presence at 25 high-traffic shopping areas across the nation, including Manhattan, by the end of the year. Another store has opened in the Los Angeles area. 
It is an aggressive move during an economic slowdown, with sales of personal computers sliding and hardware manufacturers stinging from price-cutting wars. Gateway, which only recently developed its own retail stores, is retrenching by closing underperforming ones and pulling out of OfficeMax outlets. 
Apple's strategy is to do for computer shopping what Starbucks did for coffee and what Barnes & Noble did for book browsing. It is a notion of consumerism that is less about the product than about a way of life.
Like the curvaceous iMac and the sleek Titanium PowerBook that it stocks, the McLean store is an emblem of the Apple aesthetic. But as Apple has learned -- most recently with the decision to end production of the lauded but poor-selling G4 Cube -- design may stimulate sales, but it is no substitute. Apple has only a 5 percent share of the personal computer market.
On a recent Saturday afternoon, parents with strollers meandered through the crowded store at Tysons Corner Center while teenagers experimented with digital cameras. A wide-screen theater in the back offers presentations, but the entire store is the real show. 
A knee-high kiosk of iMacs equipped with games is ostensibly for the elementary school set. But adults are just as likely to be found sitting on the bouncy ball stools, legs crimped, playing video games. There is a help desk, dubbed the Genius Bar, with troubleshooters who can address technical problems. 
Tony Watson, a Nokia phone clipped to his waist, spent 20 minutes talking about the G4 computer with an animated salesman. He walked out impressed that he could run Windows software on the Macintosh. "In terms of digital information gathering, this is the Bloomingdale's of computer stores," said Mr. Watson, of Sterling, Va., who has no Macintosh but is interested in using its film-editing software to create DVD's featuring his 4-month-old son.
Mr. Watson said he was frustrated with clerks at larger stores who were unable to answer his questions.
Customer service has long been cited as a source of tension in Apple's on-again off-again relationship with retailers. Apple recently announced that it was pulling its products out of retail chains including Best Buy, Circuit City, OfficeMax and Sears, though it said it would keep its dedicated sections at CompUSA. 
Mr. Watson said he almost bought a G4 after his conversation with the salesman. "The question is not whether," he said, "it's when."
For Apple, the question is whether there will be enough Mr. Watsons to make the retail venture worthwhile. 
To break even, Apple will have to generate $7 million in annual sales per store, estimated David Goldstein, president of the Channel Marketing Corporation, a retail consulting firm that has worked with Apple. Even then, the stores may hurt relationships with traditional retailers by cutting into their sales. ComputerWare, a Macintosh retail chain in the San Francisco area, closed in April, citing declining sales and the impact of Apple's online store. 
No computer manufacturer has successfully branched into retail stores, Mr. Goldstein said. "It's completely flawed," he said of Apple's venture. "They'll shut it down and write off the huge losses in two years." 
But Apple estimates that the stores will break even by the end of this year. Ultimately it hopes to double its market share to 10 percent, in part by making an impression on people like Dominic Buckner, 11. 
"Some of the computers at Comp USA you can look at but you can't touch," Dominic said. The Apple store is more like an arcade. "It's nice," he said, "that they want you to have an experience with the computer so you want to buy one." 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 20, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Circuits on July 12 about Apple Computer's new retail stores misstated the history of the company's relationship with several retailers. Apple's announcement that it would stop selling computers through Best Buy, Circuit City, Of-ficeMax and Sears was made in February 1998, not recently. Circuit City resumed Apple sales last July; sales also resumed for a time at Sears but have again been discontinued.

HEADLINE: Biogen Fights Rival Over Drug Claim 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 11 

 BODY:
Two major biopharmaceutical companies faced off in court today, as Biogen of Cambridge, Mass., sought to convince a panel of judges here that Serono's claims of a superior multiple sclerosis drug were misleading and should not be publicized.
 At stake is the $1 billion American drug market for treating multiple sclerosis, a disease of the central nervous system. 
 Biogen, whose multiple sclerois drug, Avonex, provided $220 million of the company's $237 million in sales in the first quarter of the year, has exclusive marketing rights in the United States until mid-2003 unless a competitor can come up with a better treatment. 
Last month, it won a preliminary injunction barring certain Serono statements hours before it was set to announce the findings of its comparative trial of its drug, Rebif, and Avonex.
Two million people worldwide are estimated to have multiple sclerosis, for which there is no cure, but the United States market is key.
While the European market is roughly the same size, more multiple sclerosis patients in the United States are receiving drug treatment, which costs about $10,000 yearly, said Birgit Kulhoff, an analyst with Lombard Odier in Zurich. 
Rebif is the top-selling multiple sclerosis drug outside the United States. To break Biogen's seven-year hold on the American market, Serono has to show the United States Food and Drug Administration that Rebif is better. It undertook a six-month study of 677 patients on the two treatment regimes. The drugs are close chemically -- both are beta interferons. Avonex is injected once a week; Rebif three times a week.
Biogen has contested the study's findings, which Serono says are overwhelmingly favorable to Rebif. Among the claims Biogen disputes is that patients using Rebif have a 90 percent greater chance of avoiding a relapse.
Biogen won the preliminary court order just as Serono, based in Geneva, was set to deliver the results to thousands of doctors gathered in London on June 22 for the annual World Congress of Neurology. Serono scientists nonetheless announced their claims.
Today was the first time the two sides have confronted each other in court, since the preliminary injunction was granted without a hearing. Serono faces fines unless it can convince the judges it acted properly.
In addition to disputing Serono's conclusions about relapses, Biogen took issue with its claim that Avonex patients had 50 percent more brain lesions than Rebif patients. Patients taking Avonex started with more lesions, and that distorted the conclusions, Biogen said.
Serono has maintained that Biogen has acted in a "destructive and mischievous" way to stifle the drug trial's results, and has unfairly attacked the company's chief executive, Ernesto Bertarellli.
The judges' decision is not expected for at least 10 days and will not decide access to the American market. That is determined by American regulators.
Analysts are divided over the importance of the study, but not over the significance of the marketing rights fight. "This is very important economically to both companies," said Kevin Lyne-Smith of Bank Julius Baer in Zurich, "and they can't afford to lose."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Holding a Lead"Disappointing new drugs have hurt Biogen's stock this year, pushing the company to defend its dominance of the market for multiple sclerosis drugs against Serono S.A. Chart tracks percentage change in share prices since June 30, 2000 for Serono and Biogen.(Source: Bloomberg Financial Markets)

HEADLINE: Nissan Says It Can Refute Report of Bias In Car Loans 

BYLINE:  By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
The Nissan Motor Acceptance Corporation yesterday released a report that it said "strongly refuted" two recent studies indicating that black customers had paid more than whites to finance cars through Nissan dealerships.
 The report, by a research firm hired by Nissan, said the earlier studies, by two professors hired by black consumers suing the Nissan finance corporation, or NMAC, ignored credit differences and variations in loan terms that might explain patterns in financing costs. 
 Moreover, the Nissan report said, the sample the professors relied on -- believed by experts to be the largest pool of car loan data ever analyzed for racial patterns -- was too small and too geographically skewed to be fairly representative of Nissan's lending practices. 
The professors studied 310,000 of the 1.1 million loans made by NMAC since 1993 -- all those on which they found racial information. 
"After a critical review, NMAC has determined that the reports commissioned by the plaintiffs used seriously flawed methodology to reach a contrived conclusion," said a statement released by Nissan.
The company's report was filed in Federal District Court in Nashville on Tuesday, a spokeswoman said.
Neither the lawsuit against NMAC nor similar cases against the lending units of other major auto dealers accuse the lenders themselves of racial bias. Rather, lawyers for the black consumers argue, lenders engage in loan-pricing arrangements with dealers that result in blacks paying more to finance cars.
Lenders like NMAC routinely allow dealers to add several percentage points, the dealer markup, to the interest rate the lender has established for customers based on income and credit history. That becomes the rate the dealer quotes to the customer, who has no way of learning that the lender approved his loan at a lower rate. The lender splits the money generated by the extra percentage points with the dealer.
After analyzing the amount of extra interest that dealers added to loans financed by NMAC, Prof. Mark A. Cohen of Vanderbilt University concluded that blacks were more likely than whites to have paid a dealer markup and that blacks paid larger markups than whites, regardless of their credit history.
Prof. Ian Ayres, a lawyer and economist at Yale Law School, reviewed and endorsed Professor Cohen's findings and suggested that NMAC might inadvertently be contributing to the disparate pattern by limiting the markup on certain loans that are more likely to have been made to whites.
Janet Thornton, a labor economist at Economic Research Services in Tallahassee, Fla., who reviewed the two reports for Nissan, argued that both professors "have a flawed understanding of the actual markets for vehicles and credit." Professor Cohen, Ms. Thornton said, relied on a small, unrepresentative sample and ignored the effect of credit history on the dealer markup.
Clint Watkins, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, said the professors stood by their conclusions.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
In a Shift, Microsoft to Give PC Makers More Freedom
Acknowledging that it must change its business practices, Microsoft announced that it would give personal computer makers more freedom to choose what software and services they offer on the machines they sell.
 The concession is a response to the decision last month by a federal court of appeals, which found that many of Microsoft's licensing deals with computer makers were an illegal abuse of its monopoly power. Page A1. 

A Definition of an Electronic Book
A federal judge in Manhattan ruled that the term "book" in book contracts does not automatically include electronic books. The decision, which could affect hundreds of thousands of authors and books, is the latest in a series of rulings indicating that courts view the Internet as a new and different form of media. A1.

Screaming About Ice Cream Prices
Ice cream makers massed in Washington, complaining that the government had pushed up the cost of milk fat, the principal ingredient in ice cream, no less than 50 percent in the last year. That in turn, they say, has caused them to charge prices that even summer-struck consumers do not want to pay. C2.

Yahoo Reports $48.5 Million Loss
Yahoo, which was once one of the few money-making Internet companies, said that it lost $48.5 million in the first quarter. It nonetheless modestly beat its financial goals. C2.

Nissan Says It Refutes Loan Bias
Nissan Motor Acceptance released a report that it said "strongly refuted" two recent studies showing that black customers had paid more than whites to finance cars through Nissan dealerships. A19.

Ford Motor is changing its year-old performance evaluation system that graded managers and supervisors with letter rankings. C15.

Household to End Mortgage Tactic
Household International said it would stop selling single-premium credit life insurance policies to people who take out home loans. The loans were criticized by consumer groups as being predatory. C9.

Motorola Reports Operating Loss
Motorola lost $232 million, or 11 cents a share, in the second quarter. Revenue for the wireless communications and semiconductor company tumbled 19 percent, to $7.52 billion. C6.

Dow and Nasdaq Gain as S.& P. Falls
Blue chips and technology shares rose as the broader market fell. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 65.38 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,241.02. The Nasdaq composite index gained 9.25 points, to 1,972.04. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 1.34 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,180.18. C10.

Profit to Fall at Emerson Electric
Emerson Electric said its annual profit would drop for the first time in 43 years, dragged down by a plunge in spending by telecommunications companies. Shareholders responded to the projected 5 percent decline with the biggest sell-off in shares since 1987, driving them down $8.48, or 12.2 percent, to $52.93. C5.

Bill to Allow Some Drug Imports
The House voted to make it easier for people to import low-cost prescription drugs for their own use, after rejecting a more sweeping proposal to allow such imports by drug wholesalers and pharmacies. A21.

Napster Is Ordered to Shut Down
A federal judge ordered Napster to shut down its music-sharing service until it could prove that its technology could filter 100 percent of copyrighted material. Napster had been shut down temporarily. C7.

Examining the Apple Cube's Demise
With 20-20 hindsight, it is easy to see why Apple's beautiful but pricey Power Mac G4 Cube was doomed. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: MICROSOFT TO GIVE COMPUTER MAKERS GREATER FREEDOM 

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Acknowledging that it must change its business practices, Microsoft announced yesterday that it would give personal computer makers more freedom to choose what software and services they offer on the machines they sell. 
 The concession by Microsoft is a response to the decision last month by a federal court of appeals, which found many of the dominant software maker's licensing deals with computer makers were an illegal abuse of its monopoly power. 
 The move by Microsoft is a limited step, according to industry analysts and the company's opponents in the long-running antitrust suit. Specifically, Microsoft said it would allow computer makers to remove its Internet browser if they choose and place icons for software programs and services -- including ones that compete with Microsoft offerings -- on the main screen of the company's new Windows XP operating system.
Until now, Microsoft had said that the new version of its Windows operating system, which will be introduced in October, would not give PC makers those freedoms. And Microsoft's contracts powerfully shape the nature of competition and consumer choice in the industry because its Windows operating system is a monopoly, controlling the basic operations of about 90 percent of all PC's sold. 
"Microsoft made a gesture -- that's nice," said Timothy Bresnahan, a Stanford University economist who was a senior official in the Justice Department's antitrust division during much of the Microsoft trial. "But in terms of impact on the industry and competition, it's a nonevent. These concessions would have been significant years ago but not now. The browser war is over."
Indeed the antitrust suit, filed by the Justice Department and several states, did focus on the market for Internet browsing software -- but it raised broader competitive issues as well. When the suit was filed in May 1998, Microsoft had far less than half of the market for Internet browsing software, while the leader was Netscape Communication, which was later acquired by America Online. Today, Microsoft's Internet Explorer holds 87 percent of the browser market, according to Statmarket, a research firm. 
What is unclear is whether Microsoft's measured step is an initial signal that the company is willing to accept the court decision, modify its behavior and take significant further steps to settle the suit. "What Microsoft did today was certainly not overwhelming," said Richard Blumenthal, the attorney general for Connecticut, one of the states that sued the company. "But the issue is whether this indicates a change in mindset or culture in a proven monopolist. Or is this just a symbolic and public relations gesture intended to improve its image?"
In announcing the move, Steven A. Ballmer, the chief executive of Microsoft, said, "We recognize that some provisions of our existing Windows licenses have been ruled improper by the court, so we are providing computer manufacturers with greater flexibility and we are doing this immediately so that computer manufacturers can take advantage of them in planning for the upcoming release of Windows XP."
The easing of restrictions on PC makers, Mr. Ballmer noted, does "not take the place of settlement discussions with the government parties or any future steps in the legal process." But, he added, "We wanted to take immediate steps in light of the court's ruling." 
A federal appeals court last month ruled that Microsoft had repeatedly abused its monopoly power in thwarting the potential threat from Internet software. But the appeals court swept aside the order by the lower court that the company be split in two. It sent the case down to a new Federal District Court to determine what sanctions should be imposed on Microsoft.
The appeals court found that several of Microsoft's licensing practices with PC makers were exclusionary, thus stifling competition and limiting consumer choice. The court also found that Microsoft's decision to bundle its browser with Windows could not be justified on the grounds that it was good for consumers.
With its upcoming Windows XP operating system, Microsoft is to some degree working from the same playbook. It is tightly integrating new Internet software for listening to music, shopping and instant messaging into its new operating system. But the new flexibility Microsoft is giving PC makers is centered on the browser, allowing manufacturers to remove access to Internet Explorer, if they choose.
Yet with the browser war over, few, if any, computer makers are expected to opt for the Netscape browser now. And the more flexible contract rules from Microsoft do not allow computer makers to remove the new features, like Windows Media Player and Windows Messenger.
Only a few weeks ago, for example, talks between Microsoft and AOL Time Warner on including a link to the AOL online service in Windows XP broke down partly over Internet media software. Microsoft pressed AOL to drop its exclusive relationship with RealNetworks, the leader in software for playing music over the Internet.
And AOL Time Warner, not surprisingly, was not much impressed with Microsoft's announcement yesterday. "Microsoft is facing a new reality and adjusting minutely in the right direction," said John Buckley, a vice president of AOL Time Warner. But Mr. Buckley added that other steps that were part of Microsoft's plans for Windows XP like "bolting Windows Media Player and Windows Messenger are harmful to consumers and to competition."
Microsoft has said its reading of the appeals court decision is that the company still has the right to integrate new features into its Windows operating system as it sees fit.
While the appeals court found little merit in Microsoft's arguments for bundling its browser with Windows, the court did not say that the company was prohibited from adding new features to its operating system. And it established a standard for weighing consumer benefit against potential competitive harm, if a court is examining whether to permit software to be added to a monopoly product like Windows.
Still, industry analysts said that the steps Microsoft announced were minimal and mainly addressed the somewhat dated issue of the browser. "These moves by Microsoft represent an extremely literal reading of the appeals court decision," observed David Yoffie, a professor at the Harvard Business School. "If Microsoft were going to adhere to the spirit of the ruling, it would apply the same freedoms to remove things like Windows Media Player and Windows Messenger."
Yet in statements accompanying the Microsoft announcement, computer makers warmly welcomed the software maker's concessions. "With this new flexibility, we're looking forward to taking Windows XP to the next level, tailoring technology to meet our customers needs," said Ted Waitt, the chief executive of Gateway.
For years, Gateway had been among the more restless of the PC makers, quietly complaining about Microsoft's licensing restrictions. A Gateway spokesman said that it might now add "one or two" icons, featuring other software products or Internet services, on the Windows XP desktop screen.
In earlier version of Windows, PC makers were allowed to place such icons to promote other software on the Microsoft operating system. But with Windows XP, Microsoft said that based on user testing it had chosen to opt for a "clean" desktop. Microsoft has now retreated a bit from that stance.

Investment Losses
 SEATTLE, July 11, (Reuters) -- Microsoft said today that its quarterly revenues would be higher than expected, but said it would record $2.6 billion in investment losses.
The company said results from operations during its fourth quarter ended June 30 were in line with expectations.
Microsoft was expected to earn 42 cents a share, according to a consensus of analysts. Including the noncash investment loss, earnings would be a cent a share.
Microsoft said revenues were stronger than expected and would come in at $6.5 billion to $6.6 billion, up from the company's previous estimate of $6.3 billion to $6.5 billion.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 17, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Thursday about Microsoft's relaxing of some contract restrictions on personal computer makers incompletely described a federal appeals court ruling on June 28 about the company's bundling of its Internet browser with its Windows operating system. The court ruled that Microsoft had bundled the browsing software with Windows in a way that violated antitrust laws on two counts. But the court also said that bundling of software was not inherently illegal. It vacated that finding by a lower court and sent the issue back for reconsideration by a new judge.

REMOVING EXPLORERIn Windows XP, computer users can use the add/remove function to remove Internet Explorer. HEADLINE: Declining Surplus Renews Debate Over the Budget Outlook 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11 

 BODY:
The Bush administration said today that the weakening of the economy might push the federal budget surplus this year down to a level that, Democrats said, would portend a return to fiscal difficulties in the years ahead.
 Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, said the government would run a surplus this year big enough to meet the bipartisan commitment to use excess Social Security revenue only for reducing the national debt. And Mr. Daniels said there was no risk "at present" that the economic downturn would force the government to dip into Social Security surpluses in coming years. 
 But he did not rule out the possibility that the surplus this year would fall short of earlier expectations by enough to breach what Democrats have sought to establish as a standard for fiscal responsibility: reserving excess funds generated by the Medicare system, as well as the entire Social Security surplus, for debt reduction.
The Congressional Budget Office's most recent projections, made two months ago, forecast a surplus in Social Security this year of $156 billion and a surplus in Medicare's hospital insurance trust fund of $28 billion, a total of $184 billion. At the time, the budget office forecast a surplus in the general budget of an additional $16 billion, leaving the government $200 billion in the black for the year.
Since the economy all but stalled this spring, however, private economists and government budget analysts have been marking down their surplus estimates. Today Mr. Daniels said the White House now expected a surplus of at least $160 billion for the fiscal year that ends on Sept. 30. 
In a briefing for reporters, Mr. Daniels said the actual figure could be higher, and in any case would be larger than the Social Security surplus. But he said it was too early to know whether it would dip below the level of the combined Medicare and Social Security surpluses.
"The surplus is in great shape," Mr. Daniels said. "It's the economy that's not in the best of shape."
Mr. Daniels said the 10-year, $1.35 trillion tax cut signed into law by President Bush last month would give the economy a big lift in coming months, ensuring that tax receipts rebound in the new fiscal year, starting Oct. 1.
In a $2 trillion federal budget and a $10 trillion national economy, there is little or no economic significance to whether the surplus is slightly above or slightly below the combined Medicare and Social Security surpluses. 
But the political implications of its falling below could be substantial, providing Democrats an opportunity to portray Mr. Bush's tax cut as too expensive and to cast themselves as guardians of fiscal restraint.
The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, will hold a hearing on Thursday where he plans to question Mr. Daniels closely on the budget outlook. 
In an interview, Mr. Conrad said the possibility that the government would be forced to dip into the Medicare surplus this year was evidence that Congress and the administration were likely to "raid" both the Medicare and Social Security surpluses starting next year.
"It shows we're into the Medicare trust fund already this year," Mr. Conrad said, "and we see serious danger" of using all of the Medicare surplus next year, along with some of the Social Security surplus.
Mr. Conrad maintained that the fiscal outlook was even dimmer than it seemed, saying his own projections did not take account of a variety of tax and spending measures that have strong bipartisan support and are likely to create even more budget pressure in coming years. 
Among them, he said, are proposed spending increases for the military and education, the extension of popular tax breaks and reductions in the alternative minimum tax, a complex provision that will push up the tax bills of millions of middle- and upper-income people over the next decade unless revised.
"It suggests to me that we have to go back to the drawing boards with respect to the budget for next year and beyond," Mr. Conrad said. 
Mr. Daniels said Mr. Conrad was assuming that government spending would increase at a pace higher than what Mr. Bush will support. In any case, he said, it is meaningless to measure fiscal health relative to the Medicare surplus, which he described as an accounting gimmick.
The Medicare surplus is generated by one part of the Medicare program, its hospital insurance trust fund. The rest of Medicare requires infusions of general tax revenue each year. So there is no Medicare surplus, Mr. Daniels said, when the program is looked at as a whole.
"With respect," he said, "the notion of a Medicare surplus is flawed, it's misleading, and it's dangerous."
He said Mr. Bush's standard for fiscal prudence was the Social Security surplus, which he said the administration would protect at all costs, even if that meant vetoing spending bills passed by Congress. The Social Security surplus is projected to be nearly $2.6 trillion over the next decade, Mr. Daniels said, enough to pay off as much of the $3 trillion publicly held national debt as can be redeemed, as a practical matter, between now and 2011 -- about $2.1 trillion, by the administration's estimate.
Any effort to redeem more debt, by offering premiums to holders of Treasury bonds, would apportion the government's resources unduly to bondholders at the expense of initiatives, including tax cuts and spending programs, that would benefit more people, Mr. Daniels said.

HEADLINE: Left Uninspired by Mayor's Race, Democrats Put Off Endorsements 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
In what is emerging as a clear and not particularly kind verdict on the field of New York mayoral candidates, powerful players in Democratic politics -- including unions and elected officials -- have decided to hold back their endorsements in this year's primary contest. They said none of the candidates had yet presented compelling reasons to take sides, and that voters seemed persistently uninterested in a contest just eight weeks away from a vote.
 After eagerly anticipating this year as an opportunity to succeed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, these elected officials and union leaders, whose support has been intensely courted by the four major Democratic candidates, expressed concern about a race that they described as flat and unengaged. Several said they were now considering staying neutral in the primary, and waiting to see who emerges in the expected two-way runoff, which would take place on Sept. 25. 
 Others whose endorsements have been sought said they would not announce any decision until it appeared that voters were paying attention.
"I've never done anything like this before in my political life," said Charles B. Rangel, the Harlem Democrat who is the dean of the New York Congressional delegation. He said he was leaning toward staying neutral in the primary. "My wife doesn't believe it. I just don't think any of the candidates has really made the type of impression that would allow you to feel excited."
Mr. Rangel, the irritation evident in his voice, said the Democratic mayoral candidates were "stuck in the mud," adding that he wished they would just "do something" to draw voter attention and justify their campaigns for mayor.
Randi Weingarten, the president of the New York City teachers' union, said her union was also considering sitting out the primary, and said none of the candidates had commanded the attention of her members. "There is not a lot of interest yet in the election," she said.
There are some exceptions to a trend that has clearly concerned advisers to the Democrats. The executive committee of District Council 37, the municipal workers union, recommended yesterday that its members support Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker. The union's administrator, Lee Saunders, described Mr. Vallone as a consistent supporter of union positions in the Council, and said Mr. Vallone deserved to be rewarded. Mr. Vallone's supporters, who had been worried about a campaign that had appeared to be adrift, seized on the decision.
The city comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, has attracted a large number of endorsements from elected officials and county leaders; his advisers say the endorsements validated his credentials among different segments of voters who did not know him yet. And Mark Green, the public advocate, has won two big-name endorsements: David N. Dinkins, the former Democratic mayor, and William J. Bratton, who was Mr. Giuliani's first police commissioner.
Democrats said they were struck by the major players who had still not endorsed. In addition to teachers, the city's health care workers' union, one of the most important when it comes to getting out the vote, has been unable to come to an agreement on any candidate. Its influential leader, Dennis Rivera, is serving a 30-day prison term for protesting on Vieques, P.R. 
Similarly, the city's police union, after meeting twice with the candidates, has yet to reach a consensus on whom, if anybody, to endorse.
In Congress, Representative Jerrold Nadler, a West Side Democrat who is thought to be particularly influential among liberal voters, has yet to take sides in the race, despite entreaties from the candidates. The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, yesterday remarked on what he called the absence of voter interest in the race and said he was deferring any endorsement. He was said by other Democrats to be prepared to support Mr. Hevesi.
And the Rev. Al Sharpton, after offering fairly encouraging words to Mr. Green and a fourth candidate, Fernando Ferrer, says he will not make an endorsement until after the candidates appear at a forum he is calling in August, and perhaps not even after that.
This turn of events is the latest reflection on the difficult adjustment the city clearly faces with the departure of Mr. Giuliani, a more lively public figure than any of the Democratic candidates. As a constant reminder of this, the Democrats have routinely found that Mr. Giuliani has frequently overshadowed them as they have tried to campaign.
At a time of relative prosperity and low crime, no candidate has found the issue that will allow him to break though. Yesterday, Mr. Hevesi gave a speech in which he called for revolving credit loans as a way of encouraging economic development, while Mr. Green offered up a six-point plan to improve procedures for awarding contracts.
All the candidates are stressing the same issues -- education first, housing second -- reflecting what all their pollsters are discovering in their examination of voter attitudes. 
"The difficulty is candidates' distinguishing themselves from other candidates," Mr. Silver said. "They are Democratic candidates who basically stand for the same Democratic issues." This suggests that any of the candidates would be acceptable to the union leaders and other major Democrats.
Not surprisingly, this is producing some frustration among some of the candidates. In an interview yesterday, Mr. Vallone made a point of noting that the next mayor would remember next January just who did what this summer.
"They can't just hold back forever," Mr. Vallone said. "The train is going to leave the station. The safest thing to do is to wait, obviously, but that's not going to get you anything in the end."

HEADLINE: Bloomberg Makes a Pledge To Travel via Mass Transit 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

 BODY:
Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he will do his part to alleviate congestion if elected mayor by using mass transit every day. Mr. Bloomberg, a wealthy Republican businessman who is accustomed to traveling by limousine, said that would include commuting to City Hall by taxi as well as by bus or subway.
 Mr. Bloomberg made his pledge at a news conference in Chinatown, where he disclosed his campaign proposal to solve the city's traffic problems. 
 Two Democratic candidates for mayor also released some details yesterday about their platforms. One of them, Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller, spoke in Harlem about economic development. The other, Mark Green, the public advocate, discussed city contracting procedures with business leaders from Union Square.
Mr. Hevesi said that he would create a mayor's office to serve the biotech industry and reduce or eliminate some taxes on businesses. Mr. Green said he would be aggressive in screening and monitoring contractors to improve the quality of work done for the city.
Mr. Bloomberg's eight-page traffic plan includes ideas to make the streets safer for pedestrians and to encourage the use of public transportation. Mr. Bloomberg said he would try to take control of the city's transit authority from the state and would improve the enforcement of traffic laws by using cameras, perhaps mounted on buses, to catch people who drive their cars in bus lanes.
"I have made a commitment that I will every single day at least take one form of mass transit," Mr. Bloomberg said. "It could be a bus, it could be a taxi, it could be a subway. If you are mayor, you have to know how well it works. And also you have to lead by example."
Mr. Bloomberg rode the subway with reporters before and after presenting his plan at an entrance to the Grand Street station. He said he normally uses mass transit only when it rains or if he is running late. He carries two MetroCards because he said he had difficulty reading the dollar amount displayed at the turnstiles and did not want to be caught short.
"One of the problems is that everybody acknowledges that it is nice to sit in an air-conditioned car, sipping a cup of coffee and having a little bit of down time by yourself," he said. "That unfortunately is a luxury that, if everybody does it, the city can't afford."
Taxis cost more than a bus or a subway and are not typically associated with mass transit. But Mr. Bloomberg said that people have strong emotions about taxis and he would need to see for himself how well they operate. He also suggested creating franchises for new taxi services in neighborhoods not served by yellow cabs or public transportation.
In tackling economic issues yesterday, Mr. Hevesi said he wanted to build on the reduction of crime during the Giuliani administration to create an environment that is attractive to business. He pledged to help small businesses in poor neighborhoods through a revolving loan program and to simplify the city's building code. He also said the city's schools needed to be improved, to ensure that the city maintained a qualified work force.
"If we fail, we'll have a lot more than low test scores to worry about," Mr. Hevesi said. "Our economy will eventually hit a wall."
As for Mr. Green, he acknowledged that talking about city contracts might bore many voters, but he said the mayor has an obligation to make sure the city's money is well spent. He said the city enters into 7,000 contracts every year for a total of $7 billion. Among his ideas were proposals to consolidate procurement, and expanding performance evaluations of companies along with seeking customer feedback. 
"In uncertain economic times, we often feel we have to choose either between raising taxes or lowering services," Mr. Green said. "But there's a third way, and a better way -- smarter management."

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing . . . And Cutting Flights 

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 CommutAir, an upstate New York airline, plans to reduce its staff and fleet of planes and drop service to some cities. The airline, which is based in Plattsburgh, was expected to give layoff notices to 165 of its 375 employees this week. The company's president, Andrew Price, said the carrier would trim its fleet to 14 planes from 26. Mr. Price said the company has been hard hit by a lagging economy. It plans to eliminate service out of Binghamton, Elmira and Ithaca in mid-August. The company provides Continental Connection service in a partnership with Continental Airlines. Mr. Price said CommutAir would focus on providing service to markets like Albany, Syracuse, Rochester and Buffalo.
