HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "ABCD: A COLLECTION OF ART BRUT," Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street, Manhattan, (212) 977-7170 (through July 22). Memorably vivid and widely abused, the phrase Art Brut (meaning raw or rough art) was coined in the 1940's by the French artist Jean Dubuffet. This exhibition, drawn from the holdings of a Paris-based foundation, tries to reinstate his original meaning, revisiting the amazing pantheon of artists who inspired it and proposing some additions. Its many highlights include works by acknowledged greats like Adolf Wolfli, Aloise Corbaz, Henry Darger and Augustin Lesage, but the show also introduces many equally riveting artists unfamiliar to American audiences. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Roberta Smith).

"BEYOND THE EASEL: DECORATIVE PAINTING BY BONNARD, VUILLARD, DENIS AND ROUSSEL, 1890-1930," Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue, at 82nd St., (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 9.) The themes of the 80 or so French paintings in this show, created for bourgeois homes by artists who called themselves the Nabis, couldn't be more lightweight: city parks and country gardens, gift-wrapped tots and fusspot nannies, with the ocasional nymph thrown in for tone. Yet the results, with their clotted textures and mildewy palettes of puce, mauve and brown, often look leaden and suffocating, trapped in nostalgia. Bonnard and Vuillard, unsurprisingly, come off best; Maurice Denis and Ker Xavier Roussel less well. Works that haven't been seen together for a century have been gathered for the occasion. Of most interest, though, is the concept of decoration the Nabis promoted, one that was at once radical and reactionary. Hours and admissions: See above (Holland Cotter).

* "EL GRECO: THEMES AND VARIATIONS," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through July 29). This gemlike single-digit exhibition (just seven canvases) outweighs some of the more grandiose shows in New York museums at the moment. It brings together, mostly for the first time, four versions of the artist's tumultuous "Purification of the Temple," which provide a vivid time line of his transcultural development, and three versions of his resonant portrait of St. Jerome as a cardinal, which were all painted toward the end of his life when he skillfully copied -- always with interesting differences -- his works for private patrons. The show makes its small oval gallery reverberate with thoughts about painting: as craft, thought, commodity and lifelong pursuit. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 62+ (Smith).

* WILLIAM KENTRIDGE, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 16). By way of drawings and film animations, Mr. Kentridge addresses in searing images South Africa and its racial problems, along with the longings and frustrations of bourgeois lives played out in the country's deeply dysfunctional setting. The exhibition begins with his jarring "Shadow Procession" (1999), a ragtag parade of silhouetted moving images projected on a big screen, which evokes the displaced and dispossessed who haunt not only South Africa but also the history of the world. At the heart of the show are his drawings and the short animated films he makes of them, in which the process shares importance with the content. Many of the films contrast the lives of two antiheroes, one a crude rapacious businessman, the other a sensitive artist, in compelling medleys of images that touch on the personal and the political. Departing from this format is "Ubu Tells the Truth" (1997), a highly charged satire based on the hearings of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, set up in 1995 to investigate human rights abuses during the apartheid era. It's not often that good art is shaped from such raw angry material, but Mr. Kentridge's powers of invention are equal to the challenge. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students, artists and 65+ (Grace Glueck).

* "MASTER DRAWINGS FROM THE CLEVELAND MUSEUM OF ART," Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0610 (through Aug. 19). From Michelangelo to Louise Bourgeois, from Rembrandt to Franz Kline, this cornucopia of drawings from one of the most important collections in the United States bristles with the work of stellar talents. A standout is a double-sided drawing in red chalk by Michelangelo, probably done around 1510-11. One side reveals the trouble he had sketching a foot that fits the position of a youthful male nude on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel; the other shows the headless nude itself, a powerful, ingeniously posed figure that emphasizes the sculptor's magnificent grasp of anatomical rendering. A rare compositional drawing by Fra Filippo Lippi, a subtly toned landscape by Claude Lorrain, a scene of battling horses by Gericault, a stately portrait by Ingres, one of Seurat's brilliant black crayon drawings of a French vaudeville scene, and works by Degas and Toulouse-Lautrec are among the highlights. The 20th-century American group is something of a disappointment, but there is enough great stuff from other eras to make this a masterpiece of a show. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6, students and 65+ (Glueck).

* "19TH- AND 20TH-CENTURY CHINESE PAINTINGS FROM THE ROBERT H. ELLSWORTH COLLECTION," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through Aug. 19). The 19th and 20th centuries were shattering times for China, bringing wars, civil violence and the fall of an empire. In art, old forms survived and flourished but also changed. This exhibition surveys how elite painting traditions developed for a new audience and under Western influences from 1850 to 1980. Among the highlights is a group of paintings by Qi Baishi (1864-1957), deservedly one of the most popular of all Chinese artists. The big news is that a major museum has quietly taken a firm stand on modern art in Asia, seeing it not as a postscript to a great tradition but as an integral, living part of the continuum. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

"PRECIOUS POSSESSIONS: TREASURES FROM THE LIBRARY OF THE JEWISH THEOLOGICAL SEMINARY," Jewish Theological Seminary, 3080 Broadway, at 122nd Street, (212) 678-8082 (through Aug. 30). These 90 or so charismatic entries date from the 11th to 20th century and come from all over the world. Almost every item has a story to tell or a name to drop. Want to see Maimonides's signature? Sigmund Freud's bookplate? A handwritten score by Leonard Bernstein? They're here. So are some spectacular illuminated manuscripts, minute and colossal, and objects that carry the warmth of ordinary life: marriage contracts, postcards and a 13th-century letter from a man in India to his wife in Egypt, assuring her of his unbroken devotion. Hours: Sundays, noon to 7 p.m.; Mondays through Thursdays, 8 a.m. to 10 p.m.; Fridays, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free (Cotter)

* WAYNE THIEBAUD: A PAINTINGS RETROSPECTIVE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through Sept. 23). The world not being a perfect place, this show will be around only through the summer, so consider yourself forewarned. At the Whitney, as in life, happiness is fleeting. Meanwhile, you are free to bask in these pumpkin pies, meat and cheese deli counters, lipsticks, hot dogs and gumball machines, which, as Mr. Thiebaud has painted them for the last 40 years, have the aura of loves lost and too fondly recalled. Joy yielding to melancholy then yields to the less jolting but more durable satisfaction of being in the presence of pictures so lovingly and wittily made. These pictures provoke happiness if for no other reason than that they are content to be what they are, which is enough -- this being the same message they convey about the modest objects and people they depict. (A smaller show of recent work by Mr. Thiebaud is at Allan Stone Gallery, 113 East 90th Street, through July 21; information: 212-987-1655.) Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays: 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8, students and 62+ (Michael Kimmelman).

Galleries: Uptown

ALEX KATZ, Adam Baumgold, 74 East 79th Street, (212) 861-7338 (through July 13). Though famous mainly for his large, elegantly flattened and simplified pictures of beautiful, well-to-do people, Mr. Katz also has a lovely touch on a small scale. This modest but rewarding show with mostly small pictures of women as well as some funky little collages from the 1950's shows to advantage his delicate brushwork, perfect compositional sense and controlled eroticism (Ken Johnson).

"MINIMAL," Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677 (through 31). This elegant show includes works of classic Minimalism like a box made of stainless steel and fluorescent red Plexiglas by Donald Judd; an iconic arrangement of red, pink and yellow fluorescent lights by Dan Flavin; and a gorgeous, glossy red, thick plank shape by John McCracken. It also embraces more Conceptually motivated works like words on the wall by Lawrence Weiner that say "Around the bend"; a square of typewritten concrete poetry by Carl Andre; and photographs of framework houses by Bernd & Hilla Becher (Johnson).

* "POP ART: THE JOHN AND KIMIKO POWERS COLLECTION," Gagosian Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through Aug. 31). With his Japanese-born wife, Kimiko, John Powers (1916-1999), a former president of the Prentice-Hall publishing company, gathered a big-bang collection of Pop Art by the movement's stars. The 26 objects shown here, including works by Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Claes Oldenburg, Roy Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol and James Rosenquist, are mostly from the 1960's, and they bring a whole era back into vivid focus. Among the signature works are Warhol's serial extravaganza, "200 Soup Cans" (1962); Mr. Rauschenberg's "Broadcast" (1959), a combine painting with a working radio attached; and Mr. Oldenburg's soft "Drum Set" (1967), a bodylike sendup of a professional drummer's instruments in vinyl and canvas that droops on a platform in a metaphor for its own spent energy. Collectors' collectors, the Powerses made the pursuit into an art of their own (Glueck).

PAUL WEINGARTEN; ADOLFO BARNATAN, Salander-O'Reilly, 20 East 79th Street, (212) 879-6606 (through July 27). The thickly painted, acid-hued still-life pictures of lobsters and fish, fruits and vegetables, and homey kitchenware by Mr. Weingarten, of Montclair, N.J., have a hectic, expressionistic energy that calls to mind Chaim Soutine, though without the latter's melting sensuousness. The Madrid-based Mr. Baratan's smooth, simplified sculptures in stone include Ancient Egyptian-style heads arranged in a Modernist grid and flat, near-Minimalist discs that evoke the sun and the moon (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

ADA GILMORE: "THE SUMMER OF 1915: WATERCOLORS FROM PROVINCETOWN," Mary Ryan, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 397-0669 (through July 31). All 22 paintings in this modestly radiant exhibition were made on the backs of official United States Postal Service postcards during the year after World War I drove this American Modernist from Paris to Provincetown. Gilmore's sunny, Impressionistic pictures of women gardening or doing laundry or views of houses among trees become more absorbing the more you look. Like her most obvious influence, Vuillard, she worked a fine balance between vibrantly patterned surface and evocative domestic space (Johnson).

MORRIS GRAVES, "Still Life," Schmidt Bingham, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 888-1122 (through Aug. 17). This small retrospective honors a great American original who died in May at 90. Ranging from vigorously palette-knifed paintings of drinking fountains, from the 1930's, to exquisitely delicate pictures of flowers in transparent bottles, from the 90's, the show gives a fine taste of Graves's craftsmanlike versatility and his modest yet intense poetic sensibility (Johnson).

ALEXANDER LIBERMAN, "Maquettes for Monuments," Ameringer/Howard, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 935-1110 (through Aug. 17). In the late 1960's, this Modernist sculptor and Conde Nast editorial director produced gigantic abstractions using old, unearthed gas pipes. On view here are sleek little copies of those monumental works, compositions of standing, leaning or tumbling cylinders finished in glossy red or matte rust-colored patina. Though not deeply consequential, they are appealingly precious (Johnson).

"SIGNS OF LIFE," Ramis Barquet, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-9090 (through July 27). This disjunctive but interesting six-artist show includes lively, comically erotic semi-abstract pink paintings by Fernanda Brunet; tires with treads recarved into traditional decorative motifs by Betsabee Romero; strangely clinical photographs of a man in his underwear by Ernesto Pujol; small, iconic realist paintings by Marco Arce; a droopy shaped painting by Leda Catunda; and a funny video by Ximena Cuevas in which the artist breathlessly practices introducing herself to the video curator John Hanhardt (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

JOHN BALDESSARI, JEFF KOONS, TOM WESSELMANN, Sonnabend, 536 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-1018 (through July 27). The big surprise is how shockingly uninteresting one finds Mr. Koons's dry, anonymously painted, Rosenquist-style montages. Mr. Baldessari's new photo-constructions offer the familiar conceptual impenetrability and visual enervation that have always characterized his least interesting works. But the unassuming hedonism of Mr. Wesselmann's three cut-out steel works -- a rippling abstraction, a still-life and a cartoon landscape -- is delightfully if not deeply seductive (Johnson).

"BEING THERE," Derek Eller, 526-30 West 25th Street, (212) 206-6411 (through July 27). Highlights of this lively eight-artist show include Carl D'Alvia's bionic monkey and child; Jeff Sonhouses' masklike face finely painted in watercolor with an Afro of real burned matches; Tricia Keightly's neo-Art Nouveau abstract painting; a comical, quirkily detailed landscape painted by Johan Nobell; and, by Jennifer Sirey, a wobbly, pyramidal tower of glass boxes with moldy interiors (Johnson).

"CAMERA WORKS: THE PHOTOGRAPHIC IMPULSE IN CONTEMPORARY ART," Marianne Boesky Gallery, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 680-9889 (through Aug. 10). Despite the encompassing title, this show focuses almost exclusively on photographs by 31 established artists, mostly in their 30's and 40's, who are not known primarily, if at all, for working with the camera. Usual suspects are in the majority, from Ross Bleckner to Lisa Yuskavage, with Peter Doig, Jessica Stockholder, Rachel Whiteread and Gregor Schneider in between. But there are still plenty of surprises and revelations, especially when you find yourself thinking that some of the assembled should stick to photography (Smith).

JASON DUVAL, Marcello Marvelli, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 627-3363 (through July 28). The small, blocky abstractions in this young painter's first solo exhibition have a painterly touch that veers from graceful to brusque and a finely tuned sense of color. At best, in two larger, more finished works that call to mind the paintings of Thomas Nozkowski, the circulating line, semi-transparent glazes and vibrating play of reds or greens reward extended contemplation (Johnson).

RICHARD HAMILTON: "PRINTS, 1968-1998," Charles Cowles Gallery, 537 West 24th Street, (212) 925-3500 (through next Friday). James Joyce's "Ulysses" and tabloid subjects like Mick Jagger's arrest for drug possession are part of the huge print repertory of the English painter Richard Hamilton. Mr. Hamilton is wide-ranging not only in subject matter but also in print technique; while not dispensing with venerable practices like etching and engraving, he sets no limits on technical possibilities, fooling around with contemporary techniques from silk-screening to computer manipulation of digital images, sometimes using several in the same print. This wonderfully animated show illustrates his belief that images will always be more important than the manner of their execution. But it also reveals the role that technical innovation plays in the impact of his graphic work (Glueck).

"HEAT," Margaret Thatcher, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 675-0222 (through July 27). This intentionally dissonant and overcrowded exhibition has some interesting things in it, like Patrick Wilson's smooth, dark red monchrome painting; a drippy, candy-colored stripe painting by Markus Linnenbrink; odd, slightly comical, smoothly carved lumps of marble by Venske and Spanle; and a radiating, psychedelic, computer-generated print by Daren Kendall (Johnson).

"OVERNIGHT TO MANY CITIES: TRAVEL AND TOURISM AT HOME AND AWAY," 303 Gallery, 525 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-1121 (through July 13). Organized by the artist and photographer Collier Schorr, this beautiful, exquisitely thought-through show reflects the intense scrutiny artists can bring to the work of others in their immediate vicinity. It includes 68 images by 32 photographers from several generations beginning with Walker Evans and encourages what might be called deep connoisseurship, a savoring of photographs as crafted objects, artistic statements and social documents, capable of releasing countless reverberations when carefully juxtaposed (Smith).

"SUPERIMPOSITION," Caren Golden Fine Art, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 727-8304 (through July 27). This smart group show by mostly young American artists, organized by the critic David Hunt, focuses on art based on stacking, layering, volume or the illusion of depth. One sculpture is made from vertically arranged reels of film, another from painstakingly assembled stones. A painting is composed from layers of drizzled paint; a fabric relief from a free-associational network of words. The deep space of science fiction gets some play in a Minimalist wall piece that doubles as a star ship control panel. And a digital work weaves together personal references, abstract forms and music (Cotter).

"THE WEDDING SHOW," Casey Kaplan, 416 West 14th Street, (212) 645-7335 (through July 31). The best piece in this miscellaneous roundup of gallery artists (titled in honor of Mr. Kaplan's recent nuptials) is Carsten Holler's reclining, hairless orangutan: with a life-size body of fleshy rubber, expressive glass eyes and bony toe- and fingernails, it has a winsome, almost human presence. Also noteworthy are Karen Yasinsky's drawing of Girl Scouts in the woods; Anna Gaskell's mysterious photographic narrative about nurses; and John Chilver's painterly play of abstraction around a primitive man and his campfire (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

* "BETWEEN STREET AND MIRROR: THE DRAWINGS OF JAMES ENSOR," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166 (through July 21). The show's pleasure partly involves serendipity. This feels like the perfect moment for an oddball like Ensor, but maybe any time would feel like the right time for somebody whose work, whether it is appalling or fantastic (and it can be both simultaneously), looks eternally modern. The drawings are from the 1880's and 90's. Some started out as ordinary sketches of household objects to which faces and monsters were added, like Rorschachs of the artist's imagination. They somehow become more luminous and translucent the more densely they are drawn, an extraordinary paradox. On the other hand, when the drawings aren't dense, they can be vaporous like Turners, with an effect akin to looking back on a dream: you can't quite place what you are seeing. But the emotion the images provoke is stronger precisely because of the frustration attached to it. Ensor is one of those artists Americans tend to forget or never really knew properly. A hero in Europe, he is vastly deserving of reappraisal here, and this excellent exhibition is a place to start (Kimmelman).

* LOUISE BOURGEOIS AND YAYOI KUSAMA, Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through Sept. 15). Bringing Ms. Bourgeois and Ms. Kusama together for the first time in this illuminating drawing show was an inspired idea. Both have found inspiration in the wilder parts of consciousness, and both have long practiced repetitive mark-making. In a recent drawing by Ms. Bourgeois, nested ovals made in a scratchy red line create a primitivistic, enigmatically iconic image. Ms. Kusama's dot fields and all-over linear networks produce, at their best, eye-buzzing opticality and cosmic transcendentalism (Johnson).

"SOME (ARE) PAINTING," John Gibson, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 925-1192 (through July 21). This well-selected show samples a type of sophisticatedly playful abstraction practiced by many young and semi-young painters these days. Highlights include Elizabeth Cooper's comically animated blobs of thick paint; Isolde Kille's glossy fields of graduated gray; Rachel Urkowitz's roundish white, cartoon-style "Ozone Hole"; Liza Stefanelli's elegant, whiplash calligraphy; and Karen Arm's finely brushed network of orange lines on a purple ground (Johnson).

JUDI WERTHEIN AND LEANDRO ERLICH: "TOURISMO," Kent Gallery, 67 Prince Street, at Crosby Street, (212) 966-4500, (through Aug. 2). This photo-installation piece by two Argentine artists, a hit at the seventh Havana Biennial last fall, revolves around big color Polaroids of ordinary Cubans posing as they please in a loonily unlikely setting: a sparkling winter wonderland incorporating a bright Alpine backdrop, fake snow underfoot and props including skis, a sled and Styrofoam snowballs. The original snow-scene set is also here -- pristine, carefully lighted and inviting. Cultural and climatic contrasts abound, and the images point up the paradox that although Cuba is economically dependent upon tourism, its citizens are not free to travel. But these beautiful, joyful, ineluctably poignant images transcend such didacticism. They exemplify the best kind of site-specific, political art, one that makes its points effortlessly and travels well (Smith).

"WET!" Luise Ross Gallery, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 343-2161, through July 27. Some summer group shows just want to have fun, and this one accomplishes the goal with admirable flair and ecumenicism. The slippery subject helps. Wetness is surveyed with a thoroughness that includes geography, food, sport and sex. The artists range from Sigmar Polke to Bill Traylor to Patty Chang and Nicole Eisenman, and the styles are just as various (Smith).

Other Galleries

"FACES AND FIGURES: CONTEMPORARY PHOTOGRAPHY IN SCANDINAVIA," Scandinavia House, 58 Park Avenue, near 38th Street, (212) 779-3587 (through July 29). Nordic photography makes a good showing here with a mix of established and lesser- known talents using a range of approaches, from documentary to personal diary. The aim is to dispel stereotypes about "coolness, control and psychic remoteness" in the words of Ann Sass, chief curator. And the show succeeds, with a humanscape of transvestite haunts in Paris, high jinks in Swedish suburbs, hunting and farming in Iceland, plain folk at home in Sweden, Christmas in Finland, prostitutes plying their trade in Denmark and children frolicking in Norway (Glueck).

Last Chance

* "COTE D'AZUR: ART, MODERNITY AND THE MYTH OF THE FRENCH RIVIERA," AXA Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street, (212) 554-4818 (through tomorrow). "A dream space created by artists for the 20th century" is how Kenneth E. Silver, author of the book that spawned this show, describes the French Riviera. And to prove the point, more than 70 works by 40 artists are on view, from Matisse and Picasso to the photographer Jacques-Henri Lartigue and the architect Le Corbusier and including more contemporary talents like Yves Klein and Eric Fischl. Rail access opened up the long-neglected southern coast to commerce and tourism in the 1860's, and the first artists, Renoir and Monet, arrived there in 1883 for a two-week tour. They evidently spread the word, for by the time of World War I the coast had become a mecca for artists whose palettes thrived on the dazzling quality of the light and the clear, fresh colors of the sky, water and vegetation. The Cote d'Azur's heyday is deftly covered, but one caveat: why clutter this persuasive survey, which really celebrates the coast as a garden of European modernism, with recent and peripheral works by a group of American artists? (Glueck).

"FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT AND THE ART OF JAPAN: THE ARCHITECT'S OTHER PASSION," Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through Sunday). Some shows are like a vigorous read; you have to concentrate and try to follow the plot. Wright, an architectural colossus and a wily diva of a man, is the main character. The story of his infatuation with Japanese art, and of how he turned that love to lucrative ends by moonlighting as a top-dollar dealer in woodblock prints -- at least until disaster struck -- is a rich one. It's told through dozens of architectural drawings, documentary photographs, woodblock prints and a superb accompanying book by the curator, Julia Meech, that wraps wide-ranging art historical research in a nimble, personable style. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "HOMAGE TO THE SQUARE: PICTURING WASHINGTON SQUARE, 1890-1965," Berry-Hill Galleries, 11 East 70th Street, (212) 744-2300 (through today). For generations Washington Square, with its grandiose marble arch, its pocket-handkerchief park, its stately phalanx of row houses on the north and other attractions, has drawn artists to live there as well as capture its image. This show of 90 paintings, photographs, drawings and prints reveals the square in many aspects and moods, with works by Edward Hopper, John Sloan, William Glackens, Jessie Tarbox Beals, Andre Kertesz, Diane Arbus and lesser lights. Even Thomas Hart Benton, who became famous for his depictions of hillbilly folk in the Ozarks, contributed to the area's iconology, painting a garrulous scene at the outdoor Washington Square art show in 1946. This mixed exhibition has a number of not-great works, but the park comes through, warts and all, as the New York legend that it is (Glueck).

MAUREEN McCABE: "ENCHANTMENTS," Kouros Gallery, 23 East 73rd Street, (212) 288-5888 (through today). The highly inventive fantasy behind these delicate assemblages draws on myths and ancient tales, religious symbols, charms, superstitions, the animal kingdom, the heavens and many other sources, including lore from the Ireland of Ms. McCabe's ancestors. Fish, a Mexican fortune teller, an ancient cemetery in the Irish hills, and the 19th-century interest in mesmerism are some of the subjects embroidered on by the artist, whose arcane knowledge and skilled craftsmanship combine to produce carefully plotted, well-executed riddles (Glueck).

REBECCA QUAYTMAN, Spencer Brownstone, 39 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 334-3455 (through tomorrow). Ms. Quaytman's ambitious project "The Sun" meditates on modernity and the deaths of her grandfather and great-grandfather in a train accident in 1940. It consists of 40 easel-size panels, half on view here and the rest in "Crossing the Line" at the Queens Museum. Installed here in a grid on one wall, Constructivist-style abstractions mix with silkscreened photographic images of trains, an Old World cemetery and a newspaper article about the accident, all to poetic and cinematic effect (Johnson).

HEADLINE: The I.M.F. Representative to Palestine 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 12 

 BODY:
A delegation of European diplomats was being quizzed in Israel recently about European financial support for the Palestinian Authority, which was supposed to be delayed until the Palestinians adopted strict new spending guidelines and put a stop to off-the-books business deals.
 "The budget is under control now," Miguel Moratinos, the European Union's envoy to the Middle East, said. "The International Monetary Fund has gone over everything and given its approval." 
 A few months earlier, Persian Gulf leaders were balking at direct disbursement of promised aid to the Palestinian Authority, which they worried might be squandered through inefficiency or corruption. Without their support, the authority faced almost certain bankruptcy. Nabil Shaath, the Palestinian minister responsible for foreign aid, approached the wealthy Arab states with a proposal: the I.M.F. would monitor Palestinian income and expenditures, and report to them directly every month. The money started flowing within weeks. 
"The I.M.F. has been very helpful to us," said an appreciative Ahmed Qurie, the speaker of the Palestinian parliament.
In dealings with the Palestinian Authority, the I.M.F. is embodied in one overextended man, Salaam Fayyad, a fast-talking and faster-calculating 49-year-old research economist who became the fund's first and only representative to the Palestinians five and a half years ago. In recent months, say many diplomats here, Mr. Fayyad has become the single most significant behind-the-scenes force keeping the Palestinian Authority solvent, not a role he or his employers originally envisioned.
"What I find absolutely remarkable is how much influence the I.M.F. has on the P.A. and on the donor community, and it is due entirely to Salaam's diligence," said Jeff Feltman, a special adviser on Palestinian affairs to the United States ambassador in Israel. "He has credibility with all sides."
From the start, Mr. Fayyad's assignment has been highly unusual. The Palestinian Authority is not a state, making it ineligible for I.M.F. loans or membership.
But when he volunteered for the job in 1995, Palestinian sovereignty was thought to be less than five years away. The Palestinians had asked the I.M.F. to help build a banking system, a finance ministry and a monetary authority. And big financial donors -- Japan, the United States, the European Union -- wanted the I.M.F. to provide independent oversight of aid disbursement.
Now, with prospects for peace and statehood fast receding, Mr. Fayyad is almost certainly the fund's only staff economist who routinely commutes through free-fire zones.
The four-hour round trip from his Jerusalem home to his Gaza City office takes him twice daily through the Israeli Army's Erez checkpoint, the scene of constant fighting lately. Though the I.M.F. offered him an armored car and chauffeur, he says such trappings would be ostentatious.
"I don't want to look like I am more important than anyone else here because I don't think I am," he said while driving one recent day through Gaza, dodging vendors and donkey carts.
Yet even the resolutely modest Mr. Fayyad recognizes that he and his institution have taken on an unexpected importance in the Palestinian world. "This has become a job with high visibility, with responsibilities that are very delicate, very sensitive politically," he acknowledged.
In the bloody tumult of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, the dry number-crunching of the International Monetary Fund might seem like an academic exercise at best, or at worst an insensitive distraction. Even in peaceful times, the I.M.F. is not always a welcome presence in deficit-ridden economies.
But before violence broke out in September, the fund was already a critical intermediary between the Palestinians and foreign donors -- and a powerful ally of local reformers pressing the Authority to open its books and keep revenues from vanishing into state companies run as private fiefs. Mr. Fayyad, colleagues and diplomats say, is one of the few outsiders who regularly see Yassir Arafat with little advance notice. 
"He is telling everyone the truth, as he sees it, and he has been extraordinarily effective," Stanley Fischer, the I.M.F.'s deputy director, said in a telephone interview.
Now, with the local economy devastated, the I.M.F. imprimatur has become almost essential to the authority's survival. Mr. Fayyad pushed the drafting of a pared-down Palestinian budget, and it is his monitoring efforts, backed by missions from I.M.F. headquarters, that have kept Arab and European funds filling a gap left by Israel's refusal to hand over some $180 million in Palestinian tax funds it has collected this year. Though Israel has voiced complaints about foreign financial support for the authority, it has not objected to assistance in facilitating the aid, I.M.F. officials say. 
With his University of Texas doctorate and his past service as a scholar at the Federal Reserve Bank in St. Louis and a top aide to the I.M.F.'s director in Washington, Mr. Fayyad would seem to conform to the green-eyeshades image of a fiscal overseer, scrupulous but detached. But Mr. Fayyad is a Palestinian by birth, from a family that has lived for generations in a village near the West Bank city of Tulkarm, which is now under Palestinian rule. 
He was acutely aware that some Palestinians -- and some aid donors, a group that until recently included Israel -- were expecting him to demonstrate some sympathetic leniency toward the Palestinian leadership. But by most accounts, he was more adamant in his advocacy of budget reform than were the American and European officials in the region.
"Because I am Palestinian, I was apprehensive before I came here," said Mr. Fayyad, who went to high school in Jordan and college in Lebanon before moving to the United States. "But it seems to have helped. I didn't have to overcompensate. And I was advocating things that have intrinsic value."
There is a rumor that Mr. Fayyad has a secretary, but he conducts most of his business personally, fielding calls from Washington and Riyadh and Tel Aviv on his two mobile phones while driving from appointment to appointment in an sport utility vehicle with a "UN-IMF 1" license plate. He appears to have memorized his phone book, along with the latest Palestinian balance-of-payments figures. 
Colleagues say he is intimately familiar with the erratically oscillating cash flow from aid donations and tax revenues, and the many peculiarities on the expenditure side of the Palestinian budget system. A persistent visitor to the Gaza offices of the Palestinian finance ministry, he is credited with forcing the consolidation of state accounts into one reasonably comprehensive and comprehensible document. "He is like a shadow finance minister," said a United Nations aid coordinator. "They need him, and so do we." 
But after five and a half years, Mr. Fayyad is reluctantly beginning to contemplate his next assignment. He has already far overstayed the normal two- or three-year stint for an I.M.F. field representative, Mr. Fischer said, because of the near-perpetual state of emergency in the region and the "unmatched" personal relationships he has developed with Palestinian and donor-government officials. 
Mr. Fayyad, who plays down his impact here, stresses that the emergency is not over, and that the $300 million in European and Arab aid he helped arrange will run out before the end of the year. "We have gained some time, until that money is exhausted," he said. "What will happen after that is a good question."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 14, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A headline in World Business yesterday about an International Monetary Fund representative in the Middle East referred incorrectly to the Palestinian governing body in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. It is the Palestinian Authority, not "Palestine."

HEADLINE: Overcome by Slavery 

BYLINE:  By Ira Berlin; Ira Berlin is author of "Many Thousands Gone: The First Two Centuries of Slavery in North America."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
On January 1, 1863, Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation declaring slaves forever free, but the subject remains very much alive. On the big screen we have had "Glory," "Amistad," "Shadrach" and "Beloved." On television, the four-part series "Africans in America" was followed by Henry Louis Gates Jr.'s controversial sojourn through Africa, during which he confronted African complicity in the slave trade. Such programs have come hard on the heels of new monuments and miles of freedom trails, dozens of exhibitions and the building of museums dedicated to slavery.
 In the past year, some 50 scholarly works on slavery have been published. Add dozens of Web sites, children's books and novels and at least one parody, "The Wind Done Gone." And, if that was not enough, there was the DNA confirmation of Thomas Jefferson's relationship with Sally Hemings. 
 The resonance of the Jefferson-Hemings affair provides a reminder of how much slavery has become part of contemporary politics. Bill Clinton realized this early on; hence the debate over The Apology and his appointment of the Commission on Race and Reconciliation. Congress has also gotten into the act, mandating that Civil War battle sites supervised by the National Park Service address slavery. Disputes over the Confederate flag and Confederate History Month have roiled politics in South Carolina, Georgia, Mississippi and Virginia, and California has required insurance companies to divulge if they have ever insured slave property. Finally, there is the matter of reparations, which has found advocates in some of the nation's prominent litigators.
It would be comforting to conclude that recognition of slavery's importance to the development of our economy, politics and culture has driven Americans to a consideration of the past. But there clearly is more to the current interest in slavery. There is a recognition that American racism was founded in slavery, and a general, if inchoate, understanding that any attempt to address race in the present must also address slavery in past.
This attempt has become imperative as American society perceptibly grows more segregated, the benefits of economic growth are unevenly and unfairly distributed among races, and a previous generation's remedies for segregation and inequality are discarded as politically unacceptable.
In short, behind the interest in slavery is the crisis of race. The confluence of the history of slavery and the politics of race reveals that slavery has become a language, a way to talk about race, in a society in which blacks and whites hardly talk to each other at all. In slavery, Americans have found a voice to address some of their deepest hurts and the depressing reality of how much of American life -- jobs; housing; schools; access to medical care, to justice and even to a taxi -- is controlled by race.
But while slavery serves as an entry point for a dialogue on race, it is not an easy one. For slavery carries with it deep anger, resentment, indignation and bitterness for some, embarrassment, humiliation and shame for others. The complications can be seen in the introduction of slavery into what had been a lily-white representation of Colonial Williamsburg -- by staging a slave auction. The local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People objected, finding the re-creation insulting to people of African descent -- a painful reminder of what no one wanted to have recalled. The director of the project, Christie Coleman, refused to retreat, insisting that slavery was an integral part of the history of colonial Williamsburg. The N.A.A.C.P. conceded Ms. Coleman's point.
The presentation of slavery at Colonial Williamsburg has since become routine, and the results have been astounding. Visitors get caught up in the re-enactments. Some offer to help slaves escape. Others protect slaves from abusive masters. Some turn on slaveowners, and not merely to debate the issue; several visitors have had to be physically restrained. Lest it be thought that it is only the visitors who forget they are witnesses to a re-enactment, the actors -- mostly young black men and women -- have been caught up in it as well. They report that while playing slaves they were often treated as slaves, not merely by visitors but by others as well, setting in motion nightmarish fantasies.
Viewing the present through the lens of the past is useful, necessary and perhaps inevitable. But it is also dangerous. If the re-enactment in Williamsburg and the new interest in slavery show how the past can illuminate, they also show how the differences between past and present can become blurred rather than clarified.
At the beginning of the 21st century, almost a century and a half after Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation, Americans are again struggling with slavery, and in so doing hope to vanquish slavery's legacy: the burden of race. The films, re-enactments, museums and books, as well as the politics, are part of that struggle. In turning to the past to understand the present, it has become evident that Americans will not be, in Lincoln's words, forever free until they have mastered slavery as slavery once mastered them. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Real Test of Welfare Reform Still Lies Ahead 

BYLINE:  By William Julius Wilson and Andrew J. Cherlin; William Julius Williams is a professor at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. Andrew J. Cherlin is a sociology professor at Johns Hopkins University.

 BODY:
In some circles, America's welfare reform has already been declared a success. Five years after Congress approved a time limit and work requirements for welfare, the number of people on the rolls has fallen by half, to six million, and many former recipients, including single mothers, have found at least part-time employment. But heartening as these facts are, it is premature to assume from them that the 1996 law has been a successful experiment. Five years is a short time for testing a substantively new social policy -- and these particular five years have not been ordinary ones. 
 A significant question remains: To what extent are these positive outcomes related to the extraordinary economic boom in the late 90's and into 2000? We don't know yet whether the numbers will hold if the current slowdown continues or gets worse. 
 And a close look reveals something else: a large group of women for whom the transition to work has not been successful even with the help of the boom.
To informed observers, the changes in the rates of welfare and employment from 1996 through 2000 should not be particularly surprising, given strong economic growth, extremely low unemployment rates, increases in the minimum wage and unexpectedly low inflation. The thriving economy has helped poor people happily become more self-sufficient. A study that we are conducting with several collaborators in low-income neighborhoods in Boston, Chicago and San Antonio has shown that some mothers who have left welfare and worked as security guards, shelf stockers or waitresses have an improved sense of self. However, low-wage employment by itself cannot ensure that all mothers who leave welfare will become self-sufficient. Many have not.
Our ongoing study, which began in 1999, is tracking a random sample of 2,458 families to monitor the consequences of the law. Field workers are closely observing another 235 families.
Three-fourths of the women we spoke to in 1999 who had been off welfare for two years or less had incomes below the federal poverty line. They were meeting basic expenses with government help like food stamps and, if they were working, the earned income tax credit.
The longer they had been off welfare, the less likely they were to have health insurance for themselves or their children, because decreases in the rates of Medicaid coverage were not offset by increases in their private insurance. And many mothers had great difficulties balancing work and child care without health coverage or other elements of the middle-class support system, like an automobile, some savings and paid sick leave.
Women with less education, with poorer health, with younger children and who are themselves young have considerably lower incomes and rates of employment after leaving welfare than do women with the opposite circumstances. And among those who had been on welfare for the longest periods, employment rates and incomes are considerably lower than average. Many of these women subsist by relying on money from friends and family, cutting back on necessities and delaying payment of bills.
The welfare reform law expires in 2002. As Congress gets ready to reauthorize it -- or modify it -- members should be giving serious attention to the significant numbers of women who have not fared well after leaving welfare and have been struggling in a booming economy. We have received a lot of information about the good news of welfare reform. Americans need to be aware of its limitations as well. And they must be wary of the potential for bad news, including a sharp increase in joblessness among former welfare recipients, if the economy does indeed turn sour.

HEADLINE: Dow Jones Second-Quarter Profit Fell 51% 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Second-quarter profit at Dow Jones & Company fell 51 percent because of lower advertising sales, the company said yesterday. The publisher of The Wall Street Journal said that third-quarter earnings might be less than half analysts' estimates.
 Profit from operations fell to $45.5 million, or 52 cents a share, from $93.7 million, or $1.06, in the quarter a year ago. That beat the 47-cent average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. 
 Advertising at Dow Jones and other media companies has fallen in step with the slowing economy. Dow Jones said it had eliminated 429 jobs, or 5 percent of its work force, this year to trim expenses. The cuts helped reduce costs by $150 million, Richard Zannino, the chief financial officer, said.
"The company is doing an aggressive job at managing costs," Peter Appert, a Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown analyst, said.
The shares of Dow Jones, which is based in New York, rose $2.74, to $59.69.
Third-quarter profit, before items, will be 20 cents to 30 cents a share, the company said. The average estimate of analysts was 55 cents, according to First Call.
Second-quarter sales fell 18 percent, to $484.1 million, from $593.2 million as The Wall Street Journal received fewer ads from financial and technology companies.
Dow Jones, which also publishes Barron's and SmartMoney magazine, is considering acquisitions that would add content to its newspapers and products that are distributed electronically in the United States and Europe, Peter Kann, the chief executive, said on a conference call. "It's a good time to be a buyer," Mr. Kann said.
In the recent quarter, Dow Jones took a charge of $10.4 million, or 12 cents a share, for cutting jobs and writing down assets related to its WSJ.com Web site.
The company had a gain of $8.1 million, or 9 cents a share, from the partial reversal of a reserve set aside for payment guarantees to data providers of its former Telerate unit, now owned by Bridge Information Systems. The items made net income $43.2 million, or 50 cents.

HEADLINE: Level of First-Time Unemployment Benefits Is Highest Since '92 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12 

 BODY:
The number of Americans lining up to receive first-time state unemployment benefits reached its highest level since 1992, the government said today in a report reflecting planned plant shutdowns by auto manufacturers that are gearing up for production of next year's models.
 The Labor Department said the number of initial jobless claims for the week ended July 7 rose 42,000, to 445,000. That far exceeded the slight decrease in claims Wall Street economists had expected. 
 Preliminary data showed much of the rise could be attributed to layoffs at automobile makers as they closed factories to retool for new model manufacturing, the department said. These seasonal layoffs came in at 146,000, which was much higher than the 98,000 the department had expected, an official said.
Economists typically have less concern over rises in jobless claims during this time of year because of the expected auto plant shutdowns. "As we get into the month of July it is always a difficult and very volatile period for initial claims," said Ken Mayland, an economist with ClearView Economics in Pepper Pike, Ohio.
Still, the number of initial jobless claims for the week ended July 7, was the highest since July 25, 1992, when they were at 539,000 as the economy struggled out of recession. The four-week moving average, considered a more reliable barometer of employment conditions because it irons out weekly fluctuations, rose to 410,750 last week from 408,250.
A separate Labor Department report today showed that import prices fell in June, reflecting a falloff in prices for petroleum, food, industrial and consumer goods. The data showed virtually no signs that inflation was being imported into the United States.
The department said import prices fell 0.5 percent in June after rising 0.2 percent in May. Import prices were down 2.6 percent compared with the corresponding period last year. Excluding petroleum, import prices fell 0.4 percent in June, posting the fifth-consecutive monthly decline.

HEADLINE: California Rate-Refund Request Is Curtailed 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, July 12 

 BODY:
An administrative law judge mediating talks between the State of California and energy companies said today that the state was probably owed "hundreds of millions of dollars" in refunds, much less than the $8.9 billion it wants.
 The judge, Curtis L. Wagner Jr., in a recommendation released today, said that while there were vast sums due for overcharges, California utilities, grid managers and the state agency purchasing power owed generators even more. 
 Gov. Gray Davis and state officials who attended the 15-day talks held out for $8.9 billion, but Judge Wagner said that amount "has not and cannot be substantiated."
"That very large refunds are due is clear," Judge Wagner wrote, probably amounting to "hundreds of million of dollars, probably more than a billion dollars in an aggregate sum."
The amount should be decided in a hearing, he said.
The judge recommended a method for calculating refunds back to October. California's estimate is based on figures from May 1, 2000.
Mr. Davis had no comment today.
Peter Navarro, a University of California at Irvine economist who works on energy issues, called the recommendation "insulting" to California. Mr. Navarro said the refund order should reach back to at least last July, when energy prices hit record levels and utilities were accruing billions of dollars in debts.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK; 
Chinese Officials Avoid Tough Questions

BYLINE:  By JERE LONGMAN

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 12 

 BODY:
Beijing officials took no chances on being blindsided by potentially embarrassing questions today as they met with the 1,500 members of the news media gathered for Friday's vote for the host city of the 2008 Summer Olympics.
 In an obviously rehearsed portion of the news conference, Chinese journalists from state-controlled print and broadcast outlets were chosen to ask questions about human rights, pollution and sclerotic traffic so that officials could give their carefully planned answers. 
 "We're confident with the Games coming to China, they will promote the economy and also enhance all social sectors -- education, medical care and human rights," said Wang Wei, co-leader of the Beijing bid group.
Reporters from around the world attended the news conference, and the Chinese knew that the give-and-take could hardly be scripted with everyone. So they relied on the humor and ebullience of the other bid leader, Tu Mingde, whose animated style brought to mind a cross between Stan Laurel and Tigger. 
"Thank you for your question," Tu said repeatedly, always with a smile, when reporters asked about mass executions and access to write about sensitive issues such as labor camps.
"We respect the rule of law, as any other country," Wei said when asked whether China would suspend the death penalty over the next seven years if it were awarded the 2008 Olympics.
"It's not China alone that has the death penalty," Wei said, in an apparent reference to the United States, where some members of Congress and human rights groups have urged the International Olympic Committee to choose a different site for the Games.
Despite international concerns over human rights issues, the suppression of the Falun Gong spiritual group and the jailing of journalists and Chinese-American scholars, a majority of the I.O.C. delegates seemed poised to grant the 2008 Games to Beijing over four other candidates: Paris; Toronto; Osaka, Japan; and Istanbul.
The vote, scheduled for 10 a.m. Eastern time Friday (10 p.m. in Beijing), will take place in rounds. The bid receiving the fewest votes in each round is eliminated until a majority is achieved. Delegates from the countries involved in the bids cannot vote as long as their country is in contention.
"I don't see a mood change that has all along had Beijing as the front-runner," said Kevan Gosper, an influential delegate from Australia.
Aside from appearing to want to send the Games to the world's most populous nation, the I.O.C. also appears to favor Beijing for internal political reasons.
Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the I.O.C., is stepping down after 21 years, and wants to leave a Beijing Games as his legacy. Also, some delegates seem to want to reward Beijing for its sportsmanlike behavior when it narrowly lost to Sydney in 1993 for a chance to play host to the 2000 Summer Games. Sydney prevailed by two votes, and bid officials admitted that they had made offers of $35,000 apiece to delegates from Kenya and Uganda the night before the vote.
"You bite your lip and hope the breaks will eventually come your way," Dick Pound, an I.O.C. delegate from Canada, said in reference to Beijing's restrained, uncomplaining response to the Sydney victory.
Ashwini Kumar, a recently retired I.O.C. delegate from India, said that some older members wanted the Beijing question to be settled now so they could return the Games to Europe in 2012; Paris (if it loses Friday), London, Madrid, Moscow and a German city would probably bid for those Games.
There has been much speculation here that other European delegates would not support the Paris bid this time because they were looking ahead to 2012. But French bid officials were not giving up hope. They were expected to include French President Jacques Chirac, Prime Minister Lionel Jospin and the soccer star Zinedine Zidane in a final hourlong presentation to the I.O.C. on Friday.
Bertrand Delanoe, the mayor of Paris, sought to deflect the reputation of French haughtiness today, saying that the French bid rejected "arrogance and pretension in favor of perfection, professionalism and generosity of a city that belongs to the world."
Toronto's final presentation to the I.O.C. on Friday is expected to include an appearance by Prime Minister Jean Chretien. With its sporting sites concentrated in a small waterfront area, Toronto is positioning itself as the most athlete-friendly Games. Instead of a number of officials in suits, Toronto's bid has included a number of athletes as spokesmen.
"For the first time, the foundation of the Olympic bid has been created by the athletes," said Marnie McBean, an Olympic champion rower.
Some I.O.C. officials privately said that delegates have grown resentful of Toronto officials for being too pushy and pedantic.

Warm Welcome for Samaranch
The 112th session of the International Olympic Committee opened Thursday night at the Bolshoi Theater, with President Vladimir Putin of Russia standing side by side with Juan Antonio Samaranch, who was elected I.O.C. president in Moscow during the 1980 Summer Games.
"Throughout my presidency, I have endeavored to build a unified Olympic movement," Samaranch said. "I am aware, nevertheless, that this unity is fragile and that it must constantly be protected. That is the key to our success."
Putin made gracious remarks about Samaranch, presented him with a special award and held up Samaranch's arm as if he had won a boxing match.

A New Order
At the request of its athlete's commission, the International Olympic Committee's executive board decided today to reverse the order of medal presentations as an experiment at the 2002 Winter Games in Salt Lake City.
For more than a century, the gold medalist has stood alone on the podium to receive his or her medal. Then the silver medalist was honored, followed by the bronze medalist. In Salt Lake City, the order will be reversed to bring greater attention and honor to the silver and bronze medalists and to build the ceremony to a crescendo with the gold medalist.

Ethics Commission Decides
The International Olympic Committee's ethics commission decided to continue to investigate, instead of expelling, the suspended delegate Mohamad (Bob) Hasan of Indonesia. Hasan is serving a six-year jail sentence on corruption charges stemming from logging in the rainforests. The commission also took no action against another delegate, Lassan Palenfo, who is serving a year in jail in the Ivory Coast on charges of conspiring to assassinate one of that West African country's military leaders. Juan Antonio Samaranch, the I.O.C. president, has attempted unsuccessfully, by appealing to the heads of those countries, to have Hasan and Palenfo freed from jail.

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
A New Deal For Tenant And Landlord

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
THE mayoral candidates are promising to spend billions to ease New York's housing crisis, but even their most ambitious plans won't make much difference anytime soon, if ever. Meanwhile, they're all overlooking a cheap, simple way to provide a dramatic number of new homes immediately.
 There are about a million rent-regulated apartments in the naked city, and some of those tenants would prefer to live elsewhere. Many are already living out of town and are illegally hanging on to their places as pieds-a-terre. Many elderly tenants would be happier in retirement communities; many young families would like bigger homes in the suburbs. But they're all understandably reluctant to give up a good deal. 
 The obvious solution to everyone's problems is to pay those tenants to give up their deals. Some landlords have already done that, but these buyout negotiations are problematic. Many landlords and tenants hate each other too much to sit in the same room long enough to negotiate a mutually beneficial deal. Even when landlords and tenants have civil relations, each side tends to resist a buyout proposal initiated by the other.
If the landlord makes the first offer, the tenant often suspects he's anxious to settle because he plans to convert the building into a condominium, so the tenant holds out, expecting to make more money from the conversion. If the tenant makes the first move for a buyout, the landlord suspects that the tenant is eager to move and will be leaving soon anyway, so the landlord feels no need to offer much money. 
Suppose, though, that the negotiations were a simple one-step computerized process started by a third party: the city, say, or a private organization trusted by both tenants and landlords. This referee could invite all tenants and landlords to submit bids separately for what they'd accept in a buyout offer. Participation would be purely voluntary on both sides. 
Just as Priceline.com matches passengers' bids with airlines willing to offer the fare, the referee would compare offers for each apartment and reveal which ones overlapped. If the landlord offered to give $30,000 and his tenant offered to take $20,000, the referee would split the difference and set the buyout figure at $25,000. 
Unless a landlord really hated the old tenant, he wouldn't offer a buyout unless he could make more money from a new tenant. So deals would generally be possible only when the regulated rent was well below the potential rent for the apartment. No one knows exactly how many apartments fit that category, but we can make an educated guess thanks to some unpublished data Edgar O. Olsen dug up this week from a study that he and Rachel Parkin did for the New York City Rent Guidelines Board.
Dr. Olsen, an economist at the University of Virginia, said that in 1996 about 250,000 rent-stabilized apartments were going for at least 17 percent below their market value in their current condition. That figure doesn't include the roughly 50,000 rent-controlled apartments where the disparities tend to be still higher, or the many apartments that could command higher rents if they were fixed up. 
CONSIDERING those figures, and the feverish real estate market since 1996, let's assume that landlords would be willing to buy out the tenants of at least 300,000 apartments. If, say, 20 percent of those tenants took the buyouts, there would be 60,000 new vacancies. The net gain in housing units would depend on how many of those tenants left town. (There would still be social benefits when they remained: a widow who took a buyout and moved to a smaller apartment in the same building would make room for a family that valued the extra space more highly.) 
If, say, half of those tenants used their buyout money to live outside New York, the city would end up gaining 30,000 housing units virtually overnight. That would be triple the number of new housing units built during a typical year in New York. The most ambitious plans from mayoral candidates and housing advocates call for building and rehabilitating only about 20,000 units per year -- at a cost to taxpayers of more than $1 billion. 
This buyout plan would cost virtually nothing, at least in its simplest version. But the potential numbers seem so promising that the city might want to encourage more buyouts by adding sweeteners to the deals. Wouldn't that be a more efficient use of city money than the subsidies favored by the mayoral candidates? Or am I missing something? Candidates and noncandidates are welcome to send their thoughts to
jtier@nytimes.com.

HEADLINE: Small Power Plants Planned in Nassau County 

BYLINE:  By ELISSA GOOTMAN

DATELINE: GLENWOOD LANDING, N.Y., July 12 

 BODY:
As part of efforts to stave off California-like blackouts on Long Island next summer, the Long Island Power Authority and the KeySpan Energy Corporation announced plans today to build two small power plants here on Nassau County's North Shore.
 The plants, to be built across the street from a much larger, existing plant, would be used only during periods of peak electricity demand, like the hottest days of summer and the coldest days of winter, officials said. If approved quickly, the plants, as well as at least three other proposed mini-plants, could be ready by next summer, making for a total of at least 47 peak-use plants on Long Island. 
 Meanwhile, on the other end of the Island, energy experts, politicians and utility executives gathered today at Brookhaven Town Hall for a daylong meeting. The topic was how Long Island, which has limited links to regional power grids but plenty of air-conditioners and swimming pools, can meet its power needs. 
Even as LIPA officials proposed the two plants here as an important step toward addressing those needs, some critics at the meeting said the plants were merely the latest pieces in a haphazard response to a tight electricity supply. 
"I think it's a willy-nilly approach," said Gordian Raacke, executive director of the Citizens Advisory Panel, a watchdog group that monitors LIPA. "There ought to be a comprehensive plan, and LIPA obviously does not have it," he added.
The chairman of LIPA, Richard M. Kessel, said the new plant proposals were evidence of the utility's long-term thinking. Together, the two plants would generate about 79 megawatts of electricity, enabling them to circumvent a lengthy state environmental approval process required for generators that produce at least 80 megawatts of electricity. (A megawatt is enough to power about 1,000 average homes.)
The plants, which are fired by natural gas, still need a series of state and local approvals, and utility officials said they hoped to begin operating the plants by late spring. The plants would occupy a half-acre on a 28-acre plot of land owned by KeySpan in a light-industrial tract overlooking Hempstead Harbor, where the nearest home is about a quarter-mile away. Their two stacks will rise 145 feet. A 350-megawatt power station sits across the street, and a country club and a public park are also nearby. 
Ashok Gupta, a senior energy economist at the National Resources Defense Council, criticized the technology of the smaller plants as outdated and inefficient, saying that larger plants emit much less air pollution because they require less fuel to produce the same amount of energy. He said there were better ways to meet peak demand, such as refurbishing old plants or building larger plants with components designated for peak use. 
But Mr. Kessel said that the Glenwood Landing plants would be cleaner than most existing plants on Long Island, and that a larger plant could not be completed in time to help next summer.
"I think we have enough electricity to get us through this summer, but things are tight," he told those at the meeting. On June 28, he said, Long Island was about 300 or 400 megawatts away from its total generating capacity of about 4,500 megawatts for that day. 
So, in addition to the Glenwood Landing plants, which KeySpan is spending $100 million to build, LIPA has proposed a 44-megawatt turbine in Far Rockaway and two others in Shoreham. "We are going to need a number of these small turbines on Long Island to get us through," Mr. Kessel said. 
Mr. Kessel and Robert B. Catell, the chairman and chief executive of KeySpan, said their representatives had been meeting with community groups over the course of the past month to discuss the proposed plants. 
Mr. Kessel said he hoped the Glenwood Landing plants would be received as warmly as a proposal that the two utilities announced in May to build a 250-megawatt plant in an industrial section of Melville. 
The treasurer of the Glenwood-Glen Head Civic Association, Cecelia P. McCann, said her group was not planning to oppose the two mini-plants here, in part because of the longtime presence of the power station across the street. 
"We've certainly heard nothing regarding emissions -- noise emissions, smoke emissions -- that would lead us to believe that there will be any negative impact," Ms. McCann said. 
At a public park near Tappan Beach, less than half a mile down Shore Road from the site, there was little agreement about the plants among a group of mothers waiting to collect their sons from day camp. 
Betty Clampet, 41, of Glen Head, agreed with Ms. McCann, saying she would welcome the extra tax revenue for the community. 
"We have a lot of electrical stuff down here -- what's the difference?" Mrs. Clampet said. "It's either we have electricity or we don't have electricity." But Eileen E. Murphy, 41, her neighbor, disagreed. "Let somebody else have a power plant," she said. "We already have one." 

GRAPHIC: Map of Nassau, Long Island, highlighting Glenwood Landing: The Glenwood Landing plants would be used to meet peak demand.

HEADLINE: Markets Disapprove Of Argentina's Plan To Rescue Economy 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, July 12 

 BODY:
Political leaders and investors turned a disapproving cold shoulder today to a new round of austerity measures offered by the government, sending local financial markets plummeting and a chill through some markets abroad.
 It was the second jolt in the markets this week for Argentina, which has been struggling to contain an economic and banking crisis for several months. 
 On Tuesday, interest rates spurted as the government auctioned more than $800 million in short-term bonds. Treasury bill yields soared to 14 percent, the highest rate in five years. Today, overnight bank rates were quoted as high as 150 percent, as investors signaled that they considered Argentina's finances increasingly risky. 
Late Wednesday, Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo, who engineered the country out of a economic morass a decade ago, announced major cuts in public salaries and pensions and an increase in taxes intended to eliminate a projected $1.5 billion budget deficit in the second half of the year. Although the measures would surely be painful, they were proposed to respond to growing fears internationally that Argentina was heading toward bankruptcy and a devaluation of its currency.
But the announcement sparked angry threats from labor leaders and chafing within the already fractious government. Instead of firming the weakening values of Argentine bonds and stocks, the move only gave economists and investors more evidence that the government is careering without clear direction month to month from one divergent economic approach to another. 
The Merval stock index here closed down 8.2 percent after having rebounded from a 13 percent decline. It has fallen 24 percent in two weeks.
The fallout from Argentina has been felt the most in neighboring Brazil, South America's largest economy and Argentina's largest trading partner. Its currency fell to a low today against the dollar. The currencies of Mexico and Chile also fell, as did the leading index on the Mexican stock market.
The effects of Argentina's troubles have not been as severe as past emerging market crises like those in 1997 and 1998. But in recent days, stock markets as far away as South Africa, Taiwan and Turkey have been shaken by Argentina's debt troubles. Today, though some emerging-market currencies strengthened.
In the United States, stock prices rose, owing mostly to a broad rally after a bullish forecast by Microsoft. Treasury prices also rose, and some analysts attributed that to investors' leaving emerging market debt like Argentine treasury bonds for the safety of United States securities.
The mounting political opposition to the Argentine program appeared intended to forestall greater austerity measures like cuts in health care, education and Social Security spending. But it is exactly such cuts that many economists say will be needed for the government to continue to pay interest payments on the debt. 
The uncertainty of whether the government is strong enough to take such measures has had the effect of raising interest rates, making debt payments more expensive. 
In recent weeks, a consensus has emerged among Wall Street analysts that a default or a debt restructuring was probably likely. An outright currency devaluation, considered less likely, would hurt living standards significantly.
Neither the United States nor the International Monetary Fund foresee intervening to help Argentina.
Argentina has suffered through a three-year recession, with unemployment exceeding 16 percent and a growing number of businesses entering bankruptcy. In recent weeks, the crisis has been compounded by rapidly rising interest rates rooted in investor doubts that the central government and provinces can fulfill their payment obligations on a combined debt of $150 billion.
Those doubts have been stoked by the growing perception that President Fernando de la Rua is unable to inspire public confidence or unite his diverse ruling coalition around a program to manage government finances or growing social unrest. 
Mr. Cavallo announced on Wednesday cuts of 8 to 10 percent in wages for more than a quarter of a million federal employees and equivalent cuts in pension benefits for retired government workers. He also proposed an increase in a financial transactions tax and a new court system to crack down on major tax evaders. But he stopped short of announcing cuts in services or layoffs of government workers.
"We have to spend only what we have," Mr. de la Rua said.
"The public sector will not borrow money at exorbitant rates," Mr. Cavallo said. "But we will pay the debt. We have money to do so." 
He also vowed to keep the value of the Argentine peso tied to the dollar.
Mr. Cavallo's announcement on Wednesday represented a change of emphasis, if not of direction, from the wide array of approaches that he has tried since returning as economy minister four months ago. He had previously cast aspersions on austerity, preferring to increase manufacturing through instituting protectionist measures and multiple exchange rates to subsidize exporters.
The problems have developed over several years. Although the economy grew by 43 percent in the 90's as President Carlos Saul Menem privatized much of the government and cut regulations, government spending rose by a larger 90 percent.
The economy began slowing after the Asian and Russian financial crises in 1998, as international investors began withdrawing from emerging markets. A drop in prices for agricultural exports further slowed growth, lowering tax receipts. Mr. de la Rua raised taxes shortly after taking office in January 2000, a policy that slowed growth without closing a growing fiscal deficit.
The policies did not satisfy international investors, who are seeking a stronger effort at cutting spending, nor several pivotal leaders in the center-left government coalition or opposition who say the new austerity policies will only contract the economy even more. For cuts in spending to stick, the government will look to its shaky support in Congress.
Mr. De la Rua and Mr. Cavallo had to delay announcing their program by two hours, as competing sectors of the cabinet argued heatedly behind closed doors. Then, many senior officials in the governing coalition refused to attend the announcement.
The leader of the governing Radical Party in Buenos Aires Province, Federico Storani, was one of the leaders in Mr. De la Rua's party who were caustic. "This is the kind of policy that has been proven to fail," he said. "With this adjustment, Cavallo has confessed his failure."
Leaders of the opposition Justicialist Party, who control most governors' offices and the Senate, were also critical. "It's the last card they have to play," said Senator Eduardo Menem, brother of the former president, whose recent indictment has complicated relations between the government and the opposition. "It's only going to generate more problems," he added.
