HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
A Building for Families With Low Incomes: It Took Perseverance

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Perseverance, a six-story, 30-apartment building for very low-income residents on the Lower East Side, officially opened this week, a little more than a year after the leader of the nonprofit group that sponsored the building seized on the name during an airline flight.
 As the building's name implies, it took far longer than a year to bring the project, which is between Avenues A and B, to fruition. And the wait has been worth it for residents like Gabriella Sonam, who, at a dedication ceremony on Tuesday, told how she had knelt in front of the building's doorway at 535-541 East Fifth Street, praying that she would be chosen to live there. 
 It was in May 2000 that Mary Spink, executive director of the Lower East Side People's Mutual Housing Association, was thumbing through a sales catalog on an airline when she saw an ad for motivational posters, including one labeled "Perseverance" that told the tale of Abraham Lincoln's early-life failures. 
"It reminded me of everything we've gone through with this building for nearly a decade," Ms. Spink said. "I came back and told my board and they unanimously agreed to name the building Perseverance."
Ms. Spink's housing group has renovated and manages 25 buildings containing 380 apartments for low-income people on the Lower East Side. They are mostly tax-foreclosed properties handed over by the city for $3 a lot. "Building very low-income housing is difficult enough, but this one was next to impossible," Ms. Spink said.
Originally, the project called for the gut renovation of two tenements, built in the 1890's, containing 22 apartments. In 1992, control of those buildings was granted to another housing group, which, after running into financial difficulties, merged with Ms. Spink's association. "When the merger was complete," she said, "we got new financing to renovate the buildings. But in the interim, about 20 squatters had moved in." With the city reluctant to remove the squatters, the project stalled.
"Eventually, we obtained a new funding commitment," Ms. Spink said. "But within a month of closing on our financing, there was a fire in the buildings. They were declared unsafe and had to be demolished."
Finally, three years ago, the New York State Housing Trust Fund provided $1.7 million toward construction of a new building, and the Enterprise Foundation, a nonprofit housing and community development organization, supplied $4 million.
Construction of the building -- with its cast-stone lintels and portico and a cornice reminiscent of its 19th-century neighbors -- was completed last December. Immediately, tenants who had been selected by lottery after submitting documents showing they earned less then 40 percent of the metropolitan area's median income -- no more than $22,480 for a family of four -- moved in. The building's one-bedroom apartments rent for $355 a month; its two-bedroom units, for $435.
All the tenants are members of a mutual housing association. "Any decisions, including electing the board that runs the building, are voted on by the tenants," Ms. Spink said. The board consists of seven residents and six community representatives, including a member of the community board, an architect and a lawyer.
Delio Fernandez, a cabdriver, appreciates the sense of community. He, his wife, Belkis, and sons, Anthony, 6, and Marcos, 5, used to live in a one-bedroom apartment in Inwood. Their new two-bedroom, he said, "is heaven."
"The tenants are helpful, in that we're looking after it," Mr. Fernandez said. "If I see a piece of paper on the floor, I pick it up. Here you're made aware that you should be doing it."
No one could be more grateful to be in the building than Ms. Sonam, who fervently sought "divine intervention" after submitting "at least 25 applications in 10 years" for subsidized housing.
Recently trained as a massage therapist in a transition from Social Security disability, Ms. Sonam, along with her daughter, Akrah, 10, used to live nearby on Avenue C. "My landlord harassed me," she said. "I paid $800 for 250 square feet of raggedy space -- a tenement. He could double my rent."
Ms. Sonam felt the Perseverance building was her last chance.
"I lit candles," she said. "I came by every day. On Thanksgiving Day I couldn't think of anything to be thankful for. So, in the freezing, nasty weather we came here and got down on our knees." She believed, she said, "that divine intervention was the only way to get my envelope pulled out of the 8,000" in the lottery.
In her old apartment, Ms. Sonam said, "We had a toilet behind a curtain, three feet from my bed. Now I have a bathroom with a door! And for the first time in her life my daughter has her own room."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Residents of Perseverance, like Gabriella Sonam, at left with her daughter Akrah, and Delio Fernandez were selected in a lottery. Ms. Sonam said she had prayed in the building's doorway that she would get in. (Edwine Seymour for The New York Times)

 INTERNATIONAL A3-8

U.S. Drops 2-War Strategy To Buttress Home Defense
The United States is abandoning requirements that its military be able to fight two major wars simultaneously, according to a classified document. The new strategy orders the armed forces to "win decisively" in a single major conflict, defend American territory against new threats and wage a number of actions around the globe. The shift could mean more money for the proposed missile shield and for fighting terrorism. A1

Senior Pentagon officials disclosed details of a missile defense testing plan that they said could lead to a working system within four years. Senate Democrats said it would probably violate the Antiballistic Missile Treaty within a year. A1

HEADLINE: Musicians, Drugs And Gil Scott-Heron 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The musician Gil Scott-Heron (front page, July 10) is but a highly visible casualty of the unjust and misguided "war on drugs." The Nobel economist Milton Friedman said it best in a 1972 article, and again on your Op-Ed page three years ago: 
 "On ethical grounds, do we have the right to use the machinery of government to prevent an individual from becoming an alcoholic or a drug addict? For children, almost everyone would answer at least a qualified yes. But for responsible adults, I, for one, would answer no. Reason with the potential addict, yes. Tell him the consequences, yes. Pray for and with him, yes. But I believe that we have no right to use force, directly or indirectly, to prevent a fellow man from committing suicide, let alone from drinking alcohol or taking drugs."
This system has made a criminal of Mr. Scott-Heron, as it has with so many others who should enjoy the fundamental right to be left alone.

VAUGHN A. CARNEY
Stowe, Vt., July 11, 2001

HEADLINE: School Leaders Contend Laws May Cause Lower Standards 

BYLINE:  By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12 

 BODY:
The superintendents of the nation's two largest city school systems warned today that the toughened testing and accountability measures passed by the House and Senate recently could drive down educational standards, rather than raising student achievement.
 Speaking at a panel this morning at the National Press Club, the two officials, Roy Romer, the superintendent of schools in Los Angeles, and Harold O. Levy, schools chancellor in New York City, said that despite lofty rhetoric, the legislation had numerous pitfalls and seemed to ignore the realities of running urban schools. 
 The bills give schools 10 to 12 years to bring all students -- black and white, middle class and poor, Anglo and Hispanic and those with limited English -- up to proficiency and to require states to report the performance of each category of students and to set the criteria for proficiency. Mr. Romer said the bills would tempt local authorities to dilute the meaning of proficiency, so they could avoid sanctions affecting federal aid. 
"You'll have people out there gaming the system," Mr. Romer said. "Don't give us a bill that ties us the way the Lilliputians tied Gulliver."
In Los Angeles, Mr. Romer said, the school system is sorely overcrowded. Regardless of the bills' requirements that children be allowed to transfer out of failing schools, he said that in Los Angeles "there was no option of public school choice."
Also on the panel were David W. Hornbeck, the former superintendent of schools in Philadelphia, and Eugene W. Hickock, the Bush administration's undersecretary of education and former commissioner of education in Pennsylvania.
On Tuesday, lawmakers appointed members of a House-Senate conference committee to begin deciding the final wording of the education bill. Today, the chairmen and ranking members of the House and Senate education committees met privately in what was described as a preconference meeting.
a preconference meeting.
Significant differences between the two chambers' education bills will be negotiated in closed-door sessions of the conference committee, but both House and Senate bills require annual testing of all students from third to eighth grade -- initially, in reading and math, but eventually in history and science as well. 
Unlike the House bill, which would punish states for failing to show improvement by various racial and economic groups of students, the Senate bill judges states through a complicated formula averaging the scores of all students, provided that the performance for each category edges up at least 1 percent. 
The bills leave it to the states to define proficiency and to say how they will measure it. Under legislation passed in 1994, all states must establish objective standards to measure math and reading ability, but many states have opted for cheaper, more politically expedient examinations that rate students in relation to others taking the test. Though these tests run counter to the 1994 law, the federal government has shied from penalizing states over their use.
Noting that the huge New York and Los Angeles school systems were responsible for educating nearly 6 percent of all public school children, Mr. Levy said he watched the debate over education "with some amusement." Many of the ideas under discussion here are under way in New York, including the use of magnet schools and annual testing.
"But what success we've had is much more correlated with other things," including the quality of teachers, Mr. Levy said.
The education bills combine programs that had once been dedicated to the professional training of teachers and reductions in class size into a single, diminished pot of money. In 1970, Mr. Levy recalled, a starting teacher in New York City earned $1,000 to $2,000 less than a starting lawyer at a white-shoe law firm. Now, he said, the gap is $125,000.
"If the system's accountable," he said, "then I say the politicians and policy makers also have to be accountable. With all the standards and reform, there's a need for adequate resources."
Mr. Hornbeck said he welcomed the emphasis on accountability and preferred the House's stricter provisions. "We've got to quit masking the disaggregated failure" of education, he said.
He said the move toward giving block grants in the name of cutting red tape alarmed him, given the number of urban school systems that have had to sue state officials for a fair share of education money.
"To give power over what to do with block grants to people who are only moved by lawsuits is a misguided way of running one's life," he said.

HEADLINE: Except for Discount Stores, Retailers Suffered in June 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Consumers spooked by stock market volatility and company layoffs curtailed their spending once again in June, leaving the nation's largest retailers with disappointing sales.
 Discounters, notably Wal-Mart Stores and warehouse clubs, were the only retail sector that released robust sales figures yesterday, an indication that worries about the economy were keeping consumers price conscious. 
 Department stores and apparel chains, particularly Federated Department Stores, May Department Stores and AnnTaylor Stores, continued to languish amid heavy markdowns of seasonal fashions like shorts and tank tops. 
"I expected June to be bad, but not quite this bad," said Kurt Barnard, publisher of The Barnard Retail Trend Report, based in Montclair, N.J.
"Consumers are very worried about spending money and about the future," Mr. Barnard added. "They are deep in debt to their credit cards. They will buy what they absolutely need, and they will do it while bargain hunting."
AnnTaylor, which reported a 12.3 percent decline in sales at stores open at least a year, cut its second-quarter earnings projections to 20 cents to 24 cents a share from 28 cents to 32 cents. The company, whose total sales were up a slim 2.1 percent, also lowered its full-year earnings forecast.
Federated, which last week reduced its second-quarter earnings estimates by more than one-third, reported yesterday that sales from stores open at least a year fell 6.4 percent, while total sales dropped 10.4 percent.
Sales at stores open at least a year are considered the best indicator of a retailer's health.
The Gap met expectations, but "margins fell well below plan," according to Heidi Kunz, chief financial officer. The apparel retailer had a 7 percent drop in sales at stores open at least a year, with total sales rising 12 percent.
Retailers known for low prices fared the best in June.
Wal-Mart reported that sales at stores open a year rose 6.9 percent, well above analysts' expectations of a 4 percent to 5 percent gain. Total sales were up 14.6 percent.
Kmart, which has increased discounting through its blue-light-special promotion, met expectations with a 1.1 percent increase in sales at stores open a year. Total sales fell 0.1 percent.
Costco Wholesale and BJ's Wholesale Club also reported strong sales that met analysts' projections. Costco reported a 5 percent gain in sales at stores open a year and a 12 percent total sales increase. BJ's had a 4 percent gain in sales at stores open a year, with total sales up 8.5 percent.
June, which accounts on average for 9.8 percent of total annual retail sales, is the second most important month of the year, behind December. It is a time when retailers hope to do the bulk of their summer business -- at regular price. But this year was different, analysts said, citing widespread markdowns.
"It was pretty disappointing," said Jeffrey Feiner, managing director at Lehman Brothers, who cut earning projections for about a dozen retailers yesterday.

HEADLINE: Panel Calls for Higher Mileage Standards 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12 

 BODY:
A pivotal House panel voted tonight to require carmakers to raise the fuel economy of sport-utility vehicles and minivans, setting the stage for the first congressionally mandated increase in auto efficiency standards in a generation.
 The measure, a compromise adopted by the Energy and Air Quality Subcommittee, indicated broad bipartisan support to force automobile companies to improve the mileage of sport-utility vehicles, which have surged in popularity in recent years but largely escaped regulation. 
 Though environmentalists and some leading Republicans as well favor more aggressive steps to raise auto efficiency, the 29-to-3 vote today is a rare defeat for the auto industry. The industry has relied on powerful Capitol Hill allies to head off any mandated increase in so-called Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards, which have not been altered legislatively since 1975. 
Passage of the amendment to a broader energy bill puts heavy pressure on the Bush administration to move expeditiously on fuel economy standards. The White House has said it is awaiting a scientific study of the subject before making any changes, but Congressional Republicans say they expect the administration to raise standards later this year.
"This is the first time in years that we've gotten a bipartisan vote on a provision," said Representative Billy Tauzin, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, who backed the measure passed today and predicted quick passage by his full committee next week. "We're strongly encouraging the administration to set higher standards for all kinds of vehicles."
The measure would require the Transportation Department to raise fuel economy standards for sport-utility vehicles and minivans high enough to save five billion gallons of gasoline between 2004 and 2010. The General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and DaimlerChrysler AG, the main manufacturers of the light trucks affected by the regulations, would be given some flexibility in how to achieve the targets.
Environmentalists called the step modest, but said it was a breakthrough in one respect: It placed leading Republicans and one key Democrat, Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, on the record as supporting an increase in standards. They expressed a hope that the full House would approve much stiffer increases when the measure comes to the floor, possibly before the summer recess.
"The good news is that this is in play," said Dan Becker of the Sierra Club. "We are headed for a floor vote for the first time in a long time, and the question will be whether we do something minuscule or substantial."
There was considerable debate today about the impact of the efficiency plan. Supporters said the mandate would save as much gasoline as if the government ordered all the new sport-utility vehicles and minivans produced in 1999 off the road for two years. 
They said that while they had yet to prepare final figures, achieving the savings would require the administration to raise the average fuel economy of sport-utility vehicles and minivans by three to four miles a gallon. Light trucks, a category that includes sport utilities and minivans as well as other kinds of vehicles, currently must average 20.7 miles a gallon under standards that have not been altered significantly in more than a decade.
Automobiles must on average get 27.5 miles to the gallon. They are not directly affected by today's vote.
Critics said that their back-of-the-envelope calculations showed a much less pronounced impact on fuel economy. They said that the five-billion-gallon target could result in an increase in standards of little more than one mile a gallon for light trucks.
Still, the focus on sport utilities and minivans is significant because they tend to consume far more gasoline than cars. Because they have historically been subject to less rigorous standards, their surge in popularity in recent years has dragged down the overall fuel economy of the nation's vehicles at a time when gasoline prices have risen and dependence on foreign oil has grown.
The plan was hashed out this morning by Mr. Dingell, Mr. Tauzin and Representative Joe L. Barton, a Texas Republican who heads the Energy and Air Quality Subcommittee. The compromise cleared the way for passage, but it also effectively killed an amendment that would have raised fuel efficiency standards much more aggressively.
Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, proposed to create a merged standard for light trucks and cars at 40 miles a gallon by 2017. He withdrew his amendment after it became clear that it would fail, and voted against the compromise plan.
"OPEC ministers toast our inefficiency," Mr. Markey said.
Earlier in the week, Mr. Barton indicated that he would also favor a merged standards for cars and light trucks, and proposed raising that standard to 30 to 35 miles a gallon, a sizable increase. While he supported the measure today, he said he hoped that Congress and the administration would agree to do better in coming weeks.
The Bush administration signaled its willingness this week to increase the fuel economy standards when Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta urged Congress not to reimpose a freeze it had placed on any administration move to increase standards. The freeze had kept the Clinton administration from acting on fuel economy standards.
"Responsibly crafted standards under existing law should increase efficiency without negatively impacting the U.S. automotive industry," Mr. Mineta said in a letter to lawmakers this week.

HEADLINE: Rights Group Says Taliban Aren't Solely to Blame for the Afghan Disaster 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 12 

 BODY:
Breaking ranks with most human rights groups and the American government, Human Rights Watch said in a report today that the Taliban alone were not responsible for a deepening disaster in Afghanistan. 
 Human Rights Watch, a New York-based organization, called for sanctions against the armed opposition to the Taliban, and blamed Russia and Iran for giving the opposition front significant military support. 
 "U.N. sanctions imposed on arms and fuel to the Taliban in December 2000 are one-sided and strongly influenced by short-term Russian and U.S. interests, not humanitarian goals," the report said.
The United States wants the Taliban to turn over Osama bin Laden, the Saudi financier of Muslim militancy who is believed to be living under their protection in Afghanistan. And Russia has accused the Taliban of aiding separatists in Chechnya. 
The conclusions of the report are largely in line with the thinking of experts on Afghanistan in the United Nations secretariat, but those officials cannot stray beyond the instructions of the Security Council and its most powerful members.
While the new report, "Crisis of Impunity: The Role of Pakistan, Russia and Iran in Fueling the Civil War in Afghanistan," clearly blames the Pakistani government, military and intelligence agencies for arming and training Taliban fighters, who now control more than 90 percent of Afghanistan. It also finds considerable evidence of broad Iranian and Russian support for the opposition United Front. Some Central Asian nations have assisted Russian efforts.
The forces now being aided by Russia are, interestingly, the remnants of the mujahedeen coalition that drove Soviet troops out of Afghanistan in 1989.
"Russia has played a crucial enabling role in the resupply of the United Front forces by arranging for the transportation of Iranian aid, while providing considerable direct assistance itself, including logistical and support services," the report said. "Military assistance to United Front forces has crossed the Tajikistan-Afghanistan border with the active collusion of the Russian government."
Military experts on Afghanistan say the opposition front has no hope of regaining power, but is being armed solely to keep the war going and the Taliban off balance. The Afghan economy has collapsed, public services are almost nonexistent, and more than a million people face severe hunger, if not starvation. Five million Afghans are already refugees, and this week the United Nations high commissioner for refugees said it was increasingly difficult to find help or homes for them.
The Human Rights Watch report says several members of the "six-plus-two group" -- the six nations bordering Afghanistan, plus Russia and the United States, which has been half-heartedly trying to negotiate an end to the war -- "are providing military and material support to Afghan parties that have committed gross violations of the laws of war."
United Nations officials have also reached that conclusion, and have said so in reports to the Security Council. But the United States and Russia have, in a rare show of solidarity, refused to take action against the Taliban's enemies. The Taliban are under an arms embargo that also prohibits air traffic to the landlocked country, except for religious or mercy flights. The new report calls for a lifting of the ban on civilian air traffic.
Human Rights Watch, which has in the past drawn attention to abuses committed by the opposition alliance as well as by the Taliban, whose restrictions on women have brought international notoriety, again criticized both sides in today's report. "Both the Taliban and the United Front have failed to ensure that the fundamental rights of the Afghan population under their control are protected," it said.
The report backs recommendations by a panel of experts appointed by the United Nations that effective border monitoring be set up around Afghanistan and that a coordinating office be established to supervise the work. It says the greatest immediate pressure should be put on Pakistan, since the Pakistani-Afghan border will be the most difficult to police.

HEADLINE: Senate Vote Signals That Compromise Is Likely on Gulf Drilling 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12 

 BODY:
The Senate signaled its clear support today for a compromise White House plan for new oil and gas drilling in the eastern Gulf of Mexico, turning aside a Democrat-backed measure that would have blocked exploration in the area.
 The action, by a 67-to-33 vote, followed a White House decision last week to scale back significantly its plans for drilling in the region, and it seemed quite likely to clear the way for lease sales as early as this fall. 
 Last month, the House voted to impose a six-month moratorium on any new exploration in the eastern gulf, and differences between the two bills must be resolved in a Senate-House conference committee. But the compromise plan has now won support from a number of House Republicans and Democrats who had voted for the moratorium. For that reason, House negotiators are not expected to insist on blocking exploration. 
Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, who had opposed the earlier Bush administration proposal, is among the Republicans who have endorsed the compromise. The new plan would make available considerably less oil and gas than the administration had once sought. But even so, the vote today was good news for President Bush and his team, which ended a string of defeats in Congressional votes on environmental issues.
Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton called the vote "a victory for all Americans who want to see environmentally responsible energy production." The administration had lobbied hard to defeat the proposed moratorium, with Ms. Norton making the rounds on Capitol Hill. 
The compromise plan would offer to energy companies the oil and gas rights to 1.5 million acres of undersea land in the eastern gulf, down from the 6 million acres originally proposed. Under the compromise, the area is not within 100 miles of the coast of Florida, meeting a requirement of Governor Bush and most members of Florida's Congressional delegation.
The proposed exploration area is off the coasts of Alabama, Mississippi and Louisiana, whose representatives have backed drilling.
Even so, Democrats and environmental groups have continued to warn that the environmental risks inherent in the plan outweigh economic benefits, and they have said they fear that new drilling in the area would begin a march toward Florida's gulf shores.
Senator Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida, who proposed the moratorium, described the vote as "a defeat to all of us who want to protect Florida's economy and environment from the threat of oil drilling near the coast." 
Eighteen Democrats joined all 49 Republicans in voting against the moratorium, which was proposed as an amendment to an Interior Department appropriations bill. Their opposition to the amendment signaled support for the administration's compromise plan. Thirty-two Democrats and one independent, Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, supported the proposed moratorium, which would have halted any action until April 2002.
The Senate vote was the second in two days on energy exploration, and it seemed to reflect a spirit of caution on issues involving environmentally sensitive lands. On Wednesday, the Senate approved a bill banning new energy exploration in land designated as national monuments, ruling out an option that administration officials said should not necessarily be excluded from efforts to increase domestic energy production.
Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, a strong advocate of broader oil and gas exploration, said he would not interpret the action today as "a trend in any direction" in terms of support for the administration's broader energy exploration.
"Whether it means we're going to have more aggressive energy development in other areas, I doubt it," Senator Breaux said.
Mark Rubin, of the American Petroleum Institute, said oil and gas companies would make do with whatever the Interior Department offered. "Our industry is willing to look for oil and gas reserves wherever the federal government provides opportunities," Mr. Rubin said. 
In another environmental action today, the Senate narrowly defeated a measure that would have waived provisions of a federal law to benefit farmers along the Oregon-California border who have been without irrigation water for three months. The water, in the Klamath Basin, was shut off on April 7 by the Federal Bureau of Reclamation under a provision of the Endangered Species Act requiring that priority be given to the protection of plants and animals.
The proposal, defeated 52 to 48, was introduced by Senator Gordon H. Smith, Republican of Oregon, and would have authorized a lowering of the level of the Upper Klamath Lake, on which both the farmers and the endangered suckerfish depend. The close vote on the measure showed strong support for the farmers at a time when the administration is nearing a decision on whether to begin a cabinet-level review that could authorize similar action.

HEADLINE: Oil High on Agenda as Bush Meets Algerian Leader 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12 

 BODY:
President Bush met today with the leader of oil-rich Algeria, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, the first visit of an Algerian head of state to the White House in 16 years. 
 The visit of Mr. Bouteflika comes as he has faced some of the most sustained protests in Algeria since it gained independence in 1962. More than a million demonstrators joined protest marches last month challenging the Bouteflika government over economic hardships and its authoritarian practices. A ban on protests has since been imposed. 
 After his session with Mr. Bush in the Oval Office, Mr. Bouteflika met separately with Vice President Dick Cheney. As chief executive of a major oil field services concern, Halliburton Co., Mr. Cheney developed extensive business interests for the company in Algeria. 
A White House spokesman said Mr. Bush urged Mr. Bouteflika to move ahead with economic and political reforms. The two men discussed "energy issues and United States investment in Algeria," the spokesman said.
The welcome of the Algerian leader, which appeared to put more emphasis on investment than on human rights, was criticized by human rights groups and some regional experts.
A former State Department analyst on Algeria, Mona Yacoubian, said the visit would allow Mr. Bouteflika to say he had the support of the United States. "Precisely the opposite message should be sent," Ms. Yacoubian wrote in a paper for the Washington Institute for Near East Policy. "President Bush should seize the opportunity to state publicly the need for broad-based reform in Algeria." 
In the past, Ms. Yacoubian said, Washington had "reluctantly supported the Algerian regime as the only realistic alternative to chaos or Islamic reform."
"Now that the Islamist threat has diminished," she added, "the time is at hand to push harder for reforms." 
Conoco, Exxon Mobil and Anadarko Petroleum, along with Halliburton, operate in Algeria. 
Business reports from Algeria in the last month have emphasized the growing unrest and the failure of Mr. Bouteflika to enact a privatization process aimed at reducing the monopoly of the state utility companies. An industry newspaper, The Oil Daily, said the situation in Algeria "threatens to get quite messy over the next few months."

HEADLINE: Seeing Red, or Not 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12 

 BODY:
Whatever happened to the budget surplus?
 Just five weeks after President Bush signed into law the biggest tax cut in two decades, and six months after Congress and the White House raised their surplus projections again, Democrats were talking about deficits; Republicans were warning against tax increases; and the two parties were heading toward a 1980's-style showdown over guns versus butter as they considered next year's spending bills. 
 Today the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, said the government was on the brink of lapsing back into the red by the standard he would apply to its books.
At a committee hearing, Senator Conrad suggested that the administration and Republicans in Congress had proved willing to risk the long-term financial health of Medicare and Social Security to pay for Mr. Bush's tax cut. 
Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the director of the White House's Office of Management and Budget, responded that the government was still running a large surplus by the standard the administration considered proper.
Mr. Daniels said that if any fiscal clouds were on the horizon, they were a result of a penchant among Democrats for undisciplined increases in government spending.
The re-emergence of bitter fiscal debates was a wrenching shift from the short-lived politics of prosperity, in which there seemed to be enough money for both sides to get what they wanted.
To some extent the change reflects the faltering economy, which is leading to lower estimates of tax revenues. But it has as much to do with politics and ideology as with any deterioration in the fiscal outlook.
The debate hinges largely on differing definitions of the budget surplus.
The surplus comes from two basic sources. One is general government revenues, mainly individual income taxes and corporate taxes. The other is the payroll taxes imposed to pay for Social Security and Medicare benefits.
When the government moved from deficit to surplus in the late 1990's, no one made much of the distinction.
But as the surpluses grew, the two parties agreed not to touch, with tax cuts or new spending, the part of the surplus generated by Social Security taxes, about $2.5 trillion over the next decade out of a total surplus projected at $5.6 trillion for the period.
Congress and the administration also agreed this year to cut taxes, eating at least $1.7 trillion of the 10-year surplus -- $1.35 trillion in lower taxes and $350 billion in additional interest on the national debt. And they set out plans to spend a big chunk of what was left, including $300 billion over a decade to subsidize the cost of prescription drugs for retirees.
When combined with the economic slowdown, the effect has been an immediate squeeze on the budget.
To a degree, that was what President Bush had hoped the tax cut would do. Throughout the presidential campaign, Mr. Bush had cast the tax cut as the only way to keep Congress from increasing government spending year after year. In that sense, administration officials are happy with the situation.
But the situation is complicating some of the administration's initiatives, including its proposal for a big increase in military spending. And it has created some political peril for the White House.
The Social Security surplus, intact for now, is expected to total around $150 billion this year, allowing the administration to say the government is still running large surpluses.
But the surplus for this year might fall short of the level at which the government could avoid spending any of the Medicare surplus.
Medicare's hospital insurance trust fund is expected to have a surplus of about $28 billion for the fiscal year that ends on Sept. 30.
Democrats say the Medicare surplus should be as inviolate as the Social Security surplus. The prospect that some of the Medicare surplus might be spent is the basis for the warning by Democrats that the budget is heading back into deficit. By next year, Senator Conrad said, the budget may be forced to dip into the Social Security surplus.
Spending some of the Medicare surplus would not have any direct effect on the government's ability to cover Medicare benefits, and the administration dismisses the concept of a Medicare surplus as an accounting gimmick.
But if the government spent some of the Medicare surplus this year, it would allow Democrats to press their argument that Mr. Bush's tax cut came at the expense of a commitment to provide health coverage to older Americans. And it would highlight partisan differences over tax and spending priorities as the nation headed into the 2002 midterm elections, in which control of the House and the Senate will be up for grabs.
Saying the economy has benefited tremendously from balanced budgets and debt reduction, Democrats are hinting that they will consider raising taxes later, if necessary, to avoid deficits.
But Republicans say too much debt reduction will reward bondholders at the expense of taxpayers. And they continued to make a case today for additional tax cuts, on the ground that lower taxes would stimulate economic growth.
"I don't think we should rule out any economic idea that could revive economic growth and maintain it," Mr. Daniels said.

HEADLINE: G.E. Reports 15% Increase In 2nd-Quarter Earnings 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The General Electric Company, despite its first quarterly decline in revenues since 1988, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings were up 15 percent from the same quarter last year.
 It stands as the last complete quarter under John F. Welch Jr., who stayed on as chairman past his planned retirement to shepherd G.E.'s since-aborted acquisition of Honeywell International. G.E. said that he would retire on Sept. 7. 
 If investors fear that G.E.'s prospects are hurt by the slowing economy, the failed Honeywell merger, or Mr. Welch's imminent departure, the concerns did not dampen enthusiasm for G.E. stock. G.E.'s shares closed at $47, up $2.39. 
"Margins were strong, cash flow was strong, and everything came in line with expectations," said Timothy M. Ghriskey, a senior portfolio manager of the Dreyfus Corporation. Specifically, G.E. said it had earned $3.9 billion, or 39 cents a share, in the second quarter, right in line with analyst's expectations. It also said it would meet expectations of $1.45 a share for the year. 
The quarter's revenues of $32 billion were 3 percent lower than the same period last year. But when discontinued operations like Montgomery Ward were factored out, G.E.'s revenues increased by 6 percent over the same period last year. While earnings were down at NBC, appliances and other short cycle, or economically sensitive businesses, the softness was offset by strength in GE Power Systems, GE Capital and GE Aircraft Engines. 
Still, not all analysts are ebullient about G.E.'s prospects. "G.E. may outperform every company in America, but it still must deal with the global economy," warned Tom Burnett of Merger Insight. 
Even its non-cyclical businesses might face slower growth. Power systems, for example, is already about a $20 billion company, and "the law of big numbers says it can't keep growing at 30 percent," said Martin A. Sankey of Goldman Sachs.
Still others are skeptical about the quality of G.E.'s earnings stream. "G.E.'s stock is not trading at bargain prices by any valuation," said Robert Friedman of S&P Equity Research. He worries that as much as 2 percent of G.E.'s per-share earnings come from gains in its pension fund investments, and that a high debt load at GE Capital, G.E.'s most profitable arm, could constrain the unit from making acquisitions. 
G.E. certainly faces uncertainty. Although its deal to acquire Honeywell was killed by the European Commission on July 3, the merger agreement remains in place until the end of November. 
There has been widespread speculation that Honeywell will sue G.E. for not doing its utmost to appease the Europeans. But many analysts believe that scenario became less likely when Michael R. Bonsignore was recently replaced as Honeywell's chairman by Lawrence Bossidy, Honeywell's former chairman. Mr. Bossidy worked with Mr. Welch at G.E. for many years, and the two remain friends. Several analysts suggest G.E. will pay Honeywell a few hundred million dollars and be done with it.
But the Honeywell debacle raises other specters, too. Most analysts expected Jeffrey Immelt, the former head of GE Medical Systems and Mr. Welch's annointed successor, to spend this year learning the ins and outs of G.E's businesses. Instead, warned Mr. Burnett, "Honeywell negotiations and lawyers' meetings may have kept him from learning about appliances and chemicals." 
Merging with Honeywell would have done more than enhance G.E.'s aircraft business; it would have kept G.E.'s portfolio balanced. 
GE Capital accounts for about half the company's sales. Mr. Friedman's reservations about the unit's debt notwithstanding, most analysts expect G.E. to keep expanding its finance arm. But the stocks of financial services companies trade at about 15 times earnings; G.E. shares trade at twice that multiple.
"GE Capital is still their most reliable growth engine," said Jeanne G. Terrile, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. "But if GE Capital becomes 70 percent of G.E., that would not be good for G.E.'s multiple." 
And even a diversified company like G.E. cannot withstand a prolonged economic downturn without slashing costs. Several analysts suggest that G.E. delayed any major job cuts in order not to alienate the European Commission while it was evaluating the Honeywell merger. Now, with that merger, and any expected synergies, dead, they say that bloodletting seems inevitable.

HEADLINE: Norton Rejects Call to Have Panel Review Water Cutoff 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13 

 BODY:
In a blow to farmers along the Oregon-California border, Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton refused to accept a petition today that sought reversal of a decision that has shut off irrigation water to about 200,000 acres of farmland.
 The petition requested that the government convene its Endangered Species Committee to consider whether the plight of about 1,400 farmers merited waiving provisions of federal law. The provisions have required the Bureau of Reclamation to allot all of its water in the area to protection of endangered fish. 
 The decision is a setback to the farmers, who had hoped the administration might use the cabinet-level committee to reverse, at least in part, an April 7 decision that has left the farmers unable to produce crops in the current growing season. The water was cut off by the Bureau of Reclamation, in a year of record drought, under the terms of the endangered species law, to protect the endangered suckerfish and the threatened coho salmon.
In a written statement, Ms. Norton described the decision as difficult. But she said that the local irrigation districts that had issued the complaint did not have standing under federal law to request that the committee be convened.
"This administration is dedicated to working with all parties to fashion a long-term solution so that we do not find ourselves struggling each year with these difficult issues," Ms. Norton said in a letter to the Pacific Legal Foundation, an advocacy group in Sacramento that filed the complaint on behalf of the irrigation districts. 
"We remain hopeful that we can resume exploring those solutions with you," Ms. Norton said. "To that end, we specifically request that you can work with us as we move forward."
The decision is a setback to many in the Klamath Basin who have criticized the water shutoff as a betrayal by the federal government and who had hoped the administration might waive provisions of the Endangered Species Act. Among those who had also requested that the committee be convened were two area congressmen, Representatives Wally Herger, Republican of California, and Greg Walden, Republican of Oregon. 
The panel has the limited authority to overrule provisions of the Endangered Species Act to protect vital human economic interests. But it has been convened only three times, in cases involving the snail darter, the whooping crane and the spotted owl, and only once, in the case of the spotted owl, did it authorize a waiver of the law. 
The federal law specifically lists three groups that may request that the committee be convened: federal agencies, state governors and parties whose requests for permits or licenses have been denied because of application of the endangered species law. Ms. Norton said her department had concluded that the irrigation districts did not fall into the latter category. Neither the governors of the two states nor any federal agency has shown any interest in becoming involved.
Anger in the area over the water shutoff has reached such a point that, in recent protests, people have several times reopened irrigation gates themselves. The sheriff in Klamath County, Ore., and other authorities have declined to intervene, and while the federal authorities have closed the gates, they have so far declined to take legal action against those involved.
In her statement, Ms. Norton noted that the federal government was preparing to provide the farmers with $20 million in financial aid, as a short-term solution.
"The patience exhibited by the people of the Klamath Basin is truly remarkable -- a testament to their courage, their strength, and their spirit," Ms. Norton said.

PERSON: Maceo Anderson 

HEADLINE: Maceo Anderson, 90, Tap Dancer, Is Dead 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER DUNNING 

 BODY:
Maceo Anderson, the last surviving founding member of the Four Step Brothers, one of the world's most celebrated and enduring tap acts, died on July 4 at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 90 and lived in Los Angeles. 
 The Four Step Brothers, billed as "eight feet of rhythm," played top nightclubs and theaters internationally from the 1930's into the 60's. They also appeared in films and on many television variety shows. "We went around the world four times," Prince Spencer, a tap dancer and teacher who joined the group in the 1940's, told Rusty E. Frank in her book, "Tap!" "We danced for the queen of England. We danced for Hirohito. We danced for the queen of Cambodia." 
 Ms. Frank attributes their success to "fast rhythm taps, acrobatic leaps, and boogie-woogie jitterbug-style tap dancing, all put across through the electrifying mode of challenge." The challenge style, she writes, "came right off the street -- the clapping of the hands, the encouraging yelps, the fast-paced tempos, the ceaseless topping of tap steps." 
Mr. Anderson began dancing as a child in black rural theaters in the South. He was about 6 when he arrived in New York, traveling from Charleston, S.C., with his mother. The basement of the building on West 122nd Street where they lived became an informal tap meeting place filled with young dancers, including Bill Bailey and his sister Pearl. 
Mr. Anderson was also one of the many young dancers who hung out at the Hoofers Club, a famous tap gathering place under the Lafayette Theater in Harlem. He and the others would practice in the club, which was bare but for benches and an upright piano. They would also watch and study the veteran tap stars who visited and be their gofers. Mr. Anderson also sneaked into the Lafayette to see the shows, racing between the two places at times. 
The group began as a trio of unrelated dancing teenagers, formed by Mr. Anderson and two dancers whom he had seen and admired in an amateur night at the Lafayette. In the mid-1920's, the three talked their way into performing at the Cotton Club with Duke Ellington, who wrote "The Mystery Song" for them. The trio performed at the Cotton Club for four years. Another dancer was added in the 1930's. 
The act incorporated singing, acrobatics, comedy and vernacular dance, working into the mix the traditional tap challenge in which one dancer tries to top another's steps. An exciting escalation of complexity and speed, the challenge, born on the streets, became the act's trademark by the 1940's. 
By then, Mr. Anderson had become the exuberant clown of the act, delighting the audience by heckling his colleagues. He was adept at faking the acrobatics when he wasn't in the mood to do them, although he once got so carried away that he danced off the stage into the audience. 
The Four Step Brothers worked longer than many acts, unemployed for only a year or so after a manager blackballed them for failing to appear after he denied them a raise. They toured on the Keith-Orpheum circuit, often the first black performers to appear in theaters, and also toured on black circuits. They performed annually for 10 years at Radio City Music Hall, where they were the first black act, and they appeared at the Roxy and with Frank Sinatra at the Paramount. 
Mr. Anderson continued to perform after the act disbanded. He was honored in 1994 in the annual celebration of National Tap Dance Day in Manhattan. He continued to teach at his own school in Las Vegas and at festivals and universities throughout the United States until 1999. 
He is survived by his wife, Mary Anderson, of Las Vegas, and by two grandsons, Robert L. Reed of St. Louis and Michael Allen of Colorado Springs.

HEADLINE: Airlines Are Cutting Back on Some International Flights 

BYLINE:  By JANE L. LEVERE 

 BODY:
United Airlines' decision two weeks ago to abruptly drop its nonstop service between New York and Hong Kong after only three months could be the harbinger of similar moves by other United States carriers, industry analysts say.
 On June 26, United said that it would suspend its 747-400 flights between Kennedy International Airport and Hong Kong International Airport -- the longest daily nonstop service in the world -- on Aug. 30. 
 The carrier said it was ending the service, which it introduced on April 1, because it was not selling enough tickets and did not expect sales to improve. It also blamed regulatory restrictions in Hong Kong that prevent it from continuing its flights beyond Hong Kong to other Asian destinations. 
United, a subsidiary of UAL, will continue to fly to Hong Kong nonstop, however, from a number of other cities, including Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco; earlier the airline had said it would drop another nonstop service, between Los Angeles and Paris.
United is not the first United States airline to end unprofitable flights this year. In the last few months, Delta Air Lines said it would suspend its service between Kennedy Airport and Lyon, France; American Airlines, a unit of AMR, said it would discontinue flights between Los Angeles and Paris and between Chicago and Rome; and Northwest said it would end flights between Seattle and Osaka, Japan.
Cathay Pacific Airways, meanwhile, has postponed the planned Sept. 1 start of nonstop service between Kennedy and Hong Kong because of uncertainty about the economy and a labor dispute with its pilots. Because of the dispute, it also has temporarily suspended daily service between Kennedy and Hong Kong that stops in Vancouver, British Columbia.
Most of the routes being cut were introduced within the last two years; all offer daily nonstop flights and will be phased out by late fall.
Michael Linenberg, who follows the airline industry for Merrill Lynch, called United's suspension of its nonstop New York-Hong Kong service "a sign of the times."
"I wouldn't be surprised if more carriers pull back from international markets," he added. "The amount of assets deployed to keep these markets up and running is a huge number. You can lose $100 million on an international route in 12 months."
Samuel C. Buttrick, airline analyst for UBS Warburg, said that most of the recently announced route suspensions were the result of "new routes producing lower returns than seasoned routes." These poor returns have come about, in part, because of weakened demand from business travelers, he said.
"Given the precipitous decline in corporate demand and the resulting losses projected by all U.S. carriers, they are looking at reducing their growth plans over the next 18 months, which will necessarily entail further international route cutbacks," he added.
Mr. Linenberg suggested that carriers may drop experimental routes, like American's service between San Jose, Calif., and Taipei, Taiwan, or Delta's new flights from Kennedy to both Tel Aviv and Cairo.
"I'm sure American has had second thoughts about San Jose-Taipei," he said. "The Taiwan stock market is back to 1997-1998 levels, and there's a huge falloff in the semiconductor business."
It is also unclear how much demand there is for flights between the United States and the Middle East. American declined to take over Trans World Airline's 54-year-old service between New York and Tel Aviv when it recently bought most of the carrier's other assets. "We didn't feel we could make money there, and we didn't believe T.W.A. did," said Mark Slitt, an American spokesman.
Cutbacks are not universal. Even without United and Cathay Pacific, people can still fly nonstop between New York and Hong Kong on Continental Airlines, which has offered daily service out of Newark since March.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
DowIs Up 60 as Wall Street Expects Profit Improvement

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks inched higher yesterday as Wall Street looked past disturbing second-quarter profit reports to bet the outlook may improve later in the year.
 Gains came even after technology firms, like Rambus, said earnings fell on soft demand in the slowing economy. 
 "People are shrugging off" bad news, said Joseph Ranieri, managing director of trading at Adams, Harkness & Hill in Boston. "In the third and fourth quarter, we could get some signs of an upturn and people are setting themselves up now." 
 On Thursday, stocks made their biggest gains in more than two months after icons like Microsoft lifted hopes that profits could edge higher by the fourth quarter.
 Yesterday, the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index rose 9.05 points, or 0.4 percent, to close at 2,084.79, after racing ahead more than 5 percent on Thursday, its biggest one-day percentage gain since April 18.
 The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average gained 60.07 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,539.06. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 7.54 points, or 0.6 percent, to close at 1,215.68. Both indexes rose more than 2 percent on Thursday, their biggest one-day percentage gains since May 16.
 The Dow posted its first positive week in eight weeks, rising 2.8 percent, while the Nasdaq rose 4 percent for the week, and the S.& P. 500 added 2.1 percent.
 Volume was moderate, with about 1.12 billion shares changing hands on the Big Board.
Wall Street is bracing for almost 1,500 earnings reports next week as the second-quarter earnings season gathers steam. About 300 companies reported results this week.
 Analysts expect corporate profits for S.& P. 500 companies to fall by 18 percent in the second quarter, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. But investors are hoping companies will forecast better times after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates six times this year to jump-start the economy.
 Analysts currently expect profits to show growth of 3.7 percent in the fourth quarter.
 Though 2001 over all is expected to show a dismal profit slump of 6.7 percent -- the first yearly decline since 1991 -- investors are looking ahead to 2002, which is now forecast to bring profit growth of a lively 19.2 percent, First Call said. 
 Chinese stocks traded in the United States rose after Beijing was awarded the 2008 Olympics.
 China Southern Airlines rose 81 cents, to $16.01, and Huaneng Power International increased 30 cents, to $21.40. Qualcomm, which is supplying equipment and technology for China's No. 2 telephone company to build a wireless network, rose $2.22, to $65.58.
 "You're starting to get people's hopes up that there will be economic implications," said John Hughes, market analyst and portfolio manager for Shields & Company, which oversees $500 million.
 Computer chip-related stocks were mixed.
 Infineon Technologies gained 31 cents, to $22.75, after Europe's second-largest semiconductor maker defied a poor market climate to raise $1.3 billion in Germany's biggest capital increase this year.
 Advanced Micro Devices dropped $1.62, to $21.08. It reported results that beat sharply lowered expectations, but warned that it may report a third-quarter loss and a sales drop of 10 percent to 15 percent from second-quarter levels.
 The computer memory chip developer Rambus dropped $1.03, to $9.85. The company reported that profits fell as it was hit by an industry slowdown and a mounting bill for legal fights.
 Treasury bond prices rose yesterday. The 10-year Treasury note rose 4/32, to a price of 98 12/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.22 percent from 5.23 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 13/32, to 96 16/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.62 percent from 5.65 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Safety Issue Assessed as Congress Considers Raising Mileage Standards 

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13 

 BODY:
For the first time in years, Congress appears willing to raise gasoline mileage standards, giving new importance to a longstanding question a scientific committee is struggling with: Would doing so cause more deaths?
 As they begin work on the Bush administration's energy proposals, Republican lawmakers who for years had forbidden the Transportation Department to change fuel economy standards now seem reconciled to increasing them, in large part to offset criticism that the Bush energy plan emphasizes production over conservation. 
 On Thursday, a House subcommittee voted to raise the fuel economy requirements on sport-utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks, which have surged in popularity in recent years but meet a less strict standard than cars. Thus, they have dragged down the overall fuel economy of the nation's vehicles, while promoting strong growth in demand for gasoline and imported oil. 
But even if a political consensus develops for higher standards, opponents are again raising obstacles, and a chief argument is safety. Some auto companies have argued vigorously that heavier is safer. Building vehicles smaller and lighter to improve mileage will cause more deaths, the argument goes. 
The experts agree that large vehicles like sport-utility ones and minivans are safer for those who are in them. But now a committee appointed by the National Academy of Sciences is wrestling with another question: Are they safer for society as a whole? 
"You can't really argue with the fact that weight disparities in vehicles lead to the situation where people in lighter, smaller vehicles are more at risk than people in larger, heavier vehicles," said one member of the panel, David L. Greene, an energy economist at the Energy Department's Oak Ridge National Laboratory.
Researchers say the death toll is declining in collisions of cars of equal weight, because new cars have air bags and other crash protections. But when cars and heavier vehicles collide, they say, car occupants are more likely to die. And such collisions are increasing with the rising number of sport-utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks on American highways.
By some accounts, the growing weight disparity costs society more than 2,000 deaths a year, out of about 17,500 total deaths caused by collision of two or more vehicles.
The administration deferred recommending any changes in fuel economy standards pending resolution of the safety issue by the panel, which was appointed at the Clinton administration's request.
Noting that the Academy of Sciences committee will report its findings soon, Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta sent a letter to Congressional leaders this week asking them to let his department begin drafting new rules.
The current standard is 27.5 miles for cars, last adjusted in 1989, and 20.7 miles for light trucks, last changed in 1994. But as the market share of light trucks, which includes minivans and sport-utility vehicles, has increased, the average fuel economy has declined about 7 percent, or 1.9 miles a gallon, according to the Environmental Protection Agency, and is now 24.0 miles a gallon, the lowest since 1980.
This spring, the sciences committee heard extensive testimony on whether the standards could be altered in ways that would allow the decline in the death rate to continue.
Dr. Greene and other members of the panel said they had agreed not to discuss the report before it was issued, but several spoke about the arguments raised by experts seeking to influence their conclusions.
One such argument, raised in a report by Marc Ross, a physicist at the University of Michigan, and Tom Wenzel, of Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, maintained that safety analyses to date had confused weight with size. While it is obvious that people in big, heavy cars fare better than people in small, light ones in collisions with other vehicles and with stationary objects, the analyses have failed to determine whether the benefit comes from the weight or from the size, according to the report, which was sponsored by the Energy Foundation, a nonprofit group that favors stricter fuel economy standards. 
With new materials, like advanced metal alloys or carbon composites, size and weight are independent, the report said.
Size is a benefit, engineers say, because the deceleration in a collision will be less severe if it is spread over a longer period, and extra "crush space" in a vehicle will do just that. ("Longer" is a relative term; the typical collision lasts about one-tenth of a second.) 
Weight is helpful to the occupants of a heavy vehicle because in a collision with another vehicle or with a roadside object like a utility pole or guardrail, change in speed (and therefore the deceleration experienced by vehicle occupants) is proportional to mass. In a head-on collision, vehicles of equal weight will experience equal deceleration; if they differ, they will share the deceleration in proportion to their weight. 
If two vehicles with a combined weight of 6,000 pounds collide, risk of a death is lower if it is two 3,000-pound cars, rather than a 2,000-pound car and a 4,000-pound sport-utility vehicle. The two physicists estimated that 2,200 deaths are caused each year by light trucks, minivans and sport-utility vehicles that are used as "car substitutes." They argue that engineers could preserve the benefits of big vehicles and reduce the drawbacks by making them big but light. 
But another member of the panel, Adrian K. Lund, the chief operating officer of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, pointed to studies showing that bigger cars were safer. One study, by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety in 1994 of cars one to three years old, found that deaths per million registered vehicles was 109 among those with wheelbases more than 114 inches, and was 241 among those less than 95 inches.
Dr. Lund also said that regulations that encouraged automakers to make vehicles lighter had safety drawbacks. "If all vehicles were down-weighted, there would not necessarily be any adverse safety consequence to vehicle occupants as a whole," he said. But some of the crashes would be with objects that would never weigh less, like buses and tractor-trailer trucks.
On Thursday, the General Motors Corporation released a study that predicted 400 extra deaths a year if mileage standards were tightened and automakers cut the weight of vehicles to comply. If weight reduction was limited to big cars, sport-utility vehicles and vans, the result could still be an extra 60 deaths a year, the company said.
If the government raises the mileage standards, no one is sure what method the automakers will use to meet them. Some experts hope a stricter standard on light trucks will induce the auto companies to reduce the weight of those vehicles, reducing the disparity among vehicles on the road. 
Since 1980, vehicles have gotten both heavier and faster; the Environmental Protection Agency estimated that if performance and weight had been held constant, gas mileage today would be 25 percent higher.
The National Academy committee report was due on July 1 but is now not expected to be published until next month, participants said. One person involved with the committee's deliberations said the panel might end up providing an estimate of the weight and safety trade-off, rather than making a recommendation on fuel standards.

HEADLINE: The New Laws of Nations 

BYLINE:  By Laura D. Tyson; Laura D. Tyson, former chief economic adviser to President Bill Clinton, is dean of the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley.

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif. 

 BODY:
As economic interconnections increase among countries around the world, critics protest that this globalization is eroding the ability of governments to protect the interests of their citizens against those of multinational corporations. But the European Commission's recent blocking of the proposed merger of two American companies, General Electric and Honeywell, suggests otherwise. Since the merged company would have operated on both sides of the Atlantic, the merger hinged on the consent of not just one but two sets of regulators, each with its own legal tradition and its own interpretation of the public interest. And despite public relations campaigns by both companies, attempts at personal persuasion by G.E.'s formidable outgoing chief executive, Jack Welch, and the threat of retaliation by Congress, the European antitrust authorities rejected this merger, which had easily won approval from the United States Justice Department.
 In this case globalization strengthened rather than weakened government oversight of corporate activity. 
 But if this outcome calms the fears of those who worry about corporate titans dominating the globe, it is likely to intensify the anxieties of those who worry about globalization's weakening of national sovereignty. What right does the European Commission have telling two American companies what they can and cannot do, these people might ask, especially when its decision conflicts with the decision reached by the relevant American authority? Sure, we support the rule of law, but whose law? Aren't our antitrust laws, which reflect our strong market tradition, superior to Europe's, which tend to reflect a strong statist tradition?
Tension is growing between economic globalization and the laws and institutions within national borders. The Europeans understand such tensions well. Driven by growing economic interdependence and the desire to end centuries of armed conflict, they have spent much of the last half-century cutting back national autonomy in favor of shared laws and institutions, like the Common Market; the European Union; and a common currency, the euro. But for the United States, which is less dependent on foreign trade and investment and is accustomed to using its economic and military might to get its way, giving up some national autonomy to foster globalization remains a highly questionable -- and politically risky -- proposition.
The reality, though, is that countries have already broken the most easily removed barriers to international trade and investment by getting rid of tariffs and export subsidies. The remaining barriers are embedded in a variety of national policies and institutions that were long the domain of domestic decision makers. These barriers involve politically sensitive concerns like health and safety, corporate governance and philosophies about business practices. Antitrust regulation has traditionally been one of those areas governed by domestic laws and traditions.
Yet over the past decade, antitrust experts from the European Commission have had close and frequent contact with their counterparts at the American Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission. Consultations have ranged from simple exchanges of information to detailed discussions of the merits of particular merger proposals. This cooperation has fostered a convergence in approaches, despite differing laws. In hundreds of cases, European and American regulators have reached remarkably similar conclusions without any effort to harmonize their underlying rules and procedures. The G.E.-Honeywell case was a high-profile exception.
Backers of the American position on the G.E.-Honeywell proposal believe the merger would have benefited consumers by encouraging competition and reducing prices. Those who support the European position maintain that the merger would have created a dominant market player able to raise prices and discourage innovation by driving smaller competitors out of business. There are reasonable legal and economic arguments on both sides. This was not, as some critics have suggested, a politically motivated decision on the part of the Europeans, made to protect their domestic companies.
In announcing his rejection of the merger, Mario Monti, the soft-spoken academic who heads the body responsible for antitrust regulation for the European Commission, also renewed his call for a global forum at which antitrust experts from around the world can forge common approaches. And he reiterated his support for putting policies on business competition on the agenda for discussion in the next round of World Trade Organization talks, scheduled to begin this fall.
Like the Clinton administration, the Bush administration has expressed support for the global forum idea. But also like its predecessor, it opposes negotiating a W.T.O. agreement on competition policy, fearing the loss of national sovereignty to international rules. This opposition is shortsighted and ill-advised. It is only a matter of time before there will be so many companies with global reach that developing a common international set of antitrust principles becomes a necessity.
In this area as in many others, globalization will continue to chip away at the power of the nation state. As the Europeans know from their experience over the last 50 years, surrendering some degree of national autonomy is a natural and inevitable concomitant of growing economic interdependence.
