HEADLINE: Man Is Guilty In Bomb Plot At Millennium 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS

 BODY:
An Algerian-born shopkeeper was convicted in federal court yesterday of conspiring to provide support for a plan by an Algerian terrorist to enter the United States from Canada and set off a bomb at Los Angeles International Airport in December 1999.
 Mokhtar Haouari, 32, was found guilty of conspiracy on the basis of his dealings with two men who talked of joining an Islamic holy war, but he was acquitted of the more serious charge of actually providing support for the operation. One of the men was caught trying to cross the border near Seattle with a trunk full of explosives and a plan to bomb the airport during millennium celebrations in the United States. 
 The verdict in Federal District Court in Manhattan came after a three-week trial in which both of the men testified against Mr. Haouari, who ran a gift shop in Montreal and as a sideline dealt in false identification documents, as well as check and credit card scams. He was convicted yesterday of four counts of bank and document fraud. 
Mr. Haouari's trial was highlighted by revelations about what came to be known as the millennium bombing plot. When the would-be bomber, Ahmed Ressam, was arrested at the border on Dec. 14, 1999, the Federal Bureau of Investigation started a sweeping search for suspects and information about the plot. Investigators later came to believe that the plot was linked to a worldwide network of terrorists orchestrated by Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile. 
But even though the Canadian and American authorities made arrests quickly, many details of the bombing plan, including the target, remained mysterious. Mr. Ressam kept silent throughout his trial and conviction in Los Angeles three months ago, and agreed only last month to cooperate with the government. The third man, Abdel Ghani Meskini, agreed in March to cooperate with the government in a plea agreement. 
During Mr. Haouari's trial, Mr. Ressam disclosed that he had chosen the Los Angeles airport because, he said, "an airport is sensitive politically and economically" and told of concocting explosives with agricultural chemicals in Vancouver.
He also described his training in guerrilla camps in Afghanistan that American intelligence officials say are run by Mr. bin Laden. He said an Algerian commander had given him $12,000 before his return to Canada in early 1999, along with instructions to rob banks to support a cell of "jihad fighters" there. The men who were supposed to join him apparently never made it to Canada. 
The case against Mr. Haouari turned on how much he knew about the millennium plan. Mr. Ressam said he told Mr. Haouari that he had "dangerous business in America" and needed money and false identification documents. Mr. Haouari gave him $3,000 and a fake driver's license and recruited Mr. Meskini, an old schoolmate who was living in Brooklyn, to help Mr. Ressam once he reached the United States.
But the only recorded conversation that was put into evidence, though intriguing, was ambiguous about Mr. Haouari's role in the plot. Even Mr. Ressam insisted that he had told no one, including Mr. Haouari, what he intended to do in the United States.
Much of the testimony concerned the petty criminal enterprises of a loose group of Algerians in Montreal. The prosecution portrayed the groups' bank and credit card fraud as a source of income for terrorist activities, but it was not clear that Mr. Haouari lent any of his ill-gotten gains to any particular plan. 
Although the charge of aiding and abetting was the more serious, the fraud convictions will add considerably to Mr. Haouari's total sentence. Two of the fraud charges carry a maximum sentence of 25 years each. The conspiracy charge carries a five-year sentence. 
Jurors interviewed after the verdict said Mr. Haouari should have inferred that Mr. Ressam, who had advanced training in explosives, was going to commit a bombing. That finding was enough to support a conviction on the conspiracy charge, but not on the substantive charge of aiding and abetting the plot, which would have required direct knowledge. One juror, Gary Kibble, said the final question the jurors put to themselves was whether Mr. Haouari thought he was just helping a friend, or if he knew he was abetting a terrorist. 
Other jurors said they took away very little information about wider terrorist activities. "I hope the government knows a hell of a lot more than it was telling here," said Christopher Lofting, the jury foreman.
Indeed, Mr. bin Laden's name was never spoken during the trial. When Mr. Ressam was asked whether the men he identified as leaders of the guerrilla camp, who went by the names Abu Zubaida and Ben Sheik, were "affiliated with a terrorist organization," he replied, "Yes." But the questioning ended there.
Mr. Lofting rolled his eyes when asked about Mr. Ressam's account, which included testimony that he chose the Los Angeles airport because he had been there before, missed his first flight to the West Coast and ran in panic when border guards asked him questions. 
"We got the general impression that he was a freelancer," Mr. Lofting said. "He was here to prove himself. If this was not the gang that couldn't shoot straight, I don't know what is."
Mr. Haouari, who heard the proceedings through a French interpreter, had no visible reaction to the verdict. But his lawyer, Daniel J. Ollen, said later that his client was "very, very upset." 
"It sounds like a partial victory, but it's not," Mr. Ollen said. "He's going away for a long time."

HEADLINE: Designing Women 

BYLINE:  By Laura Shapiro; Laura Shapiro's book, "Perfection Salad: Women and Cooking at the Turn of the Century," has just been reissued.

 BODY:
 A PERFECT FIT
Clothes, Character, and the Promise of America.
By Jenna Weissman Joselit.
Illustrated. 257 pp. New York:
Metropolitan Books/Henry Holt & Company. $26.
 SHORTLY after the turn of the last century, the industrial revolution finally got around to women's clothing. Factory-made pants and suits for men had been available for years, but women were still outfitting themselves the hard way: they pinned and fitted and stitched, laboriously and endlessly, day after day and long into the evening. They loved ready-to-wear.
But it wasn't just the delightful new habit of buying instead of making the family's clothes that spurred Americans to start thinking, talking, arguing and writing about clothing as they never had before. What captured people's imaginations was the moral potential of fashion, beginning with its democratic reach up and down the social scale and across the nation. Designs that started in New York could be copied by one manufacturer after another, each knockoff made to sell more cheaply than the last, until good-looking garments were hanging on the racks of dime stores from coast to coast. Now anybody, it seemed, could dress well -- could dress, that is, as if he or she enjoyed all the blessings that God so wisely bestowed upon righteous Americans.
As Jenna Weissman Joselit explains in her witty and enlightening new book, "A Perfect Fit: Clothes, Character, and the Promise of America," this was the moment when reformers, educators, writers and advertisers set about "transforming personal appearance into a civic virtue." "No housewife in America today need look dowdy and frumpy, unless she wants to be that way," Nell Donnelly asserted in 1927. Donnelly was the Kansas City homemaker who, deeply frustrated at not having anything attractive to wear while going about her work, invented the housedress.
Nowadays we tend to assume that getting dressed in the morning, be it ever so humbly in jeans and a T-shirt, has no higher purpose than displaying our favorite image of ourselves. But during the decades Joselit examines here, from the 1890's through the 1930's, fashion had quite a different responsibility. The social and economic changes spawned by the industrial revolution, the emancipation of blacks and the arrival of wave after wave of immigrants all contributed to a national conundrum: What was America? Who were Americans?
Clothing, Joselit writes, "was no private affair, subject to fancy or the whim of the moment. What one wore was a public construct, bound up with an enduring moral order." Fashion was an instrument to help people fit in, not stand out. An immigrant donning a starched collar made himself acceptable; a young black woman in the dignified dress of a schoolteacher exuded propriety. And newly hatched citizens weren't the only ones who needed prompting about what to wear. The fashion writer Mary Brooks Picken suggested that all women keep in mind a kind of shopper's pledge of allegiance, which ran as follows: "As an American woman, I pledge myself to strive always to acquire and wear only such clothes as are appropriate and individually becoming; to avoid extremes in design and color; to respect my clothes enough to care for them to the best of my ability; and to select my clothes so that, in fairness to them, they may give back to me in service more than they cost me in money."
Joselit, the historian who brought us blintzes inscribed with the Ten Commandments in her unforgettable book "The Wonders of America: Reinventing Jewish Culture, 1880-1950," this time scrutinizes dresses, suits, hats, shoes and jewelry to find out what it was Americans hoped to see when they looked in the mirror. One of her most fascinating case studies concerns women's hats, which precipitated a major social crisis around 1910.
Clergymen had long been annoyed by flamboyant headgear; now they began speaking out furiously against the gigantic dioramas that bobbed into church each Sunday. Spanning two feet in width and three feet in height, the hats carried a massive load of flowers, plumes, bows and ruffles. Pastors complained that the hats obstructed people's views and were far too ostentatious to be truly Christian. Worse, they annoyed male churchgoers, already so scarce the clergy feared they might disappear entirely. Out on the street, people worried about being stuck with hatpins; in theaters, the management ordered women to take off their hats when the curtain went up. Subway riders said the hats crowded other passengers and posed a danger to people waiting on the platform. In short, women in big hats took up too much room.
On its editorial pages, The New York Times begged women to give them up, but the paper had no more luck than the pastors. Why were women so stubborn on this point? Joselit suggests that women treasured hats precisely for the public role they played: they were signs of a woman's uniqueness, offering the world a chance to see who she was when her imagination ran free. The rest of her costume was governed by numerous codes of proper femininity -- as was the rest of her life. And, though Joselit doesn't mention it, maybe women simply enjoyed taking up too much room for a change. Especially on the subway.
After World War II, questions of national identity shifted to the political front, and fashion lost its association with the commonweal. A great many formal costumes gave way to innovations that once would have incited passionate debate: Bermuda shorts appeared on legs of every size and age, women adopted slacks and men went to work in wash-and-wear suits. Only in the 1960's did the nation start arguing about its clothes with the old fervor, using fashion to probe what it meant to be an American at a time when all standards were under siege. "Women put on miniskirts, took off their bras and claimed the pants suit as their own; men let down their hair and wore bell-bottomed trousers festooned with flowers," Joselit writes. It made for a great dust-up; but, as she points out, it was the last one.
Clearly, fashion no longer had the power to unite Americans under the banner of right living, though it took a designer to say so. Rudi Gernreich, proud father of the topless bathing suit, sounded the knell in 1969 when he decreed, "Morality is individual." Thanks to Joselit's peerless gift for turning up amazing artifacts where few historians bother to dig, we now know what morality looked like before Gernreich -- when it was a shared ideal, that is, and we could find it at Macy's.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; 
Looking Back: 14 Years of Tips

BYLINE:  By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
WHEN Paul Grimes, the originator of the Practical Traveler column, turned it over to me 14 years ago, he said the most important task was to read the fine print on everything -- tickets, insurance fliers, tour brochures, guarantees. In the big type, he said, everyone fibs. Typical is the "nine night" tour that the small type clearly shows includes one night in an airline seat.
 It's a good first principle. And now that it is time for me to yield this space, I thought to compress into the allotted 1,200 words other nuggets I have derived from 613 weeks -- I did take vacations -- of sometimes furious research. So here goes. 
 The term "direct flight" is nonsense. It's a nonstop flight or it is not. I have been shifted to other airlines as well as other planes on trips labeled direct flights. 
When you walk out into a foreign city, one where English is not the first language, snag a business card or a brochure from the desk of your hotel. It will save you from the terrors Jean Simmons suffered in "So Long at the Fair," when her hotel room apparently disappeared.
Taxes can destroy bargain rates. A car rented for $179.99 a week in Minneapolis will run $245.10 by the time the taxes and fees are piled on. A hotel room in New York City advertised at, say $129, will cost a somewhat less reasonable $148 a night after the taxes of 13.25 percent plus $2 are added. This could be a particularly unwelcome surprise. Ask about taxes when you call.
Don't let gloaters spoil your trip when they boast about the better exchange rate they got for their lire. Yes, keep your eye on the fees at places with names like KashPoynte. But even if you pay too much once, don't agonize over $2 wasted on a $500 exchange. Honor is not at stake.
Don't pack anything you cannot bear to part with. I still remember seeing a gold charm bracelet at the Unclaimed Baggage store in Scottsboro, Ala. "I bet they cried when they lost that one," the clerk said.
Most travelers have to discover this for themselves, but perhaps one or two people can be spared the embarrassment: that string over the shower in the European hotel is not the light cord. It's an emergency bell. If you pull it, people will be along when you least want them.
If you are going to anything other than a tropical spot, pack gloves: hands can get cold on the most unexpected dates. And mittens are warmer than gloves, if less chic.
Take a map. Even if you've driven the route a hundred times, accidents and detours may dispatch you to Terra Incognita.
When flying for weddings, graduations and other unalterable major dates, go a day in advance. You can probably recover the day of used-up vacation, but not the event.
When checking a suitcase, put a card inside with your name, destination hotel and phone number.
Carrying extra film is a good idea. Carrying extra camera batteries is a great idea. Shopping for an obscure size or special film where you do not speak the language is hard.
If you didn't notice on checking in, you can tell it's an economy hotel by the thinness of the towels.
Check your passport expiration date now, not the day before you leave. If yours expires in the next few months, renew now by mail rather than play the costly game of beat the deadline later. Most photo developing shops now take proper passport pictures.
There is no fast lane in a traffic jam. Or an airline check-in line. So relax. Sing. Play a tape.
Get the name of the person who takes your hotel or tour reservation. If the computer system digests badly, that name will uphold your credibility and may even help another employee trace your record.
There is no more free lunch, but the International Association for Medical Assistance to Travelers does send a directory of English-speaking doctors overseas who agree to limit their fees for office and hotel calls. Write to the organization at 417 Center Street, Lewiston, N.Y. 14092, call (716) 754-4883, or see www.iamat.org. No surprise, the organization lives by contributions, and you will be asked.
What's a double room in another country? It may have one wide bed or two narrow ones. If it matters to you, ask. Similarly, a British hotel room described as having a private bath may indeed have a bath but not a toilet. Ask.

What to Take -- and Leave
 Carry two credit cards separately when you travel. If one is stolen, and the account is frozen, you have another way to feed and house yourself.
In an airport crisis, blowing up at the gate agent will not help. It can hurt. On an occasion of awful weather at La Guardia some years ago, the man in line in front of me lost it and called the gate agent an obscene word. She told him to step aside before she called the police. He became more objectionable. I told her that if she needed a witness, I would be available. Most of us who stuck it out got on the flight, when there finally was one. He was not aboard, and may have been in detention.
Don't pack brand new shoes. Take only those that are already broken in.
The little note pad with the name and phone number of the hotel in Florence is meant to be taken with you. I have a rack of hotel note pads more treasured than objects from lost arks. When these are given to friends who ask for a recommendation, the hotel will recoup its investment many times over.
Don't pack more than you can carry up two flights of stairs.
Arrive at a hotel with some singles in your pocket; save yourself from groping and embarrassment.
Computer systems get knocked out: At hotels, at airports, at car rental counters and even in the stock exchange and A.T.M. networks. Carry a few extra dollars; do not rely utterly on electronic lifelines. And if you have a faxed confirmation sheet, it may get you into a hotel room while the reservation system is brought back up.
It is a dark topic, but children who take airplane trips alone often experience many more difficulties than airlines, parents, safety advocates and airport managers want to acknowledge. Parents should do whatever is humanly possible to avoid sending a child alone by plane before the child is old enough to ride alone on public transportation in a city. Some children are ready at 14; some are still uncertain at 16.
Airline pillows do not get fresh cases after each flight. They may not even get fresh cases each day. If this bothers you, take your own pillow or case.
Your bank may sock you with a fee of as much as $5 for getting cash from your account through an A.T.M. abroad, but those machines installed at overseas banks do not hit you for the annoying $1.50 or $2 you pay at home for using another bank's machine.
Hotels in the United States are required to provide a card by the room phone stating the telephone charges. If it's not there, ask the front desk for one before you hook up your computer.
A journalism teacher from The Daily News admonished our class at Columbia University many years ago, in colorful language, to let it enter our heads once in a great while that we might be wrong. That's a good thought for coping while traveling.

HEADLINE: A Bounty From Uneven Terrain 

BYLINE:  By MARY TAYLOR SIMETI; MARY TAYLOR SIMETI's latest book about Sicily, "Travels With a Medieval Queen" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), is to be published in November.

 BODY:
ABOUT 15 years ago, I received a letter from a reader in the United States asking for names of country inns where she and a friend, both of them great walkers, could stay in Sicily. After some thought and with considerable surprise I had to answer that there weren't any.
 Were she to write today, I could give her a different answer: country inns have not taken over the island, but agriturismo has. The guest-farm movement that started in the north, encouraged by the Italian government as a source of supplementary income to small farmers, was officially adopted by the Sicilian regional government in 1994, and now almost a hundred farms participate. My husband, Tonino, who is an agricultural economist as well as a farmer, was enthusiastic from the very beginning. But I -- who would rather write than cope with guests (and I knew immediately that it would be I who would be doing the coping) -- turned my back on the phenomenon. 
 Curiosity recently got the better of me, however, so last winter my husband and I embarked on a busman's holiday, leaving our farm in western Sicily to explore the world of agriturismo. We decided to work our way around the eastern end of the island, which offered greater choice and less familiar scenery, and where it was easier to maintain my professional anonymity. We planned our route by guidebooks and by word-of-mouth, taking our chances on pitfalls and pleasures just as any tourist must.
We began near Modica, an excellent spot from which to sample the great Baroque architecture (and the great rococo pastries) of southeastern Sicily, where we had chosen the Villa Teresa from a guidebook. 
The land here is even stonier than in New England: beautifully built stone walls divide stony fields and fence off stone houses, be they huts or aristocratic mansions. It is a very bleak landscape in summer, softened only by the dark green carob trees and the silvery olives, but in early January the fields were lush with grass. Villa Teresa is a handsome stone house with balconied French windows on the piano nobile overlooking a small garden. The entrance, through a gate to the side, gave onto a stone-paved courtyard, ringed by the guest quarters. The woman who showed us to our room announced that dinner was at 8, and that the heat was programmed to go on at 6: since we had chosen to arrive before dark fell at 5, that left us one very cold hour to pass.
Primed by our fantasies of agriturismo, we went in search of a fireplace. There was none: the dining room was dark and cavernous; the bar had two small tables, each with two straight chairs, tucked into the corners of what also served as entrance, office and passageway. We had a cup of tea and then went back to our room to climb under the covers and read (the bed was comfortable, the covers were ample, the heat was good once it got going, and there was even a television). The room was small and overstuffed with heavy, dark furnishings; the adjacent bath had an elementary shower but ranked well in the adequate but definitely not luxurious style typical of agriturismo.
As we ate a simple but well-cooked dinner at our table for two, we questioned the waitress and learned that Villa Teresa belonged to a family of substance from Syracuse who had converted the structure, printed a brochure and then put it in the hands of hearty but not particularly congenial locals, who had a small farm "down the road." The next morning one could see the elderly owner sitting at a window of the main floor and keeping an eye on the courtyard. 
We concluded that as a warm-weather and relatively inexpensive hotel in this area, Villa Teresa got passing grades, but that it had little to do with what we had been led to expect of an agriturismo.
We also concluded -- the first lesson of our trip -- that the quality of a guest farm depends a great deal on its common spaces, especially in winter when dark comes early and it is too cold to enjoy gardens and terraces. Even more important, we were to realize by the end, are the presence and the personality of the owners. 
The next two places we had chosen were in the plain inland of Syracuse, between the city and the foothills of the Hyblean Mountains. Limoneto (the Lemon Grove) was surrounded, as its name implies, by citrus trees. The main house, which contained the owners' apartment and the guests' dining room, was either modern or totally renovated, as were the low buildings surrounding it where guests were lodged. The spare furnishings in our room were contemporary and without character, but there was a TV, and the tile bathroom with shower was pleasantly modern. Architecturally less interesting than Villa Teresa, Limoneto featured green surroundings and a well-tended garden (with a boccie court and a playground) that were much more pleasant, and we were greeted by the owner herself, Adelina Norcia, who was in residence. 
Here, too, there was a shortage of indoor spaces, but at least the heat was on when we arrived, and the dining room, once it opened at 8, was furnished with long tables, one of which was set for 10. We ate with a young couple from Palermo, a magistrate from northern Italy who was touring with his wife and children, and an Englishman with a Dutch wife who always vacationed on guest farms, he said, to practice their Italian. 
A pleasant local wine accompanied pasta with ragu and beautifully fried fish and calamari, and kept the conversation going until quite late, much of which centered on an exchange of addresses and recommendations for other agriturismos. The Limoneto seemed to be getting good marks.
Le Case del Feudo, where we spent the next night after a day in Syracuse, occupies the former granaries and wine cellars of a large estate of citrus groves and vineyards belonging to Baron Pietro Beneventano del Bosco, who also owns a spectacular palace across from the Syracuse cathedral. Like many Sicilian aristocrats, he has found that the best way to maintain his estates is to welcome tourists: he organizes dinners in the palace and picnics on the Ciane River, and has built bedrooms and small apartments for guests in his baglio, as Sicilian farms round a courtyard are often called. 
We had one of the smaller rooms, the Camera del Marinaio, with a very small and spartan shower and simply decorated with ship lanterns and seagoing prints. The larger ones are extremely pretty, with stenciled walls, four-poster beds and antiques.
In the warmer months meals are served at umbrella-shaded tables in the central courtyard (the next morning, Jan. 5, we sat there in our shirt sleeves and soaked up the sun) and a swimming pool surrounded by deck chairs beckoned from the garden, but what we liked best upon arrival was a lighted fireplace in the big hall next to the dining room, where we could sit with our books until an aperitif was served.
We had happened in at a particularly grand moment -- there was a plethora of princesses sitting around the long dinner table, lingering after a New Year's celebration. But the atmosphere was informal, and over pasta con sugo, risotto di asparagi, gamberi and calamari fritti, rollo di carne, and deliciously fresh tangerines, the baron, who is an archaeology buff, regaled us with stories about nearby excavations and with descriptions of the special Syracusan dishes -- stuffed pork chops, zuppa di pesce, marinated anchovies with onions and blood oranges -- that we could have eaten upon request if we had been staying longer.
The baron himself lives in town, but he comes to the farm daily and is often there for dinner. In his absence Rosalba La Greca, his cook and manager, takes his place with obvious pride and dedication.
We wistfully concluded (our next lesson) that there is not much point in spending just one night in an agriturismo. The possibility of choosing what you want to eat the next evening is perhaps rare, but in the good establishments the atmosphere is conducive to leisurely exploration, savoring the coming and going in a familiar landscape, extending the first night's acquaintances and meeting local people. The pace is rural, so those who want to do all of Sicily in one week probably would be happier in city hotels. 
Our next stop was in Pettineo, a small town in the Nebrodi foothills on the northern coast, not far east of Cefalu. From the coast the road ran along the side of a valley, which narrowed as the road wound up through groves of centuries-old olive trees with massive contorted trunks. 
AS the road approached Pettineo, I pointed out a beautiful old house of yellow stone on a small hilltop just below us, surrounded by pines and cypresses. I had been told that to reach the farm we had to go through the town and farther along the road, but I had forgotten that mountain roads wind back upon themselves: the house we admired turned out to be our destination.
Casa Migliaca is as layered with history as Sicily itself: the foundations, and the timbered ceiling of the bedroom we slept in, date from the 17th century; the oil press downstairs, whose workings are still visible, belongs to the 18th century, while the upper story was added in the 19th. It has been in Teresa Allegra's family for several centuries, and was quite abandoned when she and her husband, Sebastiano, decided at the beginning of the 1990's to give up their interior decorating business and reclaim the house and what was left of the estate, 25 acres of olive and lemon groves that had gone wild, and have now been pruned and nurtured back into production. The farm is organic and produces most of the fruit and vegetables that appear on the table.
We had one of the four downstairs bedrooms, which look out over a terrace and down the valley to the sea. Ours was dominated by a high bed; it was a bit of a scramble to get into it, but once there I could hang over the edge and look down through a plexiglass pane onto the excavated press. A closet had a tiny bathroom and extremely simple shower. The bedrooms open onto a large room where the old olive press still stands, next to a table and chairs for reading. Near the fireplace at the other end is a huge circular stone platform on which millstones once crushed olives. Now topped by a wooden lazy susan of record diameter, this platform is a dinner table when guests are too numerous for the kitchen upstairs, where there are more bedrooms and a sitting room with a Franklin stove.
As soon as we had unpacked we were invited to join our hosts for an herb tea. Teresa was finishing dinner preparations in her 19th-century dream kitchen in which modernization has spared the majolica tiling on the walls and on the wood stove with its ovens, fireboxes and copper cauldrons. 
In abandoning city life, Teresa embraced country cooking, and Casa Migliaca offers the rare possibility to taste the beautiful vegetables and wild greens that most Sicilians consider too humble for guests. Dinner round the stone platform brought pasta with wild cardoons; egg frittatas with potatoes, with broccoli and with wild asparagus; mixed salad and cooked greens sprinkled with the house olive oil, local cheeses and fresh ricotta -- all served with good, abundant local wine, included in the price. Homemade limoncello liqueur wound up the meal.
At the end of the evening Teresa and Sebastiano went off to their cottage next door. The first guest up in the morning found the coffeepot and kettle ready to go onto the flame, and breakfast -- homemade jams, fresh bread, cheeses, oranges to eat or to squeeze -- spread out on the big kitchen table. When the hosts arrive, there are guidebooks and suggestions for a trip to Cefalu or the hill towns of the Nebrodis.
Pure curiosity prompted us, as an afterthought, to visit the Fattoria Mose, an agriturismo belonging to a friend and fellow member of Sicily's organic agriculture movement. Although I could not visit anonymously, as I had at the other B & B's, this was too good a find not to pass on, especially given the dearth of pleasant places to stay near Agrigento, where at even the best hotel, the view of the temples and the swimming pool can only just compensate for surly service and the odor of drains. 
To get there, we had to drive east from the Valley of the Temples through Villaggio Mose, a new and ghastly conglomeration of architectural flights of fancy -- hotels, supermarkets and condominiums in all conceivable shapes and colors. It was an enormous relief to arrive, up a small hill and through a gate, at the Fattoria, a vast and rambling collection of low buildings around an elegant late 19th-century manor house. 
The complex, stuccoed in a restful and weatherworn pink, is surrounded by greenery, and if in one direction it looks downhill onto a particularly unsightly condominium, the other views give onto almost a hundred acres of the estate's olive, pistachio, almond and orange groves. All these, including a small production of fruit and vegetables for use on the farm, are cultivated organically.
The Fattoria has belonged to the same family for several centuries, and is run by Chiara Agnello and her mother, who greeted us with warmth (and, had we needed it, in fluent English) and welcomed us to a dinner rich in the flavors of their vegetable garden.
Bed and breakfast, plus the evening meal if desired, are available in the manor house, whose vast sitting and dining rooms contain an appealing jumble of antiques and deep couches. Four double rooms, each with bath, can accommodate eight guests. Our room was small but comfortable, the furnishings old-fashioned and the walls decorated with family-done watercolors.
For a longer or more independent stay, outbuildings have been converted into six guests apartments of various sizes, with baths with showers, complete kitchens and simple but attractive contemporary furniture. They have separate terraces but share a courtyard -- lovely for a summer supper.
Ultimate conclusions: guest farms in Sicily run the gamut from cold to congenial, with many degrees of charm and comfort. Although I have heard of extremely luxurious ones, those we visited required some adaptability. But in most cases, the hosts were willing or even eager to share their culture and their traditions as well as their farms (and, it was rewarding to learn, were particularly appreciative of the open-minded curiosity and enthusiasm of their American guests). For those who want to travel in depth, agriturismo strikes me as an excellent introduction to the island.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
Hotel Rates Advance While Occupancy Drops

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
WHEN preliminary figures were released last month showing that nationwide occupancy rates at hotels had fallen 4 to 5 percent in May from the same month last year, it would have been logical to assume that room rates had also fallen. After all, the national economy continues to sputter, hotels are adding energy surcharges to bills, and -- until recently -- near-record gasoline prices presumably were a deterrent to travel. This would hardly seem a propitious time for rate increases.
 But the official May statistics released recently by Smith Travel Research, the scorekeeper of nationwide hotel performance, showed that along with a 5.3 percent drop in occupancy in May, room rates that month increased 0.9 percent to $86.02. (The average cost does not include energy surcharges.) 
 The latest figures are part of a 2001 trend. From January through April this year, hotel occupancy fell an average of 1.3 percent, to 59.9 percent, compared with the first four months of 2000; room rates in the same period increased an average of 3.1 percent to $85.99. Even as the economic slowdown continued, the opposing trends between occupancy and room rates remained. In April, for example, occupancy fell an average of 3.7 percent compared with April 2000, yet average room rates increased 1.2 percent to $86.87.
The pattern held true in various cities in the January-May period. Occupancy in New York plummeted 8.1 percent but room rates rose 0.2 percent to $191. In San Francisco/ San Mateo, occupancy tumbled 13.1 percent, but room rates rose 7.8 percent to $153.10. Boston's and Chicago's occupancy rates fell while room costs rose, but the differences were not quite as striking.
A number of other markets whose average room rates exceeded $100 last year lost occupancy in the first quarter this year yet still increased rates. They include Los Angeles-Long Beach, Miami-Hialeah and New Orleans. If there is such a thing as a winner in the room-rate sweepstakes, it is probably Washington, D.C. Although its occupancy fell 1.8 percent, it raised rates by 8 percent to $125.96.
A handful of hotels here and there have no doubt lowered rates, including luxury hotels, whose business through April, a Bear Stearns research study said last month, "was nothing short of terrible." The main reason for that was revealed in several surveys this year by the National Business Travel Association; one found that 77 percent of companies were reducing all but essential travel, and another showed that businesses were cutting back sharply on trips.
But a number of major business cities continue to do well, if not as well as during the past several record-breaking years. "We're seeing some softness in occupancy, especially in midweek," said Michael Deitemeyer, the chief operating officer of Omni Hotels, which owns the Omni Berkshire Place in Manhattan. "But where we'd have to turn down 400 guests a day in New York, we now sometimes have to turn away 50."
It is probably anybody's guess what the rest of the summer will bring for hotels. But Dexter C. Koehl, vice president for communications of the Washington-based Travel Industry Association of America, said his organization was sticking with its May prediction that travel would be up a modest 0.6 percent this summer over last.
Hotel occupancy in Houston increased a comparatively robust 4 percent through May of this year, although devastating floods in the city last month may take a heavy toll through much of the rest of the summer. And in a number of cities outside the major markets, including Cleveland, Indianapolis and Louisville, hotel occupancies appear to be defying the national trend. Hotel owners in Myrtle Beach, S.C., and other beach resorts still worry about high gasoline prices, a sputtering economy and the possibility that many leisure travelers will shorten their summer vacations.
Hotel occupancy has been off as much as 25 percent in Cincinnati, especially in the aftermath of three nights of rioting this April after a white police officer shot and killed an unarmed black man. (The recently settled three-month strike by pilots of Com air, based at the Cincinnati-Northern Kentucky International Airport, also contributed to the region's problems.)
Hotel companies are trying to blunt the impact on their bottom line by offering an array of amenities and freebies without lowering room rates.
For example, guests who spend two consecutive nights at an Omni hotel receive a third night free, while guests who stay any 10 nights at Starwood hotels or resorts receive two free weekends. And because almost half of adult American travelers are accompanied by children, both Embassy Suites and Ramada are giving their young guests an assortment of toys, games and books.
Guests who stay two nights at any of Choice Hotels International's various brands -- Comfort Inn and Suites, Quality, Clarion, Sleep Inn or MainStay Suites -- will receive a $5 gasoline card.
Guests at any of nearly 1,000 Holiday Inn hotels through Sept. 3 can receive a voucher allowing a companion to fly free on a domestic flight between any of 63 United States airports, along with the purchase of one nonrefundable ticket costing $299 to $599. There is no limit on the number of vouchers, which are obtained when the hotel is presented with a coupon found on the company's Web site (www.holiday-inn.com) or in print ads scheduled to run throughout the promotion.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN; 
Lake Placid

BYLINE:  By JAMES W. GRANT; JAMES W. GRANT is a freelance writer who lives in Lake Placid.

 BODY:
Lake Placid bills itself as the Winter Sports Capital of the World, and perhaps rightly so, having been host to the 1932 and 1980 Olympic Winter Games, as well as the inaugural Goodwill Winter Games in 2000. But the number of summer visitors here -- more than a million each year -- exceeds those of winter, and an estimated 65 percent of the local economy is generated from May through October, much of it from sports tourism. 
 Although still a perennial winter site for international competitions in bobsled, luge and skiing, Lake Placid in summer has world-class triathlons as well as classical music presented by members of professional orchestras from throughout the United States. 
 This particular summer is a crucial time for winter athletes, who have developed ingenious methods here to prepare for the Salt Lake City Games in 2002. Their activities, which include ski jumping on plastic snow and freestyle skiers landing in an enormous swimming pool, have become favorite attractions. Facilities include a United States Olympic Training Center (one of only three in the country) that opened in 1988 and trains athletes in all winter sports plus boxing, judo and summer events like water polo. The village is also headquarters for the United States Canoe and Kayak Team, which played host to a Pan American Games qualifier here last summer after opening in May 2000.

Events
On July 29, the Lake Placid Ironman U.S.A. Triathlon, (518) 5232665, www.ironmanusa.com, begins promptly at 7 a.m. with a 2.4-mile swim in Mirror Lake, followed by a 112-mile bike race through the Adirondacks, and ends with a full marathon run of 26.2 miles. The top finishers qualify for the world championship this fall in Hawaii. Some 1,800 athletes will compete on a course that has all three legs of competition beginning and ending near the center of town. There's a 17-hour time limit to complete the race, which ends at midnight. 
The Lake Placid Sinfonietta, www .northnet.org/lakeplacidsinfonietta, (518) 523-2512, offers free pops concerts Wednesdays at 7 p.m. through Aug. 8 at the Paul White Memorial Shell on the shore of Mirror Lake. 
Performers come from orchestras throughout the country and include present and former faculty members of the Eastman School of Music, Juilliard and the Manhattan School of Music. The artistic director and conductor is Alfred Gershfeld, founder and conductor of the Moldavian Chamber Orchestra and onetime conductor of the Bolshoi Theater Orchestra. The band shell lawn is quickly covered by blankets; an option to traditional seating is drifting in a canoe or rowboat just offshore. 
The Lake Placid Center for the Arts, 91 Saranac Avenue, (518) 523-2512, www.lpartscenter.org, will present Evening of Dance X, the last of a 10-year run of performances by dancers of the New York City Ballet, on July 23. Reserved seating ranges from $23 to $50.
The Lake Placid Institute presents LPI Jazz on Aug. 11 at 8 p.m. at the Lake Placid Center for the Arts, 91 Saranac Avenue; (518) 523-1312; www.lakeplacidinstitute.org. The Grammy winner Joe Lovano, Judi Silvano and Gary Peacock will present new compositions. Tickets are $10.

Sightseeing
At the Olympic Jumping Complex, just south of the village on Route 73, (518) 523-2202, www.orda.org, ski jumpers use 20,000 rectangles of plastic snow on the ramp to achieve speeds and distances nearly equal to those of winter. (The rectangles were made in Finland and are two and a half by one and a half feet.) Training takes place from Tuesday through Sunday from 10 a.m. to noon and from 2 to 3:30 p.m., with competitions each Saturday at 2 p.m. General admission of $8 allows visitors to view the jumping, ride a chair lift along the landing hill, and take the 26-story glass-enclosed elevator to an observation deck at the top of the 400-foot jumping tower. In addition to views of the skiers taking off from their starting point, the tower offers 360-degree views of the Adirondack High Peaks. 
At the adjacent Kodak Sports Park, included in the admission to the ski jumps, freestyle skiers perfect the acrobatics of their sport on steep ramps that propel them up to 20 feet into the air. Instead of landing on snow, aerialists land dramatically in a 750,000-gallon pool. This summer, visitors can view the Olympic freestyle teams of the United States, Canada, Russia and Byelorussia. The complex is open daily 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., and exhibitions are held Wednesdays at 1 p.m. 
The York International Luge Training Complex is about a mile away at 35 Church Street, (518) 523-2071, www.usaluge.org. At this indoor facility, computers, video cameras and refrigerated ramps analyze lugers' start technique throughout the summer months. Free public tours are held Monday to Friday at 2 p.m. 
At the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic Sports Complex, 15 minutes south of the village on Route 73, (518) 523-4436, tourists accompanied by a professional driver and brakeman can ride a bobsled on wheels at speeds of up to 50 miles an hour Wednesday through Sunday on the 1980 Winter Olympic track for $30 a person. 
Boat tours of Lake Placid are available aboard the 50-foot 100-passenger Doris II and the Lady of the Lake, a 45-foot, 33-passenger Fay & Bowen built in 1919 believed to be just one of two such vessels in the United States.
Highlights of the one-hour narrated cruise include good views of the former summer residences of the singer Kate Smith, Victor Herbert and Johnny Weissmuller. Tickets are $7.25 for adults, $5.25 for children, and $6.25 for seniors. The tours depart at 10:30 in the morning and at 1, 2:30 and 4 in the afternoon from the Lake Placid Marina; (518) 523-9704.

Where to Stay
Some of the most beautiful Adirondack sunsets and sunrises can be enjoyed at the Lake Placid Resort Hotel and Golf Club, 1 Olympic Drive, (518) 523-2556, fax (518) 523-9410, www.lakeplacidresort.com. This Holiday Inn with 207 rooms sits high above the village, minutes from Main Street shopping and convenient to the hotel's 45 holes of golf and private beach on Mirror Lake. There's also tennis, an indoor pool, a fitness center and four restaurants. Doubles range from $109 to $199. Family units, chalets, and golf and dining packages are available.
The Best Western Golden Arrow Hotel, 150 Main Street, (518) 523-3353, fax (518) 523-8063, www.golden-arrow.com, is in the heart of Lake Placid overlooking Mirror Lake. The lobby has hand-carved wood, cathedral ceilings and Bavarian murals. There's a sand beach, boating, a fitness center and a restaurant. Some of the 141 rooms and suites come with fireplaces and kitchenettes; all have balconies or patios. Doubles range from $109 to $169. Pets are welcome.
Budget: At the Cobble Mountain Lodge, Route 86 and Northwood Road, (518) 523-2040, guests can cook their dinners on gas grills or use an outdoor sauna. The lodge, rustic and simply furnished, has great mountain views and is just minutes from Main Street. Cabins and motel units with kitchenettes range from $38 to $100. Children under 15 are free.
The Stagecoach Inn, 370 Old Military Road, (518) 523-9474, www.stage coach-inn.com, opened for guests in 1833. It has nine comfortable rooms, two with working fireplaces, plus three fireplaces in the common areas in a classic Adirondack interior with floor to ceiling wainscoting and yellow birch trim. Doubles are $85 to $95, full breakfast included.
Luxury: The Mirror Lake Inn, 5 Mirror Lake Drive, (518) 523-2544, fax (518) 523-2871, www.mirrorlake inn.com, has 128 rooms, some right on the lakeshore, with comfortable country furnishings, many with balconies; doubles with lake views are $140 to $250; a two-level Presidential Suite with cathedral ceiling and oversize whirlpool is $725. The new spa includes rooms done in marble and mahogany, some with fireplaces. Treatments include a honey almond body polish (50 minutes for $85), and a Moor mud wrap in Dead Sea mud (50 minutes for $95). There are indoor and outdoor pools, a private beach, boating, sauna, tennis, a cocktail lounge and two restaurants. 
Built on the west shore of Lake Placid in 1882 as a humble lake cottage, the Lake Placid Lodge, (518) 523-2700, fax (518) 523-1124, www .lakeplacidlodge.com, is today a refurbished luxury hotel, part of the Relais & Chateaux group. The 17 rooms and 17 cabins are appointed with furniture crafted by local artisans, stone fireplaces and feather beds. Cell phones and personal computers are discouraged, and there's just one television set on the property. Guests can gaze the length of Lake Placid to unobstructed views of Whiteface Mountain. Amenities include a restaurant, free boating in canoes and kayaks, forested hiking and mountain bike trails (mountain bikes provided) and in-room massage. Golf and tennis are available at the adjacent historic Whiteface Club. Doubles $325 to $400, suites $550 to $650, cabins $500 to $800; all rates include breakfast.

Where to Eat
The deck of the Veranda Restaurant, 1 Olympic Drive, (518) 523-3339, is one of the best places to be on a summer evening, with views of Mirror Lake and the mountains of the Sentinel and Great Ranges. The fare is traditional American and French and includes Dover sole Grenobloise and fillet of beef Gorgonzola. The apple tart for dessert is a winner. A three-course dinner for two with wine is about $85. 
Nicola's Over Main, 90 Main Street, (518) 523-4430, serves classic Italian fare from antipasti and salads to veal and wood-fired pizza and fish, all prepared in an open kitchen. Expect to pay about $80 for dinner for two with wine.
Hat stretchers, log augers, cranberry pickers and hundreds of other Adirondack artifacts decorate the walls and ceiling of the Great Adirondack Steak and Seafood Company, 34 Main Street, (518) 523-1629. The petit filet mignon accompanied by John Brown Pale Ale, brewed on the premises, is a good choice. Dinner for two with wine or beer is about $60.
The open deck over Mirror Lake is the draw at the Cottage Cafe, 5 Mirror Lake Drive; (518) 523-9845. Locals come here for homemade soups, salads and sandwiches. Meals are served until 10 p.m. For lunch, arrive before noon to secure outdoor seating and perhaps see members of the United States canoe and kayak team training just offshore. Lunch or dinner for two with wine or beer is about $45.
A young crowd enjoys a pub menu of sandwiches, salads and barbecue at the Lake Placid Pub and Brewery, 14 Lake Shore Drive, (518) 523-3813. The taps pour the likes of Ubu Ale, an English strong ale ordered by the White House after President Clinton's visit here two summers ago. Lunch or dinner for two with wine or beer runs about $45.

HEADLINE: CHOICE TABLES; 
Philadelphia's Core, Well Fed, Revives

BYLINE:  By BRYAN MILLER; BRYAN MILLER, a former restaurant critic for The Times, is restaurant editor for Citysearch.com.

 BODY:
TO a returning visitor, the reawakening of downtown Philadelphia is nothing short of remarkable. Just five years ago, Center City after work was a quiet and gloomy terrain, however rich in history and colonial charm. Energized by a brawny economy and some forward thinking entrepreneurs, things began to change. And, as is often the case, restaurateurs led the charge. 
Today, this compact neighborhood -- roughly defined by Broad Street on the east and Rittenhouse Square on the west -- has such a lively dining scene that you could fling your credit card in any direction and it would likely land on a chef's doorstep. Following is a sampling.

Alma de Cuba
One of the hot newcomers to downtown is Alma de Cuba, whose chef and partner is Douglas Rodriguez (he also owns two restaurants in Manhattan, Pipa and Chicama). Mr. Rodriguez turns out a highly eccentric rendition of Central and South American cooking in a fashionable modern setting. 
You enter via a sleek bar and lounge where plangent Latin music -- so loud it could put another crack in the Liberty Bell some 10 blocks away -- sets a sassy mood. The tropical theme is expressed by overhead fans, a slat wood ceiling and black-and-white projections of Cuba on the white walls. In contrast, the rather formal main room on the second floor could be any with-it new place, with long beige banquettes, moody filtered lighting and cream-colored curtains.
Mr. Rodriguez has built a reputation on his liberal interpretation of tropical cuisine, often teasing diners with radical juxtapositions and brazen condiments -- anyone for grilled whole red snapper with green rice, chayote-and-shaved-calamari salad in lemon dressing sprinkled with cumin chili praline? In fairness, this may be a knockout dish, but my dining companion and I decided to navigate calmer waters. One starter that harmonized well comprised thin slices of rum-cured smoked marlin in hollowed-out malanga boats (a starchy tropical tuber) stoked with a generous dose of minced jalapenos. 
Another fine assembly was fried oysters set over a smoky mix of mashed plantains and bacon, along with sauteed spinach and a minty sauce called huacatay. I had forgotten how good tropical tubers can be (a nice change from the ubiquitous butter-laden mashed potatoes), especially in dishes here like grilled duck breast over mashed boniato, which tastes like a mild sweet potato with a hint of chestnut. It was accompanied by sauteed mustard greens, lean duck chorizo and a sweet pineapple-vanilla sauce that I could have done without. 
Servers seemed to have as much fun as the patrons, and their command of the challenging menu was impressive. The wine list has some singular bargains from South America, like a fresh, simple Chilean sauvignon blanc by Caliterra ($20 for the 2000 vintage).

Around Rittenhouse Square
On warm summer afternoons, tidy little Rittenhouse Square, one of Philadelphia's most patrician neighborhoods, is abloom with strolling couples, families and, in recent years, vibrant outdoor cafes. You might want to stop for a drink at Bleu, a cheerful, mural-wrapped American bistro that serves dishes like sweet steamed mussels, various composed salads, burgers and the like.
Next door, under the same ownership, is Rouge, a variation on the same theme with a more ambitious menu that carries everything from foie gras with red grape verjus (have it with a house riesling or a moscato d'Asti) to grilled salmon with lobster fried rice. Wines by the glass are modestly priced. 
My choice for lunch nearby was Opus 251, the delightful open-air cafe at the Philadelphia Art Alliance, a converted turn-of-the-century mansion that is now an exhibition space. The backyard brick patio, with marble tables, classical sculptures and a fragrant rose garden, serves a limited summer lunch menu that is light and simple, perfect before an afternoon of urban strolling.
For starters I enjoyed a glistening skein of soba noodles showered with shredded carrots, daikon and snow-pea shoots, in lively ginger vinaigrette (you can add grilled chicken to make a main course). My entree was a nicely cooked, crisp-skinned red snapper with sauteed bok choy and vegetable spring roll (unfortunately quite greasy). Another satisfying light option is a poached chicken-breast salad with red onions, olives, tomatoes and arugula, served atop charred flatbread. Fruit sorbets are the best dessert, especially the smooth and intense raspberry, papaya and lemon. 
The casual servers were pleasant and efficient, though we certainly were in no hurry in the splendid setting. Inside are two formal dining rooms for both lunch and dinner. The restaurant carries an affordable and wide-ranging international wine selection, as well as a changing handful of quality wines by the glass. 
Before heading over to the acclaimed Bec-Fin for a princely six-course, five-wine feast, we stopped for a some nibbles at a popular Latino restaurant called Pasion! -- a feat akin to running from Yonkers to Manhattan in time to join the New York City Marathon. This spirited three-year-old restaurant with a vaguely Caribbean motif specializes in ceviches, with five new ones featured daily, and they are well worth trying. 
We sat at the ceviche bar and sampled tender grilled baby octopus over a cucumber-and-black-olive salad; thinly sliced sea bass sprinkled with toasted sesame seeds along with tasty little rice croquettes and pickled seaweed salad; and rare-seared salmon strips with a wonderful cumin-coriander sauce. You can pair them with some delightful South American wines; our choice, which was perfect with the seafood, was a glass of sharp and grassy Aresti sauvignon blanc from Chile (1999). They also serve killer caipirinhas. 
While in the neighborhood, you might stop for a drink at the one of the most dramatic and popular restaurants in Philadelphia, Striped Bass. (Regrettably, we didn't have time to sample the all-seafood menu.) In a magnificent, marmoreal former bank with a 25-foot-high ceiling and massive columns, it attracts a well-dressed, upscale crowd -- no surprise, with entrees averaging about $35. The elevated bar, which serves a nice roster of wines by the glass, is a perfect perch from which to take it all in.

Le Bec-Fin
Aside from Ben Franklin, Georges Perrier may be the most celebrated and droll celebrity this city has seen over the years. When he encamped in the downtrodden Center City in 1971, Philadelphia's culinary scene was characterized by bulging cheese steaks and foil-wrapped blocks of dense cream cheese.
Today in Center City, visitors can dine at not one, but three Perrier creations. The most famous is Le Bec-Fin, which features classic Lyonnais cuisine in a suitably florid setting, served by a crew of ceremonious waiters -- and, if your tastes run to the opulent, there's still no show like it in town. Our $120 prix fixe menu (or $155 if you want the 11-course marathon) started with a rich, almost mousselike crab cake, sweet and flavorful, with a crown of osetra caviar, ringed by caramelized onions. On the lighter side was vernal cucumber soup enriched with a lemon-grass cream.
Dainty lagniappes arrive from all directions throughout the meal. My main course was a pristine fillet of sole, meaty and golden brown, surrounded by a sublime caviar-stippled lemon cream sauce; compared with that extravagance a garlicky roasted Cornish hen in a sherry vinegar sauce, while fine, seemed ordinary. The three-tier dessert trolley is so populous that you could repair to the restroom, make a few phone calls, and return to find the captain still reciting the selections.
"Most diners like to taste three or four," our waiter pointed out with a smile. And we did. Most memorable were a terrific sour-cherry risotto, and a thinly layered chocolate opera cake garnished with 24-karat gold leaf (keep it far from any inlays).
Oddly enough, the richly upholstered dining room can be shatteringly loud between 7:30 and 8:30 p.m., so you might want to work around that. Predictably, the wine list is impressive, and high-priced, although we found a relative bargain in the light and crisp 1997 Cotes de Provence Domaine Sorin ($60).
About 10 years ago, Mr. Perrier opened a tiny bar and bistro downstairs called Le Bar Lyonnais, which serves a simple, more affordable menu. And a block away is his new Art Deco-style Brasserie Perrier, serving a moderately priced international French menu. In the affluent suburb of Wayne, Pa., he recently opened a new Provencal-style restaurant, Le Mas Perrier.

Vetri
One of the most admired young chefs in Philadelphia is 34-year-old Marc Vetri, whose three-year-old restaurant serves soul-warming rustic Italian cuisine with contemporary fillips -- and at reasonable prices.
The snug 35-seat dining room has a countrified feeling with saffron stucco walls, wide-plank wood floors and bucolic faux window murals. The staff could not be more accommodating, and the easygoing Mr. Vetri occasionally appears in the dining room to take an order, clear dishes or refill wine glasses.
Hands down, the best dish of my Philadelphia tour was Mr. Vetri's roasted goat, which he prepared by simmering the meat in milk to impart a rich flavor, then roasting it until the skin was blistered and almost caramelized. Also superb was his spinach-ricotta gnocchi topped with shavings of smoked ricotta.
By coincidence, another outstanding main course was also poached in milk, a seared Alaskan white salmon. It was garnished with creme fraiche and presented over a golden potato pancake (unfortunately a bit leathery). Mr. Vetri also turned out some most-original desserts, such as a delightfully grainy polenta souffle. The smart and varied wine selection is very affordable. We had a rich and fruity red from Allegrini Palazzo della Torre 1997 ($50).

Around Town
One of Philadelphia's longtime Mexican favorites, Los Catrines, recently moved a few doors down from its original home to a baronial downtown mansion with dark mahogany walls, a 20-foot ceiling and a fine old bar. A long rectangular back room is more casual. I had heard that Los Catrines served an excellent mole poblano, and indeed it does: inky and thick, redolent of cloves and almonds, and just hot enough to keep you coming back. I had it ladled around two pieces of chicken breast the size of maracas.
If you are visiting town with children, or simply like to check out the less-trodden parts of town, hop into a cab for a five-minute ride into South Philadelphia and Carman's Country Kitchen, a wacky cafe-cum-diner that is famous for its wagon-train breakfasts and the affable antics of the owner and chef, Carman Luntzel. 
With its eight-stool counter, 20 cramped seats, and bric-a-brac galore, you can't help but be intimate with everybody in the place. In summer, overflow customers dine "alfresco" at a makeshift table in the back of Carman's red pickup truck. ("It seats eight, maybe more if I get some special welding done.")
Early on a Saturday morning I secured a coveted counter stool and scaled an escarpment of peanut-butter-and-banana pancakes with bacon drippings, along with a vat of strong coffee while chatting it up with Carman about New York City, local eccentrics who eat there, and her truck. Aside from omelets and specialties like cornflake-crusted challah French toast, she offers brunch dishes like seared tilapia in parsley and white wine sauce. The cafe serves from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m. Thursday to Monday.
It's advisable to call ahead. Thing is, Carman loves to travel ("I'm going to Egypt next month!"), so you may arrive to find a postcard stuck to the front door. And an empty pickup truck.

From risotto to ceviche

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Westchester Heads Off Development; 
County to Buy Farmland

 BODY:
After a year of negotiations, Westchester Countyannounced plans on Wednesday to acquire 178.5 acres of a historic farm in Yorktown and head off its development. The county plans to use 50 acres of Hilltop Hanover Farm, which dates to the late 1700's, for an environmental education center -- what County Executive Andrew J. Spano called "a working classroom in pesticide-free agriculture, a place to study wildflowers and birds, a laboratory and learning center for county residents." 
 Westchester is also negotiating to sell 128 acres of the property, which is near the Croton Reservoir, to the New York City Department of Environmental Protection. The department oversees the reservoir, which is part of the water supply system for the city as well as much of Westchester. 
 The owners of the farm, the investors John Sites and Giles Brophy, will retain about 70 acres.
Because Hilltop Hanover Farm had been on the market since 1995, Salvatore J. Carrera, the county's director of economic development and real estate, said he was able to negotiate the price down to $2.8 million from the $6 million the owners had been asking.
Mr. Carrera said that when developers have not obtained subdivision approval for their land -- a process that often takes years and entails many expenses -- governments "should not pay top dollar."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION/RADIO; 
The Reality Of Recovery, Unadorned

BYLINE:  By ANDY MEISLER; Andy Meisler works as a talk show segment producer and writes frequently about television.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
IF you've ever encountered Bob Dey while channel surfing, you may have had cause to rethink your definition of reality television. His on-screen world -- one without tribal warfare, $1 million prizes or more-than-minimal production values -- is about as real as it gets.
 Mr. Dey has battled addictions and emotional disorders most of his adult life. He is not an actor, but, speaking without a script, he manages to eloquently describe his overwhelming cravings, his delirium tremens, his depressions -- and the insights he has gained along the path to sobriety. 
 "My bottom came when I couldn't even make it to work," he says on "Testimony," an aptly named half-hour series which consists of one person talking, without visible prompting, about some of the most personal issues imaginable. "I kept the curtains closed in my bedroom because it hurt to have the sunlight streaming in. Every now and then I'd peek out through a crack and take a look at the world outside. I'd think to myself: 'That's life that's going on out there. And you're missing it.' " 
Mr. Dey, along with dozens of other everyday people embroiled in the webs of substance abuse and emotional disorders, is an on-screen participant in an unusual, little-seen television entity called the Recovery Network. Unlike the dramas, comedies and newsmagazines elsewhere on TV, which use topics like alcoholism, drug use and depression as grace notes in their depictions of life, the Recovery Network's programming concentrates almost entirely on the first-person struggles of people like Mr. Dey and their friends and family members.
"No, watching television isn't a substitute for going to a self-help meeting," said Mr. Dey, a retired feature writer and handicapper for The Daily Racing Form, over lunch near his Hollywood-area home recently. "But there's something about watching a peer-led meeting that's so much more effective than having a professional tell you what to do. If you see, say, an alcoholic talking to another alcoholic who's still using and abusing -- and telling him, I know exactly what you're going through because I went through it too, and this is what I did, and this is what I do today to stay clean and sober -- it has so much more meaning."
The four-year-old network, based in Irvine, Calif., and available on cable in close to 15 million households nationwide, runs occasional documentaries on addiction and subjects related to emotional illness, a "wellness" show whose host is the author Gary Null and a program called "Overcoming Overeating." But its signature series are "Testimony" and "Full Circle" -- simple programs in which recovering individuals, singly and in groups of 10 or 12, ignore the camera while starkly recounting their successes and failures. Most episodes were filmed in 1997, and -- this is low-budget television, just a step above public access -- have been rerunning constantly since then.
Under the "Full Circle" rubric, groups of adults battling problems like alcoholism, drug addiction, eating disorders, spousal abuse and mental illness -- and coping with how their problems affect their loved ones -- sit on couches in a nondescript meeting room and speak at the behest of an unobtrusive moderator.
The "Full Circle" groups "meet" for 13 one-hour episodes. The group members give up at least part of their anonymity, although no last names are used. The participants come from all economic strata and range from alcoholics who have been sober for decades to drug addicts shuttling from residential treatment centers. They were recruited by Share, a Los Angeles-based nonprofit organization that serves as an umbrella for self-help groups, and were given $25 a day for expenses.
In "Testimony," "Full Circle" participants are given a half-hour to tell their stories uninterrupted.
Regular viewers of the Recovery Network eventually get to know the "regulars." These include people like Diane, a professional woman and recovering bulimic who recalls being molested as a child and becoming a straight-A college student with an encyclopedic knowledge of her campus's least-frequented bathrooms -- where she went to throw up after her periodic eating binges; Steve, a musician who began taking drugs at 11, burned out his nose with cocaine use, has "been to jail quite often" and whose proudest accomplishment to date is being trusted to answer the telephone at his current rehabilitation facility; Mike, the son of an abusive "rage aholic," whose wife had broken her promise not to abandon him to tend to her two addicted adult children from a previous marriage; and Mr. Dey, who faced disapproval from longtime members of his alcoholism 12-step group for his use of antidepressants -- and found solace in a more tolerant group of 12-step "double trudgers" (addicts with emotional disorders who trust both in a higher power and in psychiatric medication).
Although an on-screen disclaimer at the beginning of "Full Circle" states that "it is not intended to be a 12-step meeting," and no mention is made of Alcoholics Anonymous, any of its offshoots or tools like "The Big Book" or "The Twelve Traditions," it's obvious that the organization's techniques and philosophies are being enthusiastically embraced.
Another parallel to Alcoholics Anonymous, albeit an unintentional one, is the Recovery Network's low public profile. The network does not have cable channels of its own. Instead it is carried at odd intervals, usually for several hours late at night, on public and governmental access channels.
In Los Angeles, for instance, it appears on cable Channel 36 from 10 p.m. to 2 a.m. daily. In Chicago it pops up on Channel 23 from 2 a.m. to 7 a.m.; in Las Vegas on Channel 2 from 11 p.m. to 2 a.m. 
In the New York area it is seen in the Bronx on Channel 46 from 6:30-7:30 a.m. and in various New Jersey communities, including Bayonne, Belmar, Bergen, Creskill, Hoboken, Hudson, Monmouth, Newark and Union City, at various times and on various noncommercial channels.
The availability of the network would probably be news to most of the households that receive it, since its programming is rarely if ever listed in TV Guide or local newspapers. Still, it receives hundreds of letters of thanks, most often from relatives of people with addictions or emotional problems. They write that after watching the programs, they are better able to understand the problems they and their loved ones may or may not have come around to acknowledging.
Local cable operators report a positive and unexpectedly vigorous reaction to the channel. "All of the area support groups whose phone numbers we list on the channel are very happy that we run it," said Joyce Gallagher, the cable television administrator for the city of Chicago. "As for me personally, I believe it's a life-giving service."
Steven Grace, president of Channel 36 in Los Angeles, said: "I don't have any hard ratings figures, but just talking with friends and people I meet with during the day, it seems we're satisfying a huge need and inspiring hopeful solutions.
"In fact, when I told the woman who runs the coffee shop I stop at every morning that I worked at Channel 36, she said: 'Oh, sure. I know it. That's the Recovery Network.' "
The Recovery Network is provided free to local cable operators, its programs separated by public service advertising. It is not an altogether altruistic enterprise, however.
The network was conceived in the mid-1990's as a commercial channel, in anticipation of the 500-channel basic-cable systems that seemed imminent. That market didn't materialize, and the network is now a nonprofit arm of RnetHealth Inc., a publicly traded company that recently underwent a downsizing and restructuring. RnetHealth, among other things, sells courses and teaching aids to institutions and individuals dealing with substance-abuse problems and emotional illnesses.
Wendy Boros-Johnson, president and chief executive officer of Rnet Health, said she would soon begin soliciting PBS-style corporate underwriting for the network. The company is not aggressively promoted on the Recovery Network's programs, but the name of its Web site is occasionally flashed.
The programming, she said, perhaps a bit wishfully, is a good fit with the rest of RnetHealth. "If you really look at who could be watching us," she said during a recent interview, "we are aiming at people who not only are affected by drug abuse, alcohol abuse and other behavioral disorders, but the people we call 'affected others.' Their families. Their employers.
"The truth is that almost all of us know somebody who is having problems. When you extrapolate those kinds of things into a potential audience, it's mindboggling -- it's over 100 million people."
Bob Dey, who has been an active volunteer staffer for several self-help groups, had no qualms about being named in an article. Despite having received just the $25 a day for his appearances on "Full Circle" and "Testimony," he has no objections to the Recovery Network's being connected to a profit-making enterprise.
But he does see its basic mission from a slightly different angle than does Ms. Boros-Johnson.
"I think networks and programs like these can have a tremendous effect," he said. "One of the biggest assets to those kinds of shows is just the single fact that it gets out the message: I am not alone.
"So many people who have an addiction or mental illness suffer both from their symptoms and sensations and from feeling so alone and inadequate to life. What these shows do is say: you're not alone. Look at this body of people here who have suffered, maybe for years, from what you're suffering from. And yes, there is hope."
