HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Jobless Rates Don't Convey A Key Aspect: Does It Last?

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
FOR the last six months, American companies have been laying off tens of thousands of workers, while their counterparts in Europe have been adding to their payrolls. Yet unemployment in the United States -- 4.5 percent in June -- remains lower than it is across the Atlantic.
 In Britain, the rate is 5.1 percent. In Germany, it is 7.8 percent, and in both France and Italy it is above 8 percent. 
 The gap is not new, and it contributes to a widely held perception that the condition of being without a job is different in Europe than in the United States. There, unemployment is supposed to be more pervasive, because the economies are less efficient, but also less unpleasant because the governments provide relatively generous benefits.
There is certainly some truth to this. A greater portion of Europeans are looking for jobs right now, and these unemployed workers do receive bigger checks and better health benefits from their governments than they would in the United States. But the conventional wisdom also misses an important difference between the world's two largest economies -- a difference worth considering because most economists are predicting that joblessness will rise in both places over the next year.
Employment statistics essentially break down a population into three categories: those with jobs; those without jobs but actively looking; and those without jobs who have not tried in the previous four weeks to find work. To create the unemployment rate, government data collectors exclude the third group and add the first two together, calling them the labor force. They then divide the number of those looking for work by the number in the labor force.
The resulting statistic is a snapshot. It describes people's present situation, but it says nothing about which category they were in previously. As a result, two societies with similar unemployment rates can have quite different labor markets.
Imagine two countries -- one called Flexia, the other Status. Each has a labor force of one million people, and 40,000 of them are out of work. So the unemployment rate of each is 4 percent.
In Flexia, job cuts are common. Companies can fire people almost at will, but they often hire new workers at the same time. In a typical year, some 160,000 members of Flexia's labor force are out of work at some point, but the average unemployed worker needs only three months to find a new job.
In Status, the government has passed laws that make it difficult and expensive for companies to cut jobs. As a result, executives cannot make mass layoffs easily. They are also more reluctant to hire new employees, knowing that their salaries will probably be on the company's income statement for years to come. In a typical year, only 40,000 members of the Status labor force are without jobs, but they need about a year to find work.
To think of it another way, being unemployed in Status is worse than it is in Flexia -- because it lasts longer -- but it is also less common, despite the similar jobless rates.
AS it happens, each of these make-believe nations resembles an actual country, according to a study by two researchers, Olivier Blanchard and Pedro Portugal, published in the American Economic Review in March. (They bear no responsibility for the fictional names.) Flexia is a miniature version of the United States, and Status is similar to Portugal. 
The economists chose the two countries because they have had similar unemployment rates -- between 3.9 and 5 percent -- in recent years. As the researchers dug deeper, however, they found great variation between the labor markets. 
"In Portugal, the probability of being unemployed is low, but once you're unemployed, you're likely to remain unemployed for a year," said Mr. Blanchard, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "In the U.S., you're much more likely to be unemployed. But you'll be unemployed for only a few weeks or months."
This is where the conventional wisdom about Europe and the United States is only half right. On any given day, being unemployed in Europe is better than being unemployed in the United States, because of the difference in benefits. But in neither place is it pleasant to be unable to find work. And in Europe -- where, like Portugal, most countries have strong job-protection laws -- unemployment tends to last for many months.
In any given year, in other words, being unemployed in Europe may be worse than it is in the United States.
Is that cause for another cheer on behalf of the American economy? Yes, but it should be a subdued one. The pervasiveness of layoffs here is one reason that American workers have had a harder time winning raises over the last two decades.

SECTION: Section 4; Column 1; Editorial Desk; Pg. 15

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
A Latin Tragedy

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
In the 1990's Argentina staged a dramatic recovery from decades of economic mismanagement, and in the process became an icon of the new world order. But last week the Argentine government found that it could roll over short-term debt only by offering a 14 percent interest rate, five points higher than a month earlier. And the buzz on Wall Street is that the question about an eventual Argentine debt default is no longer whether, but when.
 Both the markets and the Argentine government are treating the issue as mainly one of deficit spending. Indeed, in a desperate effort to regain market confidence, President Fernando de la Rua has called for draconian spending cuts. 
 But Argentina's fundamental problem isn't fiscal; it's monetary. Ten years ago Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo, the nation's economic hero, introduced a muchacclaimed monetary system, the nation's "currency board." Now he finds his handiwork threatened by that system's tragic flaw.
First, a word about the dire budget numbers you may have heard. Argentina, we are told, has a public debt equal to 45 percent of its G.D.P.; it has a budget deficit of more than 2 percent of G.D.P. Gee -- the budget numbers are almost as bad as they were in the United States when the elder George Bush was president!
Why does a level of debt and deficits that caused only tut-tutting here create panic in Argentina? To some extent it's a vicious circle: because investors believe default is likely, they demand usurious interest rates that may well push the country into default. But the main answer is that behind a mildly troubled budget lies a deeply troubled economy.
Argentina's economy surged between 1990 and 1998, but it has been steadily contracting ever since. Unemployment, which stayed high even during the good years, has risen above 16 percent. This dismal performance contributes to the budget problem in at least three ways. A depressed economy means low tax receipts; it's hard to slash spending or raise taxes when the populace is already feeling a lot of economic pain; and it's hard to convince lenders that you will grow out of your problems when your economy is, in fact, shrinking. It's easy to criticize Argentina's political leadership for its inability to eliminate the budget deficit. But when did you last see our own leaders raise taxes and cut spending in the face of a nasty recession?
So why is Argentina's economy depressed? Basically it comes down to the currency board, which pegs the value of the peso at one dollar and ensures (technicalities aside) that each peso in circulation is backed by a dollar in reserves. When it was introduced this system offered a welcome guarantee that hyperinflation would not return, and contributed to a stunning economic recovery. Now, however, the system's fatal flaw has become obvious. Argentina's international competitiveness has been undermined by devaluation in neighboring Brazil and by the weakness of the euro; domestic demand has fallen as consumers and companies lose confidence; but because the currency board allows no flexibility in monetary policy, policy makers cannot respond, Greenspan-style, by opening the monetary spigots. 
Mr. Cavallo, whom I know and admire (though I can't claim to have a sense of his soul) understands this very well. Yet he is understandably unwilling to abandon his creation. It would be a humiliating blow to his and his government's credibility. Also, because much of the debt of Argentina's private sector is in dollars, any devaluation of the peso would risk major financial disruption.
Yet if the latest desperate round of belt-tightening does not succeed, something will have to give. 
Some Wall Street analysts believe that the Argentine government will default but try to keep the peso pegged at one dollar. Maybe -- but that would be a bizarre strategy, choosing the worse of two evils. Advanced countries -- the status to which Argentina aspires -- regard default on debt as a mortal sin, but a sliding currency as at most a mild embarrassment. And default without devaluation, while easing Argentina's budget pressures, would do nothing to help its economy.
Meanwhile, the opposite strategy worked for Argentina's biggest neighbor. Two years ago Brazil was forced into a devaluation that many predicted would lead to economic ruin. It didn't. 
I hate to suggest that Argentina should emulate Brazil; indeed, I have been reluctant to say anything that would make Mr. Cavallo's job harder. But he and his country are rapidly running out of options.

HEADLINE: Oregon's Water War 

 BODY:
In spirit, the Endangered Species Act is the noblest of the landmark environmental statutes passed during the Nixon era. In practice, it has been by far the most controversial. It is the act right-wing property-rights advocates love to hate, and once again it is under fire for allegedly protecting animals at the expense of human economic needs -- this time in Oregon's Klamath Basin, where the federal Bureau of Reclamation has shut off irrigation water in order to save the endangered suckerfish and the threatened coho salmon. The action, coming on top of the worst drought the Pacific Northwest has seen in many years, has left 1,400 farmers without water, ruined crops on about 200,000 acres and inspired isolated acts of civil disobedience in which angry farmers have tried to reopen headgates blocking the water. It has also become the latest rallying cry for opponents of the Endangered Species Act. 
 But this is not, as right-wing critics would have us believe, a simple case of farmers vs. fish. Nor is the Endangered Species Act to blame. The fundamental problem in that the Klamath Basin is an overstressed ecosystem in which there are too many claimants for too little water -- farmers, fish, other wildlife, towns, downstream salmon fishermen whose business has long been declining and Indian tribes whose water claims predate those of the farmers. Had the system been managed in a balanced fashion in the first place, the act might never have been brought into play. Indeed, hard as it may be for the act's critics to admit, intelligent application of the law may in fact save the region by forcing the various stakeholders to devise new living arrangements aimed at ensuring the future of both people and wildlife. 
 The Bureau of Reclamation, which oversees federal water projects, acted on the basis of biological opinions from the two federal agencies that keep tabs on most of the 573 animal species listed as threatened or endangered under the Endangered Species Act. In one opinion, the Interior Department's Fish and Wildlife Service determined that the suckerfish, a bottom-feeder placed on the endangered list in 1988, would be jeopardized by further declines in water levels in Upper Klamath Lake, the source of the irrigation water. In the other opinion, the Commerce Department's National Marine Fisheries Service determined that continued irrigation would curtail the water flows necessary to coho salmon runs in the lower Klamath River.
Not surprisingly, critics have questioned the agencies' science, although it is hard to see how the suckerfish would not be harmed by declining water levels. As for the coho, there is a well-established correlation between robust water flows that push young salmon out to sea and healthy "returns" of mature salmon in later years. This year's healthy salmon runs are due partly to high water in earlier years. But as Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon has suggested, the debate here should not be about the government's response but about the fact that drastic steps were required in the first place. The current crisis has been in the making for at least 100 years, he observes, ever since the federal government decided to create a farming economy where none naturally belonged. From that perspective, the crisis is simply further affirmation of natural resources "stretched beyond their limits." 
Are there solutions? There are, but they do not lie in legislative maneuvers like the failed effort last week of Senator Gordon Smith of Oregon to overturn the biological opinions and allow drawdowns in Upper Klamath Lake. In the short term, as Interior Secretary Gale Norton suggested even as she denied a local petition to reverse the bureau's order, Washington must provide farmers with emergency financial help. Longer term, it should think more creatively, perhaps buying farmland from willing sellers in order to reduce agricultural demand for water and ensure reliable supplies for everyone.
There are notable precedents for such action. Early in his tenure, President Bill Clinton provided substantial help to loggers in the Pacific Northwest whose jobs began to disappear when timber sales were blocked to preserve habitat for the endangered spotted owl. The aid helped ease the region's transition from a dying timber industry to a more broadly based economy. In similar fashion, the administration and Congress could help the Klamath Basin's already shaky farming economy downsize to a more sustainable level. That would be a far greater gift to the region than continued grumbling about the Endangered Species Act.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
Virtual Revenge and the Decline of the Dot-Coms

BYLINE:  By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
THE hooting and jeering began the moment Webvan, the online grocer that was once a Wall Street darling, shut its doors last week, laying off its 2,000 employees and saying it would seek bankruptcy protection.
 First, there was the predictable crowing from terrestrial competitors who had been threatened by Webvan, which had symbolized the power of the Internet to transform even the most mundane industries. 
 "The supermarket landscape is littered with the skeletons of online grocers that tried to create a viable business model and failed," one news report quoted a spokesman for the grocery store chain Kroger as saying last week. "But our C.E.O. has said all along that we are not going to invest a large sum of money in a business that isn't profitable." 
Then came the haiku. Contributors to a Web site whose name refers to doomed dot-coms with an adjective that cannot be printed here, submitted approximately 400 poems, most along the lines of:
One hundred million
Could not keep us in business.
Jeez do we look dumb.
Actually, Webvan burned through something like $1.2 billion, which helps explain a certain enthusiasm for kicking the Internet bubble generation while they and their share prices are down. There are plenty of forums eager to catalog the fate of the folks who seduced investors and employees with visions of sure riches, including the dot-com graveyard, (www.upside.com /texis/mvm/graveyard/index), the dot-com deathwatch list (www.hoovers.com) and the flop tracker, which pegs the total dot-com flops at 245 (www.thestandard.com/trackers/flop/).
In any case, it's high season for schadenfreude. On Internet message boards, in media reports, at cocktail parties, almost anyone with a steady job in the old economy seems to be partaking of a new cultural pastime: gloating over the latest dot-com demise. "You can tell when you read between the lines that people are happy you are forced to go back to work," said Fred Levenson, who recently returned to the Palo Alto law firm that he had left for a job at Alta Vista, an Internet search engine company. "People are very happy that a lot of young people did not make a fortune in a very short period of time." 
The endless Internet ideas once categorized under the acronyms B2C (business to consumer) and B2B (business to business) are now being retrofitted with new definitions that satirize the entrepreneurs who hawked them. B2B now means "back to banking," B2C has morphed into "back to consulting," and, for the most ignominious failures, B2M means "back to Mom's."
EVEN The Onion, a humor publication that gained national attention through its Internet site, recently ran an article suggesting that laid-off dot-com workers receive unemployment benefits in the form of stock options in their former start-ups, accompanied by a photograph of an unemployment line of people sporting fancy messenger bags, Palm Pilots and cell phones.
Carol Kolb, The Onion's managing editor, suggests that the former Internet evangelists, notorious for their lavish parties and Aeron chairs, deserve such treatment for the excesses they committed during their glory days. "I guess it seems O.K. to be mean to them because they themselves were all too ready to jump on the bandwagon and get excited about this golden future that was going to skyrocket them to fame and fortune," she said.
Andrew Giangola, a spokesman for McKinsey & Co., a major consulting firm, simply notes that the shift in interest among top business school graduates away from start-ups over the last year speaks for itself. "I don't want to sound arrogant here but a lot of students are now realizing a career at a top consulting firm can offer interesting work in a progressive yet stable environment," he said. "Accent on the stable."
But if the hubris and high living of the would-be Internet conquerors has been widely derided, the smug satisfaction of those now enjoying their fall may suffer the same fate. Hypocrisy, after all, is not the most attractive of traits, and many of the lawyers, journalists and employees of "bricks and mortar" companies now sniggering over the latest "Ten Signs Your Dot-Com Is on the Skids" list making the rounds (via e-mail, naturally) were not long ago enviously watching the Internet gravy train pass them by.
And the Internet economy, which is a real and enormous fact, not just a business-plan fantasy, may yet emerge to take its revenge. "It's like they're relieved because it validates the position that their prudent, conservative approach was the right course," said Josh Harris, the founder of Pseudo.com, a Web-based entertainment company that shut down last fall. "But the pooh-poohers never took the chance, they never knew what it was like when there was a charge in the air, and they probably never will."
What most irks Tim Cavanaugh, the former editor of Suck, an online magazine that stopped publishing last month, is the sense that all that is good and successful about the Internet is being wrapped into the collective repudiation of it. Still, Mr. Cavanaugh admits that, but for his insistence on not mocking failing Internet companies, Suck might still be around. "There's definitely a huge market for it," he said.
Mr. Levenson, the lawyer, said he doesn't mind the ribbing he takes from colleagues and clients, because he himself has had to learn to laugh at seeing his shares in Alta Vista's parent company, CMGI, shoot from $42 to over $300 in 1999, only to plummet by 90 percent in the summer of 2000.
"But I was close," he said. "I could be sitting on a boat in Florida right now -- gloating."

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
A Rally Before the Checks Arrive

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Despite uncertainty about whether the American economy has managed to halt its decline, the stock market rallied at the end of last week. The surge began with positive sales reports from Microsoft and Motorola and came after the Dow Jones industrial average nearly slipped below 10,000 and the Nasdaq composite closed below 2,000 for the first time in four weeks. 
 An increase of 0.2 percent in retail sales in June, a gain in consumer confidence and the prospect of tax-cut checks arriving in the mail made some investors think that consumer spending would hold up well enough to keep the economy out of a recession. 
 Still, many analysts think that the Federal Reserve will have to push down its benchmark short-term interest rate, now 3.75 percent, to 3 percent or even lower to ensure that the economy turns around.
 The Nasdaq index closed at 2,084.79, up 80.63 points or 4 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed at 1,215.68, up 25.09 or 2.1 percent. The Dow Jones industrials finished at 10,539.06, up 286.38 or 2.8 percent.
 In the bond market, the financial turmoil in Argentina helped push interest rates lower. The yield on the 10-year note fell to 5.22 percent from 5.36 percent the previous week. JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK; 
Bonds Receives Support From Mr. October

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
When Barry Bonds hit 39 home runs before the All-Star Game, he surpassed Reggie Jackson and Mark McGwire as the player who hit the most home runs at that juncture of the season. Now Jackson is pulling for Bonds to pass McGwire as the player who hits the most home runs in an entire season.
 "I'm rooting for him; I'm sure he'll be fine," Jackson said before Bonds began the rest of the season with home run No. 40. 
 Jackson was reacting to the home run drought Bonds endured leading up to the break. After hitting 21 home runs in San Francisco's previous 28 games, Bonds played in 13 of the Giants' next 14 games without adding to his total of 39. Jackson saw nothing unusual about that apparent slump. 
"You don't realize that if a guy hit a home run every other day like he was, he'd hit 120," Jackson said. "Nobody's going to hit 120. I had 563 home runs and I went to bat 10,000 times. There are a lot of days when you don't hit any. So he's going to have times when he's going to slow down."
Jackson knows whereof he speaks. In 1969, he hit 37 home runs before the All-Star Game, then slowed way down, connecting for only 10 more the rest of the season and finishing with 47, behind Harmon Killebrew's 49 and Frank Howard's 48.
"I was a bust-out, but I was in the hospital for three weeks in September," Jackson recalled. "I ate some bad food. I had hives in my throat, all over my body."
Jackson actually missed nine games in September, not three weeks' worth, and he had missed hitting home runs in many more games.
"I was a little too young," he said. "I was 23. I didn't know how to handle it. If I had been a little bit older, if I had been through my New York stint, or Oakland, or had a couple of Mr. October years in me, I would have known how to handle it. I would have understood what was going on."
Throughout the rest of his career Jackson learned. He learned, for one thing, that home runs were more important than any other hits.
"I would say to Barry, I would say to McGwire, 'If you hit .220, hit 71,' " Jackson said. " 'If your average starts to suffer, hit the ball out of the ballpark.' "
He recalled saying to Griffey one time: "You said, 'My average is struggling.' If you're hitting .240, hit 50 home runs and people will say you hit 50, not that you hit .240."
Players and the news media place much more emphasis on statistics today than when he played, Jackson said.
"Numbers do mean more today," he said. "I don't know why. The media has made a big deal out of it. Then those numbers over the years have started to stand for something: Hall of Fame, greatness, that sort of thing.
"When I retired, I knew I had 563 home runs. I didn't know my lifetime average, I didn't know how many games I played, I didn't know how many hits I had. I have 2,580-some hits. I didn't know I had 400-some doubles.
"Right now Rickey Henderson is hanging on. It's unbelievable. He's hit .220 for three years. He's going to get 3,000 hits. Well, what's that? You know Rickey is going to be in the Hall of Fame. You're going to be in the Hall of Fame, Rickey, and nobody's going to vote for you. You're still going to get in; you don't need 3,000 hits. You want 3,000 hits for yourself. Well, I guess it's O.K."
Jackson also had something to say about the inflationary offense and how small parks and maybe artificial means are contributing to it: "Three, four guys on pace for 160 ribbies; seven, eight guys on pace for 50 homers, three, four guys on pace for 60. You're going to tell me the game has changed that much?"
Told that he was in danger of sounding like an oldtimer complaining about today's players, Jackson said: "I'm not whining about it. I'm telling you the truth. No matter what anybody does here, you got a long way to go before you do what I did."
"All this 63 and 24, that's real nice," he said, referring to the Seattle Mariners' won-lost record. "It counts in October, my friend. That's when it counts. The season starts Aug. 20. We all know that."

Nightmare in Denver
Ever since he signed a $121 million contract with the Colorado Rockies last December, Mike Hampton has been the target of some criticism for saying his decision wasn't based on the money but on the good schools in the Denver area. He also made another claim at the time: The Rockies would win.
"The basis of our decision was family and the chance to win," Hampton said. "The Rockies have a clear vision."
General Manager Dan O'Dowd had that vision, the pitcher said. "He convinced me that ownership is prepared to put a winner on the field," he said. "I did a lot of homework on this thing. I was up late at night. I'd go position by position. I know their team backward and forward. This team can win. I firmly believe that. We're going to be a winner. I have no doubt about that."
In Hampton's defense, he never specified this year, did he?
At last look, the Rockies were in last place in the National League West, 13 games out of first, and they had lost 18 of their last 21 games.
"Everything that could go wrong has," O'Dowd said. "Injuries, guys not playing well, a lack of confidence. It's steamrolling of one thing after another. Winning is contagious and losing is contagious. We have to change course and figure out how to get better. The important thing is gaining some confidence and going in the right direction. As for turning it around and becoming a playoff team, I'm not sure we have enough time for that."
Hampton hasn't won a game since June 10, his record falling to 9-6 and his earned run average rising to 4.32. By signing Hampton and Denny Neagle (for $51 million), the Rockies thought they would make a huge improvement in their pitching staff. But the staff E.R.A., at 5.43, is running higher than last season's 5.26.

A Ruthian Pace
First Roger Maris took away his season home run record. Then Hank Aaron took his career home run record. But for 80 years, no one has supplanted Babe Ruth as the record holder for total bases in a season. His mark of 457 in 1921 has withstood the challenge of such great hitters as Rogers Hornsby, Lou Gehrig, Jimmie Foxx, Stan Musial, Joe DiMaggio, and more recently Sammy Sosa, Larry Walker and Jim Rice.
Now comes Luis Gonzalez of Arizona, whose most productive seasons had been the past two. He amassed 336 total bases last year and 337 the year before. He entered last night's game with 254 total bases this season, an average of 2.85 a game. If he could maintain that average the rest of the season, which is not very likely, Gonzalez would finish with 462. Roger Maris, Hank Aaron and Luis Gonzalez?

A Subdued Realism
He uttered it plaintively but with so much meaning. "Everybody wants to be a superstar," Paul Wilson said earlier in the year. "I just want to be an old ballplayer."
Plucked by the Mets as the first player selected in the 1994 draft, Wilson spoke as a player who hoped that his physical distress was behind him forever. Shoulder and elbow injuries and operations had played enough havoc with his career.
"I don't look at it as snakebit," the 28-year-old pitcher said. "It's a hard game. It's a strange game. Things happen. I guess how you deal with them is what kind of person you are. I just thought of it as another challenge. I could get through it or I could say I've had enough. I decided it's what I want to do.
"I want to be a big league baseball player and I want to be successful. That's the reason I did all this, so I can be successful. I think real good things are going to happen."
Wilson began the season as the Tampa Bay Devil Rays' No. 2 starter. On May 31 he made his 12th and what is for now his last start, suffering his seventh loss in nine decisions. He has since pitched in relief, making 10 appearances but doing nothing to earn his way back into the starting rotation.
Wilson said he never considered quitting, even when his injuries kept him sidelined or in the minors. "I've always thought it was worth it," he said. "Even when I was hurt, I felt I had a good position in life. A lot of people are worse off than me."
But he'll have to begin pitching more effectively if he hopes to become that old ballplayer he dreams of being.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK; 
Cash Advances Are Under Scrutiny

BYLINE:  By MIKE FREEMAN 

 BODY:
After the police said that the Giants' rookie cornerback Will Allen had been robbed of more than $150,000 worth of jewelry, almost everyone in the Giants' organization had the same two thoughts. 
 The first was, thankfully, he's O.K. 
 The second was more blunt. How can a 22-year-old first-round draft pick, who has yet to sign an N.F.L. contract, afford a 51-carat platinum and diamond bracelet valued at $120,000, a 13-carat bracelet worth $11,000, a gold Rolex watch worth $9,000 and two diamond earrings worth $10,000? Not to mention a new Mercedes-Benz, the keys of which were also taken? 
Allen, who was robbed at gunpoint last Sunday in Syracuse, could not be reached for comment. His agent, Tom Condon, did not return a phone call. Allen has said in subsequent published reports that the amount of jewelry he was wearing was worth some $75,000, not $150,000.
Allen is not saying how he could afford such luxurious items so quickly, but there is one way rookies who have yet to sign a contract can afford a 51-carat diamond bracelet and an expensive car. It stems from a process being used increasingly by agents and financial planners, to the annoyance of some team officials.
According to agents, union officials and team officials, an agent or financial planner will advance the player a line of credit, as much as $500,000 for some first-round draft picks, that is to be paid back when the player signs with a team. Some rookies use that advance cash to purchase goodies.
In the case of a financial planner, the loan has a catch: once the player signs an N.F.L. contract, he must use the planner for investments.
There is nothing illegal about such a relationship, but officials with N.F.L. teams question these kinds of deals. 
That is because some in the league believe agents or financial planners, afraid of alienating their clients, do not caution them about using their money wisely before advancing the money.
One American Football Conference general manager said: "An agent doesn't say: 'Here's an advance, but remember you don't need three Rolex watches or four cars. Be smart.' The agent just hands over the money and the player smiles."
League officials say they have also discovered instances when players were unknowingly charged high interest rates on such loans. So, in effect, some players have paid agents and financial planners to get their own money, when they could have waited to sign their contract and gotten their cash without an interest-bearing loan.
"A small number of players come into the league with very little financial sophistication," the general manager said. "They just want the cash as fast as possible. They don't care about the fine print."
No one knows exactly what type of arrangement Allen has with an agent or financial planner, if any, except Allen and the people close to him. What is clear is that Allen is not unsophisticated. An economics major at Syracuse University, he is, according to Giants officials, considered highly intelligent. 
The robbery has brought attention to a clash of ideals. Wearing expensive jewelry and driving flashy cars is the trend among young and wealthy athletes and entertainers. At the rookie symposium in late June, one player lost a $10,000 platinum chain, just one of many pieces of jewelry he was wearing.
Rookie players defend themselves, saying they have worked hard their entire lives to make it to the N.F.L., so what is wrong with spending money on a few gifts for themselves?
But this thinking is contrary to what the N.F.L. has constantly preached in recent years to its rookies. Spend money wisely, they are told, because many N.F.L. players do not and end their careers penniless.
"You don't need six houses," the former San Francisco offensive lineman Harris Barton recently told a group of N.F.L. rookies. "You don't need 14 cars. Take care of what you get, because the rest of America gets by on far less than what you're going to get by on."
Gene Upshaw, executive director of the N.F.L. Players Association, said in an interview that his organization routinely monitored agents to make sure players were not being taken advantage of. 
Upshaw added that the N.F.L.P.A. was creating a program that would provide players a list of approved financial planners.
One of Allen's agents, Kendall Kremer, is expected to meet this week with General Manager Ernie Accorsi to open contract negotiations.

Tending to the Future
This week the N.F.L. will announce another chapter in one of its favorite initiatives, a passion of Commissioner Paul Tagliabue, Gene Upshaw and hundreds of players, and it has nothing to do with crime, drugs or the latest sports scandal. It has to do with kids.
The N.F.L. and the Pro Football Hall of Fame will hold a celebration honoring youth and high school football, which will take place during the Hall of Fame induction weekend, Aug. 2-5 in Canton, Ohio.
Usually, this type of event would be low on the radar screen of players and others in football. August is the beginning of training camps and the league is focused on the coming season. But large numbers of coaches, players and others associated with the N.F.L. have volunteered for this event, which is basically a salute to high school players and coaches, and a continuation of the league's investment in high school football activities. "We think this is one of the most important programs the league does," Upshaw said.
The reasons are both altruistic and selfish. Upshaw explained the latter.
"What we started to see happen a few years ago was that kids were getting away from football and started going to baseball or basketball," he said. "We wanted to stop that and we think some of our high school initiatives have helped."
The event at the Hall of Fame will feature dozens of current and former N.F.L. players, who will join a number of high school players and coaches. Some of those scheduled to attend include the former Pittsburgh Steeler Lynn Swann, the former Los Angeles Ram Jack Youngblood, the former Buffalo Coach Marv Levy and the former Bills tight end Pete Metzelaars.
Joining them will be coaches who have produced recent N.F.L. players, representatives from the nation's largest youth organizations, and high school football coaches from Japan, Mexico, Canada and Europe.
The event will also feature two female high school coaches, including Carol Frost, the mother of Jets defensive back Scott Frost, whom she coached in high school.

Labor Talks Ahead
Talks to extend the collective bargaining agreement could be wrapped up sooner rather than later. Gene Upshaw and other union officials are scheduled to meet with N.F.L. officials in New York tomorrow, according to a union official. The league and players are close to extending the agreement to 2006.
It is believed that only 12 to 16 minor differences, down from four or five times as many a few months ago, remain to be worked out.

HEADLINE: Belt Tightening Is Called Threat To the Economy 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
Like many other American consumers, Steven Saint-George has suddenly gone from being a source of the economy's strength to a reason to fret about its future.
 After having bought his first home, purchased a new sport-utility vehicle and taken four weekend trips to California in the last year, Mr. Saint-George was laid off two weeks ago from his $75,000-a-year job at an online real-estate company. Now he and his wife are considering selling their new truck, delaying some landscaping work on their home and trying to pay off their credit-card debt. 
 "We haven't made changes yet, but we will," said Mr. Saint-George, who is 35 and lives in the mountains north of Phoenix. "The idea is to spend a little more wisely, to be a little more frugal." 
Whether it is a lost job, a shrunken retirement account or a debt level that has reached its limit, consumers are now finding new reasons to consider cutting back on their spending. As a result, while many experts still expect the American economy to pick up a bit of speed, they say the recovery may be limited -- and that the risk of a recession remains significant.
"I'm worried about the consumer -- not putting away their wallets but using them a little less," said Alan S. Blinder, an economics professor at Princeton and a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve. "It wouldn't take much downward movement in consumer spending to cause a recession."
There are many reasons why consumers may not be able to keep up the spending spree. For starters, they are poorer: the net worth of Americans fell last year for the first time since the government began keeping statistics in 1945. In the first quarter of this year, it fell an additional 4 percent.
The best labor market in 30 years has also soured. From April through June, 300,000 jobs disappeared, and companies like Corning and Motorola have announced more cuts this month. Growth in personal income, adjusted for inflation, has dropped below a 2 percent annual rate for the first time since January 1996.
Until now, Americans have kept up their standard of living by increasing mortgage and credit-card debt at the same time. But history suggests that both are unlikely to continue rising in tandem.
"Consumers have held the economy afloat this past year, and we can't count on that to continue," said Mark Zandi, chief economist of Economy.com, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa. "A number of the supports of consumer spending are wavering."
Most analysts are still guardedly optimistic about the economy's prospects this summer, largely because the coming tax rebate, falling energy prices and lowered interest rates should effectively put more money in Americans' pockets. But many say the forces that have underpinned rising consumer spending so far may not be sustainable. 
Consumer spending is so important because it amounts to more than two-thirds of gross domestic product in the United States. In the last nine months, consumer spending has risen at about a 3 percent rate on an inflation-adjusted basis.
This has allowed the economy to grow about 1 percent in that span -- even though business spending on equipment and software, which had been advancing almost 15 percent a year in the late 1990's, suddenly fell.
In other recent economic slowdowns, consumers reined in their spending before the corporate sector -- often in response to higher interest rates engineered by the Federal Reserve. Businesses then followed, reacting to a drop in revenue, and the slowdown ended only when interest rates fell and the pent-up demand of consumers caused them to increase buying.
In this economic cycle, however, the strong dollar, the glut of products in many industries and the collapse of the dot-com stock-market bubble meant companies were the first to pull back. As a result, the economy is facing an unusual period of uncertainty, with many analysts saying they do not know whether consumer spending will remain strong -- or even accelerate -- or whether it will soon follow the path of corporate spending.
"For the first time in memory, the business sector is driving this," said Allen Sinai of Decision Economics in New York. "The consumer won't be out of the woods until the business sector turns around." 
In effect, there is now a tug-of-war between the downward pull of a deteriorating job market and the government's effort to lift the economy by cutting interest rates and income taxes. 
If people who keep their jobs continue buying enough goods and services to maintain consumer-spending growth of close to 3 percent, Mr. Blinder said, the economy will reach "a safe haven" toward the end of this year, when companies should be stronger. But if consumer spending drops, businesses may have to make even more job cuts, further weakening people's ability to afford new items.
So far, consumers have kept the economy growing, if only slightly, by continuing to take on more debt. In 1998 and 1999, consumer-credit debt was increasing about 5.5 percent a year. By the end of 2000, with people needing new sources of money, the growth rate surged to 12 percent and remained there early this year, according to Economy.com.
At the same time, a fall in interest rates at the start of the year caused the number of people applying to refinance their mortgages each month to more than triple. On average, Americans hold mortgages worth about 45 percent of the value of their homes, compared with 35 percent at the end of the 1980's, according to the Fed.
The simultaneous rise of the two types of debt was atypical because people usually refinance their mortgage in part to pay off other debts. This time, it appears that many of them used the money for consumption.
"To me, that's a sign of distress, and I don't think it's sustainable," Mr. Zandi said. In fact, the growth of both kinds of debt has slowed in recent weeks.
By itself, debt rarely forces people to change their spending habits, economists say. But, in the event of a layoff or a loss of overtime hours, it can cause people to cut their expenses more significantly than they otherwise would.
Mr. Saint-George, for example, said that when he was making a good salary, he and his wife could comfortably make the monthly payments on their large auto loan and $9,000 in consumer debt. Now that he is unemployed, though, they expect to sell their Infiniti truck and replace it with a car that has lower monthly payments and gets better mileage. They are not planning any more trips to California to visit friends.
And while he expects to find a new job within a month or so, he said he would not be surprised if he had to take a pay cut of as much as $10,000 a year. All the uncertainty makes him want to pay off their loans even when he does find new work.
"You just kind of pare down all around because you don't have the same level of income," Mr. Saint-George said.
Economists agree that wages and employment are the most important factors determining consumer spending. While unemployment remains lower than it was at almost any point in the last 30 years, it is expected to continue rising for the rest of the year.
Last week, the government reported that the number of Americans filing new jobless insurance claims rose to 445,000 in early July, its highest level in nine years.
Besides adding to the ranks of those without steady incomes, the continuing layoffs also affect those already looking for new work. Since losing his job as a recruiter of engineers in April, Mark P. Weiss has applied for about 200 jobs over the Internet and received only two responses, both negative.
"A lot of the companies I've called are cutting back," said Mr. Weiss, 31, who lives in Dallas. He and his wife no longer eat out or cook steak at home and try to buy brands of food that are on sale. He has also begun to look for work outside of his field.
"The pay in retail is a whole lot less," Mr. Weiss said. "But financially, I'll get to the point where some income is better than no income."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Your Data, Yourself; 
A Protective Path Paved in Granola

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
TO understand the state of play for privacy in the digital age, it helps to look at environmentalism as it was taking shape in the late 1960's. 
 At the time, there was a growing concern about the environment. The politics were reactive and grass-roots, led initially by activist groups rather than traditional politicians. The economic tradeoffs were difficult to measure and a subject of much debate. Individual cases of serious pollution caused alarm, but the environmental issue also mattered in a broader sense, affecting "quality of life." 
 Today, privacy seems to be on a similar trajectory. Polls show that people are increasingly worried about it. The main focus of public anxiety is the use of personal information that can be collected and tracked over the Internet. But there are also qualms about new tools of surveillance -- digital video cameras and special software -- that the police are using to scan crowds for criminals, as was done at the Super Bowl in January and began in Tampa a few weeks ago. 
It remains unclear whether privacy will become an issue with anything like the political resonance and momentum of the environment. It has no oil-covered birds or dying seals to fire public passions. There are worrying episodes, like the accidental distribution of the e-mail addresses of 600 Prozac users by Eli Lilly recently. But most of the anxiety is anticipatory, about what use might be made of vast databases being assembled online or the identifying numbers in Microsoft's software or Intel's microchips. Thoughtful, often disturbing, books have been written on privacy, but none have approached the impact of Rachel Carson's "Silent Spring" in 1962.
Still, there are enough similarities to make some comparisons illuminating. The core concept in each case has evolved over time, though the environment is much further along. As a policy issue, the environment became synonymous with health and safety. But privacy is still an elastic term that means very different things to different people. Jeffrey Rosen, the author of "The Unwanted Gaze: The Destruction of Privacy in America" (Random House, 2000), notes that privacy is an "amorphous concept" that can mean anonymity, secrecy, personal control, security, inaccessibility, even reticence. 
AND like the environment, there is a social side to privacy that extends beyond the cost-benefit analysis of economics. The widespread use of digital video surveillance, Mr. Rosen warns, is an example. "You transform the character of public spaces by putting cameras everywhere," he said.
Then there is the problem of assessing tradeoffs, a tricky reckoning in both cases. But with the environment, the variables at least are apparent and concrete -- wealth and production, health and safety. Figuring the tradeoffs surrounding privacy is more subtle: the free flow of some personal information means lower marketing costs, lower prices and more consumer choice. And the point of much new technology is convenience. Who wants to spend an extra 20 seconds to encrypt a message? 
Like the environmental activists of decades ago, privacy groups are pushing for legislation to establish basic national standards and practices, including at Senate hearings last week, just as environmental groups helped prod Congress into enacting the Clean Air Act of 1970. They even pluck their metaphors from the environment, warning of the danger of a potential "privacy Chernobyl" or "privacy oil spills." 
But as with the environment, legislation will probably come only after there is broad grass-roots support, legitimate leadership and agreement on what should be done.
"Various entities are competing for institutional competence and legitimacy," observed Andrew L. Shapiro, the author of "The Control Revolution" (Public Affairs, 1999), which examines the Internet's social impact. And there is no real consensus, he says, on how to protect privacy.
Science and technology helped bring environmental dangers to light, as biological research detailed the health effects of pollution. Some analysts say the Internet has cast light on the lax information-handling practices of the past.
Merchants have been selling credit-card data for years. The sure evidence of that is the annoying arrival of junk mail every day. Technology accelerates the practice and also makes it more visible. What was unknown in the past now seems to be exploitation.
COMPUTER technology is making information and images easy and inexpensive to collect, sift and transmit. In a study released last week, the Privacy Foundation, an educational and research organization, found that 14 million employees -- over a third of the nation's workers who use the Internet on the job -- have their Web use and e-mail under constant surveillance. 
The companies that use the surveillance software say they are monitoring productivity, checking for objectionable communications like racist or sexist e-mails and guarding against the loss of trade secrets. All those considerations, notes Andrew Schulman, a researcher at the Privacy Foundation, could apply to telephone communications as well. Such surveillance, however, would be too cumbersome and expensive. But the software for computer surveillance costs companies and some government agencies $5 to $10 a year per worker. 
Not only is it easier to collect personal information; it's also easier to sell it. An online merchant can track a visitor's every mouse click, using "cookies." Those clicks can reveal a person's interests and buying habits. And there is a brisk business in selling that information to other marketers. 
"There is already a market in information on you," observed Hal R. Varian, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley. "The trouble is, you aren't a participant in that market."
Economists analyze privacy through the same prism as the environment, trying to weigh a discrete economic benefit to a marketer (like the polluting producer) against the more elusive cost of an individual's loss of privacy (a person breathing dirtier air). The sale of personal data to third parties, in economic terms, is an "externality." That is, the seller can ignore the costs, because they are born by someone else -- the individual whose information is sold.
Externalities are a big part of environmental economics. And just as there have been efforts to develop markets in pollution rights, Kenneth C. Laudon, a professor at New York University's Stern school of business, has proposed a "national information market," intended to give individuals "fair compensation for the use of information about themselves."
Its contours may resemble the environment, but the privacy issue will likely elicit a much milder policy response. Eventually, laws curbing junk e-mail and setting basic standards for collecting and using online data are a good bet. But sweeping, environmental-style regulation is doubtful. The issue is different, and so are the times.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
An Online Auctioneer That Helps Cut Costs

BYLINE:  By ERLE NORTON 

 BODY:
FREEMARKETS INC. is doing its best impression of Lance Armstrong cycling in the Pyrenees.
 While many business-to-business companies have been warning investors that they are not meeting their revenue targets, FreeMarkets is pulling away from the competition by running online auctions that help its own customers cut costs. 
 Like many of its competitors, FreeMarkets is losing money, but it has attracted attention on Wall Street by enabling old-line industrial businesses like Deere & Company to rapidly obtain bids from suppliers, reducing costs substantially.
George Santana, an analyst at Wedbush Morgan Securities, was so impressed that his research reports place FreeMarkets in a new category he calls "Saving Companies Money," a move from the business-to-business sector that is now unfashionable with investors. Mr. Santana said that FreeMarkets offers "a tremendous value proposition" for customers. 
The stock fell sharply in the dot-com crash, but since its early April low it has risen by 188 percent, and now trades at $18.56. This month, Derek Brown, an analyst at W. R. Hambrecht, upgraded the stock to "strong buy" and said he expected it to reach $30 within 12 months. 
Dan Chung, technology portfolio manager at Fred Alger Management, which manages the Enterprise Internet fund, said he has been buying the stock. And Michael Gaffney, who manages the Pimco Opportunity fund, said, "The reasons for why we bought it still exist."
Founded in 1995, FreeMarkets, based in Pittsburgh, went public in late 1999 at an offering price of $48; it ended its first day at $280 and traded as high as $370 on Jan. 3, 2000. Then came spring 2000 and the plunge in Internet stocks, when FreeMarkets lost almost 79 percent of its value from March 1 to June 1.
All the while, FreeMarkets kept at its basic business, signing up customers like Raytheon, Schering-Plough and Texas Instruments. Analysts say customers like FreeMarkets' service, which includes analyzing spending, deciding which products are best for an auction and coming up with qualified suppliers.
The FreeMarkets online auction can accomplish in a day what once could take 30 days of negotiations, said Larry D. Ingram, vice president for procurement and services at Diebold, a North Canton, Ohio, maker of automated teller machines and vaults. The auction forces "that market price down very quickly," said Mr. Ingram, who put Diebold's savings from the process at around 15 percent. FreeMarkets says its customers save 15 to 17 percent of supply costs through its auctions.
FreeMarkets "is one that's beginning to execute against the potential they laid out originally," said Mitch Rubin, who manages the Baron iOpportunity fund, a FreeMarkets shareholder.
Competitors, meanwhile, have stumbled. Commerce One, E.piphany and i2 Technologies warned in the last couple of weeks about disappointments in the second quarter. Covisint, which was set up by automakers to buy parts online, is off to a slow start.
FreeMarkets is hardly home free. It is tied to the manufacturing sector, whose strength is being hurt by the economic slowdown in the United States and the strong dollar abroad. Analysts also wonder if the company is adding customers fast enough.
The stock had a big run recently, nearly tripling from its April 3 low of $6.44 and prompting some money managers to get out. And FreeMarkets still loses money. In the first quarter, the company posted a loss, excluding certain items, of $9.3 million, or 24 cents a share. Including those items -- stock-based expense and noncash acquisition-related costs -- the loss was $43.7 million, or $1.13 a share.
For the second quarter, analysts expect a loss of 22 cents a share on revenue of $36.8 million, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. FreeMarkets concurs with the per-share loss estimate and forecasts revenue of $36 million to $38 million. It is expected to report results on July 30.
FreeMarkets has said full-year revenue will climb to $150 million, from $91.3 million in 2000. It also sees a loss of 73 cents a share for the year. But it expects to break even on an operational basis in the first quarter of 2002 and post a profit, excluding certain items, in the second quarter. Still, the company has not said when it expects to surmount one of the tallest mountains confronting an Internet company, and actually show a net profit.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Hotels; 
Offering Business Travelers Less-Fancy Quarters

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
HARRY GROSS thinks that ballrooms, fancy restaurants and room service are unnecessary frills in the business of lodging business travelers. What executives traveling to the nation's core cities really need, he says, are the equivalent of a bed-and-breakfast with high-tech connections to keep them in contact with the rest of the world.
 Mr. Gross, a relative newcomer to the hotel scene in New York, has chosen the Marriott Corporation's Courtyard brand as his chosen instrument, so far. In December 1998 he opened a 244-room Courtyard on 40th Street between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas. Last month he opened the first new hotel at John F. Kennedy Airport in 15 years, a 166-room Courtyard. 
 A site on the northwest corner of Broadway and 54th Street has been assembled for yet another Courtyard. Construction for the 380-room hotel is scheduled to begin late next year with occupancy planned for early in 2004. 
Mr. Gross said the development at 54th Street will include parking, retail space and full-time residential units in addition to the hotel.
Although highly themed hotels have recently opened in New York, including the Bryant Park, Dylan and the Library, Mr. Gross said he believes there are people who will happily give up the architectural distinction and special services of such properties in return for technically sophisticated rooms and half the price.
Room rates at some boutique hotels can soar past $400 a night. Mr. Gross said his price range is less than $200 a night.
"The concept is for a limited-service hotel in a downtown location, without a lot of public spaces or restaurants," Mr. Gross said in his office on 39th Street in the heart of the Garment District, where he has operated a variety of trading business and is now chief executive of Britannica Home Fashions. "We give people a great room and breakfast and don't charge them for the ballrooms they are not using." 
Unlike hotels outside cities, where finding a place to eat lunch and dinner may be difficult, central business districts are restaurant-rich environments. Doing away with food service, except for the simple breakfast, simplifies the operation of a hotel and eliminates a potential source of financial losses. Many hotel food and beverage operations lose money or barely break even, Mr. Gross said.
Although Kennedy Airport is not a downtown location, Mr. Gross said the Courtyard there was built to take advantage of the investments being made at the airport and the expected increase in passenger traffic.
Mr. Gross is betting that a certain percentage of business travelers are not interested in fighting traffic on the roads leading away from the airport to reach a hotel downtown. Many prefer to fly in, hold business meetings outside Manhattan, spend the night near the airport and fly out in the morning.
"The hotel at J.F.K. is tied to the development of the airport," Mr. Gross said. Among other things, a $1.2 billion international terminal recently opened, and work is proceeding on a $1.5 billion light rail system to connect Kennedy with existing rail and subway lines in Jamaica, Queens.
The Courtyard, Mr. Gross noted, will be the only Marriott product at the airport. Most other major airports in the country have multiple Marriott brands located nearby, with the individual hotel varying in price and services.
The Courtyard concept, Mr. Gross argues, is the urban expression of the rural bed-and-breakfast inn, with one important difference. All the rooms are equipped with two-line telephones and high-speed Internet access, so travelers can be online with their portable computers and on a voice line at the same time.
The current uncertain economic outlook, which is forcing businesses to reduce costs, will drive business travelers away from boutique hotels to places like Courtyards, Mr. Gross said. 
"I want to serve the businessman who is on a budget and does not want to pay for things he does not use," he said. "That's why we have a great gym, rather than a luxury restaurant that nobody would patronize."
IN addition to the Courtyards, Mr. Gross is bringing another Marriott hotel concept to Manhattan: the Residence Inn, for extended stays. Residence Inns are for people expecting to stay in a location for four nights to a few weeks. (It is not to be confused with ExecuStay, another Marriott product, which offers apartments for people planning to stay weeks or months.)
"We are aiming at customers who are not presently being catered to by a branded hotel chain," Mr. Gross said. A Residence Inn is to be built on Avenue of the Americas near 39th Street, where a parking garage now stands. Demolition of that garage is expected to begin this November, and the hotel is expected to open 24 months later, Mr. Gross said.
The Residence Inn will contain 414 suites, which have sleeping, living and working areas with small kitchenettes. Mr. Gross's company, the G Holdings Corporation, is also converting a historic building near City Hall in Philadelphia into a 270-suite Residence Inn.
Mr. Gross said his relationship with Marriott is complex and varies with different projects. In some cases, Marriott is simply a franchiser, lending its brand and operation standards, with G Holdings as the developer and a third company as the operator of the hotel, as is the case with the Kennedy Airport property.
In other cases, Marriott is both the franchiser and the operator of the property, which is the plan for the Residence Inn in Philadelphia. In Manhattan, the company will be a franchiser and a co-investor in the Residence Inn project, Mr. Gross said.
G Holdings is a development and ownership company that does not get involved in the day-to-day operations of its hotels.
Mr. Gross is moving ahead with his projects despite the uneasy national economy and the growing evidence of a decline in travel.
But the declines are from extraordinary occupancy peaks and room rates, and the hospitality business remains strong in New York, observed John A. Fox, a senior vice president of PKF Consulting, which specializes in lodging. "In 2000, we had 250 nights when the city was sold out, and we ended the year with an 85 percent occupancy rate," he said. "That is an unheard-of level for a major metropolitan area."
Year-to-year comparisons are indeed down, but it is important to remember that are down a little from full, he said. "We may only have 150 sold-out nights this year, and the occupancy rate for the first five months of the year is about 75 percent. But this is a very healthy industry, and it will remain so."
Mr. Gross cites statistics he says show that New York does not have enough hotel rooms and that there is money to be made building them. "You look at the statistics, and then you remember stories about people having to stay 20 or 30 miles away because there are no rooms in the city," he said.
According to Smith Travel Research, New York ranks seventh in the nation with about 71,000 rooms in operation. This trails such tourism leaders as Las Vegas, which has 126,000 rooms, and Orlando, with 105,000. New York even lags Atlanta, which has 82,000 rooms, and the Washington, D.C. area, which has 74,000 rooms.
But the same research also found that New York leads the nation in hotel room revenues, with a total income of about $4 billion, compared with $3 billion for Las Vegas and $2.3 billion for Orlando, presumably because of the high price of rooms in the city. 
"When you see statistics like that, you realize that this is a market that is under-served," Mr. Gross said. In addition to the projects under way or in planning, Mr. Gross said his company had bought 4.5 acres of land near Newark Airport, close to the existing Sheraton Hotel.
"The plan is to develop it into a hotel sometime in the future," he said. "The specific brand has not yet been determined."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Harry Gross at the new Courtyard by Marriott near Kennedy Airport. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Posner v. Dershowitz 

BYLINE:  By Ethan Bronner; Ethan Bronner, education editor of The Times, covered the Supreme Court for The Boston Globe from 1986 to 1991 and is the author of "Battle for Justice: How the Bork Nomination Shook America."

 BODY:
 SUPREME INJUSTICE
How the High Court
Hijacked Election 2000.
By Alan M. Dershowitz.
275 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $25.

BREAKING THE DEADLOCK
The 2000 Election, the Constitution,
and the Courts.
By Richard A. Posner.
266 pp. Princeton, N.J.:
Princeton University Press. $24.95.
 Who can forget the scene of disarray outside the United States Supreme Court on the night of Dec. 12? Dozens of television lights and cameras were trained on the court's dark plaza as journalists and lawyers, fighting a stiff wind, flipped through the 65-page, six-opinion decision of Bush v. Gore, seeking the fate of the 2000 presidential election. 
Was the vote 7 to 2 or 5 to 4? Was the case remanded to Florida? It soon became clear that the Supreme Court, the one branch of government with no explicit constitutional role in elections, had selected the nation's next president. It had done so using an entirely novel and, for the five majority justices, entirely uncharacteristic equal protection argument from the 14th Amendment. And, contrary to the widely accepted role of such decisions, this one had no precedential value. The majority justices claimed to have sliced the nation's Gordian knot of a succession crisis. We were expected to be grateful. 
There is no doubt that many Americans were relieved that the court had put the country out of its 36-day misery. Most appear to have accepted the decision and the president. A January Gallup poll found that a majority viewed the Supreme Court with the same high measure of esteem as before. But those who make their living studying the court were generally shocked. Many have, in effect, remained on the harshly lighted court plaza, probing the decision, sifting through the constitutional chaos, assessing the damage they feel the court has brought on itself and the nation. 
These books, by two of the country's most productive legal minds, are among the first full-length treatments of Bush v. Gore. A slew of law journal articles and collections of essays are also just out or due out shortly (including the balanced and thoughtful collection "The Vote: Bush, Gore and the Supreme Court," edited by Cass R. Sunstein and Richard A. Epstein, to be published by the University of Chicago Press in October and currently available as an e-book on the Web site www.thevotebook.com). 
The overwhelming scholarly assessment is that the ruling in Bush v. Gore is a poor model of judicial reasoning. It is unsteadily grounded and hard to square with the justices' previous decisions, and it reduces confidence in the court. Most analysts simply find it impossible to swallow the idea of Justices Rehnquist, Scalia, O'Connor, Kennedy and Thomas, who have spent years fighting the liberal expansion of the equal protection clause, seizing upon it as a basis for stopping a voter recount. But on the decision's overall legitimacy and appropriateness, commentators are divided. Not evenly divided, to be sure, given the liberal bent of the legal academy, but the split is deep and troubling. It is well represented by these two books.+ 
Tocqueville commented more than a century and a half ago that "the president may slip without the state suffering" and "Congress may slip without the Union perishing," because the voters can replace both. But justices are appointed for life, he noted, and "if ever the Supreme Court came to be composed of rash or corrupt men, the confederation would be threatened by anarchy or civil war." 
In "Supreme Injustice," Alan M. Dershowitz charges that the court majority is, in fact, corrupt. Dershowitz, of course, has not built a reputation for understatement. And he played a role in this case, representing several thousand Palm Beach residents who inadvertently voted for Patrick Buchanan instead of Al Gore on the confusing "butterfly ballot." But here Dershowitz speaks for a large number of his colleagues, most of whom believe the court should have stayed out of this case and let the process take its course. Dershowitz goes so far as to place Bush v. Gore in a category beyond the court's most famous self-inflicted wounds: the Dred Scott decision, which in effect called black Americans property, and Plessy v. Ferguson, which legitimized segregation as "separate but equal." At least in those cases, Dershowitz says, the justices were acting consistently with their own warped judicial philosophies. But here, he charges, the majority acted out of personal political preference, and therefore Bush v. Gore "may be ranked as the single most corrupt decision in Supreme Court history." (That statement, it should be pointed out, is mild compared with the view of Vincent Bugliosi, a former Los Angeles deputy district attorney. In an article in The Nation that he has padded out into a book titled "The Betrayal of America: How the Supreme Court Undermined the Constitution and Chose Our President," published by Thunder's Mouth Press, he calls the justices in the majority "criminals in the very truest sense of the word." On comments by Clarence Thomas and William Rehnquist that politics played no part, he writes, "Well, at least we know they can lie as well as they can steal.") 
Richard A. Posner, a federal judge on the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, a senior lecturer at the University of Chicago Law School and the author of an extraordinary array of books on law and society, has written a powerful defense of the ruling in "Breaking the Deadlock," to be published in September and available this month as an e-book at Barnesandnoble.com and Amazon.com. Posner concedes that more Floridians probably meant to vote for Al Gore than for George W. Bush. He also concedes that the equal protection basis for the Supreme Court ruling was faulty (although he contends a better one was available). Yet he says the court ruled appropriately and honorably. It acted in the tradition of constitutional pragmatism, averting a looming national crisis that would have resulted from the dispute ending up in Congress, where partisan forces would most likely have run wild. On balance, Posner says, Bush v. Gore was therefore "a rather good" decision. 
That two such nimble and serious legal thinkers as Dershowitz and Posner can arrive at such opposing conclusions speaks to the distressingly subjective nature of the law. Some 50 court cases resulted from the Florida electoral tie, and every single one of the rulings is open to legitimate competing interpretation. Since the law is supposed to serve as an anchor under shifting political seas, this can be disconcerting to contemplate. It is especially upsetting in this case because if Gore had held the lead and Bush had sought the recount, it seems most unlikely that the justices and scholars would have taken the same positions. As Frank Michelman of Harvard Law School puts it in his contribution to the Sunstein-Epstein collection, one's view in this case seems to depend on whose Gore was getting oxed. 
To get a taste of the elasticity of judicial reasoning, it is helpful to venture, at least briefly, into the legal thicket that grew out of two conflicting Florida laws. One requires that when an election result is in doubt as a result of tabulation error, there be a hand recount (a long, laborious and subjective process); the other says that final results must be delivered within a week of Election Day. Florida's secretary of state, Katherine Harris, focused on the deadline (convenient since Bush was ahead and she had been active in Bush's campaign). The Florida Supreme Court extended the counting deadline (convenient since six of the seven justices there were appointed by Democrats). It said that to stop the counting violated the "pre-eminent" right to vote found in the state's constitution and that Harris was engaged in "hypertechnical reliance upon statutory provisions."+ 
The Florida court's action doesn't seem strange on its face. That is what state courts do -- interpret and reconcile statutes based on things like the state constitution. But Posner says the Florida court was woefully overreaching. The law permits a full hand recount if there is "an error in the vote tabulation which could affect the outcome of the election." (It also says that if the recounting goes beyond the seventh day, its results "may be ignored" by the secretary of state.) Posner says the Florida court and its defenders have confused tabulation error with voter error. Voters must fully punch through their ballot cards. If they fail to do so, the machines are programmed not to count them. That is what happened in Florida; no law was broken. As Posner puts it, "If you put a steel bar into a meat grinder and hamburger meat doesn't come out, do you call this an error by the meat grinder?" He says the Gore mantra of "count all the votes" was meaningless. All the ballots were counted, that is, tabulated twice by machine. Those ballots that had been spoiled by the voters, generally through failure to punch the hole through, were appropriately rejected. Once you allow such votes to be hand-counted, Posner says, you open the process up to unbearable subjectivity (hanging chads, dimpled chads). The Supreme Court rightly stepped in to correct the Florida court's errors. 
Agree or not, for devotees of public policy there are few pleasures as keen as reading Richard Posner. He is clever, original and tough-minded. For example, he dismisses those who argue that Bush's legitimacy is harmed by Gore's victory in the popular vote by comparing the election to a tennis match: if a player wins more sets while his opponent wins more games, no one disputes the outcome. Posner, a leader in the law and economics movement, is unsentimental about the nation's governing system: "American democracy," he writes, "is structured, formal, practical, realistic and both supportive of and supported by commercial values. It is not starry-eyed, carnivalesque or insurrectionary. It is not pure or participatory democracy, and it does not consider political chaos a price worth paying to actualize the popular will." His book is worth the price of admission just to watch him spin out a scenario whereby Lawrence Summers, then secretary of the treasury, would have become acting president -- and America's first Jewish president -- if the Supreme Court had not stepped in. 
DERSHOWITZ is at his best in his exposure of how Bush v. Gore is inconsistent with previous decisions of the majority justices. With ease, he hoists them by their own petards. Antonin Scalia, for instance, wrote in a 1996 case: "The Supreme Court of the United States does not sit to announce 'unique' dispositions. Its principal function is to establish precedent -- that is, to set forth principles of law that every court in America must follow." Yet this case was limited to the present circumstances. 
But for John Yoo, a Berkeley law professor who contributed to the Sunstein-Epstein collection, the limited nature of the decision actually increases its legitimacy. He contrasts Bush v. Gore with Roe v. Wade, the 1973 abortion decision that he and many other lawyers consider poorly grounded, saying that Roe has kept the court in the center of political controversy for years, whereas Bush will not. 
Whenever judges hand down far-reaching decisions, supporters applaud their courage while dissenters warn of the dangers of raw judicial power. In the 1930's, the left was livid at the Supreme Court's obstruction of the New Deal. In the 60's and 70's, the right was horrified at the court's expansion of the rights of privacy (read "women"), minority groups and criminal defendants. Now, with the courts again solidly in the hands of conservatives, the argument is shifting again. Dershowitz ends his book with a lament that liberals had foolishly considered the judicial system "ours" and had brought conservative judicial activism on themselves by promoting liberal judicial activism. In other words, Bush v. Gore is the payback for Roe v. Wade. The time has come, he warns, without apparent irony, to depoliticize the judiciary and seek nominees who are great rather than politically reliable. The problem, of course, is that legal greatness often shifts with the political context. Bush v. Gore simply unmasked the context in an unsettlingly partisan fashion.
